(a)  No person shall possess, control, use, or give away marijuana or cannabis, which is defined as all parts of the plant cannabis sativa l., whether growing or not; its seeds or resin; and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the above, unless such possession, control, or use is pursuant to a license or prescription as provided in Public Act 196 of 1971, as amended. This definition does not include the mature stalks of the plant, fiber produced from the stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of the plant, any other compounds, manufacture, sale, derivative, mixture or preparation of the mature stalks, except the resin extracted therefrom, fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination. 
(b)  Violations of this section shall be civil infractions. Persons convicted of violating this section shall be fined $25.00 for the first offense, $50.00 for the second offense, $100.00 for the third or subsequent offense and no incarceration, probation, nor any other punitive or rehabilitative measure shall be imposed. Fines and all other costs shall be waived upon proof that the defendant is recommended by a physician, practitioner or other qualified health professional to use or provide the marijuana or cannabis for medical treatment. The court may waive all or part of the fine upon proof that the defendant attended a substance abuse program. It is an affirmative defense to a prosecution under this section that the use or intended use of the marijuana or cannabis relieves, or has the potential to relieve, the pain, disability, discomfort or other adverse symptoms of illness or medical treatment, or restores, maintains or improves, or has the potential to restore, maintain or improve, the health or medical quality of life of the user or intended user or users of the marijuana or cannabis. Requirements of this subsection shall not be construed to exclude the assertion of other defenses. 
(c)  In all arrests and prosecutions for violations of this section, appearance tickets and the relevant procedures set forth in Michigan Public Act 147 of 1968, as amended, shall be used. 
(d)  No Grand Rapids police officer, or his or her agent, shall complain of the possession, control, use, or giving away of marijuana or cannabis to any other authority except the Grand Rapids City Attorney; and the City Attorney shall not refer any said complaint to any other authority for prosecution. 
(e)  No Grand Rapids police officer, or his or her agent, shall complain and the City Attorney shall not refer for prosecution any complaint, of the possession, control, use, giving away, or cultivation of marijuana or cannabis upon proof that the defendant is recommended by a physician, practitioner or other qualified health professional to use or provide the marijuana or cannabis for medical treatment. 
(f)  Should the State of Michigan enact lesser penalties than that set forth in subsection (b) above, or entirely repeal penalties for the possession, control, use, or giving away of marijuana or cannabis, then this section, or the relevant portions thereof, shall be null and void. 
(11-6-12) 
Editor's note— Amendment of May 4, 2010, repealed § 292 which pertained to eight hours to constitute a day's work. See the Charter Comparative Table. 
293.  Police and Fire Pensions. Sec. 23. (a). The City Commission of the City of Grand Rapids shall have and is hereby given authority to provide by ordinance for pensioning persons injured by violence, accident or exposure while employed by the City in extra-hazardous employment, when such injuries arise out of or in the course of such employment; also for the dependents of persons killed while so employed and for persons who have been in such employment of the City and shall have reached the age of fifty-five years or more and shall have elected to come under and have qualified for such pension in accordance with the provisions of an ordinance adopted in conformity with the provisions herein contained. 
(b).  Any person eligible to a pension as authorized herein, who shall also be eligible to Workmen's Compensation or to make claim by way of damages against any person, firm or corporation responsible for the injury, and shall seek by suit or claim such other remedy, such remedy so selected shall be exclusive of any claim for pension; and in case of acceptance of pension, the City shall be subrogated to all rights of the employee against the party causing the injury and responsible therefor. 
(c).  The maximum pension for the period of total disability or for dependents upon the death of the breadwinner when death or injury occur by reason of the extra-hazardous employment, shall be one hundred ($100.00) dollars per month, and the minimum shall be fifty ($50.00) dollars per month. 
(d).  In case of partial disability while in extra-hazardous employment of the City, such employee shall receive, subject to the foregoing provisions, his regular salary for a period of ninety (90) days, and then reduce to half-salary; in addition, reasonable physician's bill during continuance of such disability or until such person is given a disability pension from the service. No person shall receive a disability pension whose incapacity is caused by his own dissipation or immoral conduct. 
(e).  In case of death by violence, accident or exposure, the City Commission shall designate the dependents to whom the pension shall be paid and such pension shall be paid to the widow only during widowhood, and to the children only until sixteen years of age. 
(f).  The City Commission shall also have and it is hereby given the power and authority to provide by ordinance for a retiral and pension system for persons employed by the City in extra-hazardous employment when such injury or retirement does not arise out of or in the course of such employment; and to set up a proper Board for the administration thereof, which shall include employee representation and shall further provide for all necessary rules and regulations in regard thereto, including classification, contributions required to qualify, eligible age of retirement, length of service required, conditions under which such benefits shall cease, regulations determining benefits in whole or in part and all matters and things pertaining thereto or required thereby; and said commission shall also have authority to appropriate public funds in support of such pensions and benefits in addition to amounts received from employees, and accept gifts, endowments or legacies for the benefit of such fund. 
(g).  The pension board set up under authority of Section 25, Title XVIII of this Charter to handle and control pension matters in connection with employees other than those engaged in extra-hazardous service, as presently formed or hereafter amplified, shall have authority to and shall administer the pension and retirement funds provided for herein unless and until another board shall be established for such purposes by the City Commission. 
(h).  Subject to the foregoing provisions, the City Commission shall have plenary powers over all pension matters set up or authorized in connection herewith. 
(4-2-45) 
294.  Amendment of this Charter. Sec. 24. This Charter may be amended at any time in the manner provided in the Home Rule Act so-called, the same being Act 279 of Public Acts of 1909 as amended. 
295.  City Employees. Sec. 25. (Other than those provided for in Section 23, Title XVIII.) The City Commission of the City of Grand Rapids shall have and it is hereby given the power and authority to provide by ordinance for and to establish a retirement and/or pension system for employees of the City of Grand Rapids other than those provided for in Section 23, Title XVIII of this Charter, including the employees of the library and museums; such ordinance to set up the proper Board for administration thereof, which shall include employee representation, and shall further provide for all necessary rules and regulations in regard thereto, including classifications, contributions required to establish eligibility, age of retirement, length of service required, conditions under which benefits shall cease, regulations terminating rights to benefits in whole or in part, and all matters and things properly relating thereto or required thereby, and said Commission shall also have authority to appropriate public funds in support of such pension and benefits in addition to amounts received from employees and to accept gifts, legacies and bequests for the benefit of such fund. The authority granted in this section shall not be construed to in any way change or affect the provisions of Section 23 of this Title or the persons included therein or the benefits thereby provided. 
(3-7-38)  
TITLE XIX. - SCHEDULE 
That no inconvenience may arise from the changes hereby made in the Charter of the City, and in order to carry the same into complete operation it is hereby declared that: 
296.  Existing Ordinances and Rules Continued in Force. Sec. 1. The existing ordinances and special laws of the City, the rules and regulations of the Common Council and of all boards of the City, not inconsistent with this Charter, are hereby reenacted and shall continue in force until they expire by limitation or are superseded or repealed by action of the constituted authority: Provided, that the City Commission for a period not greater than sixty days may, by a separate vote upon each, continue in force any such ordinances, rules or regulations inconsistent with this Charter. 
297.  City to Remain Vested with Property Right and Liabilities. Sec. 2. After the adoption of this Charter, the City shall continue to be vested with all property, moneys, contracts, rights, credits, effects, and the records, files, books and papers belonging to it as formerly incorporated. No right or liability, either in favor of or against the City, existing at the time of the taking effect of this Charter, and no suit or prosecution of any character shall in any manner be affected by such change, but the same shall stand or proceed as if no change had been made. All debts and liabilities of the City shall continue to be its debts and liabilities, and all fines and penalties imposed and all taxes and assessments levied and uncollected at the time of such change shall be collected, and all licenses issued by the City shall be and remain the same as if such change had not been made: Provided, that when a different remedy is given in this Charter, or in any ordinance pursuant thereto, which can be made applicable to any rights existing upon the adoption of this Charter or subject thereto, the same shall be deemed cumulative to the remedies before provided, and may be used accordingly, unless the newly provided remedy shall be expressly declared to be exclusive. 
298.  Charter—Method of Publishing Before Submission. Sec. 3. (a). This Charter, before submission to the electors shall, together with such a statement of its provisions as shall be prepared by or under the direction of the Charter Commission, be published in the following manner: 
(b).  Within thirty days after the filing of a copy of the Charter with the City Clerk, he shall cause it to be indexed and printed, together with such statement of its provisions, in pamphlet form, on unglazed paper, in not less than ten point type, and shall within sixty days mail a copy thereof to every registered voter in the City. 
(c).  Said statement shall also be published in each of the daily newspapers of the City not more than fifteen days nor less than ten days before the election for the adoption of this Charter. 
299.  Officers to Continue in Office. Sec. 4. All officers now holding any office or appointment shall continue to hold the same, unless removed by competent authority, until superseded under laws now in force or under this Charter. 
300.  Election to Adopt Charter—Time and Manner of. Sec. 5. This Charter shall be submitted for adoption or rejection to a vote of the qualified electors of the City at a special election to be held on August 29th in the year 1916. Notice of such election shall be given in the same manner and for the same length of time as is provided in the existing Charter for special elections, and the votes shall be counted and canvassed and the returns made and the result determined and declared in the same manner, as near as may be, as provided by general law for counting, canvassing and returning of votes, and the determining of the results thereof. 
301.  Charter Election—Who Entitled to Vote—Form of Ballot. Sec. 6. The ballots used at such election shall contain the instructions required under the general election laws of the state, and the proposition to be submitted shall be in the language: 
Shall the revised Charter be adopted? ( ) Yes. 
Shall the revised Charter be adopted? ( ) No. 
Every person entitled to vote for City Officers under the existing Charter may vote upon said adoption or rejection. 
302.  Council and Clerk—Duty of upon Adoption of Charter. Sec. 7. At the next regular meeting after such election, the Common Council shall canvass the vote and declare the result thereof, and if a majority of the electors voting thereon shall have voted in favor of the adoption of the Charter, the Common Council, by a resolution entered upon its records, shall declare such result and that a majority of the electors voting thereon voted in favor of the adoption of such Charter, and that the same was thereby adopted. The City Clerk shall within thirty days after the adoption of this Charter, certify to four copies of said resolution and to four printed copies of said Charter, and file two copies of each with the Secretary of State and the County Clerk, respectively. 
303.  When Charter to take Effect. Sec. 8. For the purpose of nominating and electing officers and exercising the powers of the City as provided herein, this Charter shall take effect immediately upon compliance with the provisions of Section 7 of this title. For the purpose of establishing departments, divisions and offices and distributing the functions thereof, and for all other purposes, it shall take effect on the first Monday in May, 1917. 
304.  First Election Under this Charter. Sec. 9. (a). At the first general election held under the provisions of this Charter there shall be elected; seven City Commissioners, one of whom shall be elected by the City at large and two from each ward, to be nominated and elected by the City at large, twelve supervisors, four to be nominated and elected from and by each ward, three constables, one to be nominated and elected from and by each ward; also the other city officials whose offices are not by this Charter abolished or abrogated, and whose terms of office expire May 1, 1917. 
(b).  The Commissioner at large so elected shall hold his office for one year. The Commissioner from each ward who shall receive the highest number of votes at the election shall hold his office for two years; the other commissioner elected from each ward shall hold his office for one year. The two supervisors from each ward receiving the highest number of votes at said election shall hold their offices for two years; the other two supervisors elected from each ward shall hold their offices for one year. After the first election, the term of all such officials shall be two years and all such officials shall hold their offices unless removed by competent authority, until their successors have been elected and qualified. 
305.  Offices Superseded to Terminate. Sec. 10. The Mayor and the three Commissioners whose office expires on the first Monday of May, 1924, shall be elected (under the amendment adopted on April 2, 1923,) at the general City election to be held on the first Monday of April, 1924, and shall take office on the first Monday in May, 1924; the remaining three Commissioners shall be elected under said amendment at the election held on the first Monday in April, 1925, and shall take office on the first Monday of May, 1925. 
(4-2-23) 
306.  Present Salaries to Continue. Sec. 11. Unless otherwise herein or by ordinance provided, the salaries or compensation of all City officers shall continue as under the existing Charter and ordinances. 
307.  Special Acts—Powers Conferred by—To be Exercised Until Repealed. Sec. 12. All power and authority conferred upon any municipal officer, department or board under any special act, so long as such act remains in force, shall continue to be exercised by the board, officer or department exercising like duties under this Charter. 
308.  City Commission to Pass Ordinances to Make Charter Effective. Sec. 13. The City Commission shall as soon as possible and not later than one year from the time it assumes its duties, pass all ordinances and measures necessary to make the several provisions of this Charter effective, and shall provide proper penalties for the violation of the Charter and ordinances. Failure of the City Commission or any member thereof, to do, observe and perform the several requirements of this Charter shall be deemed to be a violation of the terms hereof, and be punishable accordingly. 
309.  Repealing Clause. Sec. 14. The existing Charter, being Act. No. 593, Local Acts of 1905, and all acts amendatory thereto or forming a part thereof, are hereby repealed, except Title XIV of said Act relating to the Board of Education; Title XVIII relating to the Police Court; Title XIX relating to dock and safety lines; Title XX relating to the Superior Court; Title XXI relating to Jury Commissioners; Title XXIV relating to repeal of the Hydraulic Company's charter; Title XXVI relating to Tax Histories and the Acts amendatory to said Titles XIV, XVIII, XIX, XX, XXI, XXIV, and XXVI which are repealed only so far as inconsistent with this Charter, Title XIV of said Act. No. 593 of the Local Acts of 1905, being the title covering the Board of Education, and the acts amendatory thereto, are hereby continued in full force and effect. All other special acts supplementary to the existing Charter of the City are hereby repealed so far as inconsistent with the provisions of this Charter and so far as consistent therewith are hereby continued in force, until the same are superseded by lawful authority exercised under this Charter or otherwise. 
Grand Rapids, Mich., October 7, 1949 
I hereby certify that the foregoing is a correct and accurate copy of the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids, Michigan, as adopted by a vote of the electors on August 29, 1916; and amended April 1, 1918; April 7, 1919; March 3, 1920; April 4, 1921; March 1, 1922; September 12, 1922; April 2, 1923; November 6, 1923; November 6, 1928; April 1, 1929; April 7, 1930; April 6, 1931; March 7, 1932; November 8, 1932; March 5, 1934; April 2, 1934; November 6, 1934; September 15, 1936; March 7, 1938; November 8, 1938; April 1, 1940; April 2, 1945; and February 21, 1949. 
R. STANTON KILPATRICK, 
City Clerk.

Chapter 1 - ADOPTION, CONTENTS AND INTERPRETATION 
 
Sec. 1.1. - Publication and Distribution of Code. 
Publication of this codification is hereby ordered. This Code shall be made available to the public for examination at no cost to the office of the City Clerk. The Code shall be available for purchase from the City Clerk at a price to be determined by the Clerk. Each City officer noted below shall receive a City Code and be responsible for its maintenance and up-dating: 
Mayor 
Each City Commissioner 
City Manager 
Each Deputy and Assistant City Manager 
Each Service Group Director 
City Clerk 
City Attorney 
City Treasurer 
Assessor 
City Comptroller 
Additional copies shall be provided at a cost to be determined by the City Clerk to such other City officers and employees as are necessary for the effective and efficient operation of the City. Any officer or employee to whom a City Code is issued shall be responsible for its maintenance and upkeep.  
Sec. 1.2. - Amendment Procedure. 
This Code shall be amended by ordinance. The title of each amendatory ordinance, adapted to the particular circumstances and purposes of the amendment, shall be substantially as follows: 
(1)  To amend any Section: 
AN ORDINANCE TO AMEND SECTION _____ (or SECTIONS _____ AND _____) OF CHAPTER _____ OF TITLE _____ OF THE CODE OF THE CITY OF GRAND RAPIDS. 
(2)  To insert a new Section, Chapter or Title: 
AN ORDINANCE TO AMEND THE CODE OF THE CITY OF GRAND RAPIDS BY ADDING A NEW SECTION _____ (NEW SECTIONS, A NEW CHAPTER, OR A NEW TITLE, AS THE CASE MAY BE) WHICH NEW SECTION (SECTIONS, CHAPTER OR TITLE) SHALL BE DESIGNATED AS SECTION _____ (SECTIONS _____ AND _____) OF CHAPTER _____ OF TITLE _____ (or proper designation if a Chapter or Title is added) OF SAID CODE. 
(3)  To repeal a Section, Chapter or Title: 
AN ORDINANCE TO REPEAL SECTION _____ (SECTIONS _____ AND _____), CHAPTER _____, TITLE _____, (as the case may be) OF THE CODE OF THE CITY OF GRAND RAPIDS.  
Sec. 1.3. - Publication and Distribution of Amendments. 
Amendments to the Code shall be published as required by the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids and not less than fifty (50) copies of each amendment shall be published in looseleaf form suitable for insertion in the looseleaf copies of the Code. The City Clerk shall distribute such copies to the officers of the City having copies of the Code assigned to them. Each officer assigned a copy of the Code shall be responsible for maintaining the same and for the proper insertion of amendatory pages as received. Each copy of said Code shall remain the property of the City and shall be turned over by each officer having custody thereof upon expiration of his or her term of office to his or her successor or to the City Clerk, in case he or she shall have no successor.  
Sec. 1.4. - Contents of Code. 
This Code contains all the ordinances of the City of Grand Rapids of a general and permanent nature. The adoption of this recodification shall be interpreted as an enactment of a new ordinance which is a recompilation or recodification of existing ordinances with only minor editorial changes. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature in effect on the effective date of this Code are hereby repealed except as to such provisions of any such ordinance as are also contained herein, provided, however, that any ordinances, Sections or parts of any ordinances which are not permanent and general in nature as herein provided, are saved from repeal. Ordinances hereafter adopted which are not of a general or permanent nature shall continue to be numbered consecutively, authenticated, published and recorded in the book of ordinances, but shall not be prepared for insertion in this Code, nor be deemed a part hereof.  
Sec. 1.5. - Short Title. 
This Code may be known and cited as the "Grand Rapids City Code." 
State Law reference— Codification Authority, MCL 117.5b, MSA 5.2084(2).  
Sec. 1.6. - Elements of the Code—Official and Unofficial. 
As adopted this Code is composed of a number of elements, including but not limited to a Preface, a Table of Contents, Comparative Tables, an Index, Editor's notes, Charter references and State law references. As adopted, the only official and authoritative elements of this Code are the Section numbers and the text of the Sections. The boldface wording immediately following the Section number is hereby defined as the catch-line. The catch-lines, although adopted as part of the enacting ordinances underlying this Code, are not substantive parts of this Code and should not be used to construe the substantive portions more broadly or more narrowly than the text indicates. All other elements of the Code whether referred herein or not, are not a substantive part of the Code. These elements are included to assist users of the Code but they should not be considered substantive or authoritative. 
Amendments to this Code shall be adopted in the form provided in Section 1.2. Only the Section numbers and the text contained in each Section shall be considered substantive. 
(Ord. No. 76-40, 5-4-76)  
Sec. 1.7. - Responsibility. 
Any person who aids, abets, counsels, procures or assists in the Commission of any offense prohibited by this Code, or by any rule or regulation adopted thereunder, shall be punishable as a principal. 
(Ord. No. 76-40, 5-4-76)  
Sec. 1.8. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this Code and any amendment thereto, shall, for the purposes of this Code, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this Section, except in those instances where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
(1)  Person shall include any individual, co-partnership, corporation, association, club, joint adventure, estate, trust, and any other group or combination acting as a unit, and the individuals constituting such group or unit. 
(2)  Public place shall mean any place to or upon which the public resorts, or travels, whether such place is owned or controlled by the City or any Agency of the State of Michigan, or is a place to or upon which the public resorts or travels by custom, or by invitation, express or implied. 
(3)  Street, highway and alley shall mean the entire width subject to an easement for public right-of-way, or owned in fee by the City, County or State, of every way or place, of whatever nature, whenever any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right for purposes of public travel. The word "alley" shall mean any such way or place providing a secondary means of ingress and egress from a property. 
(4)  Sidewalk shall mean that portion of a street between the curb lines or lateral lines and the right-of-way lines which is intended for the use of pedestrians. 
(5)  City shall mean the City of Grand Rapids.  
Sec. 1.9. - Title of Officer to Include Deputy or Subordinate. 
Whenever, by the provisions of this Code, any officer of the City of Grand Rapids is assigned any duty or empowered to perform any act or duty, the title of said officer shall mean and include such officer or his or her deputy or authorized subordinate.  
Sec. 1.10. - Tense. 
Except as otherwise specifically provided or indicated by the context, all words used in this Code indicating the present tense shall not be limited to the time of adoption of this Code but shall extend to and include the time of the happening of any act, event, or requirement for which provision is made therein, either as a power, immunity, requirement or prohibition.  
Sec. 1.11. - Notice. 
Notice regarding sidewalk repairs, sewer or water connections, dangerous structures, abating nuisances or any other act, the expense of which if performed by the City, may be assessed against the premises under the provisions of this Code shall be served: 
(1)  By delivering the notice to the owner personally or by leaving the same at his or her residence, office or place of business with some person of suitable age and discretion; or 
(2)  By mailing said notice by certified or registered mail to such owner at his or her last known address; or 
(3)  If the owner is unknown, by posting said notice in some conspicuous place on the premises for five (5) days. 
No person shall interfere with, obstruct, mutilate, conceal, or tear down any official notice or placard posted by any City officer, unless permission is given by said officer to remove said notice.  
Sec. 1.12. - Insurance and Bonds. 
(1)  Whenever any provision of this Code, or any City policy, rule, regulation, or contract requires a person to file proof of insurance or a bond, the City's Risk Manager or designee shall determine whether any certificate, binder, or policy of insurance or bond complies with the City's requirements, except that the City Attorney shall approve the form of any bond before it is accepted by the City. 
(2)  All proof of insurance filed with the City must provide that the City will be given thirty (30) days prior written notice of cancellation or termination prior to the stated expiration date. Also, if the stated expiration date precedes the ending date for the period of performance for which the insurance is provided (i.e., end of license year, end of contract term, etc.), then the proof of insurance must provide that the City will be given thirty (30) days prior written notice of an intention not to renew upon expiration. 
(3)  The Risk Manager shall have authority to modify or waive any City insurance or bond requirement or to accept any irregularity in any proof of insurance provided, or to accept a letter of credit or other alternate form of surety in lieu of a bond when, in his or her judgment and discretion, a particular requirement, under all the circumstances, poses an unnecessary hardship or is an unreasonable requirement and the City will be adequately protected in spite of such waiver or modification. 
(Ord. No. 90-01, § 1, 1-2-90) 
Cross reference— Surety bond required for City Treasurer, City Comptroller and City administrator, etc., § 1.148.  
Sec. 1.13. - General Penalty. 
(1)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided for in the City Charter or in this Code for violation of a particular provision, Section or Chapter, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this Code shall be punished as follows: 
(a)  By a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00); or 
(b)  By imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days; or 
(c)  By both a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days. 
(2)  In addition to the punishment specified above, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this Code shall be required to pay the costs of their prosecution. This subsection does not apply to any municipal civil infraction. 
(3)  In addition to the provisions of subsection (2) of this Section, any person determined to be responsible for a municipal civil infraction shall be liable for the payment of costs of prosecution in an amount of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(4)  For purposes of this Section, the words "violation of any provision of this Code" shall include any violation of the Code, any violation of a provision of the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids, and any violation of a rule or regulation adopted or issued under authority granted by this Code or by the Charter of Grand Rapids. 
(5)  Each act of violation and every day upon which any violation is permitted or suffered to exist shall constitute a separate violation and shall be punished separately upon conviction. The penalty provided by this Section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to any amendment or addition to this Code whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 66-1, 1-11-66; Ord. No. 79-22, 4-10-79; Ord. No. 2014-60, § 1, 7-22-14) 
State Law reference— Limitation on penalties, MCL 117.4i, MSA 5.2082.  
Sec. 1.14. - Severability. 
It is the legislative intent of the Commission in adopting this Code, that all provisions and Sections of this ordinance be liberally construed to protect and preserve the peace, health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the City of Grand Rapids and should any provision or Section of this ordinance be held unconstitutional or invalid, such holding shall not be construed as affecting the validity of any of the remaining provisions or Sections, it being the intent that this ordinance shall stand, notwithstanding the invalidity of any provision or Section thereof. 
The provisions of this Section shall apply to the amendment of any Section of this Code whether or not the wording of this Section is set forth in the amendatory ordinance.  
Sec. 1.15. - Effective Date. 
This Code shall take effect thirty (30) days after its adoption.  
Secs. 1.16—1.20. - Reserved.  
Chapter 2 - CITY COMMISSION[1]

ARTICLE 1. - MEETINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-42, §§ 1, 2, adopted August 27, 2013, repealed the former Art. 1, §§ 1.21, 1.22, and enacted a new Art. 1 as set out herein. The former Art. 1 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table B for complete derivation. 
 
Sec. 1.21. - Meeting Dates. 
The City Commission shall meet in regular session twice each calendar month, and such meetings shall be held on Tuesdays. In the event any Tuesday is a legal holiday for the City, the City Commission may meet in regular session the following day. 
(Ord. No. 2013-42, § 2, 8-27-13) 
Charter reference— Meetings, Title V, Sec. 5.  
Sec. 1.22. - Hours for Meetings. 
At least one regular meeting of the City Commission each month shall be held in the evening at 7:00 p.m. The remaining regular meetings each month that are not held at 7:00 p.m. shall be held in the afternoon at 2:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 2013-42, § 2, 8-27-13)  
Sec. 1.23. - Locations for Meetings. 
(1)  Regular meetings of the City Commission shall be held in the Grand Rapids City Commission Chambers, 9th floor, City Hall, Grand Rapids, Michigan, except as provided in the following subsection. 
(2)  Up to three times per year, regular meetings of the City Commission may be held at locations in the various wards of the City. 
(Ord. No. 2013-42, § 2, 8-27-13)  
Sec. 1.24. - Compliance With the Open Meetings Act. 
In accordance with the Michigan Open Meetings Act, MCL 15.261 et seq., the City Commission shall at least annually, by resolution, adopt a schedule of its regular meetings showing the dates, times and places of such meetings. 
(Ord. No. 2013-42, § 2, 8-27-13)  
ARTICLE 2. - WITNESSES BEFORE COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 1.25. - Clerk to Issue Subpoenas. 
The City Clerk upon instructions from the Mayor or any Commissioner or the City Attorney, shall issue subpoenas in the name of the Mayor of the City and under the corporate seal of said City, which subpoenas shall be signed by the said City Clerk, directed to any person whom such official ordering the subpoena may deem necessary as a witness in any matter pending before the City Commission or any Committee thereof, ordering said person to appear before said Commission or Committee at a certain time and place to be designated in said subpoena, to testify concerning such matter or thing or to produce before said Commission or Committee at said time and place, such books, records, contracts, papers or other data as shall be designated in said subpoena. 
Charter reference— Attendance of Witnesses and Production of Books, etc., Title XVIII, Sec. 1.  
Sec. 1.26. - Subpoenas to Be Served. 
Such subpoenas shall be served by some officer designated by the Director of Public Safety if requested by the official ordering such subpoena, or may be served by any person over the age of twenty-one (21) years, by delivering a copy thereof to such person.  
Sec. 1.27. - Penalty. 
If the person so subpoenaed as herein provided shall fail to appear at said time and place, and due proof by affidavit of personal service upon the person subpoenaed filed with the City Clerk, or if any witness appearing shall refuse to testify or to answer any question relative to the matter under inquiry, or produce any books, records, contracts or other papers required to be produced by the subpoena and under the control of said witness, such person on conviction thereof in the 61st District Court, shall be punished as prescribed in Section 1.13 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 73-39, 6-5-73)  
Sec. 1.28. - Aid of Circuit Court. 
If any person so subpoenaed as herein provided shall fail to appear at said time and place, or appearing shall refuse to testify or answer any question, or to produce any books, records, contracts or papers which he or she has been directed to produce, such official ordering such subpoena may by petition invoke the aid of the Circuit Court for the County of Kent in requiring the affidavits and testimony of witnesses and the production of all books, papers and documents, and have subpoenas issued from said Circuit Court for the County of Kent in the usual manner, requiring the attendance of any witness to testify and the production of any books, papers and documents before said Commission or Committee; and in case of refusal to obey a subpoena or to answer a proper question propounded by said Commission or Committee, said Circuit Court may issue an order requiring such person to appear before said Commission or Committee, and to produce books, papers, documents or data, if required, and give evidence touching matters under investigation.  
Sec. 1.29. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 3. - FALSE SWEARING BEFORE COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 1.30. - Deemed Perjury. 
Any person who may be required to take any oath or affirmation or subscribe to any affidavit in respect to any matter pending before the City Commission or any of its Committees, and shall in such affidavit swear falsely as to any material fact involved in such matter, or having taken an oath before the Mayor, President, City Clerk or the Chairman of any general or special Committee of the City Commission, shall wilfully swear falsely as to any material fact in respect to such matter, shall be guilty of perjury, and shall be punished as provided by law.  
Secs. 1.31—1.40. - Reserved.

ARTICLE 1. - WARD APPORTIONMENT 
 
Sec. 1.41. - Ward Apportionment. 
The City of Grand Rapids shall be divided into three (3) Wards, as follows: 
First Ward. All that part of the City lying westerly of a line described as commencing at the centerline of the Grand River at the north City limits, thence south along said centerline to the centerline of the Conrail Railroad (vacated), thence southeasterly along said centerline of the Conrail Railroad (vacated) to the centerline of Fulton Street, thence east along said centerline to the centerline of Jefferson Avenue, thence south along said centerline to the centerline of Burton Street, thence east along said centerline to the centerline of Eastern Avenue, thence south along said centerline to the south City limits. 
Second Ward. All that part of the City lying easterly and northerly of a line described as commencing at the centerline of the Grand River at the north City limits near Four Mile Road, thence generally south along said centerline to the centerline of the Conrail Railroad (vacated), thence southeasterly along said centerline of the Conrail Railroad (vacated) to the centerline of Fulton Street, thence east along said centerline to the centerline of Jefferson Avenue, thence south along said centerline to the centerline of Wealthy Street, thence east along said centerline to the centerline of Lake Drive, thence southeast along said centerline to the common boundary with East Grand Rapids. 
Third Ward. All that part of the City lying easterly and southerly of a line described as commencing at the centerline of Eastern Avenue at the south City limits, thence north along said centerline and the City limits to the centerline of Burton Street, thence west along said centerline to the centerline of Jefferson Avenue, thence north along said centerline to the centerline of Wealthy Street, thence east along said centerline to the centerline of Lake Drive, thence southeast along said centerline to the common boundary with East Grand Rapids. 
(Ord. No. 2014-11, § 1, 3-11-14)  
Secs. 1.42.—1.45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 2. - VOTING PRECINCTS 
 
Sec. 1.46. - Voting Precincts. 
That pursuant to Title I, Section 5(a) of the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids, the City Commission hereby establishes seventy-seven (77) election precincts with the boundaries shown on the Election Precinct Map filed with the City Clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2014-11, § 1, 3-11-14)  
Secs. 1.47.—1.70. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 2013-37, § 2, 8-13-13)

ARTICLE 2. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Police regulations, Title IX; traffic, Title X. 
 
Sec. 1.81. - Department of Police. 
The Department of Police shall be headed by the Superintendent of Police, who shall be the commanding officer of the Police Force. He or she shall direct the police work of the City and be responsible for the enforcement of law and order.  
Sec. 1.82. - Functions of Police Department. 
The police work of the City shall consist of the following functions: 
(1)  The operation of motor and foot patrol units for routine investigations and the general maintenance of law and order. 
(2)  The maintenance of the central complaint desk at Police Headquarters, the maintaining and supervising of police records, criminal and noncriminal identification, property identification, and the custody of property. 
(3)  The investigations of crimes, elimination of illegal liquor traffic and vice, and the preparation of evidence for the prosecution of criminal cases and offenses in violation of this Code. 
(4)  The prevention and control of juvenile delinquency, the removal of crime hazards and the coordination of community agencies interested in crime prevention. 
(5)  The enforcement of traffic laws, traffic educational programs, school patrols, coordination of traffic violation prosecutions and the issuance of operator's licenses. 
(6)  The operation of community policing units in the City's neighborhoods. 
(Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1, 2-16-10) 
Note— This section shall become effective on July 1, 2010 pursuant to the majority of the electors voting in the May 4, 2010 special election approve an increase in the City income tax rate to 1.5% for corporations and resident individuals, and .75% for nonresident individuals. This amendment was approved by a majority of the qualified electors voting on the question at a special election held on May 4, 2010. 
Cross reference— Issuance of alarm user permits, § 9.402; inspection of alarm systems, § 9.405; general traffic regulations, Ch. 181.  
Sec. 1.83. - Department Rules. 
The Superintendent of Police may prescribe rules for the government of police officers of the City, subject to approval by the City Manager, which shall be entered in a book of Police Department rules and orders and may be amended or revoked by the Superintendent upon written notice to the City Manager. It shall be the duty of all members of the Police Force to comply with such rules and orders while effective.  
Sec. 1.84. - Acting Superintendent. 
In case of the absence from the City of the Superintendent of Police, or his or her disability, or inability from any cause to act as Superintendent, the City Manager shall designate and appoint some other member of the Police Department to act as Superintendent during such absence or disability.  
Sec. 1.85. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-37, § 3, adopted August 13, 2013, repealed § 1.85, which pertained to Office of Traffic Engineer.  
Sec. 1.86. - Funding of Community Police Officers. 
While both a City Income Tax of 1.5% is in effect for corporations and resident individuals and a City Income Tax of .75% is in effect for non-resident individuals, community police officers within the Department of Police shall continue to be funded. 
(Ord. No. 2010-08, § 2, 2-16-10) 
Note— This section shall become effective on July 1, 2010 pursuant to the majority of the electors voting in the May 4, 2010 special election approve an increase in the City income tax rate to 1.5% for corporations and resident individuals, and .75% for nonresident individuals. This amendment was approved by a majority of the qualified electors voting on the question at a special election held on May 4, 2010.  
Secs. 1.87—1.90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 3. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Fire prevention, Ch. 159; alarms, Ch. 163. 
 
Sec. 1.91. - Fire Department. 
The Fire Department shall be headed by the Fire Chief, who shall be charged with the prevention and extinguishment of fires, the protection of life and property against fire, the removal of fire hazards, the performance of other public services of an emergency nature assigned to him or her, and the conducting of an educational fire prevention program.  
Sec. 1.92. - Fire Prevention Duties. 
The Fire Department shall be responsible for the inspecting of potential fire hazards, and the abatement of existing fire hazards, in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 159 of this Code.  
Sec. 1.93. - Departmental Rules. 
The Fire Chief shall adopt rules and regulations for the government of the Department, subject to the approval of the City Manager, and may change and repeal the same upon notice to and approval by the City Manager. Such rules and regulations shall designate the chain of command for the Department, so that in the absence or disability of the Chief or any officer of the Department, the responsibility for the operation of the Department shall immediately and automatically be vested in the next ranking officer or member of the Department on duty at the time of the fire.  
Sec. 1.94. - Department Equipment. 
The Fire Chief shall be responsible for the maintenance and care of all property and equipment used by the Fire Department.  
Sec. 1.95. - Funding of a Fire Squad for LaGrave Avenue Station. 
While both a City Income Tax of 1.5% is in effect for corporations and resident individuals and a City Income Tax of .75% is in effect for non-resident individuals, a fire squad to be located at the LaGrave Avenue Station, available to provide fire response in any area of the City, shall continue to be funded. 
(Ord. No. 2010-08, § 3, 2-16-10) 
Note— This section shall become effective on July 1, 2010 pursuant to the majority of the electors voting in the May 4, 2010 special election approve an increase in the City income tax rate to 1.5% for corporations and resident individuals, and .75% for nonresident individuals. This amendment was approved by a majority of the qualified electors voting on the question at a special election held on May 4, 2010.  
Secs. 1.96—1.100. - Reserved.

Chapter 5 - ADMINISTRATIVE POLICY AND PROCEDURE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— City Commission, Ch. 2; administrative service, Ch. 4; Boards and Commissions, Ch. 8; property tax levy and collection, Ch. 9; special assessments, Ch. 10; purchases, contracts and sales, Ch. 11; emergency management, Ch. 13; uniform City income tax, Ch. 14; investments, Ch. 18; Planning Commission, Ch. 62; historic preservation, Ch. 68; fees and bonds, Ch. 92; Housing Code, Ch. 135; nuisances, Ch. 151; civil emergency, Ch. 161. 
 
Sec. 1.141. - City Manager. 
The City Manager shall see that all laws, ordinances, rules, regulations adopted by the Commission, and the provisions of this Code are properly enforced. He or she shall attend all meetings of the Commission, regular and special. He or she shall appoint a qualified person as his or her Administrative Assistant. The Deputy City Manager, or in his or her absence the Administrative Assistant to the Manager, shall temporarily perform the duties of the Manager during his or her absence or disability, unless otherwise ordered by the City Commission.  
Sec. 1.142. - Administrative Officers. 
The administrative officers of the City, except the City Attorney, the City Clerk and City Treasurer shall, in the performance of the duties of their respective offices, be subordinate to and under the direction of the City Manager and shall report and be directly responsible to him or her.  
Sec. 1.143. - Vacancies. 
In case of a vacancy in office or during the absence of any administrative officer, the City Manager may designate an interim acting head or perform personally the functions of the office, until such vacancy is filled in accordance with the Charter.  
Sec. 1.144. - All Departments. 
All Departments of the City shall comply with the following: 
(1)  All Department Heads shall keep informed as to the latest practices in their particular field and shall inaugurate, with the approval of the City Manager in the case of Departments responsible to him or her or in the case of other Departments, with the approval of the officer or body to whom the Department Head is responsible, such new practices as appear to be of benefit to the service and to the public. 
(2)  Each Department Head shall establish a system of records and reports in sufficient detail to furnish all information necessary for proper control of Department activities and to form a basis for the periodic reports to the Manager. The City Manager shall keep the Commission fully advised at all times as to the financial condition and needs of the City. 
(3)  Each Department Head shall be held responsible for the preservation of all public records under his or her jurisdiction and shall provide a system of filing and indexing the same. No public records, reports, correspondence or other data relative to the business of any Department shall be destroyed or removed permanently from the files without the knowledge and approval of the City Commission. Inter-office communications, working memoranda or reference material used by any Department shall not be considered as a public record under this Section.  
Sec. 1.145. - Administrative Manual. 
The City Manager is authorized to adopt such administrative regulations in addition to, but not inconsistent with, the Charter and this Code, as he or she shall deem necessary and proper to provide for the adequate functioning of all Departments. Such regulations shall comprise the administrative manual.  
Sec. 1.146. - Payment of Moneys. 
All moneys belonging to the City shall be paid out upon presentation of a valid warrant issued in accordance with the Charter by warrant checks signed by the City Manager and the Director of Finance.  
Sec. 1.147. - Approval of Legal Documents. 
The Mayor shall sign or cause his or her signature to be affixed to, the City Clerk shall attest to, and the City Attorney shall approve as to form, all contracts, agreements and other documents requiring the assent of the City, unless otherwise provided for by law, the Charter ordinance or the provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 85-64, § 1, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.148. - Bonds. 
Upon recommendation of the City's Risk Manager or Insurance Agent of Record, the City Commission by resolution shall provide for the purchase and renewal of surety bonds of such types and amounts as it determines will adequately protect the City against officer and employee dishonesty. 
(Ord. No. 69-5, 1-21-69; Ord. No. 70-40, 6-23-70; Ord. No. 79-74, 10-30-79; Ord. No. 2003-42, § 1, 10-21-03) 
Cross reference— Filing of surety bonds generally, § 1.12.  
Sec. 1.149. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-68, § 1, adopted October 22, 2013, repealed § 1.149, which pertained to constables' bonds. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 1.150. - Fair Employment Practices. 
No Department of the City of Grand Rapids or any City official, agent or employee of the City for or on behalf of the City shall, because of the race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry of any individual, refuse to hire or otherwise discriminate against a person with respect to hire, tenure, terms, conditions or privileges of employment, or any matter directly or indirectly related to employment, except where based on a bona fide occupational qualification as set forth in the Michigan State Fair Employment Practices Act, being Act 251 of the Public Acts of 1955, as amended. 
No Department of the City of Grand Rapids or any City official, agent or employee of the City for or on behalf of the City shall, because any individual is between the ages of eighteen (18) and sixty (60), or because of the sex of any individual, refuse to hire or otherwise to discriminate against him or her with respect to hire, tenure, terms, conditions or privileges of employment. Any such refusal to hire or discrimination shall not be an unfair employment practice as based upon law, regulation, the requirements of any Federal or State training or employment program or on a bona fide occupational qualification. 
It shall not be an unfair employment practice to refuse to select an individual over the age of thirty-five (35) because of his or her age for an apprenticeship or an on-the-job training program intended to have a duration of more than four (4) months. 
(Ord. No. 68-49, 7-23-68; Ord. No. 73-57, 8-14-73) 
Cross reference— Provision against discrimination in contractor, § 1.517. 
State Law reference— Discrimination in employment, MCL 37.2201 et seq., MSA 3.548(201) et seq.  
Sec. 1.151. - Travel Expense Regulations. 
The regulations and procedures governing reimbursement for travel and other expenses shall be established as follows: 
(a)  Regulations governing reimbursements for travel and other expenses by elected officials of the City shall be adopted by resolution of the City Commission. 
(b)  Regulations governing reimbursements for travel and other expenses of appointed officials and employees of the City shall be prepared by the City Manager and approved by the City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 69-32, 4-15-69)  
Sec. 1.152. - Appearance Tickets. 
The following public servants are authorized to issue appearance tickets with respect to the indicated classes of violations of the Code of the City of Grand Rapids upon reasonable cause to believe that the person to whom the appearance ticket is issued has committed the violation, or violations, indicated:

(f)  The City Attorney for violation of any provision of the Code of the City of Grand Rapids or of any of the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, or for any violation of the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids.
