Chapter 7 - PENSION AND RETIREMENT BENEFITS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administrative policy and procedure, Ch. 5. 
 
ARTICLE 1. - GENERAL PENSION SYSTEM[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, adopted Nov. 3, 1998, amended Art. 1, in its entirety, to read as herein set out in §§ 1.190—1.230. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Art. 1 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table B. 
 
Sec. 1.190. - Retirement System Created. 
The City of Grand Rapids General Retirement System is hereby created and established. This Article may be cited as the City of Grand Rapids General Retirement System Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.191. - Effective Date of System and Amendments. 
The Pension System set forth in Article 1 of Chapter 7 of Title I of the Code of the City of Grand Rapids, and amended from time to time, was amended by action of the Grand Rapids City Commission on August 20, 2002 to comply with TRA '86, OBRA '87, TAMRA '88, OBRA '89, UCA '92, OBRA '93, USERRA '94, URAA/GATT/RPA '94, SBJPA '96, TRA '97, RRA '98, CRTRA '00 and EGTRRA '01, and is hereby further amended and restated to comply with the Pension Protection Act of 2006. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2002-50, § 1, 8-20-02; Ord. No. 2013-40, § 1, 8-27-13)  
Sec. 1.192. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases as used in this Article, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Accrued Benefit means the portion of an allowance earned as of the date of the computation. It is a monthly benefit commencing at the minimum service retirement age and computed in accordance with the life allowance formula in Section 1.205 using the member's final average salary and credited service at the time of the computation. 
(2)  Accumulated contributions means the total of all amounts deducted from the compensations of a member and standing to his or her credit in his or her individual account in the members' deposit fund, together with regular interest at the rate of three (3%) percent per annum, compounded annually, from and after October 1, 1964. 
(3)  Actuarial equivalent means a benefit of equal reserve value. Present values will be determined by the actuary based on mortality tables and interest rates established from time to time by the Board. No change in mortality or interest assumptions shall reduce the accrued benefit of any member determined as of the date of the change. 
(4)  Allowance or Life Allowance means the total of the annuity and the pension. All allowances shall be paid not later than the last day of each calendar month. 
(4a)  Allowance cap means the agreed upon limit to the product which results when a member's years of credited service are multiplied by the benefit multiplier applicable to the member at the time of retirement, expressed as a percentage. 
(5)  Annuity means a monthly amount derived from the accumulated contributions of a member and payable by the System throughout the life of a person or for a temporary period. 
(6)  Assumed interest means such rate or rates per annum, compounded annually, as the Board shall adopt from time to time. 
(7)  Beneficiary means any person who is receiving or designated by a member to receive a System benefit, except a retirant. 
(8)  Benefit program means a schedule of benefits or benefit formulas from which the amounts of System benefits can be determined. 
(9)  Board of Trustees or Board means the Board of Trustees of the System. 
(10)  Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 as amended. 
(11)  Compensation means remuneration actually paid or made available to an Employee within the Limitation Year, as defined in accordance with Regulation 1.415(c)—2(a), and means all items of Employer remuneration for services, including: 
(a)  Wages, salaries, and other amounts received for personal services rendered in the course of employment with Employer, to the extent amounts are includible in gross income or would have been received and includible in gross income but for an election under Internal Revenue Code ("IRC") Section 125(a), 132(f)(4), 402(e)(3), 402(h)(1)(B), 402(k), 414(h)(2), or 457(b), and further include, but are not limited to, base salary, longevity pay, educational allowance, vacation pay, bonuses, fringe benefits, and reimbursements or other expense allowances under a nonaccountable plan, plus the following additional compensation items; 
(1)  Members of the Crime Scene Technicians group: Holiday pay, clothing allowance, overtime pay, shift pay, acting assignment pay, witness fee pay, and compensatory time pay off are also considered compensation for pension computation purposes effective July 1, 2000. 
(2)  Emergency Communications Operators I, II and III: Holiday pay, overtime pay, shift pay, acting assignment pay, compensatory time pay off, and pay as an ECOII trainer are also considered compensation for pension computation purposes effective July 1, 2005. 
(b)  Amounts described in IRC Sections 104(a)(3), 105(a), or 105(h) but only to the extent includible in gross income; 
(c)  Amounts paid or reimbursed by the Employer for Employee's moving expenses to the extent it is reasonable to believe, at payment, they are not deductible pursuant to IRC Section 217; 
(d)  Amounts includible in Employee's gross income upon a IRC Section 83(b) election; and 
(e)  Amounts includible in gross income pursuant to IRC Section 409A, or because they are constructively received. 
Compensation does not include items listed in Regulation 1.415(c)—2(c). 
Compensation for a Limitation Year shall not include Compensation in excess of IRC Section 401(a)(17) limits for such Limitation Year. 
In order to be taken into account for a Limitation Year, Compensation must be actually paid or made available to employees (or, if earlier, includible in the gross income of the Employee) within the Limitation Year. For this purpose, Compensation is treated as paid on a date if it is actually paid on that date or it would have been paid on that date but for an election under IRC Section 125, 132(f)(4), 401(k), 403(b), 408(k), 408(p)(2)(a)(i), or 457(b); provided, however, Compensation for a Plan Limitation Year includes amounts earned during that Plan Limitation Year but not paid during that Plan Limitation Year solely because of the timing of pay periods and pay dates if (i) these amounts are paid during the first few weeks of the next Plan Limitation Year; (ii) the amounts are included on a uniform and consistent basis with respect to all similarly situated employees and (iii) no Compensation is included in more than one Plan Limitation Year. 
In order to be taken into account for a Plan Limitation Year, Compensation must be paid or treated as paid to the Employee prior to the Employee's severance from employment with the Employer; provided Compensation paid by the later of 2½ months after severance from employment with the Employer or the end of the Limitation Year that includes the date of severance from employment with the Employer, is included if the payment is regular compensation for service during working hours or compensation for services outside regular working hours, commissions, bonuses or similar payments and it would have been paid prior to severance had Employee continued in employment. 
Compensation includes salary continuation payments to an individual who does not currently perform services for the Employer by reason of qualified military service (as that term is used in IRC Section 414(u)(1)) to the extent those payments do not exceed the amounts the individual would have received if the individual had continued to perform services for the Company rather than entering qualified military service. 
(12)  Credited service means employment as an employee which employment is creditable as service hereunder, to the extent such service is standing to a member's credit as provided in this Article. 
(13)  Employee means any person regularly employed by the employer in a position other than police officer, police command officer or firefighter, as those positions are defined in the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System. Employees hired on or after the dates provided in the following table are excluded from participation in the General Retirement System: 
Covered Employee Group 	Date of Hire, Election or Appointment 
GREIU 	On or after May 25, 2011 
Non-Represented Members as defined in Section 1.192(18.1) 	On or after July 1, 2011 
GREIU Public Library Rank & File and Supervisory bargaining units 	On or after September 2, 2011 
GREIU 61st District Court 	On or after September 13, 2011 
APAGR 61st District Court 	On or after September 13, 2011 
Emergency Communication Supervisors 	On or after September 13, 2011 
Crime Scene Technicians 	On or after November 15, 2011* 
ECOs I, II and III 	On or after January 24, 2012 
APAGR 	On or after July 1, 2014 
 
*Members of the Crime Scene Technicians bargaining unit who have earned fewer than eight (8) years of credited service as of November 15, 2011 are permitted to voluntarily convert to a defined contribution retirement plan in lieu of continuing participation in the General Retirement System. All rights to any future benefits from the General Retirement System will be forfeited upon such member's election to convert. All member contributions will be refunded from the General Retirement System, per the provisions of Section 1.212(1), following the member's conversion to said defined contribution retirement plan. 
(14)  Employer means the City of Grand Rapids, Michigan. 
(15)  Final Average Salary of a Member means the average of each of the member's highest annual compensation rates during each of the member's three (3) calendar years of employment while participating in the System when such compensation rates were highest, provided all such compensation occurs before the end of the calendar year in which the member attains forty (40) years of credited service, or provided no such rates of salary occur after the date on which the employee attains the number of years of credited service, which, when multiplied by the applicable benefit multiplier as set forth in Section 1.205, equals the allowance cap as set forth in that section. Should a member have less than three (3) such highest annual compensation rates, "final average salary" means the average of each of the member's highest annual compensation rates during each of the member's calendar years of employment. 
Additionally, effective July 1, 2000, members of the Crime Scene Technicians group shall have an additional sum added to their final average salary or an actuarially determined addition to the final average salary (FAS) calculated by dividing (i) the average of the Section 1.192(11) additional compensation items (ACI) for the group for the previous three (3) calendar years, by (ii) the annualized average of the group's covered payroll from actuarial valuations as of June 30 of each calendar year, excluding ACI, for the five-year period immediately preceding the valuation. The calculation will be completed by June 30 of each year. 
Additionally, effective July 1, 2005, Emergency Communications Operators I and II shall have an additional sum added to their final average salary or an actuarially determined addition to the final average salary (FAS) calculated by dividing (i) the average of the Section 1.192(11) additional compensation items (ACI) for the group for the previous five (5) calendar years, by (ii) the annualized average of the group's covered payroll from actuarial valuations as of June 30 of each calendar year, excluding ACI, for the five-year period immediately preceding the valuation. In the first year the average shall be calculated based upon the preceding four (4) years, and thereafter based upon the preceding five (5) years as stated above. The calculation will be completed by June 30 of each year. 
(16)  Market Value means the quoted selling price plus accrued income on assets held in trust for the payment of benefits or, in the event the System acquires non publicly-traded assets, a price established by an independent professional appraiser chosen by the Board who is qualified to appraise assets of the subject property class. 
(17)  Member means any employee defined in Section 1.192(13) who: 
(a)  Has not elected the Officer's Option provided for in Section 1.283; or 
(b)  Becomes an Appointed Officer who had previously elected the Officer's Option provided for in Section 1.283 and has elected to resume membership as permitted in Section 1.285(b); or 
(c)  Does not hold a position of employment with the City which is specifically excluded from coverage by this System. 
(18)  Minimum service retirement age and normal retirement age mean age 62. 
(18.1)  Non-Represented Member means any member as herein defined holding a full-time permanent position who is not represented by any bargaining unit, including supervisors or other employees in administrative, clerical, or executive classifications, or any appointed or elected official with the exception of 61st District Court Judges. Non-Represented Members shall include non-represented employees of the City, the Library, the Pension System, and the 61st District Court. 
(19)  Pension means a monthly amount derived from contributions of the employer and payable by the System throughout the life of a person or for a temporary period. 
(20)  Plan Year, Fiscal Year, and Section 415 Limitation Year of this Retirement System is the 12-month period ending June 30 of each year. 
(21)  Regular Interest means the rate of three (3%) percent per annum, compounded annually. 
(22)  Reserve means the present value of all payments to be made on account of any System benefit based upon such reasonable tables of experience and assumed interest as the Board shall adopt from time to time in good faith. 
(23)  Retirant means a former member receiving a System allowance, by reason of having been a member. 
(24)  Retirement System or System means the City of Grand Rapids General Retirement System. 
(25)  Valuation Assets means the value of the current plan assets recognized for the purpose of determining required contributions to the System. For purposes of determining the employer contribution requirement for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1998 through the fiscal year ending June 30, 2009 (valuation date June 30, 2007), valuation assets shall be determined using a market-related (smoothed) asset value method which recognizes 33 1/3 % of the capital value change in a fiscal year immediately, 33 1/3 % of the capital value change in the next subsequent fiscal year and the remaining 33 1/3 % of the capital value change in the second subsequent fiscal year. For purposes of determining the employer contribution requirement for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2009 (valuation date June 30, 2008) and all subsequent fiscal years, valuation assets shall be determined using a market-related (smoothed) asset value method which recognizes 20% of the investment return in a fiscal year immediately, and 20% of the investment return in each of the next four subsequent fiscal years. The remaining unrealized investment return from June 30, 2006 shall be recognized equally over the next three fiscal years and the remaining unrealized investment return from June 30, 2007 shall be recognized equally over the next four (4) fiscal years, beginning with the June 30, 2008 valuation. 
(26)  The masculine gender shall include the feminine gender, and words of the singular number with respect to persons shall include the plural number, and vice-versa. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 77-61, 11-8-77; Ord. No. 80-10, 2-19-80; Ord. No. 80-12, 2-19-80; Ord. No. 88-31, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 90-29, § 1, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 91-68, §§ 1, 2, 12-17-91; Ord. No. 97-29, § 1, 6-24-97; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2000-45, § 1, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 2002-50, § 2, 8-20-02; Ord. No. 2003-29, §§ 1, 2, 8-5-03; Ord. No. 2005-29, §§ 1, 2, 5-17-05; Ord. No. 2008-57, § 1, 12-23-08; Ord. No. 2009-49, § 1, 9-15-09; Ord. No. 2010-46, § 1, 8-24-10; Ord. No. 2010-74, § 1, 12-21-10; Ord. No. 2011-26, § 1, 7-12-11; Ord. No. 2011-62, § 1, 12-20-11; Ord. No. 2012-08, § 1, 1-24-12; Ord. No. 2013-40, §§ 2, 3, 8-27-13; Ord. No. 2014-54, § 1, 7-22-14; Ord. No. 2019-25, § 1, 6-11-19)  
Sec. 1.193. - Board of Trustees—Appointment and Election. 
The general administration and responsibility for the proper operation of the System and for making effective the provisions of this Article are hereby vested in a Board of Trustees of seven (7) persons, as follows: 
(1)  Three (3) persons to be elected by the members of the System. Such Trustees are called member Trustees in this Article. The member Trustees shall be elected by the members of the Retirement System in accordance with such rules and regulations as the Board shall from time to time adopt to govern such elections. 
(2)  One (1) member of the City Commission to be appointed by the City Commission and to serve at the pleasure of the City Commission. Such Trustee is called employer Trustee in this Article. 
(3)  Three (3) persons appointed by the Mayor, subject to the approval of the City Commission. Such appointees, called citizen members, shall be experienced in financial matters and shall not be a member, retirant or beneficiary of the System, nor an employee or official of the employer. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 76-88, 10-19-76; Ord. No. 85-65, § 1, 10-29-85; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.194. - Board of Trustees—Terms. 
The terms of citizen members and member Trustees presently serving are hereby continued until the expiration of the terms presently provided. All terms of office of member Trustees and citizen Trustees shall be four (4) years. Each Trustee shall continue to serve as Trustee until his or her successor is elected or appointed, as the case may be, and is qualified. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 74-75, 9-24-74; Ord. No. 76-88, 10-19-76; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.195. - Board of Trustees—Vacancy, How Filled. 
In the event any Trustee fails to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the Board unless in each case excused for cause by the remaining Trustees attending such meeting or meetings, he or she shall be considered to have resigned from the Board and the Board shall by resolution declare his or her office of Trustee vacated. If a vacancy occurs in the office of Trustee, through death or resignation, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired portion of the term so vacated in the same manner as the office was previously filled. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.196. - Officers and Employees of System—Executive Director, Actuary, Legal Advisor, Investment Counselor. 
(1)  The Board shall select from its own number a Chairman and a Vice-Chairman. 
(2)  Compensation: 
(a)  Member Trustees (full-time employees of the City) and Elected Officials: The Member Trustees who are full-time employees of the City and Elected Officials of the City serving on the Board shall serve without compensation for their services, as such, as their time is otherwise compensated for by the City. Such Trustees shall be reimbursed from the income-expense fund of the System for their necessary expenses incurred in attending meetings of the Board or in the performance of other duties authorized by the Board. Such reimbursement shall be in a manner and an amount as is reasonably determined by the Board to be appropriate. 
(b)  Other Trustees: The remaining Trustees of the Board shall be compensated at the rate of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per meeting, paid from the income-expense fund of the System, for those special and sub-Committee meetings which are actually attended by such Trustee. In addition, such Trustees shall be reimbursed from the income-expense fund of the System for their necessary expenses incurred in attending meetings of the Board or in the performance of other duties authorized by the Board. Such reimbursement shall be in a manner and an amount as is reasonably determined by the Board to be appropriate. 
(3)  Executive Director and Clerical Staff. 
(a)  The Board shall have the authority to employ the service of an Executive Director for the System, to serve as the System's Chief Executive Officer. The Board shall adopt, and may amend, a job classification for the Executive Director, which shall define the duties and responsibilities of the position consistent with the provisions of this Article. 
(b)  The Board shall have the authority to employ the Executive Director upon terms and conditions that the Board determines are in the best interests of the administration of the System, and may enter into an employment agreement with the Executive Director for a period of not to exceed three (3) years, plus-options to extend or renew. 
(c)  The Executive Director shall have the authority to employ such other professional and clerical services as may be required for the proper administration of the System on such terms and conditions as the Board may determine, and with the approval of the Board. 
(d)  The Executive Director and any clerical or professional staff employed by the System shall be eligible for participation in the group hospital, medical, dental and vision insurance programs otherwise offered to City employees, the General Pension System of the City, the deferred compensation plan, the retirement insurance provisions afforded to other City employees, Worker's Compensation coverage and the Medicare Supplement Plan of the City. The actual benefits provided to the Executive Director and any clerical employees of the System shall be determined by the Board. The actual cost of any and all such coverages provided shall be the responsibility of the System and reimbursed to the City on a quarterly basis. 
(4)  Administrative Costs. 
(a)  The Board shall have the authority to acquire, through lease or purchase, such office space as may be necessary for the proper administration of the System and may provide for such liability and casualty insurance as may be necessary to protect the property and assets of the System. Such office space shall be located within the corporate limits of the City of Grand Rapids and shall, to the extent required by law, be accessible to handicapped persons. 
(b)  The Board shall have the authority to acquire, through purchase or lease, such office supplies, equipment, furniture and furnishings as it determines to be reasonably necessary for the proper administration of the System. 
(c)  All expenses of the Board necessary for the operation of the System, including compensation of the persons engaged by the Board, shall be paid at such rates and in such amounts as the Board shall approve from the income-expense fund of the System. 
(5)  System Actuary. The Board shall appoint an actuary or a firm of actuaries to be the technical advisor to the Board and the Executive Director on matters regarding the operation of the System on an actuarial basis and who shall perform such other duties as may be required in connection therewith. The appointed actuary shall (i) be a Member of The American Academy of Actuaries, (ii) be either a Fellow or Associate of the Society of Actuaries or a Member of the Conference of Consulting Actuaries, and (iii) have a minimum of five (5) years experience in providing actuarial and consulting service to public employee retirement systems. 
(6)  Investment Counselors. The Board shall appoint a professional investment counsel or firm or firms of professional investment counselors to be investment advisors to the Board upon such terms and conditions as the Board may direct. 
(7)  Legal Advisor. The City Attorney shall serve as the legal advisor to the Board and the Executive Director on matters regarding the operation of the System. The Board shall be authorized to retain the services of an attorney or law firm to represent the Board in matters in which the City Attorney has a professional conflict of interest or in other circumstances in which the Board and City Attorney determine such representation would better serve the interests of the System. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 90-35, § 1, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 91-68, § 3, 12-17-91; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.197. - Board Meetings—Quorum; Vote; Proceedings. 
The Board shall hold regular meetings, at least quarterly. Four (4) Trustees, of whom at least one (1) shall be a member Trustee, shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the Board. Each Trustee shall be entitled to one (1) vote on each question before the Board and at least four (4) concurring votes shall be required for a decision by the Board at any meeting. The Board shall adopt its own rules of procedure, and shall keep a record of its proceedings. All meetings of the Board shall be held in conformance with the Michigan Open Meetings Act described in MCL § 15.261 et. seq., as amended. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.198. - Some Specific Board Administrative Duties. 
(1)  The Board shall from time to time adopt such reasonable mortality and other tables of experience, and a rate or rates of assumed interest, as shall be necessary for the actuarial requirements of the System. 
(2)  The Executive Director shall keep, or cause to be kept in convenient form, such data as shall be necessary for actuarial investigations of the experience of the System, and such data as shall be necessary for the annual actuarial valuations of the System. 
(3)  The Board shall annually, but not later than October 31 each year, provide a report to the employer showing the financial condition of the System as of the preceding June 30. Such report shall contain, but shall not be limited to, a financial balance sheet, a statement of income and disbursements, a detailed statement of investments acquired and disposed of during the year, an actuarial balance sheet prepared by means of the last valuation of the System, and such other data as the Board shall deem necessary or desirable or as requested by the City Commission for a proper understanding of the condition of the System. 
(4)  All records of the System shall be kept and maintained by the Executive Director in space provided by the System. 
(5)  The employer shall provide the Executive Director with access to personnel and other records of the employer as may be reasonably required for the proper administration of the System. 
(6)  The Board shall have the authority to meet with and act in joint concert with the Board of Trustees of the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System on administrative matters of mutual concern to both Systems, including, but not limited to, the employment of an Executive Director, the establishment of administrative policy, the apportionment of administrative costs, the acquisition of office space, and the employment of actuaries or legal counsel. The City Commission shall have the authority to specify matters on which joint agreement of the General Pension System and the Police and Fire Pension System are required to avoid the unnecessary duplication of administrative expenses. These matters shall include, but not be limited to, the selection of the System Actuary, the selection of the Executive Director, the selection of the Auditor, and the acquisition of office space. 
(7)  The Board shall have the discretionary power and authority to determine the benefits payable to members by the System. These powers and authority include the following: 
(a)  To construe and interpret the terms and provisions of this Article as they relate to benefits payable; 
(b)  To decide all questions of eligibility for participation in the System; and 
(c)  To decide all questions of eligibility for benefit payments and determine the amount, manner and time of benefit payments under this System. These determinations must be consistent with the terms of the applicable collective bargaining agreements. 
All interpretations of Ordinance provisions, all determinations of facts, and all decisions made in good faith by the Board will be final and binding upon all participants, beneficiaries and all other interested persons. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 87-5, § 1, 1-20-87; Ord. No. 91-68, § 4, 12-17-91; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.199. - Claims Procedure. 
The Board will make all determinations concerning benefits. Any denial of benefits by the Board will be stated in writing by the Board and delivered or mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the member or beneficiary within sixty (60) days after the denial. The notice will set forth the reasons for the denial in language that may be understood by the member or beneficiary and will specify the System provisions upon which the denial was based. If the denial is based on the failure of the member or beneficiary to supply certain materials or information, the notice will so state. The notice will advise that the denial may be appealed to the Board and will include an explanation of the appeal procedure. 
The Board will adopt a procedure for reviewing appeals of denials of benefit claims. The procedure will include the following: 
(a)  The claimant or his duly authorized representative may initiate an appeal by written request for review delivered to the Board not later than sixty (60) days after receipt by the claimant of the notice of denial. The Board has the authority to extend those time limits a maximum of sixty (60) days upon the claimant or claimant's authorized representative showing of good cause or undue hardship. 
(b)  The claimant or his duly authorized representative may review documents pertinent to the appeal and may submit written statements of issues and arguments relevant to the appeal to the Board. 
(c)  The Board will review the appeal at the next regularly scheduled Board meeting which is at least twenty-one (21) days after the completed application for review is received. The Board will return its decision on the appeal not later than sixty (60) days after review. In circumstances where the Board determines that it needs additional information to make its decision, the Board will notify the claimant of the need for additional information and delay its decision until the next regularly scheduled Board meeting which is at least twenty-one (21) days after the additional information is received. 
(d)  The claimant will be advised in writing of the decision on the appeal including the reasons for the decision in language that may be understood by the claimant with references to the System provisions upon which the decision is based. 
(e)  The determination of the Board on all matters under this Section shall be final and binding on all parties. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.200. - Membership of System. 
(1)  The membership of the System shall include all persons who are employees on or after the effective date of the System; provided, however, that persons who are employed in classifications which have been specifically excluded from coverage under the System by ordinance adopted by the City Commission, and persons who have elected coverage under another retirement plan provided by the City shall be excluded from membership in the System. 
(2)  In any case of question as to the System membership status of any person, the Board shall have final power to decide the question. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 91-35, § 1, 7-2-91; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.201. - Membership Terminates; Reinstatement of Credited Services. 
(1)  When a member is no longer employed by the employer in a position covered by the System, he or she shall thereupon cease to be a member of the System. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this Article, upon termination of membership, the member's credited service shall be forfeited. If such person is not a retirant and becomes reemployed by the employer in a position covered by the System, that person shall again become a member of the System. At any time following such reemployment and reentry into membership of the System, such person's credited service last forfeited by that member shall be restored to the member's credit, provided that the member returns to the System the amount, if any, received therefrom, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. 
(b)  At any time following reentry into the System upon election by City Commission to a position of Appointed Officer as provided in Section 1.285(b), all credited service accrued from the date of commencement of employment until the date upon which participation in the Officer's Option commenced will be restored, provided contributions to the System were not withdrawn and such credited service was not forfeited by the officer during such officer's participation in the Officers Option retirement program. 
(2)  Upon a member's retirement he or she shall thereupon cease to be a member and, except as otherwise provided in this Article, he or she shall not again become a member of the System. 
(3)  Except as provided in subsection (4) below, allowance payments shall be suspended for any retirant who is employed by the employer for more than seven hundred (700) hours in a calendar year. Allowance payments shall be suspended immediately upon attainment of seven hundred (700) hours worked and shall remain suspended for the duration of that calendar year that the retirant continues to work for the employer. Any such retirant so employed shall not become a member of the system or gain any credited service or other allowance enhancements as a result of time worked after retirement. The employer shall notify the Retirement Systems of the employment of a retirant and upon the completion of seven hundred (700) hours worked by that retirant. 
(4)  The suspension of retirement allowance payments otherwise required under the provisions of subsection (3), above, may be waived for retired, former non-bargaining unit members of the System if it is determined by the City Manager that the retirant possesses critical skills and, for the good of the City, should be reemployed. In order to request a waiver the City Manager shall certify in writing to the City Commission the reason(s) for the proposed waiver and provide it with a copy of the proposed employment agreement for the retirant. The waiver of the provisions of subsection (3), above shall be effective upon approval by the City Commission. Any such waiver shall not be authorized for a period of more than three (3) calendar years. Any retirant so employed shall not become a member of the System, or gain any credited service or other allowance enhancements as a result of the time worked after retirement. The City Manager shall notify the Retirement Systems of the employment of any such retirant authorized for a waiver under this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 81-17, 3-24-81; Ord. No. 88-31, § 2, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 99-77, § 1, 12-21-99; Ord. No. 2002-12, §§ 1, 2, 2-26-02; Ord. No. 2009-49, § 2, 9-15-09)  
Sec. 1.202. - Service Credit. 
(1)  From and after July 1, 1971, a member will be given credited service for the period from the member's employment commencement date to the member's employment termination date. No credit will be given for any month in which the member does not make the required member contributions for service on ten (10) or more days. Service will be computed in whole months with a remaining period of less than thirty (30) days counted as a whole month if member contributions were made for service on ten (10) or more days. If the period of service determined before application of the immediately preceding sentence results in a period of whole years and an additional fractional year of ten (10) months or more (without rounding), the fractional years of ten (10) months or more will be treated as a whole year. The requirement that a member make the required member contributions as a condition of receiving service credit is waived for the first six months of employment. The Board will fix and determine the number of months and years of service to be credited to each member for employment as an employee in accordance with the terms of this Ordinance. No credited service will be given for employment rendered after the end of the calendar year in which the member attains forty (40) years of credited service for those eligible employees who complete forty (40) years of service on or after January 1, 1988. Effective September 20, 2009, for any Officer Elected by City Commission to a position as an Appointed Officer having accrued credited service in the System, who upon City Commission appointment elects to reenter the System as provided in Section 1.285(b), in no event shall credited service be restored for the period during which the member participated in the officer's option as provided in Section 1.283. 
(2)  In the event a member, who while an employee, entered or enters the armed forces of the United States during any period of compulsory military service, such armed service actually required of him or her shall be credited him or her as service hereunder; provided, that he or she again becomes an employee within a period of ninety (90) days after he or she is relieved from military duty, and he or she returns to the System the amount, if any, he or she may have received therefrom at the time he or she entered or while in such armed service, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment, and in no case shall any member be credited with a total of more than six (6) years of such armed service. In any case of doubt as to the period of such armed service to be so credited a member, the Board shall have power to determine such period. To receive service credit for such required armed service, such member shall have the option to continue during his or her term of military service payments which would have been required of him or her under the System had he or she remained at work, or he or she shall have the option upon reinstatement to make up any such contributions which were not made during the period of his or her military duty. 
In addition to the requirements set forth above, the following provisions shall apply for employees returning to employment after December 11, 1994. Service in the armed forces of the United States includes the performance of duty on a voluntary or involuntary basis in the Army National Guard and the Air National Guard when engaged in active duty for training, initial active duty for training, inactive duty for training, full-time National Guard duty and any other service specified in 38 U.S.C. § 4303. To be eligible for these benefits, the employee must advise the City of his or her intent to return to employment: 
(a)  In the case of service of less than 31 days, on the first full regularly scheduled work period on the first calendar day following the period of service and the expiration of eight (8) hours after a period allowing for safe transportation to the employee's residence; 
(b)  In the case of service of more than thirty (30) but less than 181 days, by submitting an application for reemployment within 14 days after the completion of the period of service; or 
(c)  In the case of service of more than one hundred eighty (180) days, by submitting an application for reemployment within ninety (90) days of the completion of the period of service. 
An employee shall not receive service credit unless payment of employee contributions for the period of absence is made within the period following reemployment equal to the lesser of five (5) years or the period equal to three (3) times the period of service. For purposes of calculating the repayment, compensation shall be based on the rate of compensation that would have been in effect but for the period of service. If this amount cannot be determined, compensation shall be the average rate of compensation paid in the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the period of service. An employee shall not be credited with a total of more than six (6) years of such armed service. 
(3)  In any case of question as to the service credit of any person, the Board shall have power to decide the question. 
(4)  In addition to the contributions deducted from the compensations of a member, as hereinbefore provided, a member may deposit in the System, (a) by a single contribution, (b) by an increased rate of contributions as approved by the Board, or (c) by a Trustee to Trustee transfer to the System from an eligible retirement plan, ("eligible retirement plan" is defined in Section 1.212(6)(b) below), the amount or amounts he or she may have received therefrom and not repaid thereto, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. In no case shall a member be given credit for service rendered prior to the date he or she received payments until he or she returns to the System all amounts due from him or her. 
(5)  Any employee member of the General Pension System who has attained eight (8) or more years of credited service may purchase a maximum of eight (8) years additional credited service for all retirement purposes for time recognized as honorable military service served prior to employment with the City. Eligible service is defined as active Federal service in excess of six (6) months in the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, or Coast Guard of the United States excluding reserve basic and regular training time and Merchant Marine duty. The request for credited service will be reviewed by Trustees at a regular meeting and, if approved, the total cost to the System will be actuarially determined. As the benefit package is borne solely by the member, all costs to the System, including actuarial calculation, shall be paid to the System within sixty (60) days from the date the amount is known in order to gain the credited service requested. The provisions of the Pension Plan at the time of purchase will be used for all calculations. 
(6)  An employee may purchase up to twenty-four (24) additional months of credited service in increments of one month by contributing a percentage of the member's annual rate of compensation at the time of such purchase. Any such periods of purchased credited service shall be recognized solely for the purpose of computing the member's life allowance as provided in Section 1.205 and not for determining eligibility for a benefit or for any other purpose. The purchase rate, expressed as a percentage of compensation, shall be the age and service cost component of the normal cost as determined by the System Actuary. 
(7)  Payments to purchase service described in Subsection (6) above, and to purchase service attributable to absences while on military service leaves described in Subsections (2) and (5), above, will be made (a) by a single cash deposit, (b) by an increased rate of member contributions, (c) by a Trustee to Trustee transfer to the System from an eligible retirement plan, ("eligible retirement plan" is defined in Section 1.212(6)(b) below), or (d) by a combination of an initial lump sum cash deposit and an increased rate of contributions as approved by the Board. The payments for any of these service purchases must be completed in a period of five years or less. Contributions that are made as a percentage of periodic pay may be considered as "picked-up" by the employer as described in Subsection 1.216(5) or may be made on an after-tax basis, at the election of the member prior to the first such payment. This election is irrevocable. Subsequent to the election to purchase service, the member may not amend or revoke a pickup election and except as described below, may not make any direct payments for any service so purchased. The contribution or portion of the contribution paid in an initial cash deposit will not be considered "picked-up." In the event that a member terminates employment prior to completion of the payments over the period elected, the City will reduce the final payroll amount due the member attributable to reimbursement for unpaid vacation, sick leave or other extraordinary forms of compensation (accrued pay) by the lesser of the accrued pay amount or the amount remaining unpaid. Any amounts thereafter remaining unpaid may be paid to the retirement system on a lump-sum, after-tax basis within thirty (30) days of termination of employment. If any amount remains unpaid thirty (30) days after termination of employment, then the additional service purchase will be reduced to reflect the number of months of additional service for which payments have not been received. 
(8)  Sick Leave Conversion. Employees who hold positions identified below may, from and after the date specified, use accumulated and unused sick leave standing to the eligible employee's credit at the time of retirement (or resignation, if noted below) for the purpose of purchasing additional credited service which shall be recognized for the sole purpose of computing the member's life allowance as provided in Section 1.205, and not for determining eligibility for a benefit or for any other purpose. 
(a)  From and after January 1, 2005, Crime Scene Technician members represented by the GRPOA bargaining unit who either resign or retire with ten (10) or more years of continuous service may use up to a maximum of one thousand two hundred sixty-five (1,265) hours of accumulated sick leave to purchase up to one (1) year of such additional credited service, on a pro rata basis. 
(b)  From and after January 1, 2005, members of the Emergency Communication Operators I, II, and III bargaining unit who either resign or retire with ten (10) or more years of continuous service may use up to a maximum of two thousand eighty (2,080) hours of accumulated sick leave to purchase up to one (1) year of such additional credited service, on a pro rata basis. 
(c)  From and after January 1, 2005, members of the Emergency Communication Supervisors bargaining unit who either resign or retire with ten (10) or more years of continuous service may use up to a maximum of two thousand eighty (2,080) hours of accumulated sick leave to purchase up to one (1) year of such additional credited service, on a pro rata basis. 
(d)  From October 21, 2008 through January 25, 2010, members who are 61st District Court Management Non-Represented; and Non-Represented Supervisors, Administrative, Clerical and Executive Classifications; and Appointed Officials who either resign or retire with ten (10) or more years of continuous service may use up to two thousand eighty (2,080) hours of accumulated sick leave to purchase up to one (1) year of such additional credited service, on a pro rata basis. 
(e)  From and after October 21, 2008, members of the APAGR or APAGR 61st District Court bargaining units who either resign or retire with ten (10) or more years of continuous service may use up to two thousand eighty (2,080) hours of accumulated sick leave to purchase up to one (1) year of such additional credited service, on a pro rata basis. 
(f)  From and after March 24, 2009, members of the GREIU bargaining unit who either resign or retire with ten (10) or more years of continuous service may use up to two thousand eighty (2,080) hours of accumulated sick leave to purchase up to one (1) year of such additional credited service, on a pro rata basis. 
(g)  From and after May 26, 2009, members of the 61st District Court GREIU bargaining unit who either resign or retire with ten (10) or more years of continuous service may use up to two thousand eighty (2,080) hours of accumulated sick leave to purchase up to one (1) year of such additional credited service, on a pro rata basis. 
(h)  From and after July 9, 2009, members of the Library GREIU Rank & File and Supervisory bargaining units who either resign or retire with ten (10) or more years of continuous service may use up to two thousand eighty (2,080) hours of accumulated sick leave to purchase up to one (1) year of such additional credited service, on a pro rata basis. 
(i)  From and after January 26, 2010, Non-Represented Members as defined in Section 1.192(18.1) who either resign or retire with ten (10) or more years of continuous service may use up to two thousand eighty (2,080) hours of accumulated sick leave to purchase up to one (1) year of such additional credited service, on a pro rata basis. 
Any such additional credited service purchased with accumulated sick leave shall be subject to the overall credited service limitation of Section 1.202(1) herein, or the allowance cap provisions applicable under Section 1.205 herein. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 80-10, 2-19-80; Ord. No. 88-31, § 3, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 98-55, § 1, 11-24-98; Ord. No. 99-78, § 1, 12-21-99; Ord. No. 2002-50, § 3, 8-20-02; Ord. No. 2005-29, § 3, 5-17-05; Ord. No. 2009-49, § 3, 9-15-09; Ord. No. 2010-48, § 1, 8-24-10)  
Sec. 1.203. - Age and Service Retirement Eligibility. 
Any member in employer service may retire with a life allowance provided for in Section 1.205 upon written application to the Board setting forth at what time not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days subsequent to the execution and filing thereof the member desires to be retired; provided, that at the time so specified for retirement the member shall have attained the minimum service retirement age, and shall have ten (10) or more years of credited service in force, notwithstanding that during such period of notification the member may have separated from service. The member shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.206. 
Any member in employer service who has not attained the minimum service retirement age and who is not eligible for Section 1.209 Special Early Retirement may retire and receive the allowance provided for in Section 1.205 (no age adjustment factor for early retirement) upon written application to the Board setting forth at what time, not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days subsequent to the execution and filing thereof, retirement is desired; provided, at the time so specified for his or her retirement the member shall have thirty (30) or more years of eligible service with the employer or effective January 1, 2001, for members covered by the Emergency Communications Operators Bargaining Unit, eight (8) years of service and fifty-five (55) years of age. The member retiring under this Section shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.206. Eligible service shall be defined as credited service and in addition thereto time spent on leave of absence (including time spent on leave of absence for military service which has not been credited as service under Section 1.202(2) of this Article); provided, however, that such leave of absence time shall not exceed two (2) years in total, time in excess of two (2) years will not be included in computing total eligible service; and further provided, that such leave of absence time shall be excluded from the calculation of the allowance provided for in Section 1.205. 
For Appointed Officers retiring under this Section having elected to reenter the System as permitted by Section 1.285, eligible service shall be defined as all time spent employed by the City, from the date upon which permanent employment commenced. As provided in this Section, eligible service shall include time spent on leave of absence not to exceed two (2) years. No credit shall be given for time during which such appointed officer may have served the City as a seasonal, temporary, contractor or otherwise less than full time employee. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 81-8, 1-27-81; Ord. No. 88-31, § 4, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2009-49, § 4, 9-15-09)  
Sec. 1.204. - Compulsory Retirement. 
There shall be no compulsory retirement. However, no member shall accrue any benefits to exceed those provided in Sections 1.202(l) and 1.205. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 88-31, § 5, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98) 
_____ 
Sec. 1.205. - Life Allowance. 
Upon a member's retirement as provided in this Chapter, the member shall receive a life allowance equal to the applicable percent of final average salary multiplied by the member's period of credited service to the nearest one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) year up to a maximum of forty (40) years of credited service, or, if applicable, up to the allowance cap as defined in Section 1.192(4)(a) herein. The applicable percent of final average salary (Benefit Multiplier) and the Allowance Cap, if any, are provided in the following table for the applicable member groups:

No. 2011-26, § 2, 7-12-11; Ord. No. 2011-62, § 2, 12-20-11; Ord. No. 2012-08, § 2, 1-24-12; Ord. No. 2014-54, § 2, 7-22-14)  
Sec. 1.206. - Allowance Options. 
(1)  Under such rules and regulations and limitations as the Board shall adopt, before the date the first payment of his or her allowance becomes due but not thereafter, a person about to become a retirant may elect to receive an optional form of allowance in lieu of the allowance otherwise payable to him or her as described in Section 1.205. The value of each such optional form of allowance shall be the actuarial equivalent of the value of the allowance otherwise payable to him or her. The optional forms of allowance made available by the Board shall be the forms following or such other forms the Board approves: 
(a)  Option B-100. Upon the death of a retirant who elected Option B100, one hundred (100%) percent of the reduced allowance to which the retirant would have been entitled had the retirant lived shall be paid to the retirant's surviving beneficiary for the lifetime of such surviving beneficiary. 
(b)  Option B-75. Upon the death of a retirant who elected Option B75, seventy-five (75%) percent of the reduced allowance to which the retirant would have been entitled had the retirant lived shall be paid to the retirant's surviving beneficiary for the lifetime of such surviving beneficiary. 
(c)  Option B-50. Upon the death of a retirant who elected Option B50, fifty (50%) percent of the reduced allowance to which the retirant would have been entitled had the retirant lived shall be paid to the retirant's surviving beneficiary for the lifetime of such surviving beneficiary. 
(d)  Option B-25. Upon the death of a retirant who elected Option B25, twenty-five (25%) percent of the reduced allowance to which the retirant would have been entitled had the retirant lived shall be paid to the retirant's surviving beneficiary for the lifetime of such surviving beneficiary. 
(e)  Option B-100 Pop-up. Same as Option B-100 with the added provision that if the designated beneficiary predeceases the retirant, the allowance shall be returned to the amount of the life allowance that would have been payable if no optional form of payment had been elected. Such change shall be made effective the month following the month in which the joint beneficiary died. 
(f)  Option B-75 Pop-up. Same as Option B-75 with the added provision that if the designated beneficiary predeceases the retirant, the allowance shall be returned to the amount of the life allowance that would have been payable if no optional form of payment had been elected. Such change shall be made effective the month following the month in which the joint beneficiary died. 
(g)  Option B-50 Pop-up. Same as Option B-50 with the added provision that if the designated beneficiary predeceases the retirant, the allowance shall be returned to the amount of the life allowance that would have been payable if no optional form of payment had been elected. Such change shall be made effective the month following the month in which the joint beneficiary died. 
(h)  Option B-25 Pop-up. Same as Option B-25 with the added provision that if the designated beneficiary predeceases the retirant, the allowance shall be returned to the amount of the life allowance that would have been payable if no optional form of payment had been elected. Such change shall be made effective the month following the month in which the joint beneficiary died. 
For employees who retire on or after January 1, 1997, who are not members of the Association of Professional Administrators, the actuarial reduction attributable to the survivor option election will be calculated using the ages of the member and spouse at the earlier of the date the member completes forty (40) years of service or the date of retirement. 
(2)  Effective July 1, 1989, benefits payable under any provision of this System will commence not later than the later of the following: 
(a)  April 1 of the calendar year following the calendar year in which the member retires; or 
(b)  April 1 of the calendar year following the calendar year in which the member attains or would have attained age seventy and one-half (70½). 
Payments to beneficiaries other than surviving spouses will commence not later than one year after the death of the member or former member. If death benefits are payable to anyone other than a surviving spouse or designated beneficiary, the entire death benefit must be paid within five years after the death of the member. 
If payments have commenced to the member or former member prior to his death, then the remaining benefits will be paid to his beneficiary at least as rapidly as under the method of payment made to the member or former member as of the date of death. 
No distribution shall be made in a form or over a period longer than permitted in Code Section 401(a)(9) and regulations thereunder, including the incidental death benefit requirements contained therein. These limitations override any inconsistent distribution options. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 84-14, § 1, 3-13-84; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.207. - Terminal Benefit Covering Retirant. 
In the event a retirant dies before he or she has received in allowance payments an aggregate amount equal to his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund at the time of his or her retirement, the difference between such accumulated contributions and such aggregate amount of allowance payments received by him or her shall be paid to such person as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the Board. If there be no such designated person surviving such retirant, such difference, if any, shall be paid to the retirant's estate. In no case shall any benefits be paid under this Section on account of the death of a retirant if any allowance becomes payable by the System on account of his or her death. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.208. - Early Retirement. 
(1)  Any member in employer service who has not attained his or her minimum service retirement age and who is not eligible for Section 1.209 special early retirement may retire with an early allowance provided for in (2) of this Section upon his or her written application to the Board setting forth at what time not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days subsequent to the execution and filing thereof he or she desires to be retired; provided, that at the time so specified for his or her retirement the member shall either (i) have twenty (20) or more years of credited service in force, or (ii) shall have attained age fifty-five (55) and have ten (10) or more years of credited service in force. He or she shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.206. 
(2)  Upon early retirement a member shall receive a percentage of the allowance provided for in Section 1.205, in accordance with the following table of actuarial equivalent percents:
