Sec. 1.209. - Special Early Retirement. 
(1)  Any member in employer service who has not attained his or her minimum service retirement age but who has attained the age of sixty (60) years shall receive a special early allowance provided for in (2) of this Section effective the first day of the calendar month following his or her termination of employer service, if the City Manager shall determine that such retirement is in the best interests of the City. Such determination shall be stated in writing and filed with the Board and the Civil Service Board. A copy of such determination shall be served personally or be certified mail upon such member. Within thirty (30) days of service upon him or her such member shall have a right to appeal such determination to the Civil Service Board by filing a written notice of appeal with the Civil Service Board. The Civil Service Board shall set a time and place for hearing such appeal, and such member shall have the right to appear at such hearing, to present evidence and to be represented by counsel. If the Civil Service Board shall determine that the retirement of such members is in the best interest of the City, it shall affirm the determination of the City Manager, and, if not, it shall set the same aside. 
(2)  Upon special early retirement a member shall receive the allowance provided for in Section 1.205 (no age adjustment factor for early retirement). He or she shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.206. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 95-41, § 1, 7-11-95; Ord. No. 95-42, § 1, 7-11-95; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.209.1. - Disability Retirement. 
(1)  Any member in employer service with ten (10) or more years of credited service who has not attained his or her minimum service retirement age and who becomes totally and permanently physically or mentally incapacitated for his or her duty as an employee, as the result of a personal injury or disease which the Board finds to have arisen other than in the course of his or her actual performance of duty as an employee, may be retired by the Board upon written application filed with the Board by or on behalf of the member; provided, that after a medical examination of such member made by or under the direction of a Medical Committee consisting of three (3) physicians, one (1) of whom shall be selected by the Board, one (1) by or on behalf of such member, and the third by the first two (2) physicians so named, the said Medical Committee reports to the Board, by majority opinion in writing, that such member is physically or mentally totally incapacitated for the further performance of duty, that such incapacity will probably be permanent, and that such member should be retired. 
(2)  Upon disability retirement as provided in (1) of this Section a member shall receive an allowance provided for in Section 1.205 and shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.206. His or her disability retirement and allowance shall be subject to the provisions of (5) of this Section and to the provisions of Section 1.209.2. 
(3)  Any member in employer service who has not attained his or her minimum service retirement age and who becomes totally and permanently physically or mentally incapacitated for his or her duty as an employee, as the natural and proximate result of a personal injury or disease which the Board finds to have arisen out of and in the course of his or her actual performance of duty as an employee, may be retired by the Board upon written application filed with the Board by or on behalf of the member; provided, that after a medical examination of such member made by or under the direction of a Medical Committee consisting of three (3) physicians, one (1) of whom shall be selected by the Board, one (1) by or on behalf of such member, and the third by the first two (2) physicians so named, the said Medical Committee reports to the Board, by majority opinion in writing, that such member is physically or mentally totally incapacitated for further performance of duty, that such incapacity will probably be permanent, and that such member should be retired. 
(4)  Upon disability retirement as provided in (3) of this Section a member shall receive an allowance provided for in Section 1.205; provided, that in no event shall such allowance be less than fifty (50) percent of their final average salary. For civilian classifications represented by the Police Bargaining Units: Crime Scene Technicians - Prisoner Security Clerks and Emergency Communications Operators I and II, the allowance shall not be less than sixty-two (62) percent of their final average salary. They shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.206. Their disability retirement and allowance shall be the subject to the provisions of (5) of this Section and to the provisions of Section 1.209.2. 
(5)  (a)  At least each year during the first five (5) years following a member's retirement on account of disability, and at least once in each three-year period thereafter, the Board may require any disability retirant who has not attained his or her minimum service retirement age to undergo a medical examination to be made by or under the direction of a physician designated by the Board. If such a retirant refuses to submit to such medical examination in any such period his or her disability allowance may be suspended by the Board until his or her withdrawal of such refusal. If such refusal continues for one (1) year all his or her rights in and to a disability allowance may be revoked by the Board. If, upon such medical examination of such retirant, such physician reports to the Board that the said retirant is physically and mentally able and capable of resuming his or her duty as an employee in the position held by him or her at the time of his or her disability retirement, then the Board shall arrange a further medical examination of such member made by or under the direction of a Medical Committee consisting of three (3) physicians, one (1) of whom shall be selected by the Board, one (1) by or on behalf of such member, and the third by the first two (2) physicians so named. Should the Medical Committee concur, by majority opinion in writing to the Board, in the finding that such disability retirant is capable of such resumption of duty, his or her disability retirement shall terminate and he or she shall be returned to duty. 
(b)  Upon a former disability retirant's return to duty as provided in this subsection, he or she shall immediately again become a member of the System, and his or her credited service at the time of his or her disability retirement shall be restored to his or her credit, and the amount of his or her accumulated contributions at the time of his or her disability retirement shall be restored to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund. If he or she was in receipt of a duty disability allowance provided for in (3) of this Section, he or she shall also be given service credit for the period he or she was in receipt of such duty disability allowance. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 74-68, 8-20-74; Ord. No. 90-29, § 2, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.209.2. - Limit on Death or Disability Pensions. 
If a death allowance is payable under the provisions of Section 1.211, or if a disability allowance is payable under the provisions of Section 1.209.1, then in no event shall the total amount of such System allowances exceed ninety (90%) percent of the amount of his or her annual rate of compensation at time of death or disability, as the case may be, less the total of the following amounts: 
(a)  Workmen's compensation, if any, on account of such death or disability. Payment of workmen's compensation on account of a disability or death shall not prohibit payment of any System allowance on account of the same disability or death, but shall reduce the amount of such allowance. 
(b)  Remuneration, if any, received by such retirant for personal services rendered by him or her in any gainful occupation; 
(c)  Benefits, if any, from the Federal social security old-age, survivors, and disability insurance program on account of such death or disability. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 74-68, 8-20-74; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.209.3. - Deferred Retirement. 
(1)  Should a member with eight (8) or more years of credited service cease to be a member, except by death or retirement, before attaining minimum service retirement age, as defined in Section 1.192 and before being eligible for an early allowance as provided in Sections 1.208 and 1.209, or being eligible, elects against receiving such early allowance, such member shall be entitled to a deferred allowance provided for in this Section; provided that the member does not withdraw his or her accumulated contributions from the members' deposit fund. Such deferred allowance shall commence as of the first day of the calendar month next following the later of: 
The attainment of the member's minimum service retirement age, or 
The date the member's written application therefore is received by the Board. 
The members who, being eligible, elect against receiving an early allowance, may elect commencement of the early allowance on the first day of the month following each anniversary of employment termination following eligibility for early retirement as described in Sec. 1.208(1), above, by filing a written application therefor. The member shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.206 at the time of filing such written application. 
For purposes of determining whether a member has eight (8) years of credited service for purposes of determining eligibility for benefits under this System, prior or subsequent periods of services while a member of the Police and Fire Retirement System of the employer shall be considered if the member has at least three (3) years of credited service in each system. Such service shall not be considered for purposes of determining the amount of life allowance hereunder. Rather, the amount of life allowance under this System shall be determined by the compensation and years of credited service while a member of this System. The Board shall have the authority to agree with the Board of Trustees of the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System to transfer assets from or to the Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System so that all benefits of a member from both systems will be paid by only one such Retirement System in an amount equal to the sum of the values of the benefits earned under both systems. 
Members vested with eight (8) or more years of service who cease to be a member by virtue of accepting the officer's option plan provided for in Section 1.283 of Chapter 7, Title I of the Code of the City of Grand Rapids, or who cease active membership in the System for any other reason and elect the deferred option of this Section, are entitled to the provisions outlined above. The deferred benefit will be the life allowance in Section 1.205 calculated using the final average compensation, the benefit percentage, the period of credited service, and other conditions in effect at the time the member ceased being a member of the System. Because the officer's option plan is entered into in lieu of any and all life allowances under the General Retirement System, the enhancement of any life allowance after the member ceased being a member is prohibited. 
(2)  A former member, or person designated by that member as beneficiary, otherwise entitled to a deferred allowance shall be entitled to a deferred allowance if written application therefor is received by the Board from the member or beneficiary as described below in accordance with Section 1.209.3(1) above, but not later than the date the member attains or would have attained age seventy-five (75). In the event such former member does not so live, has not designated a beneficiary, or in the event such written application is not received by the Board within the time limits specified, no benefits whatsoever shall be paid except under the provisions of Section 1.212. 
(3)  In the event of the death of a former member who has deferred pension rights, the designated primary beneficiary shall have the immediate option of electing to receive the deferred benefit subject to the early retirement actuarial equivalent age reduction found in Section 1.208(2), if any, in accordance with Section 1.209.3(1), based upon the age that the former member would have attained at the time application is made, at any time after the death of a former member who has deferred pension rights. 
For purposes of this Section, the beneficiary must be on file in the pension records and designated by the member as the primary beneficiary. In such case, it will be presumed that Option B-100 was elected. The distribution of benefits will be effective and prorated at the end of the month of application and in no case will the payment of any benefit in this Section 1.209.3 be retroactive. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 88-31, § 7, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 90-29, § 3, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 94-42, § 1, 11-1-94; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.209.4. - 2002 Voluntary Retirement Incentive. 
(1)  On February 26, 2002, a Voluntary Retirement Incentive Plan (the "Plan") was adopted by the Grand Rapids City Commission (the "City") which provided that employees who are members of the System, other than elected and appointed officials, and who, in addition to satisfying the requirements of Section 2(B) of such "Plan" also satisfy all of the following requirements, are eligible to receive the retirement incentive set forth in subsection (2) below: 
(a)  The employee must be eligible for normal age and service retirement under Section 1.203 utilizing his or her years of credited service and the two (2) years of additional credited service granted to individuals who retire under this Section. For purposes of this subsection, "years of credited service" does not include any months of credited service purchased under Section 1.202(6). 
(b)  The employee must be employed and actively working for the City or on an approved leave of absence on February 26, 2002. For purposes of this subsection, "actively employed" means that an employee is physically at work performing duties or is on an approved paid leave of absence (e.g. worker's compensation or FMLA leave) and does not include individuals who retired on or before February 26, 2002. 
(c)  The employee must have at least twenty-eight years of credited service; or be age 62 and have at least six (6) years of credited service; or be a member of the Emergency Communications Operators bargaining unit and be age 55 and have at least six (6) years of credited service. For purposes of this subsection, "years of credited service" does not include any months of credited service purchased under Section 1.202(6). 
(d)  The employee must sign and deliver the Retirement Election and Release Agreement to the City not later than 4:00 p.m. on April 30, 2002 and shall terminate employment with the City on or before June 30, 2002, with a retirement date the first day of the month following termination. The minimum thirty (30) day notification required by Section 1.203 shall be waived if necessary to allow an employee to retire under this Section. 
(2)  Employees who retire after satisfying all of the requirements of subsection (1) above shall be entitled to a Life Allowance payable under Section 1.205 (no age adjustment factor for early retirement), calculated using their credited service under Section 1.202 and two (2) additional years of credited service provided hereunder, provided, however, that the provisions of Section 1.202(1) to the contrary not withstanding, no employee retiring under this Section shall be eligible to receive a Life Allowance payable under Section 1.205 that is greater than 100% of his or her final average salary. Employees retiring under this Section shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.206. 
(3)  The retirement incentive of two (2) additional years of credited service as set forth in subsection (2) above shall not be provided to an eligible employee who, before his or her selected retirement date, quits, becomes eligible for disability retirement under the System, dies or otherwise is unwilling or unable to remain in the active employment of the City, or files for and receives unemployment compensation chargeable to the City's account. All costs associated with the retirement incentive provided for in subsection (2) above shall be funded in accordance with Section 1.221(1), (2), (3), (5) and (6). 
(Ord. No. 2002-16, § 1, 3-19-02)  
Sec. 1.209.5. - 2003 Voluntary Retirement Incentive—G.R. Public Museum. 
(1)  On March 5, 2003, a Voluntary Retirement Incentive Plan (the "Plan") for employees working for the Board of Art and Museum Commissioners at the Public Museum of Grand Rapids (the "Employees") was adopted by the Board of Art and Museum Commissioners of the City of Grand Rapids (the "Public Museum"), which provided that such employees who are members of the System, and who satisfy the requirements of Section 1 of the Plan and all of the following requirements, are eligible to receive the retirement incentive set forth in Subsection (2) below: 
(a)  The employee must be actively working for the Public Museum and have between twenty-six (26) and thirty (30) years of credited service as a member of the System as of June 30, 2003. Employees on leave at the time of the application or the time of the last scheduled day of work will not be eligible. Approved vacation leave or other leave approved by the Museum Director, however, will not disqualify an employee from participation. For purposes of this subsection, "years of credited service" does not include any months of credited service purchased under Section 1.202(6). 
(b)  The employee must be eligible for the thirty-year credited service retirement under Section 1.203 utilizing his or her years of credited service and the years of additional credited service up to a maximum of four (4) years granted to individuals who retire under this Section 1.209.5. For purposes of this subsection, "years of credited service" will include any months of credited service purchased under Subsection (1)(c), below. 
(c)  An employee with at least twenty-four (24) but less than twenty-six (26) years of credited service without counting any service purchased under Section 1.202(6), may purchase up to twenty-four (24) months of additional credited service, which will be counted as credited service toward the twenty-six-year minimum for eligibility for the Plan, for determining satisfaction of the thirty-year requirement of Section 1.203, and for determining the employee's Life Allowance under Section 1.205. An employee may not purchase months of credited service under this Subsection (1)(c) in excess of the amount needed to reach twenty-six (26) years of service. For purposes of this Subsection (1)(c), any months of service purchased will be in addition to any months of credited service previously purchased under Section 1.202(6). Such service must be purchased prior to June 30, 2003, at the actual cost as determined by the System's actuaries, using the same factors used to determine the cost for the Public Museum to purchase additional credit for the employee under Subsection (1)(b), above, and must be paid for in full by June 30, 2003, in accordance with Subsection (4), below. 
(d)  Employees who have signed and delivered the Retirement Election and Release Agreement to the Public Museum not later than 5:00 p.m. on March 14, 2003, will terminate employment with the City of Grand Rapids and the Public Museum on June 30, 2003, with a retirement date of July 1, 2003. The minimum thirty-day notification required by Section 1.203 will be waived if necessary to allow an employee to retire under this Section 1.209.5. 
(2)  Employees who retire after satisfying all of the requirements of Subsection (1), above, will be entitled to a Life Allowance payable under Section 1.205 (no age adjustment factor for early retirement), calculated using their credited service under Section 1.202 and up to four (4) additional years of credited service provided under Subsection (1)(b), above, and up to two (2) years provided in Subsection (1)(c), above; provided, however, that no employee retiring under this Section will be eligible to receive a Life Allowance payable under Section 1.205 that is greater than that which is based on years of credited service greater than thirty (30) years plus the amount of credited service purchased under Section 1.202(6). Employees retiring under this Section 1.209.5 will have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.206. 
(3)  The retirement incentive of up to four (4) additional years of credited service as set forth in Subsection (2), above, will not be provided to an eligible employee who, before June 30, 2003 date, quits, becomes eligible for disability retirement under the System, dies or otherwise is unwilling or unable to remain in the active employment at the Public Museum, or files for and receives unemployment compensation chargeable to the Public Museum's or the City of Grand Rapids' account. All costs for the present value of future benefits (PVFB) associated with the retirement incentive provided for in this Section 1.209.5 which are not paid by an employee, will be calculated by the System's actuaries and paid by the Public Museum to the General Retirement System, in full, on or before June 30, 2003. 
(4)  Payment to purchase the up to twenty-four (24) months of credited service provided for in Subsection (1)(c), above, must be made not later than 4:00 p.m. on June 30, 2003. The amount due will be determined under Subsection (1)(b), above, and paid by one (1) of the following methods: 
(a)  By a single lump sum payment of the total amount to the General Retirement System; or 
(b)  By a Trustee to Trustee transfer of the total amount to the System from an eligible retirement plan, ("eligible retirement plan") as defined in Section 1.212(6)(b). 
Any amount owing under this Subsection (4) that is unpaid at 4:00 p.m. on June 30, 2003 will be disregarded and will not be used in determining the employee's satisfaction of the requirements of Subsection (1), above, or the employee's eligibility to receive the retirement incentive set forth in Subsection (2), above. 
(Ord. No. 2003-16, § 1, 4-29-03)  
Sec. 1.209.6. - 2006 Voluntary Retirement Incentive—Grand Rapids Public Library. 
(1)  On May 30 th , 2006 a Voluntary Retirement Incentive Plan (the "Plan") for employees working for the Board of Library Commissioners at the Grand Rapids Public Library (the "Employees") was adopted by the Board of Library Commissioners of the City of Grand Rapids (the "Public Library"), which provided that such employees who are members of the Retirement system and who satisfy the requirements of Section 2 of the Plan and all of the following requirements, are eligible to receive the retirement incentive set forth in Subsection (2) below: 
(a)  The employee must be actively working for the Public Library and have at least twenty-eight (28) years of credited service as a member of the Retirement System by September 29, 2006 or be age sixty-two (62) or older as of May 30, 2006, with at least six (6) years of credited service. For purposes of this subsection, "years of credited service" does not include any months of credited service purchased under Section 1.202(6) of the Retirement Plan. 
(b)  The employee must be eligible for a normal age and service retirement under Section 1.203 utilizing his or her years of credited service and the two (2) years of additional credited service granted to individuals who retire under this Section 1.209.6. 
(c)  The employee must sign and deliver the Retirement Election and Release Agreement to the Library's Human Resources Department at the Main Downtown Library not later than 5:00 p.m. on September 29, 2006 and shall terminate employment with the City on or before December 31, 2006, with a retirement date the first day of the month following termination. The minimum thirty (30) day notification required by Section 1.203 shall be waived if necessary to allow an employee to retire under this Section. 
(2)  Employees who retire after satisfying all of the requirements of Subsection (1) above shall be entitled to a Life Allowance payable under Section 1.205 (no age adjustment factor for early retirement) calculated using their credited service under Section 1.202 and two (2) additional years of credited service provided hereunder; provided, however, that the provisions of Section 1.202(1) to the contrary not withstanding, no employee retiring under this Section shall be eligible to receive a Life Allowance payable under Section 1.205 that is greater than 100% of his or her final average salary. Employees retiring under this Section shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.206. 
(3)  The retirement incentive of two (2) additional years of credited service as set forth in Subsection (2) above shall not be provided to an eligible employee who, before his or her selected retirement date, quits, becomes eligible for disability retirement under the System, or dies or otherwise is unwilling or unable to remain in the active employment of the City at the Public Library, or files for and receives unemployment compensation chargeable to the City's account. All costs for the present value of future benefits (PVFB) associated with the retirement incentive provided for in this Section 1.209.6 will be calculated by the systems' actuaries and paid by the Public Library to the General Retirement System, in full, on or before December 31, 2006. 
(Ord. No. 2006-44, § 1, 6-27-06)  
Sec. 1.209.7. - 2006 Voluntary Retirement Incentive—Grand Rapids Public Museum. 
(1)  Any full-time employee of the G.R. Public Museum who is a member of the Retirement System with at least twenty-six and one-half years (26.5) of credited service without counting any service purchased under Section 1.202(6) herein, may purchase up to forty-two (42) months of additional credited service which will be counted as credited service for determining satisfaction of the thirty-year requirement of Section 1.203, and for determining the employee's Life Allowance under Section 1.205. An employee may not purchase months of credited service under this Subsection 1.209.7(1) in excess of the amount needed to reach thirty (30) years of credited service, not counting any years of credited service purchased under Section 1.202(6). 
(2)  Any employee who elects to purchase credited service under Section 1.209.7(1) above, must make said election, in writing, to the Office of the Executive Director of the General Retirement System on or before June 30, 2006 at 4:00 p.m. and shall pay for such credited service at the actual cost to the Retirement System as determined by the System's actuaries. 
(3)  The retirement incentive of up to forty-two (42) months of additional credited service as set forth in Subsection (1) above will not be provided to an eligible employee who, before June 30, 2006, quits, becomes eligible for disability retirement under the System, dies or is otherwise unwilling or unable to remain in the active employment at the Public Museum; or files for and receives unemployment compensation chargeable to the Public Museum's or the City of Grand Rapids' account.

(a)  By a single lump sum payment of the total amount to the General Retirement System; or

(c)  By an increased rate of contribution as approved by the Board of Trustees. 
Any amount owing under this Subsection (4) that is unpaid at 4:00 p.m. on July 31, 2006 will be disregarded and will not be used in determination of the employee's eligibility to receive a retirement benefit under Section 1.203. 
(Ord. No. 2006-45, § 1, 6-27-06)  
Sec. 1.210. - Termination Bonus. 
(1)  A termination bonus as herein provided shall be paid on behalf of a member only as provided in Section 1.211 herein, "Member dying while in employer service." 
(2)  The member's termination bonus shall be an amount determined in (d) below and based upon (a), (b) and (c) below; provided, the Board may defer payment of the amount for ninety (90) days: 
(a)  The member's contributions on deposit in the System at time of termination, exclusive of any interest credits thereon. 
(b)  Twenty-five (25) percent, plus seven and one-half (7½) percent for each whole year of his or her credited service in excess of ten (10) years, to a maximum total of one hundred (100) percent. 
(c)  A percent from the table following, based on the member's attained age last birthday at time of termination.

(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 75-3, 1-14-75; Ord. No. 89-17, § 1, 2-28-89; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.211. - Member Dying While in Employer Service. 
(1)  If a member dies while in employer service and before retirement there shall be paid a death benefit computed in the same manner as the termination bonus provided for in Section 1.210(2) to the same party receiving the deceased member's accumulated contributions, subject to the provisions of (2) of this Section. 
(2)  If a member dies while in employer service and before retirement but after becoming eligible to retire with an immediate allowance, and if the party designated as primary beneficiary to receive the member's accumulated contributions in the event of his or her death is one (1) person within the second-degree relationship, upon election of such person the member shall be presumed to have retired effective the date of his or her death and to have elected option B-100 provided for in Section 1.206 and to have nominated such person as beneficiary thereunder. If (i) the member's death occurs after December 31, 1996, (ii) the member was not represented by any collective bargaining unit or was represented by the Association of Public Administrators, the Grand Rapids Employees Independent Union or the 61st District Court Employee's Association, and (iii) the primary beneficiary is the surviving spouse, then the B-100 benefit amount will not be subject to an early retirement reduction as provided for in Section 1.208(2). Such allowance shall be in place of all other System benefits, and shall be subject to the provisions of Section 1.212(4). In the event the allowance provided for in this Section terminates before there has been paid an aggregate amount equal to the deceased member's accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund at the time of his or her death, the difference between such accumulated contributions and such aggregate amount of allowance payments shall be paid to such person as the member shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the Board. If there be no such designated person surviving at termination, such difference shall be paid to the member's estate. 
(3)  In the event a member has received benefits from the System and has not repaid in full amounts payable by him or her to the System, the benefit amounts otherwise provided by this Section shall be withheld, and used to effect repayment, until the total of such withholdings repays in full all amounts payable by him or her to the System. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2007-41, § 2, 7-10-07) 
Editor's note— Section 12 of Ord. No. 2007-41 provides for an effective date of July 1, 2007.  
Sec. 1.212. - Refund of Member's Accumulated Contributions. 
(1)  In the event a member ceases to be a member other than by death and he or she will not be paid an allowance or any other benefit by the System, he or she shall be paid, upon his or her written application filed with the Board, his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund. 
(2)  In the event a member dies, and no allowance becomes or will become payable by the System on account of his or her death, his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund at the time of his or her death shall be paid to such person or persons as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the Board. If there be no such designated person or persons surviving such member, such accumulated contributions shall be paid to his or her surviving spouse, or to his or her estate if there is no surviving spouse. 
(3)  In the event a member's membership in the System terminates, and no allowance becomes or will become payable on his or her account, any accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund unclaimed by such member or his or her legal representative within three (3) years from and after the date his or her membership terminated, shall be transferred to the income-expense fund. If thereafter proper application is made for such accumulated contributions, the Board shall pay them from the income-expense fund but without interest after the date payment was first due. 
(4)  Any member who terminates employer service resulting in an allowance payable by the System and whose accumulated contributions include contributions in excess of two (2%) percent of compensation for the period from January 1, 1956, through December 31, 1964, shall receive, or shall have paid on his or her behalf to his or her beneficiary, an additional lump sum payment equal to such excess, together with interest at the rate of three and one-half (3.5%) percent per annum, compounded annually. 
(5)  Effective January 1, 1993, a distributee of a member's accumulated contributions may elect to have any portion of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to an eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee in a direct rollover. 
(6)  Definitions relating to payments of member's accumulated contributions effective January 1, 1993: 
(a)  Eligible rollover distribution. An eligible rollover distribution is any distribution of all or any portion of the balance to the credit of the distributee, except that an eligible rollover distribution does not include: any distribution that is one of a series of substantially equal periodic payments (not less than annually) made for the life (or life expectancy) of the distributee or the joint lives (or joint life expectancies) of the distributee and the distributee's designated beneficiary, or for a specified period of ten years or more; any distribution to the extent such distribution is required under Code Section 401(a)(9) of the Code; and the portion of any distribution that is not includable in gross income. 
(b)  Eligible retirement plan. An eligible retirement plan is an individual retirement account described in Code Section 408(a), an individual retirement annuity described in Code Section 408(b), an annuity plan described in Code Section 403(a), a qualified trust described in Code Section 401(a), or a deferred compensation plan described in Code Section 457, that accepts the distributee's eligible rollover distribution. Effective January 1, 2002, in the case of an eligible rollover distribution to the surviving spouse, an eligible retirement plan is defined in the preceding sentence. 
(c)  Distributee. A distributee includes a member or former member. In addition, the member's or former member's surviving spouse and the member's or former member's spouse or former spouse who is the alternate payee under an eligible domestic relations order, as defined in Code Section 414(p) and MCL Section 38.1701, et. seq., are distributees with regard to the interest of the spouse or former spouse. A distributee shall also include a designated beneficiary (other than a surviving spouse) of a deceased member. 
(d)  Direct rollover. A direct rollover is a payment by the System to the eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee. 
(7)  Rules relating to payments of member's accumulated contributions effective January 1, 1993: 
(a)  Notice Requirement. No less than thirty (30) days and no more than ninety (90) days before a distribution (or as otherwise permitted or required by the Code or regulations promulgated thereunder), the Board shall provide the distributee with a written explanation of: 
(i)  The rules under which the distribution may be paid in a direct rollover to an eligible retirement plan; 
(ii)  The rules that require income tax withholding if the distribution is not paid in a direct rollover; 
(iii)  The rules under which the distributee may rollover the distribution within sixty (60) days of receipt; and 
(iv)  Any other applicable tax rules. 
However, if the distributee affirmatively elects to make or not make a direct rollover, and the distribution is either less than five thousand ($5,000.00) or is paid after the distributee attains age sixty-five (65), an immediate distribution shall not be deemed a violation of the thirty-day notice requirement. 
(b)  Limitations on Direct Rollovers. However, the distributee's right to elect a direct rollover is subject to the following: 
(i)  A distributee may elect a direct rollover of a portion of the distribution and elect to receive the remaining amount; 
(ii)  A distributee may not elect direct rollover to more than one eligible retirement plan; and 
(iii)  The distributee shall supply the Board with any information the Board reasonably requests in connection with the direct rollover. 
(c)  Income Tax Withholding. Mandatory income tax withholding shall apply to the portion of the eligible rollover distribution for which the distributee does not elect direct rollover. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 97-29, § 2, 6-24-97; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2002-50, § 4, 8-20-02; Ord. No. 2009-19, § 1, 4-14-09)  
Sec. 1.213. - Assignments Prohibited. 
(1)  The right of a person to an allowance, to the return of accumulated contributions, the allowance itself, any allowance option, and any other right accrued or accruing under the provisions of this Article, and all moneys belonging to the System shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of bankruptcy or insolvency laws, or any other process of law whatsoever, and shall be unassignable, except as is specifically provided in this Article; provided, that should a member be covered by a group insurance or prepayment plan participated in by the employer, and should he or she be permitted to, and elect to, continue such coverage as a retirant, the Board shall deduct from his or her allowance the payments required of him or her to continue coverage under such group insurance or prepayment plan, and to have deducted dues or membership fees, authorized to be paid to an association of retired municipal or public employees; provided further, that the employer shall have the right of set-off for any claim arising from embezzlement by or fraud of a member, retirant or beneficiary. Effective June 27, 1991 this provision will not apply to any "eligible domestic relations order" as described in (2), below. 
(2)  A domestic relations order is not an "eligible domestic relations order" unless it meets the requirements of Code Section 414(p)(1)(A)(i) and MCL Section 38.1701, et seq. Such order may award an alternate payee a share of the member's benefit. The order may provide that benefits are payable in any form permitted under the System and permitted by MCL Section 38.1704; provided, however, that the alternate payee may not elect a joint and survivor form of payment contingent on the life of any person except the member. If the alternate payee elects to have benefits commence at any time prior to the member's minimum service retirement date or in a form other than monthly payments for the life of the member, the benefit payable will be actuarially adjusted (based on the actuarial assumptions established pursuant to Section 1.192(3) to reflect payment at a different time and for a different form. The System will allocate to an alternate payee a pro rata share of the member's accumulated contributions as of the date of the award of accrued benefits. Such amount will be segregated for the benefit of the alternate payee and credited with regular interest thereafter. Said amount may be paid to alternate payee pursuant to Section 1.212 as if the alternate payee were the member, if appropriate. 
(3)  Whenever the System is served with a domestic relations order from a court of competent jurisdiction, the Board will follow the following procedure in determining whether the order constitutes an "eligible domestic relations order" that would be exempt from the general spendthrift protection of this Article: 
(a)  The Board will notify the member and any "alternate payees" named in the order that the order was served on the System and that objections concerning the order must be submitted in writing within fifteen (15) days; 
(b)  The Board will determine whether the order is an "eligible domestic relations order" as defined in this Section and notify the member and each alternate payee of its determination. If the Board determines that the order is an eligible domestic relations order, the Board will direct the custodian to make payment in accordance with the order except that payment will not be made until the member has attained the age and service requirements for early retirement benefits under Section 1.208; 
(c)  During the period in which the Board is determining the status of the order, payment of any benefits in dispute will be deferred and the amount of the disputed payments will be segregated in a separate account in the System. If the order is determined to be an eligible domestic relations order within eighteen (18) months after segregation of the benefits in dispute, the Board will direct the custodian to pay the segregated amount, plus investment credits, to the persons entitled to receive them in accordance with the order; 
(d)  If the Board determines that the order is not an eligible domestic relations order, or if the eighteen-month period described in (c) has expired and the qualification issue has not been resolved, the Board will direct the custodian to pay the segregated funds to the person or persons who would have received them if the order had not been served on the System. If the Board determines that the order is an eligible domestic relations order after expiration of the eighteen-month period, the order will be applied prospectively only; 
(e)  If the order is determined not to be an eligible domestic relations order, any amounts segregated pursuant to this procedure will be restored to the account of the member or distributed to the member if eligible for distribution; and 
(f)  The Board will notify the member and all other alternate payees named in the order of its decision concerning the eligible status of the order. Payments pursuant to the order will be made as soon as practicable after the status of the order has been determined or as soon as the amounts become payable pursuant to this System. 
(g)  In the event of any dispute as to the amount of benefits payable to the member or alternate payee, such dispute will be resolved in a manner consistent with the terms of MCL § 38.1702(e)(vi) which states that the domestic relations order does not require a plan to provide an increased benefit, determined on the basis of actuarial value. 
(4)  Benefits payable pursuant to an eligible domestic relations order will be made in accordance with the order and upon proper application by the alternate payee. Payment to the alternate payee may begin any time on or after the member's earliest retirement date regardless of whether the member actually terminates employment at that time if permitted in the Eligible Domestic Relations Order. If the payments begin before the member's termination of employment, the alternate payee will only be entitled to a benefit which is the actuarial equivalent of the alternate payee's share of the member's benefit that would be payable when the member reaches age sixty (60). If the member retires before age sixty (60), the System will recalculate the benefit payable to the alternate payee so that the recalculated benefit payable to the alternate payee plus the benefits previously paid to the alternate payee are the actuarial equivalent of the alternate payee's share of the benefit payable to the member. If the recalculated benefit is more than the benefit the alternate payee is receiving, the System will begin paying the recalculated benefit to the alternate payee effective the first day of the month immediately following the month in which the member retires. 
The System will make such actuarial adjustments to the benefits payable hereunder so that the actuarial value of the expected payments to alternate payee and member (assuming normal life expectancies) will be equal to the actuarial value of the member's benefit determined without regard to the eligible domestic relations order. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 78-29A, 4-25-78; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2010-47, § 1, 8-24-10)  
Sec. 1.214. - Benefit Program Before 1971. 
Any member terminating employer service before July 1, 1971, shall receive, or shall have paid on his or her behalf, benefits in accordance with the benefit program in effect at time of such termination. Any member terminating employer service after June 30, 1971, and before July 1, 1973, shall choose at time of termination between the benefit program in effect June 30, 1971, or the benefit program in effect July 1, 1971; or, if the termination is the member's death, such choice shall be made by the surviving primary beneficiary designated by him or her. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.215. - Accounting Funds of the System. 
All the assets of the System shall be held in four (4) funds, namely, the members' deposit fund, the employer accumulation fund, the benefit reserve fund, and the income-expense fund. 
Effective July 1, 1971, (i) each member's "refund value," as defined by provisions in force immediately before the July 1, 1971, amendment, shall be credited to his or her individual account in the members' deposit fund, and (ii) all assets of the System not so credited to the members' deposit fund shall be credited to the benefit reserve fund. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2007-41, § 3, 7-10-07) 
Editor's note— Section 12 of Ord. No. 2007-41 provides for an effective date of July 1, 2007. 
_____ 
Sec. 1.216. - Members' Deposit Fund; Member Contribution Rate. 
(1)  The members' deposit fund is hereby created. It shall be the fund in which shall be accumulated the contributions made by members to the System for annuities, and from which shall be made transfers and refunds of members' contributions as provided in this Article. 
(2)  The contributions of a member will be the applicable rate of compensation in the following table. Contributions shall begin following the date the member has completed six (6) months of credited service and shall continue through the end of the calendar year in which the member attains forty (40) years of credited service or until such time as the member has attained the number of years of credited service which, when multiplied by the applicable benefit multiplier as set forth in Section 1.205 equals the allowance cap as set forth in that section. The exception provided for in Section 1.202(1) applies to the aforementioned. 
Such contributions shall be made notwithstanding that the minimum salary or wages provided by law for any member shall thereby be changed. Each member shall be deemed to consent and agree to the deductions made and provided for herein. Payment of a member's compensation less such deductions shall be a full and complete discharge and acquittance of all claims and demands whatsoever for services rendered by the member to the employer except as to benefits provided by this system.

(3)  The officer or officers responsible for making up the payrolls for the employer shall cause the contributions provided for in this Section to be deducted from the compensation of each member in the employ of the employer, on each and every payroll, for each and every payroll period, after the date the member has been an employee as defined in Section 1.192(13) for six (6) months, through the end of the calendar year in which the member attains forty (40) years of credited service, but not thereafter, except as provided in Section 1.202(1). When deducted, each of said amounts shall be paid by the employer to the System; said payments to be made in such manner and form, and in such frequency, and shall be accompanied by such supporting data, as the Board shall from time to time prescribe. When paid to the System, each of said amounts shall be credited to the member's deposit fund account of the member from whose compensation said contributions were deducted. 
(4)  Upon the retirement of a member, or upon his or her death if an allowance becomes payable on account of his or her death, his or her accumulated contributions shall be transferred to the benefit reserve fund. 
(5)  The Employer shall pick up the member contributions required by this Section for all compensation earned after the effective date of this subsection. The contributions so picked up shall be treated as employer contributions in determining tax treatment under the United States Internal Revenue Code. The Employer shall pick up the member contributions from funds established and available in the salaries account, which funds would otherwise have been designated as member contributions and paid to the Retirement System. Member contributions picked up by the Employer pursuant to this subsection shall be treated for all other purposes of this and other laws of the Employer in the same manner and to the same extent as member contributions made prior to the effective date of this subsection. The member does not have the option of receiving the picked-up member contributions in cash instead of having it paid into the Retirement System. The effective date of the employer pick-up is January 1, 1990. 
(6)  Member contribution rates for the Crime Scene Technicians group shall be reduced by 1% during any period of time in which the employer makes no contribution to the System. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 77-61, 11-8-77; Ord. No. 88-31, §§ 8, 9, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 90-29, §§ 4—6, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 92-43, § 1, 7-14-92; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2005-29, §§ 5, 6, 5-17-05; Ord. No. 2007-41, §§ 4, 5, 7-10-07; Ord. No. 2010-46, § 3, 8-24-10; Ord. No. 2010-74, § 3, 12-21-10; Ord. No. 2011-11, § 2, 3-22-11; Ord. No. 2011-26, § 3, 7-12-11; Ord. No. 2011-62, § 3, 12-20-11; Ord. No. 2012-08, § 3, 1-24-12; Ord. No. 2014-54, § 3, 7-22-14)  
Sec. 1.217. - Employer Accumulation Fund. 
(1)  The employer accumulation fund is hereby created. It shall be the fund in which shall be accumulated the contributions made by the employer for pensions, and from which shall be made transfers, as provided in this Article. 
(2)  When paid to the System, the employer contributions provided for in (2) and (3) of Section 1.221 shall be credited to the employer accumulation fund account. 
(3)  When an allowance other than a special early allowance first becomes due and payable there shall be transferred to the benefit reserve fund from the employer accumulation fund the difference between: the reserve for such allowance; and the accumulated contributions, standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund at the time the allowance first becomes due and payable, of the member to whom or former member on whose behalf the allowance is payable. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2007-41, § 6, 7-10-07)  
Sec. 1.218. - Benefit Reserve Fund. 
The benefit reserve fund is hereby created. It shall be the fund into which shall be made transfers as provided in this Article and from which allowances shall be paid to retirants and beneficiaries. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2007-41, § 7, 7-10-07) 
Editor's note— Section 12 of Ord. No. 2007-41 provides for an effective date of July 1, 2007.  
Sec. 1.219. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2007-41, § 8, adopted July 10, 2007, effective as of July 1, 2007, repealed § 1.219 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to the Casualty Reserve Fund as enacted by Ord. No. 72-50, adopted June 27, 1972; as subsequently amended by Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, adopted Nov. 3, 1998.  
Sec. 1.220. - Income-Expense Fund. 
(1)  The income-expense fund is hereby created. It shall be the fund to which shall be credited all investment income from invested assets of the System, and in which shall be accumulated the contributions made by the employer for the administrative expenses of the System, and from which shall be made annual transfers of interest credits to the other funds of the System, and from which shall be paid all the expenses of the Board necessary for the administration and operation of the System. 
(2)  When paid to the System, the employer contributions provided for in (5) of Section 1.221 shall be credited to the income-expense fund. 
(3)  The Board may accept gifts and bequests, and they shall be credited to the income-expense fund, along with all other moneys received by the System the disposition of which is not specifically provided for in this Article. 
(4)  At the end of each System fiscal year the Board shall credit each member's individual account in the members' deposit fund with regular interest on the largest balance remaining in such account for the entire fiscal year (usually the beginning of the year balance). At the end of each System fiscal year, the Board shall credit to the employer accumulation fund assumed interest on the mean balance in such fund for the fiscal year, and similarly shall credit assumed interest to the benefit reserve fund. Such interest credits shall be transferred from the income-expense fund. 
(5)  Whenever the Board determines that the balance in the Income-expense Fund is more than sufficient to cover the current charges to the fund, the Board may by resolution provide for contingency reserves, or for the transfer of such excess or portions thereof to cover the needs of the other funds of the Retirement System. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2007-41, § 9, 7-10-07) 
Editor's note— Section 12 of Ord. No. 2007-41 provides for an effective date of July 1, 2007.  
Sec. 1.221. - Employer Contributions. 
1.  The employer's contributions to the System shall be the total of the contribution amounts provided for in (2) through (5) of this Section. 
2.  An employer's current service contributions shall be determined as follows; upon the basis of mortality and other tables of experience and assumed interest, the actuary shall annually compute the rate of contributions which, if paid annually by the employer during the prospective service of its members, will be sufficient to provide the pension reserves required at the time of their retirements to cover the prospective service portions of the pensions other than special early pensions to which they might be entitled or which might be payable on their behalf. The Board shall annually certify to the City Commission the amount of current service contribution so determined and the employer shall during its next ensuing fiscal year pay such amount to the System. Such payments shall be made in such manner and form and in such frequency and shall be accompanied by such supporting data as the Board shall from time to time determine. When received such payments shall be credited to the employer accumulation fund. 
3.  An employer's accrued service contributions shall be determined as follows: Upon the basis of mortality and other tables of experience and assumed interest, the actuary shall annually compute for the employer the pension reserves for the accrued service portions of the pensions other than special early pensions to be paid to or on behalf of members upon their retirements. The pension reserves so determined less the applicable balance in the employer accumulation fund shall be amortized over a period of years, as determined by the employer, to determine the employer's accrued service contribution. The Board shall annually certify to the City Commission the amount of accrued service contribution so determined, and the employer shall during its next ensuing fiscal year pay such amount to the System. Such payments shall be made in such manner and form and in such frequency and shall be accompanied by such supporting data as the Board shall from time to time determine. When received such payments shall be credited to the employer accumulation fund. 
4.  The employer's contributions for special early pensions shall be determined on a one year term basis. The Board shall annually certify to the City Commission the amount of contribution so ascertained for the employer and the employer shall during its next ensuing fiscal year pay such amount to the System. Such payments shall be made in such manner and form and in such frequency and shall be accompanied by such supporting data as the Board shall from time to time determine. When received such payments shall be credited to the benefit reserve fund. 
5.  The employer shall be responsible for the administrative expenses of the System and shall pay to the System to be credited to the income expense fund unless administrative expenses are paid from the investment income of the System. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2003-48, § 1, 11-18-03; Ord. No. 2007-41, § 10, 7-10-07) 
Editor's note— Section 12 of Ord. No. 2007-41 provides for an effective date of July 1, 2007.  
Sec. 1.222. - Investment of Assets. 
The Board shall be the Trustees of the funds of the System. The Board shall have full power to invest and reinvest the moneys of the System, and to hold, purchase, sell, assign, transfer or dispose of any of the securities and investments in which such moneys shall have been invested, as well as the proceeds of such investments and such moneys; provided, that such investment and reinvestment shall be subject to Act No. 314 of the Public Acts of 1965, as amended, and as the same may from time to time be amended. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.223. - No Trustee Shall Gain from Investments. 
Except as to the rights of a member or retirant or beneficiary, no Trustee and no officer or employee of the Board shall have any interest direct or indirect in the gains or profits of any investment made by the Board. Nor shall any of them directly or indirectly for himself or herself or as an agent in any manner engage in any sale, exchange or leasing of property with the System, the lending of money or extension of credit to or from the System, the furnishing of goods, services or facilities to or from the System, the transfer to or from or use by or for his or her benefit of the income or assets of the System or receive any consideration for his or her own personal account in connection with a transaction involving the income or assets of the System. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.224. - Limitation of Use of Assets. 
All assets of the System shall be held for the sole purpose of paying benefits and making disbursements in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance and shall be used for no other purpose whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2002-48, § 1, 8-20-02)  
Sec. 1.225. - Distribution of Assets if System Is Terminated. 
(1)  The employer hopes and expects to continue the System indefinitely but necessarily reserves the right to amend, modify, suspend or terminate the System in a manner compatible with any applicable collective bargaining agreement. 
No such action shall operate to recapture for the employer any contributions previously made under the System prior to the satisfaction of all liabilities for System benefits to members, nor, except to the extent necessary to meet the requirements of any other governmental Authority, to affect adversely the benefits of retirants and beneficiaries or the trust fund or insured fund then securing such benefits. 
(2)  If the System is terminated, the amount of the trust fund and/or insured fund then held by the System shall be allocated, subject to provisions for expenses of administration or liquidation, in the following manner for the exclusive benefit of the then retired and nonretired members (and their beneficiaries) having an interest in this System. Such assets shall be allocated to such persons in the following order of precedence: 
(a)  To provide for the payment to each nonretired member of an amount equal to his or her accumulated contributions; and 
(b)  If any assets remain after complete allocations for the purposes of (a) above, to provide for the continuance of allowances to retirants and beneficiaries, if any; 
(c)  If any assets remain after complete allocations for the purposes of (a) and (b) above, they shall be allocated toward the potential rights of nonretired members on an equitable and nondiscriminatory basis according to accepted actuarial principles; 
(d)  If any assets remain after satisfaction of all liabilities provided for in (a) and (b) and (c) above, any excess shall be delivered over and paid to the employer according to determinations made by the actuary. The above allocations shall be distributed by the System in annuities or in such other manner as may be determined by the Board. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2002-48, § 2, 8-20-02)  
Sec. 1.226. - Correction of Errors. 
Should any change or error in records result in any person receiving from the System more or less than he or she would have been entitled to receive had the records been correct, the Board shall correct such error, and as far as is practicable shall adjust the payment of the benefit in such manner that the actuarial equivalent of the benefit to which such person was correctly entitled shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.227. - Fraud Penalty. 
Any person who shall knowingly make any false statement or shall falsify or permit to be falsified any record or records in any attempt to defraud the System shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 72-50, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98)  
Sec. 1.228. - Section 415 Limits. 
(1)  Effective July 1, 2001, the maximum annual City funded benefit payable to any member under the System will not exceed the lesser of the following: 
(a)  $160,000 or, in plan years beginning after 2001, the maximum amount allowable under the adjustment provisions of IRC Section 415 effective July 1 of each year, or 
(b)  100% of the member's average compensation for the highest paid three (3) consecutive calendar years during which he was a member. 
The limitation of part (b) above, shall not apply in years beginning on or after January 1, 1995. 
For purposes of this Section, "compensation" means remuneration actually paid or made available to an Employee within the Limitation Year, as defined in Section 1.192(11) in accordance with Regulation 1.415(c)—2(a). 
If the member has less than ten (10) years of participation in the System at the time of termination of employment, the maximum dollar limitation of (1)(a), above, will be reduced by ten percent (10%) for each year of participation less than ten (10) (but the reduced amount will not be less than ten percent (10%) of such limitation). Notwithstanding the foregoing, the maximum benefit will not be reduced below the accrued benefit for the member as of the last day of the plan year beginning in 1986. 
The one hundred sixty thousand dollar ($160,000.00) limit will be reduced if benefit payments commence before age 62. The one hundred sixty thousand dollar ($160,000.00) limit will be increased if benefit payments commence after age 65. The reductions or increases in the one hundred sixty thousand dollar ($160,000.00) limit will be calculated so that the benefit payable at retirement will be the actuarial equivalent of the benefit payable at age 62 or 65, respectively. The actuarial adjustments will be based on the requirements of IRC Section 415, the actuarial table specified in Section 1.192(3) of this System, and interest at the rate specified for determining actuarial equivalence in Section 1.192(3). Effective for years beginning after December 31, 1994, the benefit reductions described in this paragraph and the preceding paragraph shall not apply to payments to a member in the form of a pension, annuity or similar allowance as a result of the member becoming disabled by reason of personal injuries or sickness, or to amounts received from this plan by the beneficiaries, survivors, or estate of a member as a result of the death of the member. 
If a member's benefit is paid in a form other than a life allowance for the member only, the optional benefit will be adjusted to the actuarially equivalent life allowance for the member only for the purpose of determining whether the City funded benefit exceeds the limitations set forth above. However, no adjustment is required for a benefit payable as a joint and survivor annuity (satisfying the requirements of a qualified joint and survivor annuity as described in IRC Section 417(b)) to the extent that the value of such annuity exceeds the value of a straight life annuity beginning on the same date. If the optional form of payment elected is a joint and survivor annuity (as described in IRC Section 417(b)), the member's City funded benefit will be reduced to reflect the payment in this optional form before the limitations of IRC Section 415 are applied. This paragraph shall apply to benefits commencing on or after January 1, 1996. 
(2)  For Plan years beginning before July 1, 2000, if any member in this System is also participating in a defined contribution plan maintained by the employer, the maximum annual benefit for the member under this System will be reduced for any plan year so that the sum of the "defined contribution fraction" and the "defined benefit fraction" for the member for the plan year does not exceed 1.0. For these purposes, the member contributions shall be annual additions used in determining the defined contribution fraction. These terms are defined as follows: 
(a)  The defined contribution fraction for any plan year means a fraction: 
(1)  the numerator of which is the sum as of the end of the plan year of the total additions for the member for each year of the member's participation in the defined contribution plan; and 
(2)  the denominator of which is the sum of the lesser of the following amounts for the year and each prior year of the member's employment with the employer, without regard to whether the System was in existence during the prior years: (i) 1.25 multiplied by thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) or the dollar limitation on additions in effect under Code Section 415(d) for each such year; or (ii) 1.40 multiplied by twenty-five (25) percent, or the percentage limitation on total additions under Code Section 415 for each such year, of the member's compensation for each such year. 
(b)  The defined benefit fraction for any plan year means a fraction: 
(1)  the numerator of which is the projected annual benefit of the member under this System, determined as of the end of the plan year; and 
(2)  the denominator of which is the lesser of the following: (i) 1.25 multiplied by ninety thousand dollars ($90,000.00) or the dollar limitation on benefits under Code Section 415 in effect for the plan year; or (ii) 1.40 multiplied by the member's average compensation during the three (3) consecutive calendar years in which the member was both an active member in the System and had the greatest compensation from the employer. 
For purposes of this Section, all defined benefit plans maintained by the employer will be considered as a single defined benefit plan and all defined contribution plans maintained by the employer will be considered as a single defined contribution plan. 
(3)  Effective for years beginning after December 31, 1997, the special rules of Code Section 415(n) regarding the purchase of permissive service credits shall apply to the return of prior payments under Section 1.202(4) and to the purchase of prior military service under Section 1.202(5) and to the purchase of additional service under 1.202(6). Not more than five (5) years of non-qualified service (as defined in Code Section 415(n)(3)(C)) may be taken into account for purposes of this paragraph. For employees who become members of the plan prior to July 1, 1999, the limitations of Code Section 415(c)(1) shall not be applied to reduce the amount of permissive service credit which may be purchased to an amount less than the amount which was allowed to be purchased under the terms of the plan as in effect on August 5, 1997. 
(4)  This Section, as amended, shall be effective July 1, 1989 unless a later effective date is specified. 
(Ord. No. 90-29, § 7, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 98-48, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 2002-50, § 5, 8-20-02; Ord. No. 2013-40, § 4, 8-27-13)  
Sec. 1.229. - Pension Benefit Options. 
(1)  Non-Represented Members. Effective September 5, 2010, each Non-Represented Member shall elect one of the following options. Election under this Section shall be irrevocable and must be made no later than September 3, 2010. Failure to elect an option shall result in the automatic election of Option (a) below. 
(a)  Maintaining a 2.7% multiplier for all credited service by agreeing to an increased contribution rate of 10.20%; or 
(b)  Selecting a reduced multiplier of 2.5% for all credited service accrued on or after September 5, 2010, by agreeing to an increased contribution rate of 8.95%; or
