Sec. 1.230. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 2. - POLICE AND FIRE RETIREMENT SYSTEM 
 
Sec. 1.231. - Retirement System Created. 
The City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System is hereby created and established. This Article may be cited as the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 1.232. - Effective Date of System and Amendments. 
The Pension System established by Ordinance 1150, effective June 4, 1945, and amended from time to time, was amended by action of the Grand Rapids City Commission to comply with TRA '86, OBRA '87, TAMRA '88, OBRA '89, UCA '92, OBRA '93, USERRA '94, URAA/GATT/RPA '94, SBJPA '96, TRA '97, RRA '98, CRTRA '00 and EGTRRA '01, and is hereby further amended and restated to comply with the Pension Protection Act of 2006. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 2013-39, § 1, 8-27-13)  
Sec. 1.233. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, as used in this Article, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Accrued benefit means the portion of an allowance earned as of the date of the computation. It is a monthly benefit commencing at the minimum service retirement age and computed in accordance with the life allowance formula in Section 1.246 using the member's final average salary and credited service at the time of the computation. 
(2)  Accumulated contributions means the total of all amounts deducted from the compensations of a member and standing to his or her credit in his or her individual account in the members' deposit fund, together with regular interest at the rate of three (3) percent per annum, compounded annually, from and after October 1, 1964. 
(3)  Actuarial equivalence means a benefit of equal reserve value. Present values will be determined by the actuary based on mortality tables and interest rates established from time to time by the Board. No change in mortality or interest assumptions shall reduce the accrued benefit of any member determined as of the date of the change. 
(4)  Allowance or life allowance means the total of the annuity and the pension. All allowances shall be paid not later than the last day of each calendar month. 
(a)  Allowance cap means the agreed upon limit to the product which results when a member's years of credited service are multiplied by the benefit multiplier applicable to the member at the time of retirement, expressed as a percentage. 
(5)  Annuity means a monthly amount derived from the accumulated contributions of a member and payable by the System throughout the life of a person or for a temporary period. 
(6)  Assumed interest means such rate or rates per annum, compounded annually, as the Board shall adopt from time to time. 
(7)  Beneficiary means any person who is receiving or designated by a member to receive a System benefit, except a retirant. 
(8)  Benefit program means a schedule of benefits or benefit formulas from which the amounts of System benefits can be determined. 
(9)  Board of Trustees or Board means the Board of Trustees of the System. 
(10)  Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
(11)  Compensation means remuneration actually paid or made available to an Employee within the Limitation Year, as defined in accordance with IRC Regulation 1.415(c)-2(a), and means all items of Employer remuneration for services, including: 
(a)  Wages, salaries, and other amounts received for personal services rendered in the course of employment with Employer, to the extent amounts are includible in gross income or would have been received and includible in gross income but for an election under Internal Revenue Code ("IRC") Section 125(a), 132(f)(4), 402(e)(3), 402(h)(1)(B), 402(k), 414(h)(2), or 457(b), and further include, but are not limited to, base salary, longevity pay, educational allowance, vacation pay, bonuses, fringe benefits, and reimbursements or other expense allowances under a nonaccountable plan, plus the additional compensation items as shown in Section 1.233(11)(f) below; 
(b)  Amounts described in IRC Sections 104(a)(3), 105(a), or 105(h) but only to the extent includible in gross income; 
(c)  Amounts paid or reimbursed by the Employer for Employee's moving expenses to the extent it is reasonable to believe, at payment, they are not deductible pursuant to IRC Section 217; 
(d)  Amounts includible in Employee's gross income upon a IRC Section 83(b) election; and 
(e)  Amounts includible in gross income pursuant to IRC Section 409A, or because they are constructively received. 
Compensation does not include items listed in Regulation 1.415(c)-2(c). 
Compensation for a Limitation Year shall not include Compensation in excess of IRC Section 401(a)(17) limits for such Limitation Year. 
In order to be taken into account for a Limitation Year, Compensation must be actually paid or made available to employees (or, if earlier, includible in the gross income of the Employee) within the Limitation Year. For this purpose, Compensation is treated as paid on a date if it is actually paid on that date or it would have been paid on that date but for an election under IRC Section 125, 132(f)(4), 401(k), 403(b), 408(k), 408(p)(2)(a)(i), or 457(b); provided, however, Compensation for a Plan Limitation Year includes amounts earned during that Plan Limitation Year but not paid during that Plan Limitation Year solely because of the timing of pay periods and pay dates if (i) these amounts are paid during the first few weeks of the next Plan Limitation Year; (ii) the amounts are included on a uniform and consistent basis with respect to all similarly situated employees and (iii) no Compensation is included in more than one Plan Limitation Year. 
In order to be taken into account for a Plan Limitation Year, Compensation must be paid or treated as paid to the Employee prior to the Employee's severance from employment with the Employer; provided Compensation paid by the later of 2½ months after severance from employment with the Employer or the end of the Limitation Year that includes the date of severance from employment with the Employer, is included if the payment is regular compensation for service during working hours or compensation for services outside regular working hours, commissions, bonuses or similar payments and it would have been paid prior to severance had Employee continued in employment. 
Compensation includes salary continuation payments to an individual who does not currently perform services for the Employer by reason of qualified military service (as that term is used in IRC Section 414(u)(1)) to the extent those payments do not exceed the amounts the individual would have received if the individual had continued to perform services for the Company rather than entering qualified military service. 
(f)  Police officers and police command officers: Effective July 1, 1992, overtime pay, compensatory time payoff, holiday pay, clothing allowance, acting assignment, witness fees and shift pay are also considered compensation for pension computation purposes. 
Firefighters: Effective July 1, 1992, holiday pay, clothing allowance, acting assignment pay, shop pay, and shift pay are considered compensation for pension computation purposes. 
In addition to the compensation listed above, overtime compensation for Firefighter members shall be calculated as follows for pension calculation purposes per Section 1.233(15)(b): 
Firefighter Retirement Date 	Calculation used in Section 1.233(15)(b) 
July 1, 1992—June 30, 1994 	Actual additional compensation items as noted above 
July 1, 1994—December 31, 2011 	Actual additional compensation items as noted above, plus 7.3% for overtime 
January 1, 2012—June 30, 2012 	The average of 4.2% for overtime for calendar years 2006—2009 and actual overtime for 2010 
July 1, 2012—June 30, 2013 	The average of 4.2% for overtime for calendar years 2007—2009 and actual overtime for 2010 and 2011 
July 1, 2013—June 30, 2014 	The average of 4.2% for overtime for calendar years 2008—2009 and actual overtime for 2010—2012 
July 1, 2014—June 30, 2015 	The average of 4.2% for overtime for calendar year 2009 and actual overtime for 2010—2013 
July 1, 2015 and after 	The average of actual overtime for all five years of the calculation required under Section 1.233(15)(b) 
 
(g)  For purposes of this Chapter, the definition of Compensation as applied to unionized Members shall apply to Non-Represented Members, being the Fire Chief, Deputy Fire Chief, Police Chief and Deputy Police Chief. 
(12)  Credited service means employment as an employee which employment is creditable as service hereunder, to the extent such service is standing to a member's credit as provided in this Article. 
(13)  Employer means the City of Grand Rapids, Michigan. 
(14)  Employee means any person regularly employed by the employer as a Police Chief, Deputy Police Chief, Police Officer, Fire Chief, Deputy Fire Chief or Firefighter. 
(15)  Final average salary of an employee means the sum of (a) and (b) below: 
(a)  The average of the employee's highest rates of salary, including longevity pay and vacation pay, during the three (3) consecutive calendar years of employment when such salary rates were highest, provided no such rates of salary occur in a calendar year after the calendar year in which the employee attains the number of years of credited service which, when multiplied by the applicable benefit multiplier as set forth in Section 1.246, equals the allowance cap as set forth in that section. Should a member have less than three (3) such salary rates, the salary rates during each of the member's calendar years of employment shall be averaged. For Firefighters retiring on or after January 1, 2012, a member may in their discretion include in the calculation of their final average salary the monetary equivalent of up to six (6) days of accrued vacation time when upon retirement, such cash payment in lieu of unused vacation is made. Effective January 9, 2019, Firefighters assigned to a forty-hour work week may convert additional vacation hours to equate to the same vacation accrual payment amount as fire members assigned to fire suppression at the same rank. The amount paid for such accrued vacation time shall be added to the salary rate earned during the calendar year in which such payment was made, which shall then be averaged as described in this paragraph. 
(b)  The average salary rate determined in (a) above, multiplied by the member's group FAS Adjustment Factor determined by dividing (i) the calendar year average of the group's Section 1.233(11) additional compensation items by (ACI), by (ii) the annualized average of the group's covered payroll from actuarial valuations as of December 31 of each calendar year, excluding ACI, for the five-year period immediately preceding the valuation. 
(c)  The calculation of Final Average Salary in this Section shall be applied to Non-Represented Members of the System, being the Fire Chief, Deputy Fire Chief, Police Chief and Deputy Police Chiefs. The calculation of the additional compensation items (ACI) for Non-Represented Members shall be based upon the ratio of the number of years served in a collective bargaining unit during which such ACI was earned, to total years of credited service. The compensation for the Non-Represented Members shall be excluded from the calculation of ACI. 
(16)  Firefighter means any regular or permanent employee of the Fire Department, including a probationary Firefighter. The term "Firefighter" shall not include: any volunteer Firefighter; any civilian employee of a Fire Department; any person temporarily employed as a Firefighter for an emergency; or any person privately employed as a Firefighter. 
(17)  Market Value means the quoted selling price plus accrued income on assets held in trust for the payment of benefits or, in the event the System acquires non-publicly traded assets, a price established by an independent professional appraiser chosen by the Board who is qualified to appraise assets of the subject property class. 
(18)  Member means any employee as defined in Section 1.233(14). 
(19)  Minimum Service Retirement Age and Normal Retirement Age shall mean age fifty-five (55) for Firefighter members of the System as defined in Section 1.233(16) and age fifty (50) for Police Officer members of the System as defined in Section 1.233(23). Provided, however, that from and after July 1, 2001, any Firefighter member of the System who has attained a number of years of credited service which, when multiplied by the applicable benefit multiplier for that member's covered group under Section 1.246, equals or exceeds the allowance cap for the member as set forth in said Section, shall be deemed to have achieved normal retirement age. Provided further, however, that for Firefighter members of the System as defined in Section 1.233(16) retiring between December 18, 2009 and December 31, 2009 inclusive, minimum service retirement age and normal retirement age shall mean age fifty-two (52). Further, any Member having been promoted to the position of Police Chief or Fire Chief and retiring on or after January 1, 2016 and on or before December 31, 2016 shall, upon achieving thirty (30) years of credited service, be deemed to have reached the minimum service retirement age. Provided however, that the Final Average Salary for any Member so retiring without reaching the minimum retirement age shall not include the overtime calculation provided in Section 1.233(11)(f). 
(19.1)  Non-Represented Member shall mean any member holding the position of Police Chief, Deputy Police Chief, or Fire Chief. 
(20)  Plan Year, Fiscal Year, and the Section 415 limitation year of this Retirement System is the twelve-month period ending December 31 of each year; provided, however, that for the time period ending December 31, 2003 the Plan year and Fiscal Year shall be from July 1, 2003 through December 31, 2003. 
(21)  Pension means a monthly amount derived from contributions of the employer and payable by the System throughout the life of a person or for a temporary period. 
(22)  Police Command Officer means any regular or permanent employee of the Police Department holding the rank of police lieutenant or police captain. 
(23)  Police Officer means any regular or permanent employee of the Police Department, including police command officers, probationary police officers and police cadets. The term "police officer" shall not include: any civilian employee of the Police Department; or any person temporarily employed as a police officer for an emergency; or any person privately employed as a police officer. 
(24)  Regular Interest means the rate of three (3) percent per annum, compounded annually. 
(25)  Reserve means the present value of all payments to be made on account of any System benefit based upon such reasonable tables of experience and assumed interest as the Board shall adopt from time to time in good faith. 
(26)  Retirant means a former member receiving a System allowance, by reason of having been a member. 
(27)  Retirement System or System means the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System. 
(28)  Valuation Assets means the value of the current plan assets recognized for the purpose of determining required contributions to the System. For purposes of determining the employer's contribution requirement for its fiscal year beginning July 1, 2004, valuation assets shall be equal to the market value of System assets as of December 31, 2003. For purposes of determining the employer contribution requirement for its fiscal year beginning July 1, 2005 through its fiscal year ending June 30, 2009 (valuation date December 31, 2007), valuation assets shall be determined using a market-related (smoothed) asset value method which recognizes projected investment income uniformly over a closed two (2) year period. For purpose of determining the employer's contribution requirements for its fiscal year beginning July 1, 2009 (valuation date December 31, 2008) and all subsequent fiscal years, valuation assets shall be determined using a market-related (smoothed) asset value method which recognizes twenty (20%) percent of the investment return in a fiscal year immediately, and twenty (20%) percent of the investment return in each of the next four (4) subsequent fiscal years. The remaining unrealized investment return from December 31, 2007 shall be recognized equally over the next four (4) fiscal years, beginning with the December 31, 2008 valuation. 
(29)  The masculine gender shall include the feminine gender, and words of the singular number with respect to persons shall include the plural number, and vice-versa. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 74-57, 7-16-74; Ord. No. 81-26, 4-7-81; Ord. No. 88-32, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 90-20, § 1, 2-20-90; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 95-64, §§ 1, 2, 11-7-95; Ord. No. 97-28, §1, 6-24-97; Ord. No. 97-37, § 1, 8-5-97; Ord. No. 2002-49, § 1, 8-20-02; Ord. No. 2002-52, §§ 1—4, 9-10-02; Ord. No. 2004-60, §§ 1—3, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 2009-31, § 1, 5-26-09; Ord. No. 2009-68, § 1, 12-15-09; Ord. No. 2010-49, § 1, 8-24-10; Ord. No. 2013-39, §§ 2—4, 8-27-13; Ord. No. 2015-70, §§ 1—4, 12-8-15; Ord. No. 2019-31, §§ 1—3, 7-23-19; Ord. No. 2019-35, § 1, 8-13-19)  
Sec. 1.234. - Board of Trustees—Appointment and Election. 
The general administration and responsibility for the proper operation of the System and for making effective the provisions of this Article are hereby vested in a Board of Trustees of seven (7) persons, as follows: 
(1)  Two (2) persons to be elected by the members of the System. Such Trustees are called member Trustees in this Article. One (1) member Trustee shall be elected by the Police Officer members and must be either a Police Officer member or a resident of the City of Grand Rapids. One (1) member Trustee shall be elected by the Firefighter members and must be either a Firefighter member or a resident of the City of Grand Rapids. The member Trustees shall be elected by the members of the Retirement System in accordance with such rules and regulations as the Board shall from time to time adopt to govern such elections. 
(2)  One (1) member of the City Commission to be appointed by the City Commission and to serve at the pleasure of the City Commission. Such Trustee is called "employer Trustee" in this Article. 
(3)  Four (4) persons, each of whom shall be experienced in financial matters and shall not be a member or retirant or beneficiary of the System, nor an employee or official of the employer. Such Trustees are called "Citizen Trustees" in this Article. One (1) Citizen Trustee shall be appointed by the Mayor. Two (2) Citizen Trustees shall be appointed by the City Commission. One (1) Citizen Trustee shall be appointed by the City Commission from a list of not less than four (4) eligible persons submitted jointly by the Police Officer members and the Firefighter members. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 85-66, § 1, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.235. - Board of Trustees—Terms. 
The terms of Citizen Trustees expiring in 1974, 1975 and 1976 are hereby extended until the succeeding first Monday in January. The Citizen Trustee appointed by the Mayor shall serve for a term expiring the first Monday in January 1978. The terms of Member Trustees due to expire in 1976 and 1977 are hereby extended until the succeeding first Monday in January. All terms of Member Trustees and Citizen Trustees hereafter appointed shall be for terms of four (4) years. Each Trustee shall continue to serve as Trustee until his or her successor is elected or appointed as the case may be and is qualified. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 74-74, 9-24-74)  
Sec. 1.236. - Board of Trustees—Vacancy, How Filled. 
In the event any Trustee fails to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the Board unless in each case excused for cause by the remaining Trustees attending such meeting or meetings, he or she shall be considered to have resigned from the Board and the Board shall by resolution declare his or her office of Trustee vacated. If a vacancy occurs in the office of Trustee, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired portion of the term so vacated in the same manner as the office was previously filled. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 1.237. - Officers and Employees of System—Executive Director, Actuary, Legal Advisor, Investment Counselor. 
(1)  The Board shall select from its own number a Chairman and a Vice-Chairman. 
(2)  Compensation: 
(a)  Member Trustees (Full-Time Employees of City) and Elected Officials: The Member Trustees who are full-time employees of employer and Elected Officials of the City serving on the Board shall serve without compensation for their services, as such, as their time is otherwise compensated for by the City. Such Trustees shall be reimbursed from the income-expense fund of the System for their necessary expenses incurred in attending meetings of the Board or in the performance of other duties authorized by the Board. Such reimbursement shall be in a manner and an amount as is reasonably determined by the Board to be appropriate. 
(b)  Other Trustees: The remaining Trustees of the Board shall be compensated at the rate of seventy-five ($75.00) per meeting, paid from the income-expense fund of the System, for those special and subcommittee meetings which are actually attended by such Trustee. In addition, such Trustees shall be reimbursed from the income-expense fund of the System for their necessary expenses incurred in attending meetings of the Board or in the performance of other duties authorized by the Board. Such reimbursement shall be in a manner and an amount as is reasonably determined by the Board to be appropriate. 
(3)  Executive Director and Clerical Staff. 
(a)  The Board shall have the authority to employ the service of an Executive Director for the System, to serve as the System's Chief Executive Officer. The Board shall adopt, and may amend, a job classification for the Executive Director, which shall define the duties and responsibilities of the position consistent with the provisions of this Article. 
(b)  The Board shall have the authority to employ the Executive Director upon terms and conditions that the Board determines are in the best interests of the administration of the System, and may enter into an employment agreement with the Executive Director for a period of not to exceed three (3) years, plus options to extend or renew. 
(c)  The Executive Director shall have the authority to employ such other professional and clerical services as may be required for the proper administration of the System on such terms and conditions as the Board may determine, and with the approval of the Board. 
(d)  The Executive Director and any clerical or professional staff employed by the System shall be eligible for participation in the group hospital, medical, dental and vision insurance programs otherwise offered to City employees, the General Pension Plan of the City, the deferred compensation plan, the retirement insurance provisions afforded to other City employees, Worker's Compensation coverage and the Medicare Supplement Plan of the City. The actual benefits provided to the Executive Director and any clerical employees of the System shall be determined by the Board. The actual cost of any and all such coverages provided shall be the responsibility of the System and reimbursed to the City on a quarterly basis. 
(4)  Administrative Costs. 
(a)  The Board shall have the authority to acquire, through lease or purchase, such office space as may be necessary for the proper administration of the System and may provide for such liability and casualty insurance as may be necessary to protect the property and assets of the System. Such office space shall be located within the corporate limits of the City of Grand Rapids and shall, to the extent required by law, be accessible to handicapped persons. 
(b)  The Board shall have the authority to acquire, through purchase or lease, such office supplies, equipment, furniture and furnishings as it determines to be reasonably necessary for the proper administration of the System. 
(c)  All reasonable expenses of the Board necessary for the operation of the System, including compensation of the persons engaged by the Board, shall be paid at such rates and in such amounts as the Board shall approve from the Income-Expense Fund of the System. 
(5)  System Actuary. The Board shall appoint an actuary to be the technical advisor to the Board and the Executive Director on matters regarding the operation of the System and who shall perform such other duties as may be required in connection therewith. The appointed actuary shall (i) be a Member of The American Academy of Actuaries, (ii) be either a Fellow or Associate of the Society of Actuaries or a Member of the Conference of Consulting Actuaries, and (iii) have a minimum of 5 years of experience in providing actuarial and consulting service to public employee retirement systems. 
(6)  Investment Counselors. The Board shall appoint a professional investment counsel or firm or firms of professional investment counselors to be investment advisors to the Board upon such terms and conditions as the Board may direct. 
(7)  Legal Advisor. The City Attorney shall serve as the legal advisor to the Board and the Executive Director on matters regarding the operation of the System. The Board shall be authorized to retain the services of an attorney or law firm to represent the Board in any matters in which the City Attorney has a professional conflict of interest or in other circumstances in which the Board and City Attorney determine such representation would better serve the interests of the System. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 90-34, § 1, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 91-67, § 1, 12-17-91; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94)  
Sec. 1.238. - Board Meetings—Quorum; Vote; Proceedings. 
The Board shall hold regular meetings, at least quarterly. Four (4) Trustees, of whom at least one (1) shall be a Member Trustee, shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the Board. Each Trustee shall be entitled to one (1) vote on each question before the Board and at least four (4) concurring votes shall be required for a decision by the Board at any meeting. The Board shall adopt its own rules of procedure, and shall keep a record of its proceedings. All meetings of the Board shall be held pursuant to the Open Meetings Act described in MCLA § 15.261 et seq., as amended. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94)  
Sec. 1.239. - Some Specific Board Administrative Duties. 
(1)  The Board shall from time to time adopt such reasonable mortality and other tables of experience, and a rate or rates of assumed interest, as shall be necessary for the actuarial requirements of the System. 
(2)  The Executive Director shall keep, or cause to be kept in convenient form, such data as shall be necessary for actuarial investigations of the experience of the System, and such data as shall be necessary for the annual actuarial valuations of the System. 
(3)  The Board shall annually, but not later than May 15 of each year, provide a report to the employer showing the financial condition of the System as of the preceding December 31. Such report shall contain, but not be limited to, a financial balance sheet, a statement of income and disbursements, a detailed statement of investments acquired and disposed of during the year, an actuarial balance sheet prepared by means of the last valuation of the System, and such other data as the Board shall deem necessary or desirable or as requested by the City Commission for a proper understanding of the condition of the System. 
(4)  All records of the System shall be kept and maintained by the Executive Director in space provided by the System. 
(5)  The employer shall provide the Executive Director with access to personnel and other records of the employer as may be reasonably required for the proper administration of the Retirement System. 
(6)  The Board shall have the authority to meet with and act in joint concert with the Board of Trustees of the City of Grand Rapids General Pension System on administrative matters of mutual concern to both Systems, including, but not limited to, the employment of an Executive Director, the establishment of administrative policy, the apportionment of administrative costs, the acquisition of office space, and the employment of actuaries or legal counsel. The City Commission shall have the authority to specify matters on which joint agreement of the General Pension System and the Police and Fire Pension System are required to avoid the unnecessary duplication of administrative expenses. These matters shall include, but not be limited to, the selection of the System Actuary, the selection of the Executive Director, the selection of the Auditor, and the acquisition of office space. 
(7)  The Board shall have the discretionary power and authority to determine the benefits payable to Members by the System. These powers and authority include the following: 
(a)  To interpret the terms and provisions of this Article as they relate to benefits payable; 
(b)  To decide all questions of eligibility for participation in the System; and 
(c)  To decide all questions of eligibility for benefit payments and determine the amount of benefit payments. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 87-4-1, § 1, 1-20-87; Ord. No. 91-67, § 2, 12-17-91; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 2004-60, § 4, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 1.240. - Claims Procedure. 
The Board will make all determinations concerning benefits. Any denial of benefits by the Board will be stated in writing by the Board and delivered or mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the member or beneficiary within sixty (60) days after the denial. The notice will set forth the reasons for the denial in language that may be understood by the member and will specify the System provisions upon which the denial was based. If the denial is based on the failure of the member or beneficiary to supply certain materials or information, the notice will so state. The notice will advise that the denial may be appealed to the Board and will include an explanation of the appeal procedure. 
The Board will adopt a procedure for reviewing appeals of denials of benefit claims. The procedure will include the following: 
(a)  The claimant or his duly authorized representative may initiate an appeal by written request for review delivered to the Board not later than sixty (60) days after receipt by the claimant of the notice of denial; 
(b)  The claimant or his duly authorized representative may review documents pertinent to the appeal and may submit written statements of issues and arguments relevant to the appeal to the Board; 
(c)  The Board will return its decision on the appeal not later than sixty (60) days after receipt of the request for review; and 
(d)  The claimant will be advised in writing of the decision on the appeal including the reasons for the decision in language that may be understood by the claimant with references to the System provisions upon which the decision is based. 
The determination of the Board in all matters under this Section will be final and binding on all parties. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94)  
Sec. 1.241. - Membership of System. 
(1)  The membership of the System shall include all persons who are employees on or after the effective date of the System. 
(2)  In any case of question as to the System membership status of any person, the Board shall have power to decide the question. 
(3)  Non-Member Hired to Non-Represented Position. 
(a)  Effective July 1, 2011, for any person hired to serve as the Police Chief or Deputy Police Chief, who upon their date of hire for such position is not a Member of the Retirement System as herein defined, such person shall be eligible for the Officer's Option Plan as provided in Article 3 of this Chapter, and shall be excluded from participation in the Police and Fire Retirement System. 
(b)  Effective April 25, 2017, for any person hired to serve as the Fire Chief or Deputy Fire Chief, who upon their date of hire for such position is not a Member of the Retirement System as herein defined, such person shall be eligible for the City of Grand Rapids Defined Contribution (CGRDC) Plan as provided in Article 8 of this Chapter, and shall be excluded from participation in the Police and Fire Retirement System and the Officer's Option Plan as provided in Article 3 of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 2015-70, § 7, 12-8-15; Ord. No. 2017-29, § 1, 4-25-17; Ord. No. 2019-31, § 4, 7-23-19)  
Sec. 1.242. - Membership Terminates; Reinstatement of Credited Service. 
(1)  When a member is no longer employed by the employer in a position covered by the System, he or she shall thereupon cease to be a member of the System. Except as otherwise provided in this Article, upon termination of membership, the member's credited service shall be forfeited. If such person is not a retirant and becomes reemployed by the employer in a position covered by the System, that person shall again become a member of the System. Should such reemployment occur within a period of four (4) years from and after the date that membership last terminated, the member's credited service last forfeited by that member shall be restored to the member's credit; provided, that the member returns to the System the amount, if any, received therefrom, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. A current employee whose participation in the plan was terminated due to attainment of age sixty (60) prior to January 1, 1988, has the option to be credited with service worked after the calendar month in which the employee attained age sixty (60), provided credited service does not exceed forty (40) years. The member shall be required to pay into the System an amount equal to that which would have been required during the time the service was performed, plus regular interest, in order to receive such credited service. 
(2)  Upon a member's retirement he or she shall thereupon cease to be a member and, except as otherwise provided in this Article, he or she shall not again become a member of the System. 
(3)  Allowance payments shall be suspended for any retirant who is employed by the employer for more than 700 hours in a calendar year. Allowance payments shall be suspended immediately upon attainment of seven hundred (700) hours worked and shall remain suspended for the duration of that calendar year that the retirant continues to work for the employer. Any such retirant so employed shall not become a member of the system or gain any credited service or other allowance enhancements as a result of time worked after retirement. The employer shall notify the Retirement Systems of the employment of a retirant and upon the completion of seven hundred (700) hours worked by that retirant. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 88-32, § 2, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 99-76, § 1, 12-21-99)  
Sec. 1.243. - Service Credit. 
(1)  A member shall be given credited service for the period from their employment commencement date to their employment termination date. No credit shall be given for any period of thirty (30) days or more in which the member does not make the required member contributions for service for eighty (80) or more hours. Service shall be computed in whole months with a remaining period of less than thirty (30) days counted as a whole month if member contributions were made for service for eighty (80) or more hours. If the period of service determined before application of the immediately preceding sentence results in a period of whole years and an additional fractional year of ten (10) months or more (without rounding), the fractional years of ten (10) months or more shall be treated as a whole year. The requirement that a member make the required member contributions as a condition of receiving service credit is waived for the first six (6) months of employment. The Board shall fix and determine the number of months and years of service to be credited to each member for employment as an employee in accordance with the terms of this ordinance. No member shall be credited with more than the years of credited service in the following table: 
Covered Group 	Date of Hire 	Credited Service Limit

or

	July 1, 2001 and after 	29 years - 7 months 
Police Command 	Prior to July 1, 2001 	37 years 
	July 1, 2001 and after 	29 years - 7 months 
Police Chief and Deputy Police Chief 	Any 	37 years

or

(2)  In the event a member, who while an employee, entered or enters the Armed Forces of the United States during any period of compulsory military service, such armed service actually required of him or her shall be credited him or her as service hereunder; provided, that he or she again becomes an employee within a period of ninety (90) days after he or she is relieved from military duty, and he or she returns to the System the amount, if any, he or she may have received therefrom at the time he or she entered or while in such armed service, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment, and in no case shall any member be credited with a total of more than six (6) years of such armed service. In any case of doubt as to the period of such armed service to be so credited a member, the Board shall have power to determine such period. To receive service credit for such required armed service, such member shall have the option to continue during his or her term of military service payments which would have been required of him or her under the System had he or she remained at work, or he or she shall have the option upon reinstatement to make up any such contributions which were not made during the period of his or her military duty. 
(3)  A member may deposit in the System the amount or amounts he or she may have received therefrom as a result of a prior termination of employment and not repaid thereto, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. In no case shall a member be given credit for service rendered prior to the date he or she received payments until he or she returns to the System all amounts due from him or her. Contributions to purchase service previously excluded under a mandatory retirement age provision shall be paid in the same manner and subject to the same conditions as the payment of amounts received and not repaid. 
(4)  Purchase of Credited Service. Except as otherwise permitted herein, a member may purchase additional periods of credited service, not exceeding two (2) years, by contributing an amount equal to 17.84 percent (.1784) of the member's annual rate of salary at the time of such purchase, including longevity pay and education allowance, multiplied by the number of years and fraction of a year of credited service being purchased. All purchases shall be in increments of one month. Any such periods of purchased credited service shall be recognized solely for the purpose of computing the member's life allowance as provided in Section 1.246. The purchase rate specified above shall be effective for purchases made between July 1, 1991 and June 30, 1994. For future periods the rate shall be the age and service cost component of the normal cost as determined by the System Actuary. Effective July 1, 1994 the System Actuary shall determine separate normal costs for Firefighters, Police Officers and Sergeants, and Police Command. Provided, however, that from and after December 20, 2011, Police Officers and Sergeants, and Police Command members, may purchase up to a total of four (4) years of credited service, subject to the provisions of this paragraph, and from and after January 10, 2012, Firefighter members may also purchase up to a total of four (4) years of credited service, subject to the provisions of this paragraph. In accordance with the IRS ruling issued to the Retirement System approving such purchase of service, the decision to purchase credited service is irrevocable. 
(5)  Payments made under Subsections (2), (3) and (4) above, shall be made (a) by a single cash deposit, (b) by an increased rate of member contributions, (c) by a Trustee to Trustee transfer to the System from an eligible retirement plan, ("eligible retirement plan" is defined in Section 1.254(5)(b) below), or (d) by a combination of an initial lump sum cash deposit and an increased rate of contributions as approved by the Board. The payments for any of these service purchases must be completed in a period of five years or less. Contributions which are made as a percentage of periodic pay may be considered as "picked up" by the employer as described in Section 1.258(6) or may be made on an after-tax basis, at the election of the member prior to the first such payment. This election is irrevocable. Subsequent to the election to purchase service, the member may not amend or revoke a pick-up election and may not make any direct payments for any service so purchased. The contribution or portion of the contribution which is paid in an initial cash deposit shall not be considered "picked up." In the event that a member terminates employment prior to completion of the payments over the period elected, the City will reduce the final payroll amount due the member attributable to reimbursement for unpaid vacation, sick leave or other extraordinary forms of compensation (accrued pay) by the lesser of the accrued pay amount or the amount remaining unpaid. Any amounts thereafter remaining unpaid may be paid to the retirement system on a lump-sum, after-tax basis within thirty (30) days of termination of employment. If any amount remains unpaid thirty (30) days after termination of employment, then the additional service purchase shall be reduced to reflect the number of months of additional service for which payments have not been received. 
(6)  In any case of question as to the service credit of any person, the Board shall have discretion to decide the question. 
(7)  Sick Leave Conversion. An employee with ten (10) or more years of continuous service may use accumulated and unused sick leave standing to the employee's credit at the time of retirement or resignation for the purpose of purchasing additional credited service which shall be recognized for the sole purpose of computing the members' life allowance as provided in Section 1.246, and not for determining eligibility for a benefit or for any other purpose. 
(a)  Police Officer members including the Police Chief and Deputy Police Chiefs may use accumulated sick leave to purchase up to a maximum of one (1) year of additional credited service by using one thousand two hundred sixty-five (1,265) hours of such sick leave for such purpose. 
(b)  Firefighter members including the Fire Chief and Deputy Fire Chief may use accumulated sick leave to purchase up to a maximum of one (1) year of additional credited service by using two thousand eighty (2,080) hours of such sick leave for such purpose. 
Any such additional credit service purchased with accumulated sick leave shall be subject to the overall credit service limitation applicable to the member under Section 1.243(1) herein. 
(8)  If a member of the General Retirement System left or leaves that system and such member later becomes a member of the Police and Fire Retirement System he or she shall be entitled to transfer all General Retirement System credited service, on a prorated basis, into the Police and Fire Retirement System under the provisions of this Section, subject to the following conditions: 
(a)  All accrued General Retirement System credited service time will be reduced by fifty percent (50%) and converted into Police and Fire Retirement System credited service. 
(b)  The former General Retirement System member, does not, or has not, withdrawn his or her accumulated contributions from the City of Grand Rapids General Retirement System and formally requests the transfer of such contributions into the Police and Fire Retirement System. 
(c)  A member who is eligible for transfer of credited service, as specified above, may only elect the transfer of such credited service in writing to the Police and Fire Retirement System Office during the period February 1, 2000 through June 30, 2000. 
(d)  The transfer of accumulated member contributions and credited service provided for in this Section revokes entitlement to any and all present or future benefits or provisions found in Title I, Chapter 7, Pension and Retirement Benefits, Article 1, General Pension System, of the Code of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 88-32, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 95-64, §§ 3, 4, 11-7-95; Ord. No. 98-49, § 1, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 99-20, §§ 1, 4, 4-13-99; Ord. No. 99-79, § 1, 12-21-99; Ord. No. 2000-02, § 1, 1-11-00; Ord. No. 2000-06, § 1, 2-8-00; Ord. No. 2002-49, § 2, 8-20-02; Ord. No. 2002-52, §§ 5, 6, 9-10-02; Ord. No. 2004-60, § 5, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 2009-68, § 2, 12-15-09; Ord. No. 2010-49, §§ 2, 3, 8-24-10; Ord. No. 2011-63, § 1, 12-20-11; Ord. No. 2013-39, §§ 5—7, 8-27-13; Ord. No. 2015-70, § 5, 12-8-15; Ord. No. 2019-31, §§ 5, 6, 7-23-19)  
Sec. 1.244. - Age and Service Retirement Eligibility. 
Any member in employer service may retire with a life allowance provided for in Section 1.246 upon his or her written application to the Board setting forth at what time not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days subsequent to the execution and filing thereof he or she desires to be retired; provided, that at the time so specified for his or her retirement the member shall have attained his or her minimum service retirement age and shall have ten (10) or more years of credited service in force, and notwithstanding that during such period of notification he or she may have separated from service. Provided further, however, that for Firefighter members of the System retiring between December 18, 2009 and December 31, 2009 inclusive, the requirement to provide thirty (30) days' notice prior to retirement shall be waived. He or she shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.247. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 2009-68, § 3, 12-15-09)  
Sec. 1.245. - Compulsory Retirement. 
There shall be no compulsory retirement. However, no member shall accrue any benefits exceeding those provided in Section 1.246, nor shall any member accrue benefits after the calendar year in which the member attains the number of years of credited service set forth in Section 1.243(1). Section 1.242(1) applies for restoration of service credit for members who attained age sixty (60) prior to January 1, 1988. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 88-32, § 4, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94)  
Sec. 1.246. - Life Allowance. 
Upon a member's retirement as provided in this Article, the member shall receive a life allowance equal to the applicable percent of final average salary in effect for the member at the time of employment termination (Benefit Multiplier), multiplied by the member's years of credited service to the nearest one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) year; provided, however, that no such life allowance shall be based upon a percentage of final average salary which exceeds the allowance cap for that member's covered group at the time of retirement as set forth below: 
_____

** Police Command members hired on or after December 20, 2011 will have a 2.0% multiplier for the first five (5) years of employment. Such members will have an option, between four (4) and five (5) years of employment, to irrevocably elect to increase their own benefit multiplier to 2.2%, 2.4%, 2.6% or 2.8%, for all future credited service after the first five (5) years. The incremental cost for a higher multiplier will be calculated by the System's actuary following each experience study, or at least every five (5) years, and shall be added to the member contributions required under Section 1.258(4)(c) for the remainder of the member's employment. If no election is made by such member prior to their five-year employment anniversary date, then all credited service shall be calculated using a 2.0% multiplier. If a Police Command member is promoted into the unit from the Police Officers and Sergeants unit and has already elected a higher multiplier, or defaulted to a 2.0% multiplier for all service, then that election or default shall be applicable for service earned while in the Command unit as well. 
Life allowances for those former members who terminated service with the employer prior to July 1, 2001 and elected to take a deferred retirement, are subject to and limited by the provisions of Section 1.250. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 80-26, 4-8-80; Ord. No. 81-26, 4-7-81; Ord. No. 81-49, 6-30-81; Ord. No. 83-42, 8-2-83; Ord. No. 83-62, 11-1-83; Ord. No. 86-50, §§ 1—3, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 88-32, § 5, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 95-64, § 5, 11-7-95; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 7, 9-10-02; Ord. No. 2009-68, § 4, 12-15-09; Ord. No. 2010-49, § 4, 8-24-10; Ord. No. 2013-39, § 8, 8-27-13; Ord. No. 2019-31, § 7, 7-23-19)
