Sec. 1.247. - Allowance Options. 
(1)  Under such rules and regulations and limitations as the Board shall adopt, before the date the first payment of his or her allowance becomes due but not thereafter, a person about to become a retirant may elect to receive an optional form of allowance in lieu of the single life annuity allowance otherwise payable to him or her as described in Section 1.246. The value of each such optional form of allowance shall be the actuarial equivalent of the value of the allowance otherwise payable to him or her. The optional forms of allowance made available by the Board shall be the forms following: 
(a)  Option B-100. Upon the death of a retirant who elected Option B-100, one hundred (100) percent of the reduced allowance to which the retirant would have been entitled had the retirant lived shall be paid to the retirant's surviving beneficiary for the lifetime of such surviving beneficiary. 
(b)  Option B-75. Upon the death of a retirant who elected Option B-75, seventy-five (75) percent of the retirant reduced allowance to which the retirant would have been entitled had the retirant lived shall be paid to the retirant's surviving beneficiary for the lifetime of such surviving beneficiary. 
(c)  Option B-50. Upon the death of a retirant who elected Option B-50, fifty (50) percent of the reduced allowance to which the retirant would have been entitled had the retirant lived shall be paid to the retirant's surviving beneficiary for the lifetime of such surviving beneficiary. 
(d)  Option B-25. Upon the death of a retirant who elected Option B-25, twenty-five (25) percent of the reduced allowance to which the retirant would have been entitled had the retirant lived shall be paid to the retirant's surviving beneficiary. 
(e)  Option B-100 Pop-Up. Same as Option B-100 with the added provision that if the designated beneficiary pre-deceases the retirant, the allowance shall be returned to the amount of the life allowance that would have been payable if no optional form of payment had been elected. Such change shall be made effective the month following the month in which the joint beneficiary died. 
(f)  Option B-75 Pop-Up. Same as Option B-75 with the added provision that if the designated beneficiary pre-deceases the retirant, the allowance shall be returned to the amount of the life allowance that would have been payable if no optional form of payment had been elected. Such change shall be made effective the month following the month in which the joint beneficiary died. 
(g)  Option B-50 Pop-Up. Same as Option B-50 with the added provision that if the designated beneficiary pre-deceases the retirant, the allowance shall be returned to the amount of the life allowance that would have been payable if no optional form of payment had been elected. Such change shall be made effective the month following the month in which the joint beneficiary died. 
(h)  Option B-25 Pop-Up. Same as Option B-25 with the added provision that if the designated beneficiary pre-deceases the retirant, the allowance shall be returned to the amount of the life allowance that would have been payable if no optional form of payment had been elected. Such change shall be made effective the month following the month in which the joint beneficiary died. 
(2)  Benefits payable under any provision of this System will commence not later than the later of the following: 
(a)  April 1 of the calendar year following the calendar year in which the member retires; or 
(b)  April 1 of the calendar year following the calendar year in which the member attains or would have attained age seventy and one-half (70½). 
Payments to beneficiaries other than surviving spouses will commence not later than one (1) year after the death of the member or former member. If death benefits are payable to anyone other than a surviving spouse or designated beneficiary, the entire death benefit must be paid within five (5) years after the death of the member. 
If payments have commenced to the member or former member prior to his death, then the remaining benefits will be paid to his beneficiary at least as rapidly as under the method of payment made to the member or former member as of the date of death. 
No distribution shall be made in a form or over a period longer than permitted in Code Section 401(a)(9) and regulations thereunder, including the incidental death benefit requirements contained therein. These limitations override any inconsistent distribution options. This subsection (2) is effective July 1, 1989. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 83-66, § 1, 11-8-83; Ord. No. 83-71, § 1, 12-6-83; Ord. No. 84-15, § 1, 3-13-84; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94)  
Sec. 1.248. - Terminal Benefit Covering Retirant. 
In the event a retirant dies before he or she has received in allowance payments an aggregate amount equal to his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund at the time of his or her retirement, the difference between such accumulated contributions and such aggregate amount of allowance payments received by him or her shall be paid to such person as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the Board. If there be no such designated person surviving such retirant such difference, if any, shall be paid to the retirant's estate. In no case shall any benefits be paid under this Section on account of the death of a retirant if any allowance becomes payable by the System on account of his or her death. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 1.249. - Early Retirement. 
(1)  Any member in employer service who has not attained his or her minimum service retirement age may retire with an early allowance provided for in (2) of this Section upon his or her written application to the Board setting forth at what time not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days subsequent to the execution and filing thereof he or she desires to be retired; provided, that at the time so specified for his or her retirement the member's age shall be within five (5) years of his or her minimum service retirement age and he or she shall have ten (10) or more years of credited service in force. He or she shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.247. 
(2)  Upon early retirement a member shall receive a percent of the allowance provided for in Section 1.246, in accordance with the following table of actuarial equivalent percents: 
Age Last Birthday 
at Time of 
Retirement 	Percent of Section 1.246 Allowance 
50 	  73.34% 
51 	 77.80 
52 	 82.65 
53 	 87.93 
54 	 93.70 
55 	100.00 
 
(3)  The above provisions of Section 1.249 shall apply only to Firefighter members of the System as defined in Section 1.233(16) and those Police Officer members similarly defined in Section 1.233(23) who terminated prior to July 1, 1989. Police Officer members terminated prior to that date who otherwise meet eligibility requirements for deferred retirement may elect in lieu thereof to receive early retirement. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 90-20, § 2, 2-20-90; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 98-49, § 2, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 99-20, § 4, 4-13-99; Ord. No. 2006-84, § 1, 12-19-06)  
Sec. 1.250. - Deferred Retirement. 
(1)  Should a member with ten (10) or more years of credited service cease to be a member, except by death or retirement, before attaining minimum service retirement age as defined in Section 1.233 and before being eligible for an early allowance as provided in Section 1.249, or being eligible, elects against receiving an early allowance, such member shall be entitled to the deferred allowance provided for in this Section; provided, that the member does not withdraw his or her accumulated contributions from the members deposit fund. Such deferred allowance shall commence as of the first day of the calendar month next following the later of the date of the members' attainment of age fifty (50) or the date written application therefor is received by the Board. The member shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.247 at the time of filing such written application. In the event of a member's death, Section 1.250(3) applies. 
For purposes of determining whether a member has ten (10) years of service for purposes of determining eligibility for benefits under this plan, prior or subsequent periods of service while a member of the General Pension System of the employer shall be considered. Such service shall not be considered for purposes of determining the amount of pension benefits hereunder. 
Members vested with ten (10) or more years of service who cease to be a member by virtue of accepting the Officers' Option Plan provided for in Section 1.283 of Chapter 7, Title I of the Code of the City of Grand Rapids, or elect the deferred option of this Section, are entitled to the provisions outlined above based only upon the life allowance of Section 1.246, and other conditions in effect at the time the member ceased being a member of the plan. Because the Officers' Option Plan is entered into in lieu of any and all pension benefits under the Police and Fire Retirement System, the enhancement of any pension benefits after the member ceased being a member is prohibited. 
(2)  The former member's deferred allowance shall be a life allowance provided for in Section 1.246. 
(3)  A former member, or person designated by that member as beneficiary, otherwise entitled to a deferred allowance shall be entitled to a deferred allowance if written application therefor is received by the Board from the member or beneficiary as described below not earlier than ninety (90) days before the member did or would have attained such age nor later than three (3) years from and after the date of the attainment of such age. In the event such former member does not so live, has not designated a beneficiary, or in the event such written application is not received by the Board within the time limits specified, no benefits whatsoever shall be paid except under the provisions of Section 1.254. For purposes of this Section, the beneficiary must be on file in the pension records and designated by the member as the primary beneficiary. In such case, it will be presumed that Option B-100 was elected. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 88-32, § 6, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 90-20, § 3, 2-20-90; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 98-49, § 3, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 99-20, § 2, 4-13-99)  
Sec. 1.250.1. - 2004 Voluntary Retirement Incentive—Police Officer Members. 
(1)  On March 16, 2004, a Voluntary Retirement Incentive Plan (the "Plan") was adopted by the Grand Rapids City Commission (the "City") which provided that employees who are Police Officer members of the System, other than elected and appointed officials, and who, in addition to satisfying the requirements of Section 2(B) of such "Plan" also satisfy all of the following requirements, are eligible to receive the retirement incentive set forth in subsection (2) below: 
(a)  The Police Officer member must be at least fifty (50) years of age by his or her selected date of retirement and eligible for normal age and service retirement under Section 1.244 utilizing his or her years of credited service and the up to two (2) years of additional credited service granted to individuals who retire under this Section. For purposes of this subsection, "years of credited service" does not include any months of credited service purchased under Section 1.243(4) or Section 1.243(7). 
(b)  The employee must be employed and actively working for the City or on an approved leave of absence on March 16, 2004. For purposes of this subsection, "actively employed" means that an employee is physically at work performing duties or is on an approved paid leave of absence (e.g. worker's compensation or FMLA leave) and does not include individuals who retired on or before March 16, 2004. 
(c)  The employee must sign and deliver the Retirement Election and Release Agreement to the City not later than 4:00 p.m. on April 30, 2004 and shall terminate employment with the City on or before June 30, 2004, with a retirement date the first day of the month following termination. Provided, however, any employee who, because of age, becomes eligible for this Plan after July 1, 2004 must indicate his or her election to retire under this Plan and must sign the Retirement Election and Release Agreement and deliver it to the City no later than 4:00 p.m. on April 30, 2004, such retirement to become effective the first day of the month after becoming eligible and prior to December 31, 2004. The minimum thirty (30) day notification required by Section 1.244 shall be waived if necessary to allow an employee to retire under this Section. 
(2)  Employees who retire after satisfying all of the requirements of subsection (1) above shall be entitled to a Life Allowance payable under Section 1.246, calculated using their credited service under Section 1.243 and the up to two (2) additional years of credited service provided hereunder, provided, however, that the provisions of Section 1.243(1) to the contrary not withstanding, no employee retiring under this Section shall be eligible to receive a Life Allowance payable under Section 1.246 that exceeds the allowance cap for that member's covered group at the time of retirement. Employees retiring under this Section shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.247. 
(3)  The retirement incentive of up to two (2) additional years of credited service as set forth in subsection (2) above shall not be provided to an eligible employee who, before his or her selected retirement date, quits, becomes eligible for disability retirement under the System, dies or otherwise is unwilling or unable to remain in the active employment of the City, or files for and receives unemployment compensation chargeable to the City's account. All costs associated with the retirement incentive provided for in subsection (2) above shall be funded in accordance with Section 1.263(1), (2), (3), (4) and (5). 
(Ord. No. 2004-17, § 1, 4-20-04)  
Sec. 1.250.2. - Key Employee Incentive Program (KEIP). 
(1)  Police officer members. Effective November 1, 2016, any eligible employee of the City of Grand Rapids Police Department who is a member of the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System may voluntarily elect to participate in the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System Key Employee Incentive Program ("KEIP"). The terms and conditions of the KEIP shall be those provisions adopted by collective bargaining agreement which shall be incorporated into this ordinance by reference. 
(2)  Firefighter members. Effective November 1, 2016, any eligible employee of the City of Grand Rapids Fire Department who is a member of the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System may voluntarily elect to participate in the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System Key Employee Incentive Program ("KEIP"). The terms and conditions of the KEIP shall be those provisions adopted by collective bargaining agreement which shall be incorporated into this ordinance by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2016-72, § 1, 11-1-16)  
Sec. 1.251. - Death of Member. 
(1)  If a member dies in employer service before retirement, the applicable benefits provided in (2), (3), (4) and (5) of this Section shall be paid, subject to (6) of this Section and to Section 1.253. 
(2)  His or her widow or widower shall receive an allowance computed in the same manner in all respects as if such member had (a) retired the day preceding the date of his or her death, not withstanding that he or she might not have attained his or her minimum service retirement age or acquired ten (10) years of credited service, (b) elected Option B-100 provided for in Section 1.247 and (c) nominated such widow or widower as joint beneficiary; provided, in no case shall the allowance payable to the widow or widower be less than twenty (20) percent of such member's final average salary. If the Board finds that the member's death occurred in the course of his or her performance of duty as an employee, the allowance payable to the widow or widower shall not be less than the difference between seventy-two (72) percent of the member's final average salary (sixty (60) percent of final average salary if the member was hired after June 30, 1992; provided, however, that from and after July 1, 2004, such sixty (60) percent limitation shall only apply to Police Command or Firefighter members hired after June 30, 1992) and any amounts payable to dependent children under 1.251(3) below. The preceding sentence of this paragraph will also apply if, in the determination of the City Commission, death occurs as the direct result of the performance of public safety type activities while off duty. 
(3)  His or her dependent child or dependent children shall each receive an allowance of fifteen (15) percent of such member's final average salary; provided, while there are four (4) or more such dependent children, each dependent child shall receive an allowance of an equal share of fifty (50) percent of such member's final average salary. A child shall be a dependent child until his or her death or his or her marriage or his or her attainment of age eighteen (18), whichever occurs first; provided, the age eighteen (18) maximum shall be extended as long as the child continues uninterruptedly being a full-time student at an accredited secondary school or college or university, but in no event beyond his or her attainment of age twenty-three (23); provided further, the age eighteen (18) maximum shall be extended for any child who has been deemed physically or mentally incompetent by a Michigan court of competent jurisdiction (or by the Board), for as long as such incompetency exists. Upon a child ceasing to be a dependent child, his or her allowance shall terminate, and there shall be a redetermination of the amounts payable to any remaining dependent children under this subsection or to a surviving widow or widower under Section 1.251(2). 
(4)  If, at the time of such member's death, there is neither a widow or widower nor a dependent child, each dependent parent shall receive an allowance of fifteen (15) percent of such member's final average salary; provided, the Board finds that such parent was dependent for at least fifty (50) percent of his or her financial support upon such member. 
(5)  In the event all the allowances provided for in this Section, payable on account of the death of a member, terminate before there has been paid an aggregate amount equal to his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund at the time of his or her retirement, the difference between such accumulated contributions and such aggregate amount of allowance payments shall be paid to such person as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the Board. If there be no such designated person surviving at termination, such difference shall be paid to the member's estate. 
(6)  In the event a member has received benefits from the System and has not repaid in full all amounts payable by him or her to the System, the allowance amounts otherwise provided by this Section shall be withheld, and used to effect repayment, until the total of such withholdings repays in full all amounts payable by him or her to the System. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 94-28, § 1, 7-12-94; Ord. No. 2004-60, § 6, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 1.252. - Disability Retirement. 
(1)  Non-duty related disability retirement. Any member in employer service with one (1) or more years of credited service who has not attained his or her minimum service retirement age and who becomes totally and permanently physically or mentally incapacitated for his or her duty as an employee, as the result of a personal injury or disease which the Board finds to have arisen other than in the course of his or her actual performance of duty as an employee, may be retired by the Board upon written application filed with the Board by or on behalf of the member; provided, that after a medical examination of such member made by or under the direction of a Medical Committee consisting of three (3) physicians, one (1) of whom shall be selected by the Board, one (1) by or on behalf of such member, and the third by the first two (2) physicians so named, the said Medical Committee reports to the Board, by majority opinion in writing, that such member is physically or mentally totally incapacitated for the further performance of duty, that such incapacity will probably be permanent, and that such member should be retired. 
(2)  (a)  Non-duty related disability allowance: Upon disability retirement as provided in (1) of this Section, a member shall receive an allowance provided for in Section 1.246, subject to the following minimum benefit provisions, and the vesting schedule provided in 1.252(2)(b): 
Covered Group 	Credited Service at Retirement 	Minimum Allowance 
Police Officers 	Less than 20 	48% of final average salary 
	20 or more 	60% of final average salary 
Police Command Officers 	Less than 20 	Based on service projected to the earlier of (i) the date the member would have completed 20 years of service if employment had continued, or (ii) the date the member would have attained 50 years of age. 
	20 or more 	Based on service projected to the earlier of (i) the date the member would have completed 25 years of service if employment had continued or (ii) the date the member would have attained 50 years of age. 
Firefighters 	Less than 20 	Based upon service projected to the earlier of (i) the date the member would have completed 20 years of service if employment had continued, or (ii) the date the member would have attained 55 years of age. 
	20 or more 	Based on service projected to the earlier of (i) the date the member would have completed 25 years of service if employment had continued or (ii) the date the member would have attained 55 years of age. 
 
The member shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.247. His or her disability allowance shall be subject to the provisions of (5) of this Section and to the provisions of Section 1.253. 
(b)  Non-duty related disability retirement vesting. Notwithstanding any provision of this Article to the contrary, any allowance paid to a Fire member hired on or after July 1, 2016 or any Police member of the Police and Fire Retirement System under this Section shall be subject to the following vesting schedule: 
Years of Service* 	Percentage of Allowance Provided in Section 1.252(2)(a) 
Less than 1 year 	No allowance 
1—5 	50% of allowance 
6 	60% of allowance 
7 	70% of allowance 
8 	80% of allowance 
9 	90% of allowance 
10 	100% of allowance 
 
*For purposes of this Section, Years of Service shall be based upon employment anniversary date, and shall not be rounded upward. 
(3)  Duty disability retirement: Any member in employer service who becomes totally and permanently physically or mentally incapacitated for his or her duty as an employee, as the natural and proximate result of a personal injury or disease which the Board finds to have arisen out of and in the course of his or her actual performance of duty as an employee, may be retired by the Board upon written application filed with the Board by or on behalf of the member; provided, that after a medical examination of such member made by or under the direction of a Medical Committee consisting of three (3) physicians, one (1) of whom shall be selected by the Board, one (1) by or on behalf of such member, and the third by the first two (2) physicians so named, the said Medical Committee reports to the Board, by majority opinion in writing, that such member is physically or mentally totally incapacitated for the further performance of duty, that such incapacity will probably be permanent, and that such member should be retired. 
(4)  Minimum allowance. Upon disability retirement as provided in (3) of this Section, a member shall receive an allowance provided for in Section 1.246; provided, that for Firefighters retiring after January 29, 2002, police officers and sergeants retiring after January 8, 2002, and police command members retiring after August 6, 2002, in no event shall such allowance be less than seventy-two (72) percent of final average salary. Any member retiring under (3) of this Section shall have the right to elect an option provided for in Section 1.247. The disability retirement and allowance shall be subject to the provisions of (5) of this Section and to the provisions of Section 1.253. 
(5)  (a)  Medical examination. At least once each year during the first five (5) years following a member's retirement on account of disability, and at least once in each three-year period thereafter, the Board may require any disability retirant who has not attained his or her minimum service retirement age to undergo a medical examination to be made by or under the direction of a physician designated by the Board. If such a retirant refuses to submit to such medical examination in any such period his or her disability allowance may be suspended by the Board until his or her withdrawal of such refusal. If such refusal continues for one (1) year all his or her rights in and to a disability allowance may be revoked by the Board. If, upon such medical examination of such retirant, such physician reports to the Board that the said retirant is physically and mentally able and capable of resuming his or her duty as an employee in the position held by him or her at the time of his or her disability retirement, then the Board shall arrange a further medical examination of such member made by or under the direction of a Medical Committee consisting of three (3) physicians, one (1) of whom shall be selected by the Board, one (1) by or on behalf of such member, and the third by the first two (2) physicians so named. Should the Medical Committee concur, by majority opinion in writing to the Board, in the finding that such disability retirant is capable of such resumption of duty, his or her disability retirement shall terminate and he or she shall be returned to duty. If the member fails to return to duty, his or her disability allowance may be suspended by the Board. If such refusal continues for one (1) year, all his or her rights to a disability allowance may be revoked by the Board. 
(b)  Return to duty. Upon a former disability retirant's return to duty as provided in this subsection, he or she shall immediately again become a member of the System, and his or her credited service at the time of his or her disability retirement shall be restored to his or her credit, and the amount of his or her accumulated contributions at the time of his or her disability retirement shall be restored to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund. If he or she was in receipt of a duty disability allowance provided for in (3) of this Section, he or she shall also be given service credit for the period he or she was in receipt of such duty disability allowance. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 74-57, 7-16-74; Ord. No. 90-20, § 4, 2-20-90; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 8, 9-10-02; Ord. No. 2016-56, § 1, 8-23-16; Ord. No. 2019-35, § 2, 8-13-19)  
Sec. 1.253. - Limit on Death Pension or Disability Pension. 
If a death allowance is payable under the provisions of Section 1.251, or if a disability allowance is payable under the provisions of Section 1.252, then in no event shall the total amount of such System allowances exceed ninety (90) percent of the amount of his or her annual rate of compensation at time of death or disability, as the case may be, less the total of the following amounts: 
(1)  Workmen's compensation, if any, on account of such death or disability. Payment of workmen's compensation on account of a disability or death shall not prohibit payment of any System allowance on account of the same disability or death, but shall reduce the amount of such allowance. If the member receives a lump sum settlement with respect to a workmen's compensation claim, the amount of the settlement which is not allocated to medical benefits shall be converted to an equivalent monthly amount on an annuitized basis using the actuarial assumptions described in Section 1.233(3). The resulting monthly amount shall be deducted from the disability benefit described in Section 1.252; 
(2)  Remuneration, if any, received by such retirant for personal services rendered by him or her in any gainful employment as a law enforcement officer or in any rank or position of Firefighter. Retirants who are employed by law enforcement agencies or fire departments shall provide certification of employment status and a description of duties performed, at least annually, in writing, to the Executive Director. The certification must be signed by the retirant's most senior ranking supervisor (i.e., Police Chief, Public Safety Chief, Fire Chief, etc.); 
(3)  Benefits, if any, from the Federal social security old age, survivors, and disability insurance program on account of such death or disability. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 86-49, § 1, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 2004-60, § 7, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 1.254. - Refund of Member's Accumulated Contributions. 
(1)  In the event a member ceases to be a member other than by death before the date he or she becomes entitled to retire with an allowance payable by the System he or she shall be paid, upon his or her written application filed with the Board, his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund. 
(2)  In the event a member dies, and no allowance becomes or will become payable by the System on account of his or her death, his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund at the time of his or her death shall be paid to such person or persons as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the Board. If there be no such designated person or persons surviving such member, such accumulated contributions shall be paid to his or her surviving spouse, or to his or her estate if there is no surviving spouse. 
(3)  In the event a member's membership in the System terminates, and no allowance becomes or will become payable on his or her account, any accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund unclaimed by such member or his or her legal representative within three (3) years from and after the date his or her membership terminated, shall be transferred to the income-expense fund. If thereafter proper application is made for such accumulated contributions, the Board shall pay them from the income-expense fund but without interest after the date payment was first due. 
(4)  Effective January 1, 1993, a distributee of a member's accumulated contributions may elect to have any portion of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to an eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee in a direct rollover. 
(5)  Definitions relating to payments of member's accumulated contributions: 
(a)  Eligible rollover distribution. An eligible rollover distribution is any distribution of all or any portion of the balance to the credit of the distributee, except that an eligible rollover distribution does not include: any distribution that is one (1) of a series of substantially equal periodic payments (not less than annually) made for the life (or life expectancy) of the distributee or the joint lives (or joint life expectancies) of the distributee and the distributee's designated beneficiary, or for a specified period of ten (10) years or more; any distribution to the extent such distribution is required under section 401(a)(9) of the Code; and the portion of any distribution that is not includable in gross income. 
(b)  Eligible retirement plan. An eligible retirement plan is an individual retirement account described in Code Section 408(a), an individual retirement annuity described in Code Section 408(b), an annuity plan described in Code Section 403(a), a qualified trust described in Code Section 401(a), or a deferred compensation plan described in Code Section 457, that accepts the distributee's eligible rollover distribution. Effective January 1, 2002, in the case of an eligible rollover distribution to the surviving spouse, an eligible retirement plan is defined in the preceding sentence. 
(c)  Distributee. A distributee includes a member or former member. In addition, the member's or former member's surviving spouse and the member's or former member's spouse or former spouse who is the alternate payee under an eligible domestic relations order, as defined in Code Section 414(p) and MCL Section 38.1701, et seq., are distributees with regard to the interest of the spouse or former spouse. A distributee shall also include a designated beneficiary (other than a surviving spouse) of a deceased member. 
(d)  Direct rollover. A direct rollover is a payment by the System to the eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee. 
(6)  Rules relating to payments of member's accumulated contributions: 
(a)  Notice Requirement. No less than thirty (30) days and no more than ninety (90) days before a distribution (or as otherwise permitted or required by the Code or regulations promulgated thereunder), the Board shall provide the distributee with a written explanation of: 
(i)  The rules under which the distribution may be paid in a direct rollover to an eligible retirement plan; 
(ii)  The rules that require income tax withholding if the distribution is not paid in a direct rollover; 
(iii)  The rules under which the distributee may rollover the distribution within sixty (60) days of receipt; and 
(iv)  Any other applicable tax rules. 
However, if the distributee affirmatively elects to make or not make a direct rollover, and the distribution is either less than five thousand ($5,000.00) or is paid after the distributee attains age sixty-five (65), an immediate distribution shall not be deemed a violation of the thirty-day notice requirement. 
(b)  Limitations on Direct Rollovers. However, the distributee's right to elect a direct rollover is subject to the following: 
(i)  A distributee may elect a direct rollover of a portion of the distribution and elect to receive the remaining amount; 
(ii)  A distributee may not elect direct rollover to more than one eligible retirement plan; and 
(iii)  The distributee shall supply the Board with any information the Board reasonably requests in connection with the direct rollover. 
(c)  Income Tax Withholding. Mandatory income tax withholding shall apply to the portion of the eligible rollover distribution for which the distributee does not elect direct rollover. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 2002-49, § 3, 8-20-02; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 1, 4-14-09) 
Editor's note— It should be noted that the provisions of Ord. No. 2009-18, adopted April 14, 2009, 2002, provides for an effective date of April 27, 2009.  
Sec. 1.255. - Assignments Prohibited. 
(1)  The right of a person to an allowance, to the return of accumulated contributions, the allowance itself, any allowance option, and any other right accrued or accruing under the provisions of this Article, and all moneys belonging to the System shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of bankruptcy or insolvency laws, or any other process of law whatsoever, and shall be unassignable, except as is specifically provided in this Article; provided, that should a member be covered by a group insurance or prepayment plan participated in by the employer, and should he or she be permitted to, and elect to, continue such coverage as a retirant, the Board shall deduct from his or her allowance the payments required of him or her to continue coverage under such group insurance or prepayment plan, and to have deducted dues or membership fees, authorized to be paid to an association of retired municipal or public employees; provided, further, that the employer shall have the right of set-off for any claim arising from embezzlement by or fraud of a member, retirant or beneficiary. Effective June 27, 1991 this provision will not apply to any "eligible domestic relations order" as described in paragraph (2), below. 
(2)  A domestic relations order is not an "eligible domestic relations order" unless it meets the requirements of Code Section 414(p)(1)(A)(i) and MCLA 38.1701, et seq. Such order may award an alternate payee a share of the member's benefit. The order may provide that benefits are payable in any form permitted under the Plan and permitted by MCL 38.1704; provided, however, that the alternate payee may not elect a joint and survivor form of payment contingent on the life of any person except the member. If the alternate payee elects to have benefits commence at any time prior to the member's minimum service retirement date or in a form other than monthly payments for the life of the member, the benefit payable shall be actuarially adjusted (based on the actuarial assumptions established pursuant to Section 1.233(3) to reflect payment at a different time and for a different form. The Plan shall allocate to an alternate payee a prorata share of the member's accumulated contributions as of the date of the award of accrued benefits. Such amount shall be segregated for the benefit of the alternate payee and credited with regular interest thereafter. Said amount may be paid to alternate payee pursuant to Section 1.254 as if the alternate payee were the member, if appropriate. 
(3)  Whenever the employer is served with a domestic relations order from a court of competent jurisdiction, the employer will follow the following procedure in determining whether the order constitutes an "eligible domestic relations order" that would be exempt from the general spendthrift protection of this Article: 
(a)  The employer will notify the member and any "alternate payees" named in the order that the order was served on the employer and that objections concerning the order must be submitted in writing within 15 days; 
(b)  The employer will determine whether the order is an "eligible domestic relations order" as defined in this Section and notify the member and each alternate payee of its determination. If the employer determines that the order is an eligible domestic relations order, the employer will direct the custodian to make payment in accordance with the order except that payment will not be made until the member has attained the age and service requirements for early retirement benefits under Section 1.249; 
(c)  During the period in which the employer is determining the status of the order, payment of any benefits in dispute will be deferred and the amount of the disputed payments will be segregated in a separate account in the System. If the order is determined to be an eligible domestic relations order within eighteen (18) months after segregation of the benefits in dispute, the employer will direct the custodian to pay the segregated amount, plus investment credits, to the persons entitled to receive them in accordance with the order; 
(d)  If the employer determines that the order is not an eligible domestic relations order, or if the eighteen-month period described in (c) has expired and the qualification issue has not been resolved, the employer will direct the custodian to pay the segregated funds to the person or persons who would have received them if the order had not been served on the employer. If the employer determines that the order is an eligible domestic relations order after expiration of the eighteen-month period, the order will be applied prospectively only; 
(e)  If the order is determined not to be an eligible domestic relations order, any amounts segregated pursuant to this procedure will be restored to the account of the member or distributed to the member if eligible for distribution; and 
(f)  The employer will notify the member and all other alternate payees named in the order of its decision concerning the eligible status of the order. Payments pursuant to the order will be made as soon as practicable after the status of the order has been determined or as soon as the amounts become payable pursuant to this System. 
(4)  Benefits payable pursuant to an eligible domestic relations order will be made in accordance with the order and upon proper application by the alternate payee. Payment to the alternate payee may begin anytime on or after the member's earliest retirement date regardless of whether the member actually terminates employment at that time. If the payments begin before the member's termination of employment, the alternate payee shall only be entitled to a benefit which is the actuarial equivalent of the alternate payee's share of the member's benefit that would be payable when the member reaches age sixty (60). If the member retires before age sixty (60), the Plan shall recalculate the benefit payable to the alternate payee so that the recalculated benefit payable to the alternate payee plus the benefits previously paid to the alternate payee are the actuarial equivalent of the alternate payee's share of the benefit payable to the member. If the recalculated benefit is more than the benefit the alternate payee is receiving, the System shall begin paying the recalculated benefit to the alternate payee effective the first day of the month immediately following the month in which the member retires. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 78-29A, 4-25-78; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 2010-47, § 2, 8-24-10)  
Sec. 1.256. - Benefit Program Before 1967. 
Any member terminating employment before November 1, 1967, shall receive, or shall have paid on his or her behalf, benefits in accordance with the benefit program in effect at time of such termination. For a member who retired between January 1, 1965, and November 1, 1967 this means that: 
(1)  Any supplemental benefit payable to him or her shall be payable to him or her for life but, if and when a primary benefit is payable to him or her, after attaining age sixty-five (65), under the provisions of the Federal social security old age, survivors, and disability insurance program (as amended and as it may be amended from time to time), resulting from any gainful employment by him or her, reduced by the amount of such primary benefit payable; for the purpose of computations hereunder "primary benefit payable" shall be the primary benefit unreduced for age or on account of earned income; and 
(2)  Any supplemental benefit payable to his or her widow or widower and/or children upon his or her death shall be payable to his or her widow or widower for life and/or to his or her children to attainment of age eighteen (18) but, if and when a widow's or widower's benefit and/or children's benefits are payable under the provisions of the Federal social security old age, survivors, and disability insurance program (as amended and as it may be amended from time to time), resulting from any gainful employment by him or her, reduced by the amount of any such widow's or widower's and/or children's benefits payable. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 1.257. - Accounting Funds of the System. 
All the assets of the System shall be held in four (4) funds, namely, the members' deposit fund, the employer accumulation fund, the benefit reserve fund, and the income-expense fund. 
Effective November 1, 1967, (i) each member's "refund value," as defined by provisions in force immediately before the November 1, 1967, amendment, shall be credited to his or her individual account in the members' deposit fund, and (ii) all assets of the System not so credited to the members' deposit fund shall be credited to the benefit reserve fund. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 2006-84, § 2, 12-19-06)  
Sec. 1.258. - Members' Deposit Fund; Member Contributions Rate. 
(1)  Members' Deposit Fund Established. The members' deposit fund is hereby created. It shall be the fund in which shall be accumulated the contributions made by members to the System for annuities, and from which shall be made transfers and refunds of members' contributions as provided in this Article. 
(2)  Contributions; Consent to Deduction. The contributions of a member shall be the applicable rate of compensation as defined in this Section. Each member shall be deemed to consent and agree to the deductions made and provided for herein. 
(3)  Payment of Contributions to the System. The officer or officers responsible for making up the payrolls for the employer shall cause the contributions provided for in this Section to be deducted from the compensation of each member for each and every payroll period following the date the member has completed six (6) months of credited service, and shall continue until such time as the member has attained the number of years of credited service which, when multiplied by the applicable benefit multiplier as set forth in Section 1.246, equals the allowance cap as set forth in that Section. When deducted, each of said amounts shall be paid by the employer to the System; said payments to be made in such manner and form, and in such frequency, and shall be accompanied by such supporting data, as the Board shall from time to time prescribe. When paid to the System, each of said amounts shall be credited to the members' deposit fund account of the member from whose compensation said contributions were deducted. 
(4)  Contribution Rates.

(6)  The employer shall pick up the member contributions required by this Section for all compensation earned after January 1, 1990. The contributions so picked up shall be treated as employer contributions in determining tax treatment under the United States Internal Revenue Code. The employer shall pick up the member contributions from funds established and available in the salaries account, which funds would otherwise have been designated as member contributions and paid to the Retirement System. Member contributions picked up by the employer pursuant to this subsection shall be treated for all other purposes of this and other laws of the employer in the same manner and to the same extent as member contributions made prior to January 1, 1990. The member does not have the option of receiving the picked-up member contributions in cash instead of having it paid into the Retirement System.
