Sec. 1.259. - Employer Accumulation Fund. 
(1)  The employer accumulation fund is hereby created. It shall be the fund in which shall be accumulated the contributions made by the employer for pensions, and from which shall be made transfers, as provided in this Article. 
(2)  When paid to the System, the employer contributions provided for in (2) and (3) of Section 1.263 shall be credited to the employer accumulation fund account. 
(3)  When an allowance first becomes due and payable there shall be transferred to the benefit reserve fund from the employer accumulation fund the difference between the reserve for such allowance and the accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the members' deposit fund at the time the allowance first becomes due and payable, of the member to whom or former member on whose behalf the allowance is payable. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 2006-84, §§ 4, 5, 12-19-06)  
Sec. 1.260. - Benefit Reserve Fund. 
The benefit reserve fund is hereby created. It shall be the fund into which shall be made transfers as provided in this Article and from which allowances shall be paid to retirants and beneficiaries. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 2006-84, § 6, 12-19-06)  
Sec. 1.261. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2006-84, § 7, adopted Dec. 19, 2006, repealed § 1.261 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to the Casualty Reserve Fund as enacted by Ord. No. 68-34, adopted May 21, 1968.  
Sec. 1.262. - Income-Expense Fund. 
(1)  The income-expense fund is hereby created. It shall be the fund to which shall be credited all investment income from invested assets of the System, and in which shall be accumulated the contributions made by the employer for the administrative expenses of the System, and from which shall be made annual transfers of interest credits to the other funds of the System, and from which shall be paid all the expenses of the Board necessary for the administration and operation of the System. 
(2)  When paid to the System, the employer contributions provided for in (5) of Section 1.263 shall be credited to the income-expense fund. 
(3)  The Board may accept gifts and bequests and they shall be credited to the income-expense fund, along with all other moneys received by the System the disposition of which is not specifically provided for in this Article. 
(4)  At the end of each System fiscal year the Board shall credit each member's individual account in the members' deposit fund with regular interest on the largest balance remaining in such account for the entire fiscal year. For the period from July 1, 2003 through December 31, 2003, the Board shall credit each member's individual account with one-half (½) of the regular interest on the largest balance remaining in such account for that entire time period. 
At the end of each System fiscal year, the Board shall credit to the employer accumulation fund assumed interest on the mean balance in such fund for the fiscal year, and similarly shall credit assumed interest to the benefit reserve fund. For the period from July 1, 2003 through December 31, 2003, the Board shall credit such funds at the rate of one-half (½) of the assumed rate of interest. All such interest credits shall be transferred from the income-expense fund. 
(5)  Whenever the Board determines that the balance in the income-expense fund is more than sufficient to cover the current charges to the fund, the Board may by resolution provide for contingency reserves, or for the transfer of such excess or portions thereof to cover the needs of the other funds of the Retirement System. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 2004-60, § 10, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 2006-84, § 8, 12-19-06)  
Sec. 1.263. - Employer Contributions. 
(1)  The financial objective of the Retirement System shall be to receive contributions each fiscal year which are sufficient to (i) fund the actuarial cost of benefits likely to be paid on account of service earned by members during the fiscal year (the current service contribution), and (ii) amortize the unfunded actuarial cost of benefits likely to be paid on account of service earned by members prior to the fiscal year, if any, over a period of years as established by the City. The rate calculated by the actuary shall be paid during the fiscal year beginning eighteen (18) months after the valuation date. Beginning January 1, 2013 the City's contribution rate shall in no event be lower than 3.0%. 
(2)  If valuation assets exceed actuarial accrued liabilities, the difference shall be the full funding credit. The contributions determined under Section 1.263(1) shall be reduced by an amount which will amortize the full funding credit, if any, over a period of years as established by the City. 
(3)  Notwithstanding the offset to current service contributions under Section 1.263(2) the City shall make a contribution in the amount determined in this paragraph. In the event the System has greater valuation assets than actuarial accrued liabilities, the City will pay its current service contribution during its fiscal year beginning eighteen (18) months after the valuation date, reduced by ten (10) percent for each one (1) percent, or portion thereof, that valuation assets exceed the actuarial accrued liabilities. 
(4)  Contribution requirements under Sections 1.263(1), (2) and (3) shall be determined by annual actuarial valuations using a generally recognized level percent of payroll actuarial cost method. 
(5)  The Board shall certify to the City Commission the amount of annual contribution needed to meet the financial objective and the City Commission shall appropriate and cause the contribution to be paid to the Retirement System. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 74-57, 7-16-74; Ord. No. 83-79, § 1, 12-20-83; Ord. No. 84-94, § 2, 12-18-84; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 98-49, § 4, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 99-20, § 4, 4-13-99; Ord. No. 2004-60, § 11, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 2013-39, § 12, 8-27-13; Ord. No. 2019-24, § 1, 6-11-19)  
Sec. 1.264. - Social Security Provision. 
Should police officers or Firefighters of the employer, or both groups, become covered by the Federal social security old age, survivors, and disability insurance program, the benefit program then in effect shall be amended so that the total of the employer contributions to support the benefit program so amended and the employer contributions to such Federal program will not be more than the employer contributions to support the benefit program in effect immediately before such Federal social security coverage. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 1.265. - Investment of Assets. 
The Board shall be the Trustees of the funds of the System. The Board shall have full power to invest and reinvest the moneys of the System, and to hold, purchase, sell, assign, transfer or dispose of any of the securities and investments in which such moneys shall have been invested, as well as the proceeds of such investments and such moneys; provided, that such investment and reinvestment shall be subject to Act No. 314 of the Public Acts of 1965, as amended and as the same may from time to time be amended. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 1.266. - No Trustee Shall Gain from Investments. 
Except as to the rights of a member or retirant or beneficiary, no Trustee and no officer or employee of the Board shall have any interest direct or indirect in the gains or profits of any investment made by the Board. Nor shall any of them directly or indirectly for himself or herself or as an agent in any manner engage in any sale, exchange or leasing of property with the System, the lending of money or extension of credit to or from the System, the furnishing of goods, services or facilities to or from the System, the transfer to or from or use by or for his or her benefit of the income or assets of the System or receive any consideration for his or her own personal account in connection with a transaction involving the income or assets of the System. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94)  
Sec. 1.267. - Limitation of Use of Assets. 
(1)  All assets of the System shall be held for the sole purpose of paying benefits and making disbursements in accordance with the provisions of this Article and shall be used for no other purpose whatsoever. 
(2)  The Board shall not cause the System to (1) lend any part of its income or corpus to the City without the receipt of adequate security and a reasonable rate of interest, (2) pay any compensation to the City, in excess of a reasonable allowance for salaries or other compensation for personal services actually rendered, to the City, (3) make any part of its services available on a preferential basis to the City, (4) make any substantial purchase of securities or any other property for more than adequate consideration in money or money's worth from the City, (5) sell any substantial part of its securities or other property to the City for less than adequate consideration in money or money's worth or (6) engage in any other transaction with the City which results in a substantial diversion of its income or corpus to the City. Nothing in this Section shall require the Board to loan assets of the System to the City or to engage in any other transaction referred to in this Section. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94)  
Sec. 1.268. - Distribution of Assets if System is Terminated. 
(1)  The employer hopes and expects to continue the System indefinitely but necessarily reserves the right to amend, modify, suspend or terminate the System in a manner compatible with any applicable collective bargaining agreement. 
No such action shall operate to recapture for the employer any contributions previously made under the System prior to the satisfaction of all liabilities for System benefits to members, nor, except to the extent necessary to meet the requirements of any governmental authority, to affect adversely the benefits of retirants and beneficiaries or the trust fund or insured fund then securing such benefits. 
(2)  If the System is terminated, the amount of the trust fund and/or insured fund then held by the System shall be allocated, subject to provisions for expenses of administration or liquidation, in the following manner for the exclusive benefit of the then retired and nonretired members (and their beneficiaries) having an interest in this System. Such assets shall be allocated to such persons in the following order of precedence: 
(a)  To provide for the payment of each nonretired member of an amount equal to his or her accumulated contributions; and 
(b)  If any assets remain after complete allocations for the purposes of (a) above, to provide for the continuance of allowances to retirants and beneficiaries, if any; 
(c)  If any assets remain after complete allocations for the purposes of (a) and (b) above, they shall be allocated toward the potential rights of nonretired members on an equitable and nondiscriminatory basis according to accepted actuarial principles; 
(d)  If any assets remain after satisfaction of all liabilities provided for in (a) and (b) and (c) above, any excess shall be delivered over and paid to the employer according to determinations made by the actuary. 
The above allocations to System participants shall be distributed by the System in annuities or in such other manner as may be determined by the Board. Payment of all other assets shall be made as determined by the City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94)  
Sec. 1.269. - Correction of Errors. 
Should any change or error in records result in any person receiving from the System more or less than he or she would have been entitled to receive had the records been correct, the Board shall correct such error, and as far as is practicable shall adjust the payment of the benefit in such manner that the actuarial equivalent of the benefit to which such person was correctly entitled shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94)  
Sec. 1.270. - Fraud Penalty. 
Any person who shall knowingly make any false statement or shall falsify or permit to be falsified any record or records in any attempt to defraud the System shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 68-34, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 1.271. - Section 415 Limits. 
(1)  Effective July 1, 2001, the maximum annual City funded benefit payable to any member under the System will not exceed the lesser of the following: 
(a)  $160,000 or, in plan years beginning after 2001, the maximum amount allowable under the adjustment provisions of IRC Section 415 effective July 1 of each year, or 
(b)  100% of the member's average compensation for the highest paid three (3) consecutive calendar years during which he was a member. 
The limitation of part (b) above, shall not apply in years beginning on or after January 1, 1995. 
For purposes of this Section, "compensation" means remuneration actually paid or made available to an Employee within the Limitation Year, as defined in Section 1.233(11) in accordance with Regulation 1.415(c)-2(a). 
If the member has less than ten (10) years of participation in the System at the time of termination of employment, the maximum dollar limitation of (1)(a), above, will be reduced by ten percent (10%) for each year of participation less than ten (10) (but the reduced amount will not be less than ten percent (10%) of such limitation). Notwithstanding the foregoing, the maximum benefit will not be reduced below the accrued benefit for the member as of the last day of the plan year beginning in 1986. 
The one hundred sixty thousand dollar ($160,000.00) limit will be reduced if benefit payments commence before age 62. The one hundred sixty thousand dollar ($160,000.00) limit will be increased if benefit payments commence after age 65. The reductions or increases in the one hundred sixty thousand dollar ($160,000.00) limit will be calculated so that the benefit payable at retirement will be the actuarial equivalent of the benefit payable at age 62 or 65, respectively. The actuarial adjustments will be based on the requirements of IRC Section 415, the actuarial table specified in Section 1.233(3) of this System, and interest at the rate specified for determining actuarial equivalence in Section 1.233(3). The reduction under this paragraph shall not reduce the dollar limitation of (1)(a), above, to an amount less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for qualified Police Officers and Firefighters. A qualified police officer or firefighter is a member who has earned fifteen (15) or more years of credited service while serving the employer on a full-time basis in the capacity of a Firefighter, Police Officer or Emergency Medical Service employee or as a member of the Armed Forces of the United States. The fifty thousand dollar ($50,000.00) amount shall be adjusted under the provisions of IRC Section 415(d) effective July 1 of each year. The benefit reductions described in this paragraph will not apply to qualified police officers or firefighters in years beginning after December 31, 1996. Effective for years beginning after December 31, 1994, the benefit reductions described in this paragraph and the preceding paragraph shall not apply to payments to a member in the form of a pension, annuity or similar allowance as a result of the member becoming disabled by reason of personal injuries or sickness, or to amounts received from this plan by the beneficiaries, survivors, or estate of a member as a result of the death of the member. 
If a member's benefit is paid in a form other than a life allowance for the member only, the optional benefit will be adjusted to the actuarially equivalent life allowance for the member only for the purpose of determining whether the City funded benefit exceeds the limitations set forth above. However, no adjustment is required for a benefit payable as a joint and survivor annuity satisfying the requirements of a qualified joint and survivor annuity as described in IRC Section 417(b) to the extent that the value of such annuity exceeds the value of a straight life annuity beginning on the same date. If the optional form of payment elected is a joint and survivor annuity (as described in IRC Section 417(b)), the member's City funded benefit will be reduced to reflect the payment in this optional form before the limitations of IRC Section 415 are applied. This paragraph shall apply to benefits commencing on or after January 1, 1996. 
(2)  For Plan years beginning before July 1, 2000, if any member in this System is also participating in a defined contribution plan maintained by the employer, the maximum annual benefit for the member under this System will be reduced for any plan year so that the sum of the "defined contribution fraction" and the "defined benefit fraction" for the member for the plan year does not exceed 1.0. For these purposes, the member contributions will be annual additions used in determining the defined contribution fraction. These terms are defined as follows: 
(a)  The defined contribution fraction for any plan year means a fraction: 
(1)  The numerator of which is the sum as of the end of the plan year of the total additions for the member for each year of the member's participation in the defined contribution plan; and 
(2)  The denominator of which is the sum of the lesser of the following amounts for the year and each prior year of the member's employment with the employer, without regard to whether the System was in existence during the prior years: (i) 1.25 multiplied by thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) or the dollar limitation on additions in effect under Code Section 415(d) for each such year; or (ii) 1.40 multiplied by twenty-five (25) percent, or the percentage limitation on total additions under Code Section 415 for each such year, of the member's compensation for each such year. 
(b)  The defined benefit fraction for any plan year means a fraction: 
(1)  The numerator of which is the projected annual benefit of the member under this System, determined as of the end of the plan year; and 
(2)  The denominator of which is the lesser of the following: (i) 1.25 multiplied by ninety thousand dollars ($90,000.00) or the dollar limitation on benefits under Code Section 415 in effect for the plan year; or (ii) 1.40 multiplied by the member's average compensation during the three (3) consecutive calendar years in which the member was both an active member in the System and had the greatest compensation from the employer. 
For purposes of this Section, all defined benefit plans maintained by the employer will be considered as a single defined benefit plan and all defined contribution plans maintained by the employer will be considered as a single defined contribution plan. 
(3)  Effective for years beginning after December 31, 1997, the special rules of Code Section 415(n) regarding the purchase of permissive service credits will apply to the return of prior payments under Section 1.243(3) and to the purchase of additional service under 1.243(4). Not more than five (5) years of non-qualified service (as defined in Code Section 415(n)(3)(C)) may be taken into account for purposes of this paragraph. For employees who become members of the plan prior to July 1, 1999, the limitations of Code Section 415(c)(1) will not be applied to reduce the amount of permissive service credit which may be purchased to an amount less than the amount which was allowed to be purchased under the terms of the plan as in effect on August 5, 1997. 
(4)  This Section, as amended, will be effective July 1, 1989 unless a later effective date is specified. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 7, 2-20-90; Ord. No. 94-12, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 98-49, § 5, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 99-20, § 3, 4-13-99; Ord. No. 2002-49, § 4, 8-20-02; Ord. No. 2013-39, § 13, 8-27-13)  
Secs. 1.272—1.282. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 3. - OFFICER'S OPTION PLAN 
 
Sec. 1.283. - Officer's Option. 
(a)  At the individual option of a City Officer, as defined in Section 1.284(a), the City, in lieu of any and all benefits under the General Retirement System or the Police and Fire Retirement System, will contribute a percentage of the officer's annual compensation to a retirement program with the International City Management Association Retirement Corporation in the following amounts: 
For City Officers hired before July 1, 2011: 
Date of Payment 	Employer's Contribution 	Employee's Contribution 	Vesting Period 
Before January 1, 1990 	10.85% 		None 
1/1/90 to 12/31/94 	12% 	6% 	None 
1/1/95 to 12/31/96 	13% 	6% 	None 
01/01/97 to 08/18/2004 	14% 	6% 	None 
08/19/04 to 9/27/10 	15% 	6% 	None 
After 09/28/10 	12% 	6-9% 	None 
 
Such contribution will be computed from the date of appointment as a qualified officer hereunder; provided, however, that if such officer has been a member of the General Retirement System or the Police and Fire Retirement System, such contribution will be computed from the date of election to participate in this retirement program. 
For City Officers hired on or after July 1, 2011: 
Date of Payment 	Employer's Contribution 	Employee's Contribution 	Vesting Period 
After 07/01/11 	6% 	6% 	None 
 
(b)  To elect a retirement program hereunder, such officer shall, within six (6) months of the date of his or her appointment to a position eligible for the election of the officer's option, submit to the City Commission his or her election, in writing, to accept benefits hereunder in lieu of benefits under the General Retirement System or the Police and Fire Retirement System. The City Commission may, in its discretion, waive the six-month requirement. The officer who elects such benefit shall be required to participate in the International City Management Association Retirement Corporation Prototype Money Purchase Plan and Trust. Such officer shall be required to contribute not less than six (6) percent of his or her compensation. In no event shall the total paid into the plan, for and on behalf of the officer, exceed the amount allowed under the terms of the Internal Revenue Code regulating such plan. 
(c)  Such officer shall submit to the City Commission annual accountings prepared by administrators of the program that he/she has elected. Such annual accounting shall include the following information: 
(1)  The amount of the contributions of such officer; 
(2)  The amount of payment or distribution made to such officer or made on his or her behalf, if any; 
(3)  The amount of any loan made by such insurance or trust company upon the security, or by assignment, of the trust assets or annuity contract or any part thereafter. 
(d)  The Employer shall pick up the member contributions required by this Section for all compensation earned after the effective date of this subsection. The contributions so picked up shall be treated as employer contributions in determining tax treatment under the United States Internal Revenue Code. The Employer shall pick up the member contributions from funds established and available in the salaries account, which funds would otherwise have been designated as member contributions and paid to the Retirement System. Member contributions picked up by the Employer pursuant to this subsection shall be treated for all other purposes of this and other laws of the Employer in the same manner and to the same extent as member contributions made prior to the effective date of this subsection. The member does not have the option of receiving the picked-up member contributions in cash instead of having it paid into the Retirement System. The effective date of the employer pick-up is January 1, 1990. 
(e)  Anything to the contrary notwithstanding, any benefit payable under this System shall not exceed the limits set forth in Internal Revenue Code Section 415 and Regulations thereunder, the terms of which are specifically incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 68-41, 6-25-68; Ord. No. 68-61, 8-27-68; Ord. No. 75-104, 12-23-75; Ord. No. 77-66, 11-22-77; Ord. No. 82-85, 12-7-82; Ord. No. 83-2, 1-18-83; Ord. No. 83-37, 6-28-83; Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 2-11-86; Ord. No. 86-43, § 1, 7-1-86; Ord. No. 88-30, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 90-02, § 1, 1-2-90; Ord. No. 90-30, §§ 1, 2, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 98-49, §§ 6, 7, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 99-20, § 5, 4-13-99; Ord. No. 2015-38, § 1, 7-28-15)  
Sec. 1.284. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this Article 3 only, the following terms are defined as indicated: 
(a)  City Officer. The term "City Officer" shall include officers of the City appointed by the City Commission (herein "Appointed Officers" namely City Manager, City Treasurer, City Attorney or City Clerk) and except for the Fire Chief, persons within the executive classification. 
(b)  Appointed Officer means an officer elected by the City Commission as authorized by City Charter Compiler's Paragraph 9, namely City Manager, City Attorney, City Clerk and City Treasurer. 
(c)  Compensation means remuneration paid an employee by the City for his or her personal services rendered, expressed as the rate of salary including allowance for longevity pay and vacation pay, but excluding overtime pay, holiday pay and other fringe benefits. 
(Ord. No. 68-41, 6-25-68; Ord. No. 68-61, 8-27-68; Ord. No. 75-104, 12-23-75; Ord. No. 86-8, § 2, 2-11-86; Ord. No. 2009-49, § 5, 9-15-09; Ord. No. 2017-29, § 2, 4-25-17)  
Sec. 1.285. - Participation Status. 
(a)  Should any officer employed by the City who qualifies for and has elected to participate in the retirement program as defined in Section 1.283 herein, lose department head status, or be assigned to another position within the employment of the City which would otherwise not qualify for coverage under Section 1.283, for any reason other than disciplinary action, that officer shall be entitled to continue participation in the retirement program as provided in Section 1.283. 
(b)  Should any City officer employed by the City who has elected to participate in the retirement program as provided in Section 1.283 herein, become an officer appointed by the City Commission in the capacity of City Manager, City Treasurer, City Attorney or City Clerk ("Appointed Officer") having been a vested member of the System prior to their election by City Commission as an Appointed Officer, then such Appointed Officer may elect to again become a member of the System. Such election to rejoin the System must be made within six (6) months after such officer's appointment by City Commission, and shall be effective on the date upon which such option is exercised by the Appointed Officer. Determinations regarding reinstatement of credited service and eligible service for Appointed Officers who rejoin the System as permitted by this Section shall be made pursuant to Sections 1.201(1)(b), 1.202(1) and 1.203. 
(c)  Effective November 1, 2016, the Officer's Option shall be closed to any Non-Represented Member of the Police and Fire Retirement System, as defined in Section 1.233(19.1), who was previously a member of the Police and Fire Retirement System as a represented employee. Such Non-Represented Members shall be ineligible to elect the Officer's Option program established in this Article. 
(Ord. No. 80-11, 2-19-80; Ord. No. 2009-49, § 6, 9-15-09; Ord. No. 2016-83, § 1, 12-6-16)  
Secs. 1.286—1.289. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 4. - SUPPLEMENTAL ALLOWANCE BENEFIT 
 
Sec. 1.290. - Purpose. 
The City Commission of the City of Grand Rapids has determined that some of the retired employees of the City of Grand Rapids, or their surviving beneficiaries, are receiving retirement allowances which are disparagingly low, when compared to the ever-increasing cost of living. The City Commission has determined that it is in furtherance of the public interest to supplement these modest retirement allowances pursuant to this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 78-44, 6-20-78; Ord. No. 79-43, 6-26-79; Ord. No. 81-5, 1-13-81)  
Sec. 1.291. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, as used in this Article, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Annuity means a monthly amount derived from the accumulated contributions of a member and payable by the System throughout the life of a person or for a temporary period. 
(2)  Allowance means the gross total of the annuity and the pension. 
(3)  Beneficiary means any person who is receiving or designated by a member to receive a System benefit, except a retirant. 
(4)  Pension means a monthly amount derived from contributions of the employer and payable by the System throughout the life of a person or for a temporary period. 
(5)  Qualified retirant means a former member of the General Retirement System or the Police and Fire Retirement System of the City of Grand Rapids receiving a System allowance by reason of having been a member, and having completed at least twenty (20) years of employment with the City prior to retirement. 
(6)  Supplemental allowance benefit means the additional benefit paid to qualified retirants or their beneficiaries, as computed under this Chapter, which supplements the monthly allowance received by the qualified retirant or his or her beneficiary from the System. Supplemental allowance benefits shall be payable from the general fund of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(7)  System means either the City of Grand Rapids General Retirement System or the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System. 
(8)  Years retired means the number of full years of retirement completed by a retirant as of each annual computation date. Beneficiaries shall be entitled to receive credit for the same number of years retired as the qualified retirant through which they receive their System allowance would have been entitled. 
(Ord. No. 81-5, 1-13-81; Ord. No. 89-88, § 1, 12-19-89)  
Sec. 1.292. - Computation of Supplemental Allowance Benefit. 
(1)  Qualified retirants of the General Retirement System, or their beneficiaries, shall be entitled to receive a monthly supplemental allowance benefit equal to one dollar ($1.00) times the number of years retired; provided, however, that the total of any System allowance and supplemental allowance benefit paid to a qualified retirant or his or her beneficiary under this Section shall not exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per month; and provided further, that if any such qualified retirant or his or her beneficiary shall receive a monthly System allowance and monthly supplemental allowance benefit which totals less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) then the supplemental allowance benefit of such qualified retirant or beneficiary shall be increased in such an amount that the total of such payments equals two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month. 
(2)  Qualified retirants of the Police and Fire Retirement System, or their beneficiaries, shall be entitled to receive a monthly supplemental allowance benefit equal to one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) times the number of years retired; provided, however, that the total of any System allowance and supplemental allowance benefit paid to a qualified retirant or his or her beneficiary under this Section shall not exceed three hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00) per month; and provided further, that if any such qualified retirant or his or her beneficiary shall receive a monthly System allowance and a monthly supplemental allowance benefit which totals less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), then the supplemental allowance benefit of such qualified retirant or beneficiary shall be increased in such an amount that the total of such payments equals two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per month. 
(3)  Supplemental allowance benefits shall be limited to present qualified retirees, or their surviving beneficiaries, who currently receive such benefit. The payment of future benefits will be unaltered from the amount established on July 1, 1989. 
(Ord. No. 81-5, 1-13-81; Ord. No. 83-38, 7-12-83; Ord. No. 84-79, § 1, 12-4-84; Ord. No. 88-13, § 1, 3-15-88; Ord. No. 89-88, § 2, 12-19-89)  
Sec. 1.293. - Effect. 
Nothing in this Article shall affect the rights of any member, retirant or beneficiary of either the General Retirement System or the Police and Fire Retirement System to receive any benefits or allowances otherwise afforded to them under the pension ordinances of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(Ord. No. 81-5, 1-13-81)  
Sec. 1.294. - Effective Date. 
The supplemental allowances benefit provisions of this Article shall be effective as of July 1, 1980. 
(Ord. No. 81-5, 1-13-81)  
Sec. 1.295. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 5. - POST RETIREMENT BENEFITS—POLICE AND FIRE RETIREMENT SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-32, § 1, adopted August 23, 2011, amended article 5 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article 5, §§ 1.296—1.299, pertained to Thirteenth Check Pension Supplement—Police and Fire Pension System, and derived from Ord. No. 89-87, § 1, 12-19-89; Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-14-00; Ord. No. 200-53, § 1, 9-5-00; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 12, 9-10-02; Ord. No. 2004-60, § 12, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 2006-84, §§ 9, 10, 12-19-06. 
 
Sec. 1.296. - Thirteenth Check Pension Supplement. 
(1)  Authorized. A supplement to the pension benefit currently received by eligible retirants as defined in Section 1.296(2)(a) may occur annually in the form of a thirteenth pension check during the month of January. The issuance of a thirteenth check will be determined by funds available pursuant to Section 1.296(2)(b). 
(2)  Definitions. The following words and phrases interpret the implementation and intent of this Section as an adjunct to Section 1.233. 
(a)  Eligibility. Eligibility is limited to retirants or surviving beneficiaries who receive a monthly benefit from the City of Grand Rapids Police and Fire Retirement System and who have been receiving a System allowance for five (5) or more years by reason of having been a member. The five-year eligibility requirement is based upon the number of calendar years of retirement calculated from the first day of January of the retirement year without regard to the actual retirement date. Upon retirant's death only the surviving designated beneficiary at time of retirement pursuant to Section 1.247, who is otherwise eligible to receive a monthly pension benefit shall be eligible to continue receipt of this supplement benefit. Provided, however, that retirants terminating employment as shown in the following table, and their surviving beneficiaries pursuant to Section 1.247, shall be included when computing payment amounts for thirteenth check distributions, and in lieu of a thirteenth check shall be eligible to receive an escalator increase under Section 1.298. 
COVERED GROUP 	TERMINATION DATE 
Firefighters 	On or after July 1, 2007 
Police Officers 	On or after December 17, 2008 
Police Command 	On or after February 19, 2010 
Fire Chief 	On or after January 1, 2016 
Police Chief and Deputy Police Chief 	On or after January 1, 2016 
Deputy Fire Chief 	On or after October 6, 2016 
 
(b)  Fund availability. Fund availability will be determined by totaling the net annual market value investment rates of return for the preceding five (5) years prior to the year of payment, as determined by the System's investment consultant, and dividing that amount by five (5). Should this result in a figure less than eight percent (8%), no funds would be available for distribution. If the resulting figure is more than eight percent (8%), then fifty percent (50%) of the amount in excess of eight percent (8%) is to be multiplied by the funds available in the benefit reserve fund as determined on the prior June 30th. The resulting sum is the amount available for distribution to the eligible retirees following the deductions required in Section 1.296(2)(e). 
(c)  Computation of thirteenth check benefit. Qualified retirants of the Police and Fire Retirement System or their surviving beneficiaries shall be entitled to receive the available benefit that grants one (1) point for each full year of retirement to a maximum of fifteen (15) years and one (1) point or fraction thereof for each year of service at retirement. Formula for all: The retiree/surviving beneficiary will receive an amount based on his or her total number of points for years and months of service multiplied by number of years of retirement. The individual benefit is then calculated. The total of all retiree points so calculated shall equal one hundred percent (100%) of the net distributable reserve which will be allocated to retirees/beneficiaries in an amount commensurate to their individual point total. Subsequent to the calculations above, the benefit so calculated for the Chief of Police, Deputy Chief, Police Command, Police Officers and Sergeants, Fire Service and beneficiaries having had at least ten (10) years of service under any of the bargaining units shall be increased by twenty percent (20%). The monies for such increase shall be obtained after the initial calculation provided for in Section 1.296(2)(b) by increasing the sum to be distributed by the amount necessary to fund the additional benefits calculated herein. Such amounts shall be paid from the benefit reserve fund as identified in Section 1.296(2)(b). This benefit increase will be effective with the first distribution subsequent to July 1, 2001. Provided, however, that retirants terminating employment as shown in the table in Section 1.296(2)(a), and their surviving beneficiaries, shall be awarded points as provided in this paragraph for computing payment amounts for thirteenth check distributions, but shall not receive a thirteenth check as authorized by this Section. 
(d)  Benefit distribution. The Trustees of the Police and Fire Retirement System will annually ascertain if a reserve excess is available for distribution pursuant to the provisions of this Section and authorize payment of that amount to the retiree members or surviving beneficiaries. 
(e)  Payment. Retirant/surviving beneficiary must be an active retirant at time thirteenth check is issued. The custodial bank will administer the distribution of the amount determined in 1.296(2)(c) to retirees/surviving beneficiaries, with all fees for each service deducted from the net amount available for distribution. Provided however, that no payment shall be made to any retirant who terminates employment as outlined in the table in Section 1.296(2)(a), or to his or her surviving beneficiary. 
(3)  Effect. Nothing in this Section shall affect the rights of any member, retirant or beneficiary of the Police and Fire Retirement System to receive any benefits or allowances otherwise afforded to them under Chapter 7, Article 4, of the police and fire pension ordinance of the City of Grand Rapids. No retirant or surviving beneficiary shall receive payment under both Sections 1.296 and 1.298. 
(4)  Effective Date. The supplemental allowance benefit provisions of this Section shall be effective as of January 1, 1990. 
(Ord. No. 2011-32, § 1, 8-23-11; Ord. No. 2013-81, § 1, 12-3-13; Ord. No. 2019-31, § 9, 7-23-19)  
Sec. 1.297. - Reserved.  
Sec. 1.298. - Escalator Increase. 
(1)  An annual increase shall be provided to retirants who terminate employment as shown in the following table, or their surviving beneficiaries: 
COVERED GROUP 	TERMINATION DATE 
Fire Chief 	On or after January 1, 2016 
Deputy Fire Chief 	On or after October 6, 2016 
Firefighters, except Fire Chief 	On or after July 1, 2007 
Police Chief or Deputy Police Chief 	On or after January 1, 2016 
Police Officers, except Police Chief and Deputy Police Chief 	On or after December 17, 2008 
Police Command 	On or after February 19, 2010 
 
(2)  Annual escalator increases shall be determined as follows: 
COVERED GROUP 	TERMINATION DATE 
Fire Chief, Deputy Fire Chief, Firefighters 	1.5% after two years of retirement 
Police Chief, Deputy Police Chief, Police Command, Police Officers 	1.0% after five years of retirement 
 
Increases shall be granted on the first January or July following the retirant's waiting period, whichever occurs first, and shall be paid annually thereafter. The amount of the monthly escalator increase shall be based on the original retirement benefit computation and shall not be compounded. In the event of a change in monthly benefit amount due to either the death of a retirant or surviving beneficiary, or an automatic adjustment necessitated by the option elected at the time of retirement, the escalator increase shall be determined based on the original corresponding benefit amount and shall be applied based on the original retirement date. 
(3)  Retirants with termination dates as shown in Section 1.298(1), and their surviving beneficiaries, shall not receive any payment under Section 1.296. 
(4)  Nothing in this Section shall affect the rights of any member, retirant or beneficiary of the Police and Fire Retirement System to receive any benefits or allowances otherwise afforded to them under Chapter 7, Article 4, of the police and fire pension ordinance of the City of Grand Rapids. No retirant or surviving beneficiary shall receive payment under both Sections 1.296 and 1.298. 
(5)  The benefit provisions of this Section shall be effective as of July 1, 2007. 
(Ord. No. 2011-32, § 1, 8-23-11; Ord. No. 2015-70, § 6, 12-8-15; Ord. No. 2019-31, § 10, 7-23-19)  
Secs. 1.299—1.301. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 6. - POST RETIREMENT BENEFITS—GENERAL RETIREMENT SYSTEM[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-47, § 1, adopted September 10, 2013, amended Article 6 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Article 6, §§ 1.302—1.305, pertained to thirteenth check pension supplement—general pension system. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
 
Sec. 1.302. - Thirteenth Check Pension Supplement. 
(1)  Authorized. A supplement to the pension benefit currently received by eligible retirants as defined in Section 1.302(2)(a) may occur annually in the form of a thirteenth pension check during the month of January. The issuance of a thirteenth check will be determined by funds available pursuant to Section 1.302(2)(b). 
(2)  Definitions. The following words and phrases interpret the implementation and intent of this Section as an adjunct to Section 1.192. 
(a)  Eligibility. Eligibility is limited to retirees or surviving beneficiaries who receive a monthly benefit from the City of Grand Rapids General Retirement System and who have been receiving a System allowance for five (5) or more years by reason of having been a member. The five-year eligibility requirement is based upon the number of calendar years of retirement calculated from January first of the retirement year without regard to the actual retirement date. Upon retiree's death only the surviving designated beneficiary at time of retirement pursuant to Section 1.206, who is otherwise eligible to receive a monthly pension benefit, shall be eligible to continue receipt of this supplement benefit. Provided, however, that retirants terminating employment as shown in the table shown in Section 1.304(1), and their surviving beneficiaries pursuant to Section 1.206, shall be included when computing payment amounts for thirteenth check distributions, and in lieu of a thirteenth check shall be eligible to receive an escalator increase under Section 1.304. 
(b)  Fund availability. Fund availability will be determined by totaling the net annual market value investment rates of return for the preceding five (5) years prior to the year of payment, as determined by the System's investment consultant, and dividing that amount by five (5). Should this result in a figure less than eight percent (8%), no funds would be available for distribution. If the resulting figure is more than eight percent (8%), then fifty percent (50%) of the amount in excess of eight percent (8%) is to be multiplied by the funds available in the benefit reserve fund as determined by the most recent annual actuarial valuation. The resulting sum is the amount available for distribution to the eligible retirees following the deductions required in Section 1.302(2)(e). 
(c)  Computation of thirteenth check benefit. Qualified retirees of the General Retirement System, or their surviving beneficiary, shall be entitled to receive the available benefit that grants one (1) point for each full year of retirement to a maximum of fifteen (15) years and one (1) point or fraction thereof for each year of service at retirement. Formula: the retiree or surviving beneficiary will receive an amount based on his or her total number of points for years and months of service multiplied by number of years of retirement. The total of all retiree points so calculated shall equal one hundred percent (100%) of the net distributable reserve which will be allocated to retirees or surviving beneficiaries in an amount commensurate to their individual point total. Provided, however, that retirants terminating employment as shown in the table in Section 1.304(1), and their surviving beneficiaries, shall be awarded points as provided in this paragraph for computing payment amounts for thirteenth check distributions, but shall not receive a thirteenth check as authorized by this Section. 
(d)  Benefit distribution. The Trustees of the General Retirement System will annually ascertain if a reserve excess is available for distribution pursuant to the provisions of this Section and authorize payment of that amount to the retiree members or surviving beneficiaries. 
(e)  Payment. Retiree or surviving beneficiary must be an active retiree at time thirteenth check is issued. The custodial bank will administer the distribution of the amount determined in 1.304(2)(c) to retirees or surviving beneficiaries, with all fees for each service deducted from the net amount available for distribution. Provided however, that no payment shall be made to any retiree who terminates employment as outlined in the table in Section 1.304(1), or to his or her surviving beneficiary. 
(3)  Effect. Nothing in this Section shall affect the rights of any member, retiree or beneficiary of the General Retirement System to receive any benefits or allowances otherwise afforded to them under Chapter 7, Article 4, of the general pension ordinance of the City of Grand Rapids. No retiree or surviving beneficiary shall receive payment under both Sections 1.302 and 1.304. 
(4)  Effective Date. The supplemental allowance benefit provisions of this Section shall be effective as of January 1, 1990. 
(Ord. No. 2013-47, § 1, 9-10-13; Ord. No. 2013-82, §§ 1—3, 12-3-13)  
Sec. 1.303. - Reserved.  
Sec. 1.304. - Escalator Increase. 
(1)  An annual increase shall be provided to retirees who terminate employment as shown in the following table, or their surviving beneficiaries: 
COVERED GROUP 	TERMINATION DATE 
APAGR; APAGR 61st District Court 	On or after October 21, 2008 
GREIU; GREIU 61st District Court 	On or after March 24, 2009 
Crime Scene Technicians 	On or after May 12, 2009 
GREIU Public Library Rank & File and Supervisory bargaining units 	On or after July 9, 2009 
Emergency Communication Supervisors 	On or after September 13, 2011 
Non-Represented Members 	On or after July 1, 2014 
 
(2)  Annual escalator increases shall be determined as follows: 
COVERED GROUP 	AMOUNT and WAITING PERIOD 
APAGR; APAGR 61st District Court; GREIU; GREIU 61st District Court; GREIU Public Library Rank & File and Supervisory bargaining units 	1.0% after four years of retirement 
Crime Scene Technicians 	1.0% after six years of retirement 
Emergency Communication Supervisors 	1.0% after six years of retirement 
Non-Represented Members 	1.0% after seven years of retirement 
 
Increases shall be granted on the first January or July following the retiree's waiting period, whichever occurs first, and shall be paid annually thereafter. The amount of the monthly escalator increase shall be based on the original retirement benefit computation and shall not be compounded. In the event of a change in monthly benefit amount due to either the death of a retiree or surviving beneficiary, or an automatic adjustment necessitated by the option elected at the time of retirement, the escalator increase shall be determined based on the original corresponding benefit amount and shall be applied based on the original retirement date. 
(3)  Retirees with termination dates as shown in Section 1.304(1), and their surviving beneficiaries, shall not receive any payment under Section 1.302. 
(4)  Nothing in this Section shall affect the rights of any member, retiree or beneficiary of the General Retirement System to receive any benefits or allowances otherwise afforded to them under Chapter 7, Article 4, of the general pension ordinance of the City of Grand Rapids. No retiree or surviving beneficiary shall receive payment under both Sections 1.302 and 1.304. 
(5)  The benefit provisions of this Section shall be effective as of October 21, 2008. 
(Ord. No. 2013-47, § 1, 9-10-13; Ord. No. 2014-53, §§ 1, 2, 7-22-14)  
Secs. 1.305—1.319. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 7. - MEDICARE SUPPLEMENT TRUST FUND 
 
Sec. 1.320. - Establishment and Operation. 
A Medicare Supplemental Trust Fund is established as set out in this Article. This separate and distinct trust fund is established to provide a financial base for the purpose of funding payment of a portion of each eligible retiree's Medicare Supplemental health insurance Benefit premium from contributions provided by the City of Grand Rapids, the 61st District Court, or the Board of Library Commissioners of the Grand Rapids Public Library pursuant to collective bargaining agreements with the Grand Rapids Employees Independent Union. The intent of this Article is that the payments made will be applied solely to reduce the cost of Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage and for no other purpose. 
(1)  As used in this Article, the words and phrases defined below shall have the indicated meanings: 
(a)  Trust Fund means contributions set aside in trust for the benefit of designated retired City, Court and Library employees and the accumulated investment income from the investment of those contributions. "Trust Fund" may also include any voluntary contributions made which are designated to be used for the purpose of this fund. "Trust Fund" means the total amount in the Trust Account except as otherwise set out in this Article. 
(b)  Eligible Participants means those retirees of the City of Grand Rapids General Retirement System who receive a monthly benefit from the Retirement System as a result of having retired on or after January 1, 1990 and who are receiving a Medicare benefit under federal law as a result of having reached age sixty-five (65), and eligible beneficiaries as determined by the Joint Committee defined herein. 
(c)  Contribution means that amount that the employer contributes in separate quarterly payments to the Trust Fund in an amount equal to one-half of one (0.5) percent of the annual salary rate, including longevity pay, of those employees covered by the General Retirement System and who, upon retirement, will be eligible for Medicare coverage. The quarterly payments provided for in this Section shall be made by the employer in January, April, July, and October of each year. 
(d)  Joint Committee means the seven-member committee of Trustees appointed to administer this Trust. Four (4) members shall be appointed and may be removed by the Grand Rapids Employees Independent Union under a procedure to be established and administered by the Union. Three (3) members shall be appointed and may be removed by the City Manager. 
(e)  Investment of Trust Funds means the placement of trust fund reserves into investments determined by the Joint Committee to be likely to enhance value of the Trust and to provide timely cash flow to meet benefit payment needs as determined by the Joint Committee. 
(f)  Annual Benefit Amount means the total amount of the Trust Fund determined by the Joint Committee to be distributed to insurance companies for Medicare Supplement Benefits for eligible participants. 
(g)  Premium means the monthly fee charged for the Supplement to Medicare Parts A and B then being offered to retirees by the employer, or an equal amount paid to the retiree's designated alternate insurance. 
(h)  Alternate Insurance means an insurance policy for health care benefits that is individually purchased by the retiree and comparable in nature to that provided by the City of Grand Rapids to members of the respective bargaining units represented by the Grand Rapids Employees Independent Union members. 
(2)  The Joint Committee shall have the following duties: 
(a)  The Joint Committee shall be responsible for the investment of the Trust Funds in the manner and for the purposes provided for in this Article. The Joint Committee is authorized to enter into an agreement with the Trustees of the General Retirement System to delegate all of the Joint Committee's investment powers to the Trustees of the General Retirement System. Upon execution of such an agreement, the Retirement System Trustees will act as the sole investing body of the Trust with authority to enter into contracts with and discharge investment managers at its sole discretion. The General Retirement System Trustees shall be held harmless by the City from personal liability for the performance of their duties pursuant to this Section. The Joint Committee is also authorized to delegate its investment authority to other investment managers as is deemed appropriate. 
(b)  The Joint Committee shall determine how much of the Trust Fund shall be designated for use as an annual benefit amount as provided for in this Article. The maximum amount available for distribution during any fiscal year shall be limited to fifty (50) percent of the value of the Trust Fund. The Joint Committee shall decide and certify to the City how much of the stated maximum shall be authorized for payments during the coming fiscal year. The benefit of any part time employee shall be prorated to reflect a reduction commensurate with the percentage of hours normally worked. 
(c)  The Joint Committee shall determine what the expenses of the Trust Fund shall be and shall authorize the payment of those expenses deemed to be appropriate. Such expenses shall include, but not be limited to, supplies, fees for professional services, custodial fees, investment costs and commissions, auditing and performance evaluation fees and reimbursement for other expenditures necessary for the proper and efficient operation of the Trust Fund. Upon approval by the Joint Committee, the expenses shall be promptly paid by the custodian of the Trust Fund. 
(3)  The amount designated as the Annual Benefit Amount by the Joint Committee shall be paid to the insurance company providing Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage to each eligible participant. The total annual Benefit Amount shall be prorated so that each eligible retiree's insurance carrier receives the same amount to be credited to each retiree's Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage premium whether the employee has coverage provided by the City's health insurance carrier or by an alternative carrier. No payment shall be made to any employee directly or to any person or entity other than a bona fide insurance company for Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage. The payment disbursement will occur on an advance quarterly basis. Payment of benefits will begin on January 1, 1993. 
(4)  Any employee may transfer any contributions made to the Trust Fund on the employee's behalf into another City of Grand Rapids Supplement to Medicare Trust Fund when the employee ceases to be in a position that is represented by the Grand Rapids Employees Independent Union bargaining unit. The amount to be transferred shall be computed as provided herein based upon the employee's annual salary rate including longevity plus three (3) percent interest. The City Comptroller's Office shall determine the exact dollar amount for transfer subject to review by the Joint Committee prior to the transfer. Should any other Supplement to Medicare Trust Funds be created that do not have a reciprocal transfer provision, no funds will be transferred to said trust and upon retirement the benefit payment will be prorated on a percentage basis according to the number of years served in a position represented by the Grand Rapids Employees Independent Union bargaining unit. 
(5)  Benefits provided by the plan shall apply only to those who retire or have retired on or after January 1, 1990 and immediately receive regular age and service or disability benefits as described in Chapter 7, Title I of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. 96-6, § 2, 2-13-96  
Sec. 1.321. - Establishment and Operation—Grand Rapids Firefighters, Local 366. 
A Medicare Supplemental Trust Fund is established as set out in this Article. This separate and distinct trust fund is established to provide a financial base for the purpose of funding payment of a portion of each eligible retiree's Medicare Supplemental Health Insurance Benefit premium from contributions provided by the City of Grand Rapids pursuant to the collective bargaining agreement with the Grand Rapids Firefighters, Local 366. The intent of this Article is that the payments made will be applied solely to reduce the cost of Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage and for no other purpose. 
1.  As used in this Article, the words and phrases defined below shall have the indicated meanings: 
A.  "Trust Fund" means contributions set aside in trust for the benefit of designated retired City Firefighter employees and the accumulated investment income from the investment of those contributions. "Trust Fund" may also include any voluntary contributions made which are designated to be used for the purpose of this fund. "Trust Fund" means the total amount in the Trust Account except as otherwise set out in this Article. 
B.  "Eligible Participants" means those retirees of the City of Grand Rapids Police/Fire Retirement System who receive a monthly benefit from the Retirement System as a result of having retired on or after July 1, 1989, and who are receiving a Medicare benefit under federal law as a result of having reached age sixty-five (65), or spouses of those retirees. Spouses are only eligible to receive the unused portion of the Annual Benefit afforded to the retiree. This provision is not intended to provide spouses with a separate or additional benefit than the amount afforded to the retiree. 
C.  "Contribution" means that amount that the employer contributes in separate quarterly payments to the Trust Fund in an amount equal to one-half of one (0.5) percent of the annual salary rate, including longevity pay, of those employees covered by the Police/Fire Retirement System and who will be eligible for Medicare coverage after retirement. The quarterly payments provided for in this Section shall be made by the employer in January, April, July, and October of each year. 
D.  "Joint Committee" means the seven member committee of Trustees appointed to administer this Trust. Four (4) members shall be appointed and may be removed by the Grand Rapids Firefighters, Local 366 under a procedure to be established and administered by the union. Three (3) members shall be appointed and may be removed by the City Manager. 
E.  "Investment of Trust Funds" means the placement of trust fund reserves into investments determined by the Joint Committee to be likely to enhance value of the Trust and to provide timely cash flow to meet benefit payment needs as determined by the Joint Committee. 
F.  "Annual Benefit Amount" means the total amount of the Trust Fund determined by the Joint Committee to be distributed to insurance companies for Medicare Supplement Benefits for eligible participants, or to eligible participants who purchase Alternate Insurance subject to the limitations regarding spouses provided in Section 1.321(1)(B). 
G.  "Premium" means the monthly fee charged for the supplement to Medicare Parts A & B then being offered to eligible participants by the employer or an equal amount paid for the eligible participant's Alternate Insurance. 
H.  "Alternate Insurance" means an insurance policy for health care benefits that is individually purchased by an eligible participant and is comparable in nature to that provided by the City of Grand Rapids to members of the respective bargaining unit represented by the Grand Rapids Firefighters, Local 366. 
2.  The Joint Committee shall have the following duties: 
A.  The Joint Committee shall be responsible for the investment of the Trust Funds in the manner and for the purposes provided for in this Article. The Joint Committee is authorized to enter into an agreement with the Trustees of the Police/Fire Retirement System to delegate all of the Joint Committee's investment powers to the Trustees of the Police/Fire Retirement System. Upon execution of such an agreement, the Retirement System Trustees will act as the sole investing body of the Trust with authority to enter into contracts with and discharge investment managers at its sole discretion. The Police/Fire Retirement System Trustees shall be held harmless by the City from personal liability for the performance of their duties pursuant to this Section. The Joint Committee is also authorized to delegate its investment authority to other investment managers as is deemed appropriate. 
B.  The Joint Committee shall determine how much of the Trust Fund shall be designated for use as an annual benefit amount as provided for in this Article. The maximum amount available for distribution during any fiscal year shall be limited to fifty (50) percent of the value of the trust fund. The Joint Committee shall decide and certify to the City how much of the stated maximum shall be authorized for payments during the coming fiscal year. 
C.  The Joint Committee shall determine what the expenses of the Trust Fund shall be and shall authorize the payment of those expenses deemed to be appropriate. Such expenses shall include, but not be limited to, supplies, fees for professional services, custodial fees, investment costs, and commissions, auditing and performance evaluation fees and reimbursement for other expenditures necessary for the proper and efficient operation of the Trust Fund. Upon approval by the Joint Committee, the expenses shall be promptly paid by the custodian of the Trust Fund. 
3.  The amount designated as the Annual Benefit Amount by the Joint Committee shall be paid to the insurance company providing Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage to each eligible participant, or to the eligible participant who provides the City's Human Resources Director with proof that, as provided in this Subsection (3), he or she has obtained and paid the most recent premium for Alternate Insurance. The total annual Benefit Amount shall be prorated so that each eligible participant's insurance carrier receives the same amount to be credited to each eligible participant's Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage premium whether the eligible participant has coverage provided by the City's health insurance carrier or has Alternate Insurance provided by an alternative carrier. This provision is subject to the limitations regarding spouses provided in Section 1.321(1)(B). No payment shall be made to any eligible participant unless he or she provides documents which confirm, to the satisfaction of the Joint Committee, that he or she has Alternate Insurance in force and has paid the most recent premium for that Alternate Insurance. Except as otherwise provided in the preceding sentence, no payment shall be made to any person or entity other than a bona fide insurance company for Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage. The payment disbursement will occur on an advance quarterly basis. Payment of benefits will begin on January 1, 1994. 
4.  Benefits provided by the plan shall apply only to those who retire or have retired on or after July 1, 1989, and receive regular age and service or disability benefits as described in Chapter 7, Title I, Article 2 of City Code. This is provided, however, that no benefits will be paid in instances of deferred pension annuity to members with less than twenty (20) years of service. 
(Ord. No. 93-55, § 1, 12-7-93; Ord. No. 96-6, § 3, 2-13-96; Ord. No. 2004-38, § 1, 7-13-04)

Should any other Supplement to Medicare Trust Funds be created that do not have a reciprocal transfer provision, no funds will be transferred to said trust and upon retirement the benefit payment will be pro-rated on a percentage basis according to the number of years served in a position represented by the Association of Public Administrators of Grand Rapids.

(Ord. No. 94-9, § 1, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 96-6, § 5, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 1.324. - Establishment and Operation—Non-union Employees Covered by the Management Compensation and Fringe Benefits Handbook. 
A Medicare Supplemental Trust Fund is established as set out in this Article. This separate and distinct trust fund is established to provide a financial base for the purpose of funding payment of a portion of each eligible retiree's Medicare Supplemental health insurance benefit premium from contributions provided by the City of Grand Rapids on behalf of non-union employees covered by the Management Compensation and Fringe Benefits Handbook in effect at the time of the enactment or any subsequent amendment of this ordinance and as otherwise provided for in this Code. The intent of this Article is that the payments made will be applied solely to reduce the cost of Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage for these employees and for no other purpose.

"Trust Fund" may also include any voluntary contributions made which are designated to be used for the purpose of this fund. The quarterly payments provided for in this Section shall be made by the employer in January, April, July, and October of each year.

G.  "Premium" means the monthly fee charged for the Supplement to Medicare Parts A & B then being offered to retirees by the employer or an equal amount paid to the retiree's designated alternate insurance. 
H.  "Alternate Insurance" means an insurance policy for health care benefits that is individually purchased by the retiree and comparable in nature to that provided by the City of Grand Rapids to non-union employees. 
2.  The Joint Committee shall have the following duties: 
A.  The Joint Committee shall be responsible for the investment of the Trust Funds in the manner and for the purposes provided for in this Article. The Joint Committee is authorized to enter into an agreement with the Trustees of the General Retirement System to delegate all of the Joint Committee's investment powers to the Trustees of the General Retirement System. Upon execution of such an agreement, the Retirement System Trustees will act as the sole investing body of the Trust with authority to enter into contracts with and discharge investment managers at its sole discretion. The General Retirement System Trustees shall be held harmless by the City from personal liability for the performance of their duties pursuant to this Section. The Joint Committee is also authorized to delegate its investment authority to other investment managers as is deemed appropriate. 
B.  The Joint Committee shall determine how much of the Trust Fund shall be designated for use as an annual benefit amount as provided for in this Article. The maximum amount available for distribution during any fiscal year shall be limited to fifty (50) percent of the value of the trust fund. The Joint Committee shall decide and certify to the City how much of the stated maximum shall be authorized for payments during the coming fiscal year. The benefit level established shall be uniformly applied on behalf of each eligible participant. 
C.  The Joint Committee shall determine what the expenses of the Trust Fund shall be and shall authorize the payment of those expenses deemed to be appropriate. Such expenses shall include, but not be limited to, supplies, fees for professional services, custodial fees, investment costs, and commissions, auditing and performance evaluation fees and reimbursement for other expenditures necessary for the proper and efficient operation of the Trust Fund. Upon approval by the Joint Committee, the expenses shall be promptly paid by the custodian of the Trust Fund. 
3.  The amount designated as the Annual Benefit Amount by the Joint Committee shall be paid to the insurance company providing Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage premium whether the employee has coverage provided by the City's health insurance carrier or by an alternative carrier. No payment shall be made to any employee directly or to any person or entity other than a bona fide insurance company for Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage. The payment disbursement will occur on an advance quarterly basis. 
4.  Any employee may transfer any contributions made to the Trust Fund on the employee's behalf into another City of Grand Rapids Supplement to Medicare Trust Fund when the employee ceases to be in a position that is non-union. The amount to be transferred shall be computed as provided herein based upon the employee's annual salary rate including longevity plus three (3) percent interest. The City Comptroller's Office shall determine the exact dollar amount for transfer subject to review by the Joint Committee prior to the transfer. Should any other Supplement to Medicare Trust Funds be created that do not have a reciprocal transfer provision, no funds will be transferred to said trust and upon retirement the benefit payment will be pro-rated on a percentage basis according to the number of years served in a position not represented by a collective bargaining unit. 
5.  Benefits provided by the plan shall apply only to those who retire or have retired on or after January 1, 1990. 
(Ord. No. 94-9, § 1, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 96-6, § 6, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 1.325. - Establishment and Operation - Grand Rapids Police Command Officers Bargaining Unit. 
1.  A Medicare Supplemental Trust Fund is established as set out in this Article. This separate and distinct trust fund is established to provide a financial base for the purpose of funding payment of a portion of each eligible retiree's Medicare Supplemental health insurance benefit premium from contributions provided by the City of Grand Rapids pursuant to the collective bargaining agreement with the Grand Rapids Police Command Officers Bargaining Unit, and is in addition to the fund established under Section 1.322 of this Article. The intent of this Article is that the payments made will be applied solely to reduce the cost of Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage and for no other purpose. 
As used in this Article, the words and phrases defined below shall have the indicated meanings: 
A.  "Trust Fund" means contributions set aside in trust for the benefit of the designated retired City police employees and the accumulated investment income from the investment of those contributions. "Trust Fund" may also include any voluntary contributions made which are designated to be used for the purpose of this fund. "Trust Fund" means the total amount in the Trust Account except as otherwise set out in this Article. 
B.  "Eligible Participants" means those retirees of the City of Grand Rapids Police/Fire Retirement System who receive a monthly benefit from the Retirement System as a result of having retired on or after January 1, 1995, and who are receiving a Medicare benefit under federal law as a result of having reached age 65, and eligible beneficiaries as determined by the Joint Committee defined herein. 
C.  "Contribution" means that amount that the employer contributes in separate quarterly payments to the Trust Fund in an amount equal to one-half of one (0.5) percent of the annual salary rate, including longevity pay, of those employees covered by the Police/Fire Retirement System and who will be eligible for Medicare coverage after retirement. The quarterly payments provided for in this Section shall be made by the employer in January, April, July, and October of each year, effective January 1, 1995. 
D.  "Joint Committee" means the five (5) member committee of Trustees appointed to administer this Trust. Three (3) members from the Police Command Officers Bargaining Unit shall be appointed and may be removed under a procedure to be established and administered by the respective labor organizations. Two (2) members shall be appointed and may be removed by the City Manager. 
E.  "investment of Trust Funds" means the placement of trust fund reserves into investments determined by the Joint Committee to be likely to enhance value of the Trust and to provide timely cash flow to meet benefit payment needs as determined by the Joint Committee. 
F.  "Annual Benefit Amount" means the total amount of the Trust Fund determined by the Joint Committee to be distributed to insurance companies for Medicare Supplement Benefits for eligible participants. 
G.  "Premium" means the monthly fee charged for the Supplement to Medicare Parts A & B then being offered to retirees by the employer or an equal amount paid to the retiree's designated alternate insurance. 
H.  "Alternate Insurance" means an insurance policy for health care benefits that is individually purchased by the retiree and comparable in nature to that provided by the City of Grand Rapids to members represented by the Police Command Officers Bargaining Unit. 
2.  The Joint Committee shall have the following duties: 
A.  The Joint Committee shall be responsible for the investment of the Trust Funds in the manner and for the purposes provided for in this Article. The Joint Committee is authorized to enter into an agreement with the Trustees of the Police/Fire Retirement System to delegate all of the Joint Committee's investment powers to the Trustees of the Police/Fire Retirement System. Upon execution of such an agreement, the Retirement System Trustees will act as the sole investing body of the Trust with authority to enter into contracts with and discharge investment managers at its sole discretion. The Police/Fire Retirement System Trustees shall be held harmless by the City from personal liability for the performance of their duties pursuant to this Section. The Joint Committee is also authorized to delegate its investment authority to other investment managers as is deemed appropriate. 
B.  The Joint Committee shall determine how much of the Trust Fund shall be designated for use as an annual benefit amount as provided for in this Article. The maximum amount available for distribution during any fiscal year shall be limited to fifty (50) percent of the value of the trust fund. The Joint Committee shall decide and certify to the City how much of the stated maximum shall be authorized for payments during the coming fiscal year. 
C.  The Joint Committee shall determine what the expenses of the Trust Fund shall be and shall authorize the payment of those expenses deemed to be appropriate. Such expenses shall include, but not be limited to, supplies, fees for professional services, custodial fees, investment costs, and commissions, auditing and performance evaluation fees and reimbursement for other expenditures necessary for the proper and efficient operation of the Trust Fund. Upon approval by the Joint Committee, the expenses shall be promptly paid by the custodian of the Trust Fund. 
3.  The amount designated as the Annual Benefit Amount by the Joint Committee shall be paid to the insurance company providing Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage premium whether the employee has coverage provided by the City's health insurance carrier or by an alternative carrier. No payment shall be made to any employee directly or to any person or entity other than a bona fide insurance company for Medicare Supplemental Benefit coverage. The payment disbursement will occur on an advance quarterly basis. Payment of benefits will begin on January 1, 1996. 
4.  Benefits provided by the plan shall apply only to those who retire or have retired on or after January 1, 1995, and receive regular age and service or disability benefits as described in Chapter 7, Title I, Article 2 of City Code. This is provided, however, that no benefits will be paid in instances of deferred pension annuity to members with less than 20 years of service. 
(Ord. No. 96-6, § 7, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 1.326. - Establishment and Operation - Emergency Communications Operators Bargaining Unit.

ARTICLE 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 95-16, § 1, adopted March 7, 1995, added § 1.331 to read as herein set out. Section 2 of said ordinance, repealed § 1.321, which pertained to general provisions. Also, at the request of the city, appropriate reserved sections have been included. See the Code Comparative Table. 
 
Sec. 1.331. - General Provisions. 
All Boards and Commissions existing at the time of the adoption of this provision shall be continued and the members serving thereon shall remain in office for the duration of the term for which they were appointed. Except as otherwise provided as to any particular Board or Commission, all Boards and Commissions shall be subject to the following general provisions: 
(1)  Any vacancy occurring in the membership of any Board or Commission shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term in the manner provided for original appointment. 
(2)  The appointing Authority may remove any member of any Board or Commission for cause, but any member shall be entitled to a public hearing on such removal, on written demand filed with the appointing Authority within ten (10) days after notice of removal has been given to such member. Such a hearing shall be limited to a statement by the appointing Authority of the reason for removal and any response that the removed member makes regarding the removal. The hearing is not an appeal hearing but shall be held only to provide a removed member an opportunity to publicly respond to the stated reason for the removal. Cause as provided for in this subsection shall include, but not be limited to, a member's failure to file with the City Clerk a sworn acceptance and oath of office or a member's failure to comply with any statement of privileges and duties or other standards of attendance or conduct promulgated by the City. 
(3)  All members of Boards and Commissions shall serve without compensation as members thereof. 
(4)  Pursuant to Title VI of Section 7, being compiler's paragraph 93 of the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids, the City Attorney is hereby designated to be the legal advisor and representative of all bodies, offices, agents, Commissions, Boards, Departments and any other agencies of the City of Grand Rapids, unless the City Commission expressly authorizes another Attorney by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 95-16, § 1, 3-7-95)  
Secs. 1.332—1.340. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 3. - COMMUNITY RELATIONS COMMISSION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) ---
