Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-61, § 1, adopted October 13, 2015, repealed the former Art. 3, §§ 1.341—1.347, and enacted a new Art. 3 as set out herein. The former Art. 3 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
 
Sec. 1.341. - Statement of Public Policy and Finding of Necessity. 
It is hereby declared to be contrary to the public policy of the City of Grand Rapids for any person to deny any other person the enjoyment of his or her civil rights or for any persons to discriminate against any other person in the exercise of his or her civil rights because of race, color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, gender, marital status, disability, height, weight, sexual orientation, or gender identity. 
It is hereby found that prejudice and discrimination against any individual or group because of race, color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, gender, marital status, disability, height, weight, sexual orientation or gender identity are inimical to democracy, the cornerstone of our American tradition, and menace peace and the general public welfare; that to eliminate such prejudice and discrimination, instrumentalities of government should be established through which the citizens of Grand Rapids may be kept informed of developments in community relations and from which the elected and appointed officials, and the Departments of this City may obtain expert advice and assistance in adopting measures to keep peace, good order and harmony among the citizens of Grand Rapids; and that such instrumentalities will promote harmony, help to avoid intergroup tensions, promote good will, and ensure equality of treatment and opportunity to all regardless of race, color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, gender, marital status, disability, height, weight, sexual orientation or gender identity. 
(Ord. No. 2015-61, § 1, 10-13-15)  
Sec. 1.342. - Created; Membership. 
There is hereby created a Commission to be known as the Community Relations Commission, consisting of nine (9) members to be appointed by the Mayor, with the approval of the City Commission. The members of the Commission should be selected, to the extent possible, so as to be representative of the community at large. 
The members shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for expenses necessarily incurred in connection with their duties as members of the Commission. All terms of members of the Commission shall be for three (3) years. Three (3) members shall be appointed for terms commencing on the first Monday in January each year. In the event of death, resignation, or removal from membership of any member, his or her successor shall be appointed to serve for the unexpired term of the departed member. 
(Ord. No. 2015-61, § 1, 10-13-15)  
Sec. 1.343. - Duties. 
The duties of the Community Relations Commission shall be as follows: 
(a)  It shall foster mutual understanding and respect among all racially, ethnically, religiously and culturally diverse groups in the City of Grand Rapids. It shall discourage and prevent discrimination practices toward any such group. 
(b)  It may upon its own initiative or upon referral to it by the City Manager's designee, investigate complaints of particular instances or complaints as to general conditions relative to any tensions, practices of discrimination or acts of prejudices against any person or group because of race, color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, gender, marital status, disability, height, weight, sexual orientation or gender identity and it may conduct public hearings with regard thereto. 
(c)  It shall carry on research projects and obtain factual data to ascertain the status and treatment racially, ethnically, religiously and culturally diverse groups within the City; and it shall make reports and recommendations to the City Commission and the City Manager as to its findings of fact relative to existing conditions and as to policies, programs and legislation for relief and alleviation of such discriminatory practices and conditions. 
(d)  It shall cooperate with other public, governmental or private agencies in developing courses of instruction for presentation in public and/or private schools, in public libraries, at public museums or other suitable places, showing and illustrating the contributions of various religious, nationality and ethnic groups to the culture, tradition and progress of our City, State and Nation, and further showing the deplorable effects and menace of prejudice, intolerance and discrimination. 
(e)  It may assist the City Manager and his or her designee in the performance of their duties as set forth in this Code. 
(f)  It shall formulate and carry out programs of community education and information with the object of discouraging and eliminating any such tensions, prejudice and discrimination. 
(g)  It shall issue such publications and reports of investigations and research as in its judgment will tend to minimize or eliminate prejudice, intolerance, race or area tensions and discrimination or which will promote or tend to promote good will. 
(h)  It shall cooperate with and seek the cooperation of federal, state and city agencies and departments in carrying out projects within their respective authorities to eliminate intergroup tensions, and to promote intergroup harmony. It shall recommend to the Mayor and to the City Commission measures, including legislation, aimed at improving relations within and among the population, as well as improving the ability of the various City departments and agencies to ensure protection of any and all persons and groups from discrimination because of race, color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, gender, marital status, disability, height, weight, sexual orientation or gender identity. It shall advise, and may recommend action to any official of competent authority, on any matters involving civil rights or the violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2015-61, § 1, 10-13-15)  
Sec. 1.344. - Meetings. 
The Community Relations Commission shall meet not less than once a month and shall adopt by majority vote such rules as it shall deem expedient for the conduct of its business. It shall elect such officers as it shall deem necessary. The Chairperson thereof shall appoint such Committees as the rules of the Community Relations Commission shall provide, and other Committees as shall from time to time be found necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2015-61, § 1, 10-13-15)  
Sec. 1.345. - Investigations. 
The obtaining of factual information by the Community Relations Commission in the performance of its duties hereunder is hereby declared to be necessary to its functions. In the event any person or persons shall fail to give such necessary information to the Community Relations Commission, or any Committee or authorized representative thereof, the said Commission may in its discretion make its report thereof to the City Commission. Pursuant to the City Charter, Title XVIII, Section 1, such report shall be deemed and it is hereby declared to be a proceeding or hearing pending before the City Commission. Thereafter upon instructions from the Mayor or any Commissioner of the City Commission, or the City Attorney, proceedings may then be initiated and had pursuant to the provisions of Articles 2 and 3 of Chapter 2 of Title I of the City Code of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(Ord. No. 2015-61, § 1, 10-13-15)  
Sec. 1.346. - Self-incrimination. 
Nothing contained in this Article shall be so construed as to require any person in any criminal case to be a witness against himself or herself. 
(Ord. No. 2015-61, § 1, 10-13-15)  
Sec. 1.347. - Civil Rights Defined. 
EMPLOYMENT - The opportunity to obtain employment without discrimination because of race, color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, gender, marital status, disability, height, weight, sexual orientation or gender identity is hereby recognized and declared to be a civil right. Further, it shall be contrary to the public policy of the City of Grand Rapids for any employer because of race, color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, gender, marital status, disability, height, weight, sexual orientation or gender identity to refuse to hire or otherwise discriminate against him or her with respect to hire, tenure, terms, conditions or privileges of employment unless such refusal to hire or discriminate is based on a bona fide occupational qualification. 
HOUSING - The opportunity to purchase, lease, sell, hold, use and convey dwelling housing or dwelling units without discrimination because of race, color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, gender, marital status, familial status, disability, height, weight, source of lawful income, public assistance recipient status, sexual orientation or gender identity is hereby recognized and declared to be a civil right. It shall not be a violation of this Section for the owner of an owner-occupied one-family or two-family dwelling to restrict occupancy. 
PUBLIC ACCOMMODATIONS - The opportunity to enjoy full and equal access to all goods and services, accommodations, advantages and facilities in all places of public accommodation, service, amusement and recreation, including, but not limited to, inns, hotels, motels, government housing, restaurants and eating places, barber shops, billiard parlors, stores, public transportation and conveyances, theaters and motion picture houses and educational institutions without discrimination because of race, color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, gender, marital status, disability, height, weight, familial status, source of lawful income, public assistance recipient status, sexual orientation or gender identity is hereby recognized and declared to be a civil right. 
(Ord. No. 2015-61, § 1, 10-13-15)  
Secs. 1.348—1.350. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 4. - BOARD OF ART AND MUSEUM COMMISSIONERS 
 
Sec. 1.351. - Board of Art and Museum Commissioners. 
The Board of Art and Museum Commissioners shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the City Commission for a term of four (4) years beginning the first Monday in January. Three (3) terms shall expire January 5, 2009, and the remaining two (2) terms shall expire January 4, 2010. In the event of a vacancy, the City Commission may appoint a successor to fill the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 65-28, 11-2-65; Ord. No. 74-23, 3-26-74; Ord. No. 2008-47, § 1, 11-12-08) 
Charter reference— Board of Art and Museum Commissioners, Title XIV.  
Sec. 1.352. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 85-13, § 1, adopted Feb. 26, 1985, repealed, § 1.352, concerning Municipal Art Advisory Commission, as derived from Ord. No. 77-41, adopted July 26, 1977.  
ARTICLE 5. - GRAND RAPIDS HOUSING COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Property Maintenance Code, Ch. 140. 
State Law reference— Authority to create, MCL 125.653. 
 
Sec. 1.353. - Created. 
Pursuant to Public Act. No. 18 of the Extra Session of 1933, as amended, a Commission is hereby created in and for the City of Grand Rapids, Michigan, to be known as the "Grand Rapids Housing Commission." 
(Ord. No. 66-12, 3-8-86)  
Sec. 1.354. - Appointed Members; Term of Office; Compensation. 
(1)  The Grand Rapids Housing Commission shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the City Manager, and confirmed by the City Commission. 
(2)  The term of office of members of the Grand Rapids Housing Commission shall be five (5) years. The members currently appointed and serving on the Commission upon the effective date of this ordinance shall continue in the terms for which they have been appointed. Pursuant to MCL § 125.654(2), at least one member of the Commission shall be a tenant of public or subsidized housing, appointed as required by law upon the happening of a vacancy on the Commission. Members may be removed from the Commission in accordance with procedures established in MCL § 125.654. 
(3)  The members of the Grand Rapids Housing Commission shall serve without compensation; provided, however, they may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in serving as a member of the Commission in an amount to be determined by the Commission. 
(Ord. No. 66-12, 3-8-66; Ord. No. 97-36, § 1, 8-5-97)  
Sec. 1.355. - Powers and Duties. 
(1)  The Grand Rapids Housing Commission shall have all of the powers and duties vested or permitted to be vested in the Housing Commission by Act 18 of the Public Acts of 1933, Ex. Sess., as amended heretofore or hereafter, and any laws heretofore or hereafter enacted which are supplemented thereto, it being the intention of this Article to vest in the Grand Rapids Housing Commission all powers and duties permitted by law. 
(2)  The Grand Rapids Housing Commission is authorized to act as a borrower for purposes of issuing bonds or notes in accordance with the provisions of Act 18 of the Public Acts of 1933, Ex. Sess., as amended. 
(3)  All deeds, mortgages, contracts, leases, purchases or other agreements regarding real property, including agreements to acquire or dispose of real property, shall be approved and executed in the name of the Grand Rapids Housing Commission. 
(Ord. No. 66-12, 3-8-66; Ord. No. 97-36, § 2, 8-5-97)  
Sec. 1.356. - Selection and Payment of Employees. 
The Grand Rapids Housing Commission may appoint a Director who may also serve as Secretary, and other employees or officers as are necessary. The Grand Rapids Housing Commission shall prescribe the duties of its officers and employees and shall have the sole authority to fix their compensation and fringe benefits, and terms and conditions of employment. 
(Ord. No. 66-12, 3-8-66; Ord. No. 97-36, § 3, 8-5-97)  
Sec. 1.357. - Financial Reporting. 
The Grand Rapids Housing Commission shall submit to the City Commission and the City Comptroller, in a form and with such detail as is reasonably determined by the City Comptroller to be sufficient, the following information: 
(a)  On a monthly basis, not later than 30 days after the end of each month, a statement of financial position, a statement of cash flows, and a financial accounting of all operations, contracts and grant activities. 
(b)  Not later than ninety (90) days after the close of the fiscal year, an annual accounting of financial activity of the Housing Commission shall be submitted to the City Commission along with an unqualified opinion of an independent certified public accountant for the financial statements, including the auditors report on the Schedule of Federal Awards, and any management reports filed with the Housing Commission pursuant to such audit. 
The books and records of the Housing Commission shall be available for review and audit by the City Comptroller's staff upon reasonable notice during business hours. 
(Ord. No. 66-12, 3-8-66; Ord. No. 97-36, § 4, 8-5-97)  
ARTICLE 6. - GRAND RAPIDS HISTORICAL COMMISSION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Historic preservation Commission, Ch. 68. 
 
Sec. 1.358. - Grand Rapids Historical Commission. 
The Grand Rapids Historical Commission shall consist of thirteen (13) persons to be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the City Commission. One (1) member may be the Museum Director of the City of Grand Rapids. All appointments shall be for a term of three (3) years, which term shall expire the first Monday in January the third year after appointment. 
(Ord. No. 68-28, 5-6-68; Ord. No. 70-41, 6-23-70; Ord. No. 74-9, 1-9-74; Ord. No. 76-50, 6-29-76)  
Sec. 1.359. - Duties. 
The Grand Rapids Historical Commission shall have the responsibility for the collection of source material and other data for purposes of compiling and keeping current the history of the City of Grand Rapids and such other responsibilities as may be assigned to it from time to time by the City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 68-28, 5-6-68)  
ARTICLE 7. - LOCAL OFFICERS COMPENSATION COMMISSION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to create a Local Officers Compensation Commission, MCL 117.5c, MSA 5.2084(3). 
 
Sec. 1.360. - Local Officers Compensation Commission. 
(1)  A Local Officers Compensation Commission is hereby created which shall determine the salaries of the Mayor, City Commissioners and Comptroller. The Compensation Commission shall consist of seven (7) members who are registered electors of the City, appointed by the Mayor subject to confirmation by a majority of the members elected and serving on the City Commission. The terms of office shall be seven (7) years, except that of the members first appointed, one (1) each shall be appointed for terms of one (1), two (2), three (3), four (4), five (5), six (6) and seven (7) years. All first members shall be appointed within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this Section. Thereafter members shall be appointed before October 1 of the year of appointment. Vacancies shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term. No member or employee of the legislative, judicial or executive branch of any level of government or members of the immediate family of such member or employee shall be eligible to be a member of the Compensation Commission. 
(2)  The Compensation Commission shall determine the salary of each local elected official, which determination shall be the salary unless the City Commission, by resolution adopted by two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the members elected to and serving on the City Commission rejects it. The determination of the Compensation Commission for each local elected official shall be effective thirty (30) days following its filing with the City Clerk unless rejected by the City Commission. In case of rejection, the existing salary shall prevail. Any expense allowance or reimbursement paid to elected officials in addition to salary shall be for expenses incurred in the course of City business and accounted for to the City. 
(3)  The Compensation Commission shall meet for not more than fifteen (15) session days in 1972 and every odd numbered year thereafter and shall make its determination within forty-five (45) calendar days of its first meeting. A majority of the members of the Compensation Commission shall constitute a quorum for conducting the business of the Compensation Commission. The Compensation Commission shall take no action or make any determination without a concurrence of a majority of the members appointed and serving on the Compensation Commission. The Compensation Commission shall elect a Chairman from among its members. 
"Session days" means any calendar day on which the Compensation Commission meets and a quorum is present. 
(4)  The members of the Compensation Commission shall receive no compensation, but shall be entitled to their actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. The City Commission shall implement this provision by resolution. After one (1) year following the date this Section goes into effect the procedure for establishing the compensation of elected officials may be changed by Charter amendment or revision. 
(5)  Within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this Section, a petition for a referendum on the ordinance may be filed in accordance with the procedure provided in the City Charter or otherwise by filing a petition with the City Clerk containing the signatures of at least five (5) percent of the registered electors of the City on the effective date of this Section in which case the election shall be conducted in the same manner as an election on a Charter amendment. If a petition for referendum is filed, any determination of the Compensation Commission shall not be effective until this Section has been approved by the electors. 
(6)  This Section 1.360 of the Code shall be in lieu of Section 36 of Title V of the Grand Rapids City Charter and is adopted in pursuance of Act No. 8 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1972. 
(Ord. No. 72-26, 4-11-72; Ord. No. 83-30, 5-31-83)  
Chapter 9 - PROPERTY TAX LEVY AND COLLECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Uniform City income tax, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference— General property tax act, MCL 211.1 et seq., MSA 7.1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE 1. - BOARD OF REVIEW AND TAX CALENDAR 
 
Sec. 1.361. - Board of Review. 
In accordance with the provisions of Act 206 of the Public Acts of 1893, as amended, and Title II and Title IX of the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids, as amended, a Board of Review is hereby created for the City of Grand Rapids. 
(Ord. No. 90-93, § 1, 12-18-90)  
Sec. 1.362. - Appointed Members; Qualifications. 
The Board of Review shall consist of six (6) members who shall be selected by the Mayor, subject to the approval of the City Commission, upon the basis of their knowledge of the subject of taxation and of property values. Members must be taxpayers and residents of the City for five (5) years. 
(Ord. No. 90-93, § 1, 12-18-90; Ord. No. 91-16, § 1, 3-19-91)  
Sec. 1.363. - Terms of Office. 
Members of the Board of Review shall be appointed on or before February 1 of each year for staggered five-year terms. Two (2) members of the Board shall have terms expiring on the same year. 
(Ord. No. 90-93, § 1, 12-18-90)  
Sec. 1.364. - Powers and Duties. 
The Board of Review shall have the powers and duties as provided in Act 206 of the Public Acts of 1893, as amended and Title IX of the City Charter, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 90-93, § 1, 12-18-90)  
Sec. 1.365. - Procedure. 
The Board shall be divided into two (2) Committees consisting of three (3) members each for the purpose of hearing and deciding issues protested pursuant to Section 30 of Act 206 of the Public Acts of 1893, as amended (MCL § 211.30). Two (2) of the three (3) members of a Board of Review Committee shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of the business of the Committee. All meetings of the members of the Board of Review and Committees shall be held the same hours of the same day at the same location. 
A majority of the entire Board of Review membership shall endorse the assessment roll as provided in Section 30 of Act 206 of the Public Acts of 1893, as amended (MCL § 211.30). The duties and responsibilities of the Board contained in Section 29 of Act 206 of the Public Acts of 1893, as amended (MCL § 211.29) shall be carried out by the entire membership of the Board of Review and a majority of the membership shall constitute a quorum for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 90-93, § 1, 12-18-90)  
Sec. 1.366. - Compensation. 
Pursuant to Section 10 of Title IX of the City Charter, the City Commission shall, by resolution, fix the compensation rates for members of the Board of Review. For the purpose of calculating such compensation, meetings lasting four (4) hours or less shall constitute a one-half (½) day meeting. Those lasting longer than four (4) hours shall be a full day meeting. 
(Ord. No. 90-93, § 1, 12-18-90)  
Sec. 1.367. - Assessment Roll Completion. 
In order to comply with the provisions of Act No. 206 of the Public Acts of 1893, as amended, concerning date for completion of the Assessment Roll and date for completion of the review of the Assessment Roll by the Board of Review in each year, the following dates and periods for preparing, making, completing and reviewing the Assessment Roll in each year are hereby provided for: 
December 31—Tax Day; 
Fourth Monday in January—Final date for return of personal property statements; 
First Monday in February—Commencement of the ten-day period for the Assessor's Review, as provided in Section 9 of Title IX of the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(1)  Notice of completion of the assessment roll for the purpose of Assessor's review shall be published for ten (10) days prior to the first Monday in February in the manner provided for in Section 9 Title IX of the Charter. 
(2)  The Assessment Rolls shall be completed on this date for the purpose of the Assessor's Review. 
The first Monday in March—Completion of the Assessment Rolls; 
Tuesday following the first Monday in March—First meeting of Board of Review for purposes of organization; 
The fifth day following the first Monday in March—On or before this date written notices of appeal to the Board of Review shall be filed in the office of the City Assessor in the manner provided in Section 10 of Title IX of the Charter; 
Second Monday in March—Commencement of Review by the Board of Review; 
First Monday in April—Completion of review by the Board of Review. 
(Ord. No. 90-93, § 1, 12-18-90)  
Sec. 1.368. - General Tax Laws. 
Except as herein otherwise provided the manner and periods for preparing, making, completing and reviewing the Assessment Roll shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids and the general tax laws of the State of Michigan. The dates and periods herein provided for shall prevail, any provisions of the Charter to the contrary notwithstanding. 
(Ord. No. 90-93, § 1, 12-18-90)  
Secs. 1.369, 1.370. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 2. - INSTALLMENT PAYMENTS, TAX SALES 
 
Sec. 1.371. - City and School Taxes. 
City and school taxes shall become due and payable on July first of each year hereafter and may be paid or postmarked during the month of July without interest or penalties; provided, however, that in the event the City and school tax rolls shall not be delivered to the City Treasurer in sufficient time to allow the giving of notice as provided in Title IX, Section 20, of the Charter, prior to July first of any year, then the City and school taxes on such tax roll shall become due on the first day of the first month following the month in which the aforesaid notice was given and such City and school taxes may be paid at any time after the delivery of the tax roll to the Treasurer and prior to the due date thereof and during the period from such due date to and including the last day of the first month following the month in which such notice is given, without interest or penalties. 
(Ord. No. 94-1, § 1, 1-4-94)  
Sec. 1.372. - Installment Payment Permitted. 
Taxpayers may, at any time prior to sale, pay City and school taxes in installments of not less than one-sixth of the amount of the original tax plus, in any event, penalties due on the portion so paid to the date of payment; provided, no payment shall be less than ten dollars ($10.00).  
Sec. 1.373. - Penalties. 
Penalties on all unpaid taxes or portions thereof shall be paid as follows: 
(1)  There shall be added to such taxes not paid or postmarked one (1) percent on the first day of the month following the month in which the tax became due and one (1) percent on the first of each succeeding month thereafter until the date of payment, date of the tax sale, or until return of the tax to the County Treasurer. 
(2)  On the first of March next following there shall be added, in addition to all other amounts, a collection fee which shall be four (4) percent of the total amount not paid or postmarked or such amount as shall be provided for collection fees to be charged by counties under State law for the collection of City and school taxes, whichever amount shall be the greater. 
(3)  Taxes being collected by the City on behalf of the County of Kent may be paid or postmarked before February 15 of the succeeding year without penalty. On all taxes paid or postmarked after February 14, the Treasurer shall add to the tax a collection fee equal to four (4) percent of the tax, which collection fee is hereby waived for a senior citizen, paraplegic, quadriplegic, eligible service person, eligible veteran, eligible widow or widower, totally and permanently disabled or blind person as those persons are defined in Chapter 9 of Act No. 281 of the Public Acts of 1967 as amended, being Sections 206.501 to 206.532 of the Michigan Compiled Laws [MSA 7.557(1501) to (1532)]; who makes a claim before February 15 for the credit provided by Chapter 9 of Act No. 281 of the Public Acts of 1967 as amended, being Sections 206.501 to 206.532 of the Michigan Compiled Laws, who presents a copy of the form filed for that credit to the City Treasurer and who has not received the credit before February 15. 
(Ord. No. 76-30, 4-20-76; Ord. No. 78-11, 2-14-78; Ord. No. 80-47, 6-24-80; Ord. No. 94-1, § 1, 1-4-94) 
Editor's note— Provisions added as subsection 1.373(4) by Ord. No. 82-48, adopted June 15, 1982, were deleted by citizen referendum at the general election of Nov. 2, 1982. 
State Law reference— Income tax act of 1967, MCL 206.1 et seq., MSA 7.557(101) et seq.  
Sec. 1.374. - Notices. 
The City Treasurer shall cause to be prepared proper proofs of the giving of notice as required by Title IX, Section 20, of the Charter, which proofs shall be by affidavits of the person or persons familiar with the facts relative to the publication of notice in two (2) newspapers and also relative to the posting of notice in at least twenty (20) public places in each of the wards of the City, such affidavits setting forth the facts of publication. Such proofs shall be affixed to the City and school tax roll by the City Treasurer and shall become a part thereof and shall be prima facie evidence of the facts therein set forth.  
Sec. 1.375. - Public and Special Improvement Assessments, Penalties. 
Public and special improvement assessments shall be due and payable when the rolls therefor are placed in the hands of the City Treasurer for collection and the entire tax may be paid or postmarked during the first month thereafter without interest or penalties. If a roll is divided into installments the first installment may be paid or postmarked during the first month without penalties and subsequent installments shall be paid as they fall due. Should any installment not be paid or postmarked during the first month when due, interest shall cease and penalties shall be added at one (1) percent for each month until the tax is paid, until the tax sale, or until return of the tax to the County Treasurer, whichever shall first occur. There shall also be added on the first of March next following a collection fee in addition to such penalties. The collection fee shall be four (4) percent of the total then due or the amount provided by State law for such collection fees for counties making such collection fees, whichever amount shall be the greater. 
(Ord. No. 66-40, 8-30-66; Ord. No. 76-30, 4-20-76; Ord. No. 80-47, 6-24-80; Ord. No. 94-1, § 1, 1-4-94) 
Cross reference— Special assessments generally, § 1.421 et seq.  
Sec. 1.376. - Installment Payment Permitted. 
Taxpayers may pay any public or special improvement tax, or installment, at any time prior to sale in installments of not less than one-sixth thereof, plus, in any event, penalties due on the portion so paid to the date of payment, but no such payment shall be less than ten dollars ($10.00).  
Sec. 1.377. - Waiver of Penalties. 
The City Commission may, by resolution, provide that penalties assessed under this Article be waived in whole or in part, as equity may require. The City Treasurer may waive penalties assessed under this Article up to two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year per property number as equity may require. 
(Ord. No. 80-56, 7-8-80; Ord. No. 94-1, § 1, 1-4-94)  
Sec. 1.378. - Tax Sales. 
Proceedings for sale of real estate for delinquent City and school taxes and public and special improvement assessments shall be instituted each year, commencing with the year 1941, in the manner provided by law. 
Cross reference— Tax sales, § 1.391 et seq.  
Sec. 1.379. - Penalties After Sale. 
After sale, a penalty of one (1) percent of the amount of sale shall be added on the first day of each succeeding month during the period of redemption. 
Tax sales may be redeemed in installments of not less than one-sixth of the amount of the sale. No payment shall be less than ten dollars ($10.00). The period of redemption shall be one (1) year from the date of sale, but if fifty (50) percent or more of the amount of the sale is paid during such year, the period of redemption shall be extended for one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 80-47, 6-24-80)  
Sec. 1.380. - Amount Necessary to Redeem. 
When the period of redemption has expired, the balance of the tax plus any penalties to date shall be computed, which, in addition to the further sum of five dollars ($5.00) or twenty-five (25) percent of the balance of the tax to date, whichever is greater for each description, shall be collected by the holder of the certificate or tax deed from any purchaser thereof.  
Sec. 1.381. - Fee for Duplicate Tax Statement Preparation. 
After the City Treasurer's computerized summer and winter tax billings have been prepared, any request for a duplicate tax statement which requires the manual preparation of the statement shall be subject to a fee to cover the extra expense involved in such preparation, with the amount of such fee to be established from time to time by resolution of the City Commission. Provided, however, that the City Treasurer shall be authorized to waive such fee when he or she determines that the requesting party either has acted with due diligence or has acted in good faith and has requested the preparation of fewer than ten (10) duplicate statements within any one (1) summer or winter tax billing cycle. 
(Ord. No. 86-70, § 2, 12-9-86)  
Secs. 1.382—1.390. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 3. - TAX SALES 
 
Sec. 1.391. - Collection and Sale Under Title IX of the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids. 
All unpaid or delinquent taxes on the City and school real estate tax roll of the City of Grand Rapids for 1974, 1975, and all years subsequent thereto shall be returned to the County Treasurer for collection and sale under the State law. Unpaid or delinquent taxes on the City and school real estate tax roll for 1974 and 1975 shall be returned on March 3, 1976, and for 1976 and years subsequent thereto shall be returned on March first of the year following the tax levy. 
(Ord. No. 76-15, 3-2-76)  
Sec. 1.392. - Statement of Unpaid Taxes. 
If the City Treasurer shall be unable to collect any of the taxes on the City and school tax roll assessed on real property, he or she shall, on or before April first of the second year after such taxes become delinquent, make a statement of same in duplicate, with a full and perfect description of such property as assessed upon said roll, with the several taxes assessed upon each parcel thereof; each of which statements shall be verified by the affidavit of the City Treasurer, or his or her deputy, that such taxes remain unpaid. The City Treasurer shall file one (1) of said statements in his or her office, and the other statement shall be delivered by him or her to the City Attorney, who shall retain the same for the purpose of taking the necessary proceedings for a sale of said lands for the delinquent taxes thereon. The City Commission may, by resolution, extend the time for making and filing such verified statement for twenty (20) days.  
Sec. 1.393. - City's Lien. 
All lands included in the verified statement mentioned in Section 1.392 upon which any taxes shall remain unpaid for a period of one (1) year or more after becoming delinquent, shall be subject to disposition, sale and redemption for the enforcement and collection of such tax liens, in the method and manner as hereinafter provided. In the disposition and sale of such delinquent tax lands, the City of Grand Rapids shall be deemed to have a valid lien upon such lands with all the rights to endorse the same as a preferred or first claim upon such lands, and the rights and choses to enforce such lien shall be held and construed by all the courts of this State as the prima facie rights of the said City of Grand Rapids and shall not be set aside or annulled except in the manner and for the causes specified by law.  
Sec. 1.394. - Resolution by Commission. 
It shall be the duty of the City Attorney, upon receipt of the statement of the unpaid taxes mentioned in Section 1.392, to notify the City Commission that the same is in his or her possession, and the City Commission may thereupon by resolution, instruct the City Attorney to institute proceedings for the sale of lands listed in said verified statement for unpaid taxes.  
Sec. 1.395. - Petition for Sale. 
The City Attorney shall thereupon file a petition for the sale of said lands, in the Circuit Court of Kent County, and the same proceedings shall be had, the same notices given, the same orders and decree made, the same sale had, as near as may be as provided in Chapter 10 (Special Assessments) and all the provisions of said Chapter 10 in regard to payment of the taxes before sale, the giving of deeds, the period of redemption, the power, authority and jurisdiction of the Circuit Court of Kent County in regard thereto, the issuance of writs of assistance and the notice required prior thereto, together with the right to appeal and the practice thereunder and each and every other provision thereof, shall, as far as applicable, be and become a part of this Article except insofar as the same may be modified or changed by this Article. Provided that said petition and the proceedings thereafter shall include interest to the date of sale, figured the same as the prior interest at one (1) percent per month; provided, further, that where in said Chapter 10 the word "assessment" is used as meaning the tax or amount to be collected, the word "tax" shall be substituted for the purposes of this Article.  
Secs. 1.396—1.400. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 4. - CITY TAX LANDS 
 
Sec. 1.401. - Manager to Have Custody. 
The City Manager, subject to the supervision and control of the City Commission and the provisions of this Article, shall have the care, custody and disposition of all real estate, or any interest therein, now held or which may be hereafter acquired by the City of Grand Rapids by reason of any City or State tax or assessment sales.  
Sec. 1.402. - Period of Redemption. 
Before offering for sale such real estate or any interest therein which the City shall hereafter acquire, the City Manager shall hold said real estate for a period of thirty (30) days after the acquisition of title, during which time the owner or holder of a mortgage thereon shall have the right to obtain the City's interest therein by the payment to the City of not less than the amount of money which the City has invested therein in the form of unpaid taxes or otherwise, plus interest, penalties and costs. 
If no application is made to revest title within the thirty-day period above mentioned, then the right to sell the City's interest in such real estate shall become absolute. In the event that both the owner and holder of the mortgage shall make application to revest title as above provided, the owner thereof shall be given preference.  
Sec. 1.403. - Lease of Unsold Land. 
It shall be the duty of the City Manager as soon as the City of Grand Rapids obtains title to any real estate, whether by City or State tax or assessment sales, if the same cannot be sold as herein provided, to negotiate a lease of the same upon the best terms he or she can procure, and report such lease to the City Commission for its approval, reserving however, in any such lease, the right of said City to sell the real estate embraced therein at any time during the continuance thereof. It shall also be the duty of the City Manager to negotiate terms of sale of such real estate and report same to the City Commission for approval.  
Sec. 1.404. - Determining Land Value; Sales. 
After the lapse of thirty (30) days from the date when the City of Grand Rapids first obtained title to any real estate, or any interest therein, the City Manager shall offer the same for sale, but no sale shall be then made to any person whomsoever for less than the market value thereof, and which valuation shall be determined and established by the City Commission by and with the aid of the City Assessors if it deem it expedient, or the City Commission may appoint appraisers to examine the property and report on the value thereof to the City Commission. The final findings of the City Commission on the value thereof shall be binding and final as to such value.  
Sec. 1.405. - List of Tax Lands. 
The City Manager shall prepare a list of all the lands in which the City holds title through tax sales, and ascertain and list in connection with each parcel, the value thereof, and thereafter from time to time make such additions to or corrections in the same as may be necessary to keep it up to date.  
Secs. 1.406—1.409. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 5. - TAXATION OF ASSISTED LOWER-INCOME HOUSING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 91-54, § 1, adopted October 29, 1991, amended Art. 5 to read as herein set out in §§ 1.410—1.413. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Art. 5, §§ 1.410—1.412, pertained to taxation of low cost housing and derived from Ord. No. 68-80, adopted Dec. 30, 1968; Ord. No. 74-103, adopted Dec. 31, 1974; Ord. No. 75-87, adopted Oct. 7, 1975; Ord. No. 76-99, adopted Dec. 21, 1976; Ord. No. 78-10, adopted Feb. 14, 1978 and Ord. No. 89-86, § 1, adopted Dec. 19, 1989. 
 
Sec. 1.410. - Eligible Housing Projects. 
The tax exemption established in Subsection (1) of Section 15(a) of Act 346 of 1966 as amended (hereinafter referred to as the "Act"), Section 125.1415(a) shall apply to housing projects within the boundaries of the City of Grand Rapids which meet all of the following criteria, upon approval of the City Commission: 
(1)  Projects which are financed with a Federally-aided or State Housing Development Authority-aided mortgage or with an advance or grant from such Authority, 
(2)  Projects which serve lower-income families, elderly, and/or handicapped, and 
(3)  Projects which are owned by "consumer housing cooperatives," "qualified nonprofit housing corporations," and "limited dividend housing associations" as defined in Act No. 346 of the Public Acts of 1966, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 91-54, § 1, 10-29-91; Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 1-30-18)  
Sec. 1.411. - Property Tax Exemption. 
Housing projects which qualify under Section 1.410 above shall have the tax exemption provided in the above-mentioned subsection (1) of Section 15(a), provided the owner of a housing project has complied with the Act, is current with all taxes and assessments on the subject property, and has annually filed before August 1st an audited financial statement for each previous calendar year, as requested, with the City Assessor. 
(Ord. No. 91-54, § 1, 10-29-91; Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 1-30-18)  
Sec. 1.412. - Service Charge in Lieu of Taxes. 
The service charge in lieu of property taxes shall be paid by the housing project owner as follows: 
(1)  Housing projects approved for tax exemption under this ordinance on or before December 31, 1990 shall pay a service charge in the amount equal to ten (10) percent of annual shelter rent, except as provided in 1.412(3) below. Annual shelter rent is defined as the total collections from all occupants of a housing project exclusive of any charges for gas, electricity, heat, or other utilities furnished to the occupants. 
(2)  Housing projects approved for tax exemption under this ordinance on or after January 1, 1991 shall pay a service charge in the amount equal to four (4) percent of annual shelter rent or may choose to pay a service charge in the amount equal to one (1) percent of annual shelter rent in addition to making an annual contribution to the City of Grand Rapids' Affordable Housing Fund in an amount equal to two (2) percent of annual shelter rent. If the annual contribution to the Housing Fund is not made, the service charge shall revert to four (4) percent of annual shelter rent. 
(3)  Housing projects approved for tax exemption under this ordinance between January 1, 1990 and December 31, 1990 may request requalification at the four (4) percent rate. The granting of requalification requests shall require the approval of the City Commission and would be effective the subsequent tax year. 
(4)  Housing projects provided with rent assistance under the Section 8 Program of the United States Housing Act of 1937, as amended by the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 as amended, shall pay a service charge in the amount equal to four (4) percent of the contract rents of the preceding calendar year, exclusive of any charges for gas, electricity, heat, or other utilities furnished to the occupants. 
(5)  Housing projects defined as emergency shelters or transitional housing for the homeless shall not be assessed a service charge in lieu of property taxes. 
(6)  Service charges shall only be applied to rent restricted units that are actually occupied by low-income individuals consistent with P.A. 346 of 1966, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 91-54, § 1, 10-29-91; Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 1-30-18)  
Sec. 1.413. - Duration of Exemptions and Service Charges in Lieu of Taxes. 
The exemptions and service charges authorized under this ordinance shall be in effect for the life of the Federally-aided or State-aided mortgage loan or other eligible assistance, not to exceed fifty (50) years. 
(Ord. No. 91-54, § 1, 10-29-91; Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 1-30-18)  
Sec. 1.414. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 6. - COLLECTION OF DELINQUENT PERSONAL PROPERTY TAXES 
 
Sec. 1.415. - Purpose and Intent. 
The purpose and intent of this Article is to implement specifically some of the authority granted to the City Treasurer by Title IX, Section 22, of the Charter of the City of Grand Rapids, to use all means which are lawful for the collection of debts generally to collect delinquent personal property taxes. Because State law prohibits officials of the political subdivisions of the State from compromising personal property taxes, nothing in this Article should be construed as authorizing the release of property from any lien for unpaid taxes, penalties and collection fees until such taxes, penalties and collection fees have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 83-4, 2-1-83)  
Sec. 1.416. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this Article only, certain terms shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Base taxes. The amount of taxes originally due, without the addition of collection fees or accrued delinquency penalties. 
(2)  Collection fees. Those charges imposed for the collection of personal property taxes which are authorized by this Chapter or by State law and which are added to the base amount of taxes. 
(3)  Delinquency penalties. Those charges imposed for nonpayment of taxes by the due date which are authorized by this Chapter or State law and which are added to the base amount of taxes. 
(4)  Delinquent personal property taxes. Taxes levied against personal property pursuant to this Chapter and State law which have not been paid by their due date. 
(5)  Personal property tax account. An account established by the City Treasurer for the levy and collection of personal property taxes for each taxing unit for each year's taxes for each taxpayer. 
(6)  Taxing unit. The local government agency imposing the tax involved and for whose use and benefit the tax is collected; i.e., the City of Grand Rapids; the County of Kent; each public school System with some portion of its district located within the City limits and for which taxes are collected by the City Treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 83-4, 2-1-83)  
Sec. 1.417. - Contracts for Collection Authorized. 
The City Commission may award professional services contracts to assist the City Treasurer in the collection of delinquent personal property taxes under the following conditions: 
(1)  Contracts may be awarded only to collection agencies properly licensed pursuant to Act 299, Public Acts of Michigan of 1980, as amended, and to duly licensed Michigan Attorneys. 
(2)  In the collection of delinquent personal property taxes, collection agencies and attorneys must conform to the requirements and standards imposed upon them by State "collection practices" statutes applicable to them in the collection of claims or debts as defined in those statutes. For collection agencies, the relevant statute is Act 299, Public Acts of Michigan of 1980, as amended (Article 9 thereof), being MCLA § 339.901 et seq. For attorneys, the relevant statute is Act 70, Public Acts of Michigan of 1981, being MCLA § 445.251 et seq. 
(3)  Contracts may be awarded only for the collection of delinquent personal property taxes of those taxing units which have authorized their use either by concurring in the award of specific contracts or by providing the City Treasurer with separate written authorization valid for all contracts awarded for either a time certain or until revoked. 
(4)  The contract fee paid to a collection agency or attorney shall be calculated on an individual delinquent personal property tax account basis. In no event shall the fee on each individual delinquent account collected exceed the delinquency penalty and collection fee on such account. For purposes of this Article, if less than the full balance in a delinquent account is collected, all amounts collected shall be allocated between base taxes, collection fee, and delinquency penalty on a pro rata basis in the same ratio that each bears to their sum. 
(5)  The City Commission may require collection agencies and attorneys awarded contracts to provide the City with bonds, insurance, and indemnification assurances as conditions of contract. 
(Ord. No. 83-4, 2-1-83) 
State Law reference— Collection practices, MCL 339.901 et seq., MSA 18.425(901) et seq.; regulation of collection practices of certain persons, MCL 445.251 et seq., MSA 19.658(1) et seq.  
Secs. 1.418—1.420. - Reserved.  
Chapter 10 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Public and special improvement assessments, penalties, § 1.375. 
State Law reference— Power re special assessments, MCL 117.4a, 117.4b, 117.4d, 117.5; MSA 5.2074, 5.2075, 5.2077, 5.2084. 
 
Sec. 1.421. - Declaration of Necessity. 
Whenever it shall become necessary to appropriate private property for any public improvement, the City Commission shall first declare by resolution the necessity for such improvement and the necessity for taking such property for such use or improvement. Such property may be acquired by the City of Grand Rapids either by purchase through the City Commission, or by condemnation for public use in the manner provided for by the general laws of the State of Michigan relating to the taking of private property for public use. 
Cross reference— Determination of necessity, § 1.427.  
Sec. 1.422. - Owner May Be Relieved of Cost of Improvement. 
Whenever such property has been contributed by the owner, the City Commission may, by a majority vote, relieve the property owner who has so contributed a portion of the improvement from the whole or any part of the assessment for such improvement. Provided, the same shall be done in strict compliance with Section 21 of Title X of the Charter.  
Sec. 1.423. - Financing by Special Assessment. 
The City Commission shall have power to determine that the whole or any part of the cost of any public improvement shall be defrayed by special assessment upon the property especially benefited. The term "public improvement" as used in this Chapter shall be construed to mean any public work or public and special improvement which the City is empowered to undertake under the City Charter or the laws of the State of Michigan, any part of the cost of which may be assessed against property benefited. 
(Ord. No. 65-18, 9-14-65)  
Sec. 1.424. - Advisory Petitions. 
The City Commission may, by a majority vote, make a preliminary determination of necessity of any improvement without a petition being filed therefor, except in those cases where the Charter may require a petition. The City Commission, in order to ascertain whether or not a reasonable number of property owners to be assessed desire any particular public improvement to be made, may request and receive a petition therefor, or may receive such a petition voluntarily presented, but in either event, such petition shall be advisory only and shall not be jurisdictional except in those cases where the City Charter requires a petition to confer jurisdiction. In the case of public improvements, part or all of the cost of which may be assessed to the property benefited upon a front-foot basis, such petition may be signed by the owners of a majority of the front footage of the real estate abutting said improvement or proposed to be improved or benefited thereby, as shown by the current tax assessment roll of the City. 
(Ord. No. 65-18, 9-14-65)  
Sec. 1.425. - Maps and Estimates. 
Before the City Commission shall take action respecting any public improvement hereunder, the City Manager shall prepare a map of the proposed special assessment district, an estimate of the cost of the proposed improvement and plans and specifications therefor and shall present the same to the City Commission, together with his or her recommendation as to what portion of the cost should be paid by special assessment and the amount, if any, of the cost of such public improvement which shall be levied upon the City at large, the number of installments in which the assessments may be paid, and the lands which should be included in the special assessment district. After the report is presented to the City Commission, it may be filed with the City Engineer and made available to the public for examination.  
Sec. 1.426. - Hearing on Improvement. 
After the material required to be prepared by the City Manager is presented to the City Commission, it may direct by resolution of a majority of the members elect that a public hearing concerning such proposed public improvement shall be held before the City Commission at a time and place to be fixed by it. The City Engineer shall cause notice of the time and place of such hearing to be published once in the official newspaper of the City not less than ten (10) days prior to the date of said hearing. Such notice shall also State that the report, plans and specifications and estimate of cost are on file with the City Engineer for public examination. A like ten-day notice shall also be sent by first class mail to each owner of property subject to assessment in the proposed special assessment district as indicated by the records of the Assessor's Office at the address and to the person shown on the current tax assessment roll of the City. At the time and place specified in such notice of public hearing the City Commission shall meet and hear any person to be affected by the proposed public improvement. The hearing may be adjourned from time to time as shall be determined by the City Commission. 
Cross reference— Service of notice generally, § 1.11; notice of assessment, § 1.437. 
State Law reference— Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq., MSA 5.3534(1) et seq.  
Sec. 1.427. - Determination of Necessity. 
After completion of the hearing, the City Commission may, by resolution of a majority of the members elect, declare the public improvement to be necessary and order the same to be acquired and constructed, determine to defray the whole or any part of the cost of the improvement by special assessment upon the property especially benefited in proportion to the benefits thereto, approve the plans and specifications for the improvement, determine the estimated cost thereof, approve the map of the special assessment district, determine the character of the improvement, determine and fix the district over which the assessment to pay the cost thereof shall be levied and the amount, if any, of the cost of such improvement which shall be spread and levied upon the City at large and the cost which shall be spread and levied upon the special assessment district, and specify whether the cost of the public improvement in the first instance shall be met by issuing bonds of the City therefor in anticipation of the collection of the assessments to defray the expense thereof. In addition, by said resolution the City Commission shall order to be transmitted to the Assessor a map of the district fixed by it and a certified copy of said resolution. The City Manager shall transmit to the Assessor such facts as he or she may have necessary to make proper assessment.  
Sec. 1.428. - Preparation of Assessment Roll. 
Within one hundred and fifty (150) days after receipt of said resolution specified in Section 1.427, the Assessor shall prepare a special assessment roll which shall contain the names of the owners and the descriptions of the several parcels of property in the special assessment district as fixed by the City Commission to be assessed for such public improvement, and upon such roll and against each of such descriptions of property the Assessor shall spread and levy that part of the cost of such improvement determined by the City Commission to be spread and levied upon the special assessment district, in proportion as near as may be to the advantages which each parcel in such district shall be deemed by the Assessor to be benefited by the making of such improvement. After the assessment roll is completed, the Assessor shall give notice to all persons assessed thereon of the completion of such roll and that the same will be open for ten (10) days for public inspection and for correction by the Assessor and of the time and place of the meeting of the Board of Review on the special assessment roll. Said notice shall be given by publication at least once in the official newspaper of the City not less than ten (10) full days prior to the first day on which such special assessment roll will be open for public inspection. A like ten-day notice shall also be sent by first class mail by the Assessor to each owner of property subject to assessment as chosen on the current tax assessment rolls of the City. Immediately after the expiration of the ten-day period during which the special assessment roll shall be signed by the Assessor and returned forthwith to the City Commission.  
Sec. 1.429. - Hearing on Roll. 
At a regular session not less than one (1) week after the receipt of such special assessment roll from the Assessor and at the time and place specified in the notice given by the Assessor as required by Section 1.428, the City Commission shall act thereon as a Board of Review and shall continue to act at such other times as may be necessary and as it shall from time to time designate. Any person may appeal in writing to the City Commission acting as such Board of Review at any time prior to the opening of its first session as such Board of Review. The City Commission as such Board of Review shall have the power to correct or change the whole or any part of such special assessment roll or to return it to the Assessor for reassessment, in which latter case it shall take the same course as an original special assessment roll. At such time as the City Commission sitting as a Board of Review is satisfied with the special assessment roll, and is of the opinion that such special assessment roll results in the assessments being levied in accordance with the benefits, it shall cause such determination to be entered upon it minutes. Thereafter the City Commission shall adopt a resolution ratifying and confirming said special assessment roll and, in addition, by the terms of said resolution shall determine when such special assessments shall be due and paid or, if the same shall be divided into installments, the number thereof, not to exceed ten (10), in which the special assessment roll may be paid, and shall determine the due dates of the first and subsequent installments on said special assessment roll.  
Sec. 1.430. - Return of Roll. 
If it shall be determined by the City Commission, acting as such Board of Review, to return said assessment roll to the City Assessor for reassessment, the reason for so doing and any instructions or recommendations shall be embodied in a resolution and a copy thereof certified to by the City Clerk as correct, shall be at once delivered, with said assessment roll, to the City Assessor.  
Sec. 1.431. - Plans and Specifications. 
It shall be the duty of the City Manager to prepare or cause to be prepared all plans, specifications and drawings, including profiles and blue prints, of such public or special improvement that may be necessary for the proper construction thereof, and which same shall be public records of his or her office and open to inspection.  
Sec. 1.432. - Bids. 
The City Manager shall advertise for bids at least once in a daily newspaper published in the City of Grand Rapids, and not less than one (1) week before the opening of said bids. Bids shall be received, opened and tabulated by the Director of Public Service, who shall report the same together with his or her recommendation thereon to the City Manager, who shall examine the same, together with such report, and report the same with his or her recommendation to the City Commission, together with the reasons upon which said recommendation is based, and thereupon the City Commission shall pass on said proposals and enter into a contract with any responsible bidder; provided, the City Commission shall require security for the performance of the proposals tendered, and if a bid is accepted, security for the performance of any contract entered into, and the statutory bond for the protection of material suppliers, laborers and subcontractors. The City Commission shall have the right to reject any and all bids, and in case all bids are rejected the City Commission may order the City Manager to readvertise the same, or the City Commission may, by resolution, carried by four (4) votes, order the City Manager to perform such work and furnish such material himself or herself, keeping an itemized account of the cost thereof and reporting the same in writing to the City Commission at once after the same shall be completed. The City Commission shall thereupon examine such report and if found correct, order the same paid by resolution duly adopted by at least four (4) votes; provided, that the City Commission may from time to time, by resolution so adopted, order payment of the work and materials as the same progresses upon recommendation by the City Manager.  
Sec. 1.433. - Bonds. 
For the purpose of meeting the expense of any public or special improvement, or in anticipation of the collection of assessments levied for that purpose, the City Commission may by resolution or ordinance, authorize and direct the Mayor, City Comptroller and City Clerk to borrow not to exceed one and one-half (1.5) percent of the assessed valuation of the City, according to the last preceding City tax roll; provided, that the total amount of bonds issued for such purpose and outstanding at any one (1) time, shall not exceed three (3) percent of the total assessed valuation of the City, according to the last preceding City tax roll; and to issue bonds therefor bearing interest at the rate of not exceeding six (6) percent per annum with interest coupons attached, and said bonds shall be made payable in equal yearly amounts for a period of not exceeding ten (10) years from the date of issue, as the City Commission may direct and which bonds shall be signed by the Mayor and counter-signed by the City Comptroller and attested by the City Clerk of said City. The said bonds, if issued for street or sewer purposes, shall be endorsed "Special Improvement Bonds, year 19 …," and shall be numbered or lettered consecutively. Said bonds may be made registered or unregistered, and shall not be sold for less than par and the accrued interest, if any, and be payable at the office of the City Treasurer and the proceeds of the same shall be paid to the City Treasurer and by him or her placed to the credit of the improvement fund for which said bonds were issued. The said bonds shall be paid at maturity and cancelled and shall not be reissued or refunded. 
(Ord. No. 68-67, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 1.434. - Delivery of Roll to Treasurer. 
The special assessment roll as confirmed by the City Commission shall be delivered by the City Clerk to the City Treasurer for collection with the proper warrant for such purpose attached thereto signed by the Mayor and attested in due form by the City Clerk. In the event that the project will not be started immediately, the City Commission may, in the same resolution confirming the assessment roll, establish a date for collection by the City Treasurer.  
Sec. 1.435. - Lien Established. 
All special assessment and nuisance special assessment contained in any special assessment roll, including any part thereof deferred as to payment and such administrative charge as may be applicable thereto, shall from the date and time of receipt thereof by the City Treasurer constitute a lien upon the respective lots or parcels of land assessed, and until paid shall be a charge against the respective owners of the several lots and parcels of land. Such lien shall be of the same character and effect as the lien created for City taxes and shall include accrued interest and penalties. No judgment or decree nor any act of the City Commission vacating a special assessment shall destroy or impair the lien of the City on the premises assessed for such amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the same. 
(Ord. No. 84-40, § 1, 6-5-84)  
Sec. 1.436. - Deficiency Assessments. 
The City Commission may provide for spreading of an additional assessment for any improvement in case it determines that the former assessment or assessments will not produce sufficient funds to pay for such improvement. Such additional assessment shall be spread upon a supplemental roll, which shall conform so far as may be to the original roll for such improvement, and shall be made, reviewed, delivered, collected, accounted for and returned in the same manner as the original roll, and all sales and redemptions of property therein described shall be made in the same manner as the sales and redemption upon said original roll.  
Sec. 1.437. - Notice of Assessment. 
Upon receipt of a special assessment roll with the proper warrant for such purpose attached thereto as hereinbefore provided for, the City Treasurer shall mail statements of the several assessments to the respective owners, stating the amount of the assessment and the manner in which it may be paid, and, in addition, the City Treasurer shall publish notice of the fact that said special assessments are due in the official newspaper of the City on or prior to the date that said statements are mailed. Where the special assessment roll is divided into more than one (1) installment, published notice of the second and subsequent installments need not be given, but mailed notice to the owner as shown on the current tax assessment rolls of the City, stating the due date and amount of the next installment, shall be deemed sufficient. 
State Law reference— Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq., MSA 5.3534(1) et seq.  
Sec. 1.438. - Interest on Unpaid Installments. 
In addition to the principal amount of each annual installment there shall be added thereto and collected from the special assessment roll by the City Treasurer as part of each annual installment interest at a rate which shall be determined by the City Commission, which shall be adjusted to a rate equal to the rate borne by the bonds or other evidences of indebtedness issued or authorized to defray the cost plus one (1) percentum per annum on the entire unpaid balance of the special assessment, commencing with the due date of the first installment and computed to the due date of each particular installment. In addition to said annual interest, in the event that any special assessment or installment thereof shall not be paid within one (1) month of the due date thereof, penalties shall thereafter be charged and added to said past due assessment or installment in lieu of further interest on said installment, as provided in Section 1.375 of Chapter 9 of Title I of the Code of the City of Grand Rapids. Such penalties shall be collected at the same time and in the same manner as the special assessments and interest thereon are collected. The entire assessment, or the first installment thereof if divided into installments, may be paid during the first month after the due date thereof without interest. 
(Ord. No. 66-40, 8-30-66; Ord. No. 70-23, 4-28-70; Ord. No. 77-68, 11-29-77)  
Sec. 1.439. - Delinquent Installments. 
When any special assessment or any installment thereof, when divided into installments, shall have been due and unpaid for more than ninety (90) days on the first day of April of any year, such fact shall be certified by the City Treasurer to the City Commission, and the lot or parcel of land against which the special assessment has been spread and levied shall thereupon be sold for delinquent and unpaid assessments and other charges in manner provided hereafter.  
Sec. 1.440. - Reassessments. 
Whenever any special assessment shall in the opinion of the City Commission be invalid by reason of irregularity or nonconformity in the proceedings, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge said assessment to be illegal, the City Commission may, whether the improvement has been made or not, or whether any part of the assessment has been paid or not, have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made. All proceedings on such reassessment and for the collection thereof shall be conducted, so far as may be necessary, in the same manner as provided for in the original assessment and, whenever the assessment or any part thereof levied upon any premises has been so set aside after the same has been paid and not refunded, the payment so made shall be applied on the reassessment and the reassessment shall to that extent be deemed satisfied.  
Sec. 1.441. - Refunds. 
Should the assessments levied or the moneys derived through the sale of special assessment bonds issued in anticipation of the collection of said assessments prove to be more than five (5) percent larger than necessary to defray the cost of the public improvement, then all excess over such five (5) percent shall, pursuant to resolution of the City Commission so directing, be applied pro-rata to the unpaid installments of such special assessments against each lot or parcel of land in such proportion as the original assessment against any such lot or parcel bears to the total amount assessed. Any amount which cannot be applied as aforesaid shall be refunded in cash to the person then assessed for taxes on such property, according to the latest tax assessment roll.  
Sec. 1.442. - Railroads, Assessments. 
All freight houses, roadbeds, rights-of-way and other premises or property belonging to the owner of any steam, electric or street railway or other common carrier within the corporate limits of the City, which are necessarily used in the operating of the respective franchises of the owners of said railroads or other common carriers, and the person, corporation or company owning the same shall be liable for all valid assessments for public improvements hereafter made within the City and assessed against such property. Assessments of such property shall be made in the same manner as that of other property for special improvements under this Chapter, and the assessment roll therefor shall be prima facie evidence in any court of the regularity of all proceedings up to and including such assessment and the making of said roll.  
Sec. 1.443. - Collection from Railway Companies. 
When any assessment is made against any railway or street railway company or the same shall become due by reason of any franchise given to said company, and the same shall not have been paid within the time fixed for the collection of taxes in said warrant, an action of assumpsit may be instituted in behalf of the City in the proper court to recover the amount of said assessment or assessments, or that shall be due the City under the franchise of said company.  
Sec. 1.444. - Payment of Tax on Part of Whole Parcel. 
Any person owning any undivided share or other part or parcel of real estate assessed in one (1) description may pay the tax on the part thus owned by paying an amount having the same relation to the whole tax as the part on which payment is made has to the whole parcel. The person making such payment shall accurately describe the part on which he or she desires to make payment, and the receipt given and the record of the City Treasurer shall so show such description and by whom paid.  
Sec. 1.445. - Collection by Treasurer. 
In proceeding to collect an assessment upon a roll made as aforesaid the City Treasurer shall credit on such roll all sums paid by any person, and shall mark "paid" all the real estate or any distinct parcel thereof, which is separately assessed upon which the assessments have been paid, and shall then proceed to collect the unpaid assessments thereon in the manner directed in his or her warrant.  
Sec. 1.446. - City May Purchase. 
The City of Grand Rapids is hereby authorized and empowered to purchase all parcels of land which shall be advertised and offered for sale under the provisions of this Chapter, which shall not be sold as aforesaid, and in case the same is not redeemed as provided by law, to receive a deed thereof, and to hold, occupy and enjoy, use, possess, lease and convey the same as fully and as completely as a natural person might or could do.  
Sec. 1.447. - All Moneys to Be Placed in Contingent Fund. 
All moneys received on account of real estate owned by said City, the title to which is vested in the City in pursuance of the provisions of this Chapter, shall be paid into the City Treasury, and placed in the contingent fund.  
Sec. 1.448. - Treasurer to File List of Unpaid Assessments. 
Ninety (90) days after any assessment roll has been placed in the hands of the City Treasurer for collection, without further time shall have been granted to him or her to make collections of assessments on such assessment roll by resolution of the City Commission passed to such effect and duly entered upon the minutes, and at the expiration of such further time, if granted, he or she shall file in his or her office a complete list of real estate upon which the assessments have not been paid or collected, and describe such real estate, and give the amount of the assessment, together with the collection fees, interest and penalties as added upon each parcel; and he or she shall annex thereto a certificate substantially in the following form: "I hereby certify that the above list contains a true and accurate statement of each parcel of real estate, and the assessment and collection fees, interest and penalties thereon remaining unpaid," and the improvement or work on account of which such assessment was made shall be named in such certificate.  
Sec. 1.449. - Disposition, Sale and Redemption to Be Made Under State Law. 
All lands which have been or may hereafter be returned as delinquent for assessments for public or special improvements, after their return to the City Manager as provided for in Chapter 9, Article 4, shall be subject to disposition, sale and redemption for the enforcement and collection of such assessment liens, in the manner as near as may be, and subject to the change of procedure provided in this Chapter, provided under the general State law for the enforcement of the collection of State and County taxes.  
Sec. 1.450. - List of Delinquents to Be Referred to City Attorney. 
Whenever the City Commission shall by resolution determine to enforce the collection of an assessment or assessments by sale of the property subject to lien for such assessments, and the time for the collection of same by the City Treasurer and any extension of same has elapsed, and the City Treasurer has made and certified to the list or lists of delinquents as required herein, the City Commission shall by resolution refer the matter to the City Attorney to take such further proceedings under the State law and this Chapter as may be necessary to enforce such sale or sales, and thereupon the City Treasurer shall prepare the schedules and assessment records hereinafter mentioned in such form and manner as directed and advised by the City Attorney for use in the proceedings to be taken for said sales and in the making of said sales.  
Sec. 1.451. - Petition for Sale. 
The City Attorney shall thereupon file a petition addressed to the Circuit Court of the County of Kent, which shall contain, by reference, the list of property, as required by the foregoing Sections of this Chapter, upon which assessments for public or special improvements have remained delinquent for more than thirty (30) days. Said lists shall show the total amount of delinquent assessments and collection fees, with interest computed thereon to ninety (90) days from the filing of said petition, and there shall be included with and added to said total amount of delinquent assessments upon each description, one dollar ($1.00) for expenses. 
Such petition shall pray a decree in favor of the City of Grand Rapids against said land for the payment of the several amounts specified therein, and in default thereof that such lands be sold. It shall be signed by the City Attorney and need not be otherwise verified, and shall seek to enforce the lien for such assessments, interest and charges, averring their validity, and that they have not been paid, and praying for a sale to pay such lien. Lands heretofore or hereafter bid off in the name of the City of Grand Rapids and thus held, and on which assessments have been made subsequent to the tax or assessment for which such lands were sold to the City, may be included in such petition for all such subsequent assessments which have remained unpaid for more than thirty (30) days after they were so returned as delinquent. The petition shall be substantially bound or fastened with the list of lands and assessments annexed following the same therein. It shall be ruled with appropriate columns, one (1) containing a description of the lands with column for the total amount of assessment, interest and charges claimed due on each parcel of land opposite thereto; also with blank columns with the following headings: "Amount Decreed Against Lands"; "Interest in Each Parcel Sold"; "Name of Purchaser"; "Address of Purchaser"; "Number of Certificate"; "Remarks." The City Attorney may add such other columns as he or she may find necessary. The word "petition" shall be construed to include the lists annexed thereto by reference. Said records shall be called "Assessment Record." Parts of descriptions of land upon which assessments are paid before sale, or which are withheld from sale, the amount of assessments, interest and charges decreed against lands, special orders made by the court relating to any parcel of land or any assessment, the interest in each parcel of land sold, the name of each purchaser and his or her address, and the number of certificates of sale shall be entered in said record opposite the description of land affected thereby. The City Attorney is hereby empowered to include in such petition any lands returned as delinquent for assessments for public or special improvements.
