Wherever the word "assessment" occurs in this Chapter, unless it clearly appears otherwise, it shall be deemed to mean the tax or assessment levied by the City Assessors as the amount of the benefit or advantage accruing to the land by reason of a public or special improvement.  
Sec. 1.452. - Notice of Sale. 
As soon as said petition and lists or schedules annexed shall be filed with the Kent County Clerk, and not less than thirty (30) days before the day of any sale thereunder the City Treasurer shall notify the owner or owners so far as possible, of each piece or parcel of property whose assessments are then delinquent and subject to sale, by mailing to the last known address of such owner or owners a notice in substantially the following form: Sir—You are hereby notified that sale of lands for delinquent assessments for the improvement of (construction of) ___________ will be made at the office of the City Treasurer on the ________ day of 19_____. A list of such lands with the amount of assessment, interest and charges is published in ___________ a newspaper published at the City of Grand Rapids, Michigan. Whether you are uncertain of having paid your assessment or not, you should avoid the possibility of sale by procuring a copy of such paper and examining the descriptions to ascertain if your lands are to be sold. Payment or redemption may be made of the City Treasurer at any time prior to the day of the sale. 
	Yours, etc., 
_____ 
 
Provided, that failure to serve or receive such notice shall not invalidate the proceedings taken under the City Attorney's petition and decree of the Kent County Circuit Court, in foreclosure and sale of the lands for said assessment or assessments.  
Sec. 1.453. - Order for Sale of Lands. 
It shall be the duty of the Circuit Court Judge, on the presentation of said petition, to make an order in substantially the form herein described, which order when so made and signed by the said Judge shall be countersigned by the Clerk of said court, and recorded by him or her in the proper books of his or her office. Said order shall be substantially in the following form: 
STATE OF MICHIGAN  ) 
               ss. 
County of Kent      ) 
The Circuit Court of Kent County. 
In the matter of the petition of ___________, City Attorney of the City of Grand Rapids, for and in behalf of said City of Grand Rapids, for the sale of certain lands for assessments for public or special improvements assessed thereon; on reading and filing the petition of the City Attorney of the City of Grand Rapids, praying for a decree in favor of the City of Grand Rapids, against each parcel of land therein described, for the amounts therein specified, claimed to be due for assessments, interest and charges on each such parcel of land, and that such lands be sold for the amounts so claimed by the City of Grand Rapids. It is ordered that said petition will be brought on for hearing and decree before said court at the Circuit Court rooms in the County building in the City of Grand Rapids, Kent County, Michigan, on the ________ day of ________, A.D., 19___ at the opening of Court on said day, and that all persons interested in such lands or any part thereof, desiring to contest the lien claimed thereon by the City of Grand Rapids, for such assessments, interest and charges, or any part thereof, shall appear in said Court, and file with the Clerk thereof their objections thereto, on or before the day last aforesaid, and that in default thereof the same will be taken as confessed, and a decree will be taken and entered as prayed for in said petition. And it is further ordered that in pursuance of said decree the lands described in said petition for which a decree of sale shall be made, will be sold for the several assessments, interest and charges thereon as determined by such decree, on the ________ day of ________ A.D. 19___, beginning at 10:00 a.m. on the day or days subsequent thereto, as may be necessary to complete the sale of said lands, and of each and every parcel thereof, at the office of the City Treasurer, or at such convenient place as shall be selected by him or her in the City Hall in said City of Grand Rapids; and that the sale then and there made will be a public sale, and each parcel described in the decree shall be separately exposed for sale for the total assessments, interest and charges, and the sale shall be made to the person paying the full amount charged against such parcel, and accepting a conveyance of the smallest undivided fee simple interest therein; or, if no person will pay the assessment, interest and charges and take a conveyance of less than the entire thereof, then the whole parcel shall be offered and sold. If any parcel of land cannot be sold for the assessment, interest and charges, such parcel shall be passed over for the time being, and shall, before the close of the sale, be reoffered, and if, on such second offer, or during such sale, the same cannot be sold for the amount of aforesaid, the City Treasurer shall bid off the same in the name of the City of Grand Rapids. 
Witness the Hon. ___________ Circuit Judge, Kent County, Michigan, and the Seal of said Court.  
Sec. 1.454. - Publication of Order and Petition. 
The City Attorney shall cause a copy of said order and a copy of said petition to be published at least once in each week for three (3) successive weeks next prior to the time fixed for the hearing thereof, in the official City newspaper published and circulated in the City of Grand Rapids. Provided, in such petition it shall be sufficient to print against each parcel the total amount of assessment, interest and charges due on each. The proprietor of such paper shall furnish the City Attorney with two (2) copies of each issue of said paper, and said City Attorney shall carefully examine the notices published and see that they are correct. Any person familiar with the facts may make an affidavit as to the publication required. The publication of the order and petition aforesaid shall be equivalent to a personal service of notice on all persons who are interested in the lands specified in such petition, of the filing thereof, of all proceedings thereon, and of the sale of the lands under the decree, and shall give the court jurisdiction to hear such petition, determine all questions arising thereon, and to decree the sale of such lands for the payment of all assessments, interest and charges thereon, the same as if personal service of summons was had on each person interested in such lands. Proof of the publication of the order and petition herein required shall be filed in the office of the Clerk of said court before any final order is made. Any person having any interest in the lands or any portion thereof included or referred to in said petition desiring to contest the validity of any assessment shall file in writing his or her objections thereto with the Clerk of said court, and serve a copy thereof on the City Attorney on or before the day fixed in said notice for the hearing of such petition, and shall not be allowed to make any objections not therein specified. If on the day fixed in such notice for the hearing of such petition or on the day following that day, it shall be made to appear to the court that any person has been prevented from filing his or her objection to any tax without any fault on his or her part such further time may be granted for that purpose as may seem proper, not exceeding five (5) days. The court shall give precedence to the hearing of such petition over all other business, shall examine, consider and determine the matters therein stated and objections made, in a summary manner without other pleadings, and make final decree thereon as the right of the case may be. The taxes specified in the petition shall be presumed to be legal and a decree be made thereof unless the contrary is proven. Evidence shall be taken in open court. All oral testimony shall, at the request of any person interested, be taken in shorthand by the court reporter. The court may make such orders from time to time as may be necessary to facilitate the proceedings, and shall decide all questions as to the admissibility of evidence, and the decisions so made shall be final and not subject to review or appeal. If the lands of two (2) or more persons have been assessed together, the court may, if practicable, separate the same and apportion to each parcel its just proportion of the taxes, interest and charges. If any tax shall be found illegal, such part shall be set aside and the remaining tax shall be decreed valid. The total amount of assessments, interest and charges, as fixed by the court, shall be entered by the Clerk of Court opposite each parcel of land in the column of said record under the heading, "Amount decreed against lands." If the court shall make any order setting aside the assessment on any parcel of land, or any part thereof, or any special order relating to any particular parcel of land, or taxes thereon, a brief entry of such order shall be made upon said record opposite such land or tax, which shall be signed by the Judge of the court, either by his or her full name or initials, and such entry shall have the same effect as if made and entered as a part of the final decree. At least ten (10) days prior to the time fixed for the sale of such lands, the court shall make a final decree in favor of the City of Grand Rapids for such assessment, interest and charges as shall be valid, and determine the total amount thereof chargeable against each parcel of land, and shall order and decree that such several parcels of land, or so much of each as may be necessary to satisfy the amount fixed by such decree, shall severally be sold as the law directs. Such decree shall be considered as a several decree in favor of the City of Grand Rapids against each parcel of land for each tax included therein, and to avoid prolixity the decree may refer to the petition and by such reference the same shall be considered a part of such decree. The court may decree such costs against a person contesting any tax as may be equitable, if the assessment or any part thereof which remains unpaid, be adjudged valid. 
(Ord. No. 72-58, 8-1-72)  
Sec. 1.455. - Form of Decree. 
Such final decree shall be entered in the chancery record for recording decrees of such court, have the usual caption for decrees, and shall be substantially in the following form: 
STATE OF MICHIGAN 
The Circuit Court for the County of Kent 
At a session of said court held at the Court Room in the County Building in the City of Grand Rapids, on the ________ day of ________ A.D., 19___ Present: Hon. ___________ Circuit Judge. 
In the matter of the petition of ___________ City Attorney of the City of Grand Rapids, for and in behalf of said City, for the sale of certain lands for assessments for public or special improvements assessed thereon: 
The said petition and the matters therein stated, and the objections filed to certain taxes therein claimed (if any such objections are filed) came on to be heard and proof of the due publication of the order of hearing, and of said petition having been made and filed, and after hearing all parties interested therein: It is ordered, adjudged and decreed that the amount of assessments, interest, collection fee, and charges set down in the column headed "Amount decreed against lands" in the Assessment Record of which said petition forms a part, are valid, and decree is made in favor of the City of Grand Rapids therefor against each parcel of said land for the amount set down in said column opposite to such parcel. It is further ordered, adjudged and decreed that said several parcels of land, or such interest therein as may be necessary to satisfy the amount herein decreed against the same, shall be severally sold as the law directs on the ________ day of ________ A.D., 19___, beginning at 10:00 a.m. on said day, or on the day or days subsequent thereto as may be necessary to complete the sale of said lands and of each and every parcel thereof, at the office of the City Treasurer, or at such convenient place in the City Hall of said City as shall be selected by him or her. It is further adjudged and decreed that the petition and attached schedule and the several special orders made by this court, and entered on said Assessment Record, are made a part hereof, with the same effect as if entered herein. 
              ___________ 
              Circuit Judge 
(Countersigned) 
___________ Clerk. 
If costs are adjudged against any person contesting a tax, the decree therefor shall be in proper form and execution awarded. The decree shall be signed by the Judge and countersigned by the Clerk. After the entry of such decree, the Clerk of said court shall make a certified copy thereof, and annex the same to the assessment record. He or she shall thereupon deliver such tax record to the City Treasurer, in whose office the same shall remain. If from any cause the hearing on said petition is not had on the day fixed in the notice therefor, the same shall stand continued from day to day during the term without the entry of any order of continuance, until disposed of, and if it shall for any reason be found impracticable to hear and determine the objections to all of the taxes specified in such petition within the time herein fixed for that purpose, then and in that case the court shall, within the time herein named, make a final decree as to all taxes to which no objections have been filed, and also those to which objections have been filed, which the court has then heard and passed upon. Such decrees shall be signed and recorded as hereinbefore provided. The court shall proceed with the consideration of the remaining assessments embraced in such petition, and objections thereto, and as soon as practicable dispose of the same by one (1) or more decrees and in such form as the court may determine, which shall be entered in the chancery record of decrees of such court, and the same shall describe the lands and specify the total amount of assessments, interest and charges on each parcel thereof. The Clerk shall immediately thereafter deliver to the City Treasurer a certified copy of such decree, to be kept and used as hereinbefore provided. Such copy of decree shall be annexed to the assessment record and shall thereby become a part thereof. If from any cause no decree shall be made on such petition as to the assessments therein named, or any part thereof, the City Attorney shall, as soon as practicable, file a new petition for decree and sale, and proceedings thereon shall be the same and a decree and sale made as herein provided. 
In case a decree is given in favor of the validity of any disputed assessment and the person contesting its validity desires to appeal to an appellate court, he or she shall be allowed to do so on paying the amount of the decree to the City Treasurer, within ten (10) days after the date of such decree, who shall retain the same until the decision of the appellate court, and pay the same to the party interested, if such assessment is held invalid; if held valid, then such money shall be credited to the proper fund. By such payment the land in question shall be discharged from the lien of the assessment. In case the decision is against the validity of any assessment, either the City Treasurer or the City Attorney shall have a right to direct an appeal therefrom on behalf of the City, but there shall be no sale for the assessment held invalid, until such decision has been reversed or modified by the appellate court. 
The proceedings where the validity of any assessment is in dispute shall, where no other provision is made herein, follow the ordinary chancery practice and the court may allow amendments as in ordinary cases. Notice shall be given of all appeals and such appeal shall be claimed, entered and bond for costs given, within twenty (20) days after the making and entering of the decree. When the appeal is taken in behalf of the City no bond shall be required. The Judge shall, at the request of either party and on due notice, settle in proper form a case containing so much of the record and proceedings as may be necessary to the due understanding thereof by the appellate court, and if appeal shall be taken, such case shall be transmitted to such court. An appeal as to the assessment on any parcel shall not delay or affect the proceedings for the sale of any land on which there has been no appeal.  
Sec. 1.456. - Lands Not Included in Decree. 
If for any reason the City Treasurer shall fail to offer the lands lying therein and included in the decree for sale for delinquent assessments thereon, then so many of such lands so included in such decree as shall not be so offered for sale, shall be considered and treated as if bid off to the City by the City Treasurer, and shall be subject to redemption and sale in the same manner and within the same time as may be provided by law in the case of lands actually bid off for the City as provided in this Chapter. All lands bid off for the City as provided in this Section, shall continue liable to be taxed and assessed in the same manner as if not held as belonging to the City, and all such assessments shall be a charge and lien upon such lands as in case of other tax lands, except as hereinafter provided.  
Sec. 1.457. - Procedure to Be Under Act 206 of P.A. 1893. 
All proceedings taken in the filing of said petition and the subsequent steps therein up to and including the sale of the lands for the different assessments and the execution and delivery of deeds therefor and the redemption thereof shall conform as far as may be to Act. No. 206 of the Public Acts of 1893 and the amendments thereto for the assessment and collection of taxes and the same, so far as may be necessary and is applicable, is hereby made a part of this Chapter.  
Sec. 1.458. - Rules of Sale. 
At the date specified by the said court in its order for the sale of said lands for delinquent assessments beginning at 10:00 a.m., the City Treasurer shall commence the sale of lands mentioned in the decree upon which the amounts charged shall not have been paid, and shall continue the same from day to day, Sundays and legal holidays excepted, until so much of each parcel shall have been sold as shall be sufficient to pay such amounts. Each parcel described in the decree shall be separately exposed for sale for the total assessments, interest and charges, and the sale shall be made to the person paying the full amount charged against such parcel, and accepting a conveyance of the smallest undivided fee simple interest therein. No greater interest in any parcel shall be sold than is sufficient to pay the amount of the assessments and charges and take a conveyance of less than the entire thereof, then the whole parcel shall be offered and sold. The sale shall be at the City of Grand Rapids, at the office of, or at such convenient place in the City Hall as shall be selected by the City Treasurer, and shall be subject to the taxes assessed subsequent to assessment included in the decree. The City Treasurer may, in his or her discretion, require immediate payment of any person to whom any parcel of such land may be struck off, and in all cases where payment is not made in twenty-four (24) hours after sale, he or she shall declare the bid cancelled and sell the land again. Any subsequent bid of such person made at the sale may be disregarded by the Treasurer. If any parcel of land cannot be sold for assessments, interest and charges, such parcel shall be passed over for the time being, and shall, on the succeeding day, or before the close of the sale, be reoffered; and if, on such second offer, or during such sale, the same cannot be sold for the amount aforesaid, the City Treasurer shall bid off the same in the name of the City. And in such case the assessments on the lands so bid off to the City, and the interest and charges thereon, shall remain a lien upon said lands, and any person or persons may thereafter purchase such lands of the City. The City Treasurer shall enter in the proper columns of the assessment record the interest in lands sold, the name and post office address of each purchaser opposite each parcel of land sold, and the word "City" opposite each parcel bid off in the name of the City. Certificates shall be given to each purchaser of the lands and interest bid off by him or her, showing the assessment for which he or she has purchased, and also the amount thereof, and of all charges paid by him or her at the time of such purchase, stating that he or she will be entitled to a deed after the period of redemption provided for in this Chapter has expired, and that if the sale is not confirmed the money will be returned. As soon as possible after the conclusion of any sale, and within twenty (20) days after the day named in the notice for the commencement thereof, the City Treasurer shall make and file with the Clerk of the Court a report of such sale, therein referring to the assessment record for the particulars thereof. All sales shall stand confirmed, subject to the right of redemption provided for herein, unless objections thereto are filed within eight (8) days after the time limited for filing such report, without the entry of an order or further notice. The practice with reference to setting aside such sale shall be the same, so far as applicable, as in a sale in equity on the foreclosure of mortgages. Provided, no sale shall be set aside for inadequacy of price, except upon payment of the amount bid upon such sale, with interest and costs. Provided further, that no sale shall be set aside after confirmation, except in cases where the assessments were paid, or the property was exempt from assessment. In such cases the owner of such lands may move the court at any time within one (1) year after he or she shall have notice of such sale, to set the same aside, and the court may so order upon such terms as may be just. All lands bid off in the name of the City shall continue liable to be taxed in the same manner as if they were not the property of the City except as hereinafter provided. If from any cause the lands, or any parcel thereof, decreed for sale shall not be sold as advertised, it shall be the duty of the City Attorney to cause sale to be made at such other time as he or she may fix for that purpose, of which notice shall be published at least four (4) weeks prior to such day, and such notice shall contain a description of the lands and the amount claimed thereon, as hereinbefore provided in the first instance. The sale and all proceedings thereon shall be the same as if made on the first day fixed therefor; provided, that no sales of any property for any such assessments upon which the State of Michigan or City of Grand Rapids holds a tax lien shall be made to any person without the payment of all such tax liens. All sales made in contravention of this requirement shall be void. The City Treasurer shall receive on such sale only such funds as shall be receivable at the State Treasury. All bids made at any sale of real estate as provided for in this Chapter shall be deemed to be made subject to the provisions thereof.  
Sec. 1.459. - Form of Certificate. 
At the sale aforesaid the City Treasurer shall give to the purchasers, on the payment of the bids, a separate certificate in writing for each parcel, describing the lands purchased and the amount paid therefor, the name of the person to whom the same was issued, the number, date and amount of each certificate, and such certificate shall be regularly numbered and entered in the book kept for that purpose and designated as the assessment record. Such certificate shall be in substantially the following form: 
STATE OF MICHIGAN,  ) 
                ss. 
County of Kent.       ) 
City of Grand Rapids. 
City Treasurer's Office ________ A.D. 19___ 
I, ___________ City Treasurer of the City of Grand Rapids, in said State, do hereby certify that I did, at public auction, pursuant to notice given as by law required, on this ________ day of ________ A.D. 19___ sell to ___________ of ___________ the lands herein described for the sum of _____ dollars and _____ cents, said sum being the amount due and unpaid for assessment, interest and charges on said lands for the ___________ that the said ___________ his or her heirs or assigns, will, if said sale stands confirmed, be entitled to a deed of conveyance of said lands, after one (1) year from ________ unless sooner redeemed from such sale according to law. Said lands are described as follows, with the sum for which they were sold set opposite each description, that is to say: (Here insert description, and the amount bid therefor.) 
             ___________ 
             City Treasurer.  
Sec. 1.460. - Deed. 
On presentation of such certificate of sale to the City Comptroller or his or her deputy after the expiration of the time provided by law for the redemption of land sold as aforesaid, the Mayor and City Comptroller shall execute and deliver to the purchaser, his or her heirs or assigns, a deed of the land therein described, unless the sale thereof shall have been redeemed or annulled as by law provided, which deed shall be entitled to record in the office of the Register of Deeds of the proper County, in the same manner and with like effect as other deeds duly witnessed, acknowledged and certified. Such deeds shall convey an absolute title to the land sold, and be conclusive evidence of title, in fee, in the grantee, subject, however, to all taxes assessed and levied on such lands subsequent to the taxes for which the same was bid off. The courts may, on application, put the purchaser in possession of the premises by writs of assistance. In the case of the loss of such certificate of sale, the purchaser or his or her legal representatives or assignee, may file his or her affidavit of such loss, and that he or she was at the time of such loss the bona fide and legal holder thereof; and the Mayor and City Comptroller shall thereupon execute, as aforesaid, a deed for the lands described in such certificate, if the same shall not have been redeemed, in the same manner as though it had been presented and surrendered; and if the same shall have been redeemed on the presentation of such affidavit, the money shall be paid to such person in the same manner as though the certificate of sale had been surrendered. Any person who shall make an affidavit as above required, or concerning any other matter which may be filed in the office of the City Comptroller shall be liable to the penalties of perjury for any false statement made in such affidavit with intent to defraud, upon conviction thereof before a court having jurisdiction of the offense.  
Sec. 1.461. - Procedure if Sale Is Set Aside. 
No sale of any lands or deed made by the Mayor and City Comptroller under the provisions of this Chapter shall be set aside or annulled by any court of this State after the purchaser, his or her heirs or assigns have been in actual and undisputed possession of such lands so sold or conveyed for a period of five (5) years from the date of such purchase or deed. Whenever any sale made under this Chapter is set aside by any court in a time less than five (5) years, the court shall determine and decree the value of improvements made by the purchaser, if he or she has been in possession, and give judgment therefor, and issue execution to collect the same of the claimant before putting him or her in possession. If a sale made under this Chapter is set aside by any court, the City shall refund to the purchaser the amount paid at the time of the sale, with interest thereon at the rate of five (5) percent per annum from the time of the purchase to the time when said sale was set aside or cancelled.  
Sec. 1.462. - Right to Recover on Failure to Give Notice. 
The right to recover possession of any land, or to a refunding of the amount paid, by any person claiming through or under any deed executed by the Mayor and Comptroller or by virtue of a certificate of purchase issued under the provisions of this Chapter shall be forever barred by the actual, open and continuous possession of any person claiming such land adversely to such deed, or certificate of purchase, for the period of five (5) years after the purchaser of such title, his or her heirs or assigns, is entitled to a deed thereof, or by failure of such purchaser, his or her heirs or assigns, to give the notice or notices required by this Chapter for a reconveyance of the premises within the above specified period of five (5) years. In case of such failure to give the required notice for reconveyance within the period of five (5) years from the date such purchaser, his or her heirs or assigns shall become entitled to a deed to be issued by the Mayor and Comptroller, the person or persons claiming title under assessment, deed or certificate of purchase shall be forever barred from asserting such title or claiming a lien on the land by reason of such purchase; and such purchaser, his or her heirs or assigns shall not thereafter be entitled to a refunding of the amount paid as a condition of the purchase of such title by reason of any defect, irregularity, invalidity, or any cause whatever affecting the assessments or the sale of the lands for such lien.  
Sec. 1.463. - May Redeem in One Year. 
Any person owning any of the lands sold as aforesaid, or any interest therein, may, at any time within one (1) year after the date of such sale, redeem any parcel of such lands, or any part or interest in such lands, by showing to the satisfaction of the City Treasurer that he or she owns only that part or interest in the same which he or she proposes to redeem, by paying to the City Treasurer the amount of the sale of the parcel of land, or any portion thereof wished to be redeemed, and interest thereon from the date of such sale. Upon the payment of the redemption money and interest thereon at one (1) percent per month or fraction thereof to the City Treasurer as aforesaid, he or she shall issue a redemption certificate in such form as may be prescribed by the City Attorney, which certificate shall be delivered to the person making such redemption payment. The City Treasurer shall also make a minute of such redemption certificate in the assessment record book kept in his or her office, with the name of the payee, the date and the amount paid. Such certificate or the duplicate, and the entry thereof, shall be evidence of such redemption payment in the courts of this State.  
Sec. 1.464. - Irregularities in Sale or Assessment. 
The City Treasurer shall withhold a conveyance of lands sold on account of nonpayment of assessments thereon, and shall, on demand, cause the money paid therefor to be refunded to the purchaser with interest thereon at five (5) percent per annum if he or she shall discover before a conveyance of said lands is executed and delivered: 
(1)  That the land so sold was not subject to assessment at the date of the assessment for which it was sold; or 
(2)  That the assessment had been paid to the proper officer within the time limited by law for the payment or redemption thereof; or 
(3)  That such sale was in contravention of any of the provisions of this Chapter; or 
(4)  That a certificate that no assessments were charged against said lands has been given by the proper officer within the time limited by law for the payment or redemption thereof. 
Provided, that in the last mentioned case the person in whose behalf such certificate was given shall, at the time of presenting such certificate to the City Treasurer, pay to the City Treasurer all taxes and charges due to the City upon such lands at the time such certificate was issued. If the discovery is not made until after the conveyance has been executed and delivered, a certificate of error may be issued in proper form for record; and the deed, if not recorded, shall be surrendered when the purchase money is refunded. If the deed has been recorded the money shall be refunded on a recorded release from the holder of the tax deed. Provided, further, that the conveyance of such lands shall not be withheld or a certificate of error issued after a period of five (5) years from the date of sale thereof, except for the reasons, first, that the land described therein was not subject to assessment at the time of the assessment for which it was sold; or, second, that the assessment had been paid to the proper officer within the time limited by law for the payment or redemption thereof.  
Sec. 1.465. - Correction of Imperfect or Erroneous Descriptions. 
Whenever the City Commission shall discover that any real estate on which any tax or assessment remains unpaid has been so imperfectly or erroneously described that the same cannot in its opinion be located with certainty, or that the sale thereof would not convey to the purchaser a valid title to the real estate intended to be charged with such assessment by reason of the imperfect or erroneous description thereof, the City Commission shall by an order entered in its minutes, accurately describe such real estate intended to be charged with such tax or assessment, and shall direct the City Treasurer to correct the assessment roll on file in his or her office containing such imperfect or erroneous description so as to make it correspond with the accurate description contained in said order of the City Commission, and thereupon all copies of such assessment roll required by the provisions of this Chapter to be made to correspond therewith as corrected. Provided, that no such imperfect or erroneous description shall be corrected until the owner of the real estate shall be notified of such intended correction by a printed or written, or partly printed and partly written notice, either served upon him or her personally, or by leaving the same at his or her place of abode with some suitable person of proper age and discretion, at least ten (10) days before such correction shall be made. In case such owner is a nonresident of the City, such notice shall be published in one (1) of the newspapers of the City at least ten (10) days before such correction shall be made.  
Sec. 1.466. - Errors Shall Not Defeat Collection. 
No mistake or error in the proceedings in regard to the opening or improvement of streets, avenues, public ways or alleys or in the construction of sewers, or in the assessment or collection of costs or expenses thereof, or in the proceedings for the assessment or collection of assessments for any special improvements by reason of the proceedings therefor not being had within the time required by law, or the property having been assessed to the wrong owner, or any irregularity, informality or omission or want of any form or substance in the proceedings that does not prejudice the property rights of the person whose property is taxed, shall defeat the City in the collection thereof, but any such errors may be corrected on equitable principles under the direction of the City Commission, if discovered before suit is brought thereon, or by the court after suit is instituted, and the equitable amount due the City may be enforced as though no such error has occurred. All proceedings in assessing and levying taxes for special improvements and the sale and conveyance of land thereunder shall be presumed by all courts of this State to be legal until the contrary is affirmatively shown. The absence of any record of any proceeding or proceedings, or the omission of any mention in any record of any vote or proceeding, or of mention of any matter in any statement or certificate that should appear therein, under the provisions of this Chapter or of any law of this State shall not affect the validity of said proceedings, tax or title depending thereon, provided the fact that such vote or proceedings was had or tax authorized is shown by any other record, statement or certificate made evidence by the terms of this Chapter, or any other law of this State. No special tax or proceedings leading up to such tax or sale of property for said tax shall be rendered or held invalid by showing that any record, statement, certificate, affidavit, paper or return, cannot be found in the proper office; and unless the contrary is affirmatively shown, the presumption shall be that such record was made and such certificate, statement, affidavit, paper or return was duly made and filed.  
Sec. 1.467. - Possession of Premises. 
The Kent County Circuit Court may, on application, put the purchaser of any lands sold under the provisions of this Chapter in possession of the premises by writs of assistance; this provision shall also include the City of Grand Rapids in all cases where it shall acquire title under this Chapter.  
Sec. 1.468. - Writ of Assistance. 
No writ of assistance or other process for possession of any land, the title of which has been obtained under and in pursuance of any sale made under this Chapter, shall be issued until six (6) months after there shall have been filed with the County Clerk of the County where the land is situated, a return by the Sheriff of said County showing that he or she has made personal service of a notice, or proof of substituted service thereof, as hereinafter provided, upon the person or persons appearing by the records in the office of the Register of Deeds of said County to be the last grantee or grantees in the regular chain of title of such lands, or of any interest therein, at the date of the delivery of such notice to the Sheriff for service, and upon the person or persons, if any there be, in the actual open possession of such lands at the date aforesaid, and upon the grantee or grantees under any tax deed issued for the latest year's taxes then appearing of record in said registry of deeds, and upon the mortgagee of mortgagees named in all undischarged recorded mortgages or any assignee or assignees thereof of record at the date aforesaid, and upon the holder of record of all undischarged recorded liens, which shall be substantially in the following form: 
To the owner or owners of any and all interests in, or liens upon the land herein described: 
Take Notice, That sale has been lawfully made of the following described land for unpaid assessments thereon, and that the undersigned has title thereto under deed or deeds issued therefor, and that you are entitled to a reconveyance thereof at any time within six (6) months after return of service of this notice, upon payment to the undersigned, or to the County Clerk of the County in which the lands lie, of all sums paid upon such purchase, together with one hundred (100) per centum additional thereto and the fees of the Sheriff for the service or cost of publication of this notice, to be computed as upon personal service of a declaration as commencement of suit, and the further sum of five dollars ($5.00) for each description without other additional costs or charges. If payment as aforesaid is not made, the undersigned will institute proceedings for possession of the land. 
Description _____ 
assessment for _____ 
Place of business _____ 
Provided, that if the grantee or grantees, or the person or persons holding the interest in said lands as aforesaid shall be residents of any County of the State other than the County of Kent, then such return as to such person shall be made by the Sheriff of the County where such person or persons reside, or may be found. Provide further, that if the person or persons entitled to such notice, or any of them, shall be nonresidents of this State, if from the said record aforesaid, or from inquiry, the Sheriff can obtain the post office address of such person or persons, or if said addresses be known to him or her, he or she shall either send to such nonresident person or persons a copy of said notice be registered letter, and return the receipt or receipts of the postmaster received for said letter or letters with his or her return to the County Clerk's office; or said Sheriff shall cause to be served personally on such person or persons aforesaid a copy of the said notice, and whenever such notice shall be personally served outside of this State, proof of such service shall be made by the affidavit of the person who shall serve the same, made before a Justice of the Peace or Notary Public, and when such affidavit shall be made outside this State, it shall have attached thereto the certificate of the Clerk of the Court of Record, certifying to the official character of the Justice or Notary and the genuineness of his or her signature to the jurat of the affidavit, and such Sheriff shall return the said proof of personal service with his or her return to the County Clerk's office. Provided further, that if any person entitled to notice as hereinbefore provided is dead, or if his or her estate shall be under control of a trustee or guardian, then, and in such case, notice as hereinbefore provided may be served upon the executor or administrator of said deceased person, or upon his or her heirs, if there be no executor or administrator, or upon the trustee or guardian of any incompetent person, with like effect as if served upon the grantee, mortgagee or assignee. Provided further, that if the Sheriff of the County where any such lands are located shall make a return that after careful inquiry he or she is unable to ascertain the whereabouts or the post office address of the persons upon whom notice may be served as aforesaid, or any of them, then such notice as herein provided for shall be published for four (4) successive weeks, which shall be construed to mean four (4) publications once each week, in some newspaper published and circulating in the City of Grand Rapids, and due proof of publication, by affidavit of the printer or publisher of such newspaper shall be filed with the County Clerk, and shall be in lieu of personal service upon the person or persons whose whereabouts or post office address cannot be ascertained in aforesaid. Provided further, that such service may be made upon any resident of this State by leaving such notice at his or her usual place of residence with some member of his or her family of mature age, and upon any nonresident of this State by delivering such notice to him or her personally in any County of this State where he or she may be found, and return thereof shall be made by the Sheriff of such County. Service in all cases and return thereof may be made by the Under-Sheriff or any Deputy Sheriff with like effect as if made by the Sheriff. Corporations formed under the laws of this State shall be regarded, for the purposes of this Chapter, as residents of the County in this State where their office for the transaction of business therein is, by their Articles, located and service on such corporations may be made on the President, Secretary, Treasurer or general agent of such corporation, or by leaving such notice at the office of such corporation with some person in charge of such office. If the Sheriff of any County in this State in which the office of any such corporation for the transaction of business is, by its Articles, fixed, shall return that upon careful inquiry he or she has been unable to find any such office or any President, Secretary, Treasurer or general agent of such corporation in such County, service of such notice may be made upon such corporation by publication as hereinbefore provided in case of persons whose whereabouts or post office address cannot be ascertained; and this provision shall apply as well as to corporations whose term of corporate existence has expired as to those whose term of existence has not expired. Foreign corporations doing business in this State and having an agent therein appointed to accept service of process as required or as may be required by the laws of this State, shall be regarded, for the purposes of this Chapter, as residents of the County where such agent resides, and service on such corporations may be made on such agent, or by registered letter addressed to such corporations at their home office. The Sheriff shall, in his or her return, state the time when such notice was delivered to him or her for service, and his or her return shall be prima facie evidence of the facts therein stated.  
Sec. 1.469. - Quit Claim. 
Any person having any estate in such lands or any interest therein, either in fee, for life or for years, or any mortgage thereof or assignee of any undischarged mortgage thereon, or the holder of any lien thereon, or any executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of such persons, or any of them, or any person in the actual possession of such lands at the time of such purchase, shall be entitled to receive from the person so claiming under and by virtue of such deed, his or her heirs or assigns, at any time within six (6) months after the filing of return of service or the filing of proof of publication of such notice, as hereinbefore provided, a release and quit claim of all right and interest in such land acquired under such tax deed or deeds, upon payment to him or her or them, or to the Clerk of the County of Kent, of the amount paid upon, such purchase, together with one hundred (100) per centum in addition thereto, and the lawful fees of such personal or substituted service, which fee shall be the same as provided by law for such service of subpoenas or for orders of publication or the cost of such service by registered mail, and the further sum of five dollars ($5.00) for each description, without additional cost or charge; provided, that any person or persons entitled to a release and quit claim under the foregoing provisions of this Section, at any time after the issue of deeds on such lands, or after the purchaser thereof shall be entitled to such deeds, and before service of notice or return thereof as herein provided, shall have the right to redeem such lands from such sale by paying to the purchaser, or his or her grantee, or the Clerk of the County of Kent, on the certificate of the City Treasurer, all sums paid as a condition of such purchase, together with one hundred (100) per centum additional thereto, and the further sum of five dollars ($5.00) for each description. By such payment the said title and any and all such certificates of sale shall become void and of no effect against the lands to be redeemed. 
The Clerk of the County of Kent shall, whenever payment is made to him or her as provided in this Section, at once notify the owner of the assessment title or of any and all such certificates of sale, of the payment so made, and the owner of such title, or of any such certificates of sale, shall forthwith deliver to said Clerk a release and quit claim of all rights acquired by him or her under said purchase, running to the person making such payment, and shall also deliver to said Clerk the deed, certificates or purchase, assessment and tax receipts, and all other conveyances relating to said assessment title or assessment interest before he or she shall be entitled to receive the money paid to said Clerk as herein provided. Upon delivery of such release and quit claim, and of such certificates of purchase and tax and assessment receipts, the Clerk of the County of Kent shall at once pay over to the owner of the assessment title all sums received by him or her for the redemption of the lands therein described. Provided further, that no quit claim or reconveyance made under the provisions of this Section shall be construed to vest in the grantee any title or interest in such lands beyond that already owned by him or her, but such grantee shall be entitled to a lien on such lands, or on such parts thereof or interests therein as are not owned by him or her, for the amount paid, or such portion thereof as is lawfully chargeable to such parts or interests, in addition to the lien or other interest before held by such grantee, which lien may be enforced in any court of competent jurisdiction as in other cases of liens upon lands, with interest thereon at the rate of six (6) per centum per annum from the date of such payment. The Circuit Court of the County of Kent shall have jurisdiction to enforce the liens herein provided for without regard to the amount of such liens. Provided further, that any such application for a writ of assistance shall show that such applicant had complied with the provisions of this act as to the giving of notice, as herein directed, and he or she shall attach to such application a copy of the notice aforesaid, and the return of the Sheriff serving the same or a copy of the proof of publication, or the registry receipt or receipts from the registry department of the post office showing that such notice has been served by registered mail.  
Sec. 1.470. - Possession After Six Months. 
No purchaser under any assessment sale hereafter made shall enter into possession of the land so purchased until six (6) months after he or she has given notice to the party or parties in interest as provided for in the preceding Sections, unless he or she shall have acquired from said parties their title thereto under conveyance from said party or parties of his or her or their interest in said lands. Where the land is vacant and unoccupied and no writ of assistance is needed to put the purchaser into possession thereof, the time for redemption herein provided shall expire six (6) months after delivery of such notice to said party or parties in interest, or date of mailing such notice by registered letter, or of the County where said lands are situated as herein provided. Provided, that if suit or other proceedings is commenced before the expiration of the said six (6) months by the owner of the land so purchased, or one (1) having a redeemable interest therein, to set aside the sale thereof, the purchaser under tax sale or his or her grantee shall not enter into possession of land until the final determination of such suit or other proceeding.  
Sec. 1.471. - Evidence of Ownership. 
If any such grantee or grantees, mortgagee or mortgagees or person or persons so in possession shall fail and neglect to redeem such land within said six (6) months, as provided in the foregoing Sections, at any time after the expiration thereof, the purchaser under such sale or deed may cause to be recorded in the office of the Register of Deeds of the County in which such land is situate, in a record to be provided for that purpose, a copy of said notice and proof of service thereof, duly certified by the County Clerk in whose office the same is filed, and the record thereof shall be prima facie evidence in all courts and tribunals that such purchaser is the owner of said land under said purchase.  
Sec. 1.472. - Barred from Questioning Validity. 
Every person personally served with the notice provided for by this Chapter, and every person lawfully chargeable with such notice by registered mail, as provided for in said Chapter, together with the heirs, executors, administrators or assigns of such persons, who shall refuse or neglect to pay or tender to the purchaser as aforesaid, the sum provided for in this Chapter within the time therein limited, and who shall have neglected within the said six (6) months to commence suit to set aside the said tax deed, shall thereafter be barred from questioning the validity of such assessment title or assessment deed mentioned therein.  
Secs. 1.473—1.500. - Reserved.  
Chapter 11 - PURCHASES, CONTRACTS AND SALES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Tax sales, §§ 1.378, 1.391—1.395; payment of moneys, § 1.146; licensing and regulation, Title VII; consumer protection, Ch. 158. 
 
Sec. 1.501. - Purchasing Agent, General Authority. 
The general authority of the Purchasing Agent shall be pursuant to Title VI, Section 12 of the City Charter of Grand Rapids.  
Sec. 1.502. - Requisitions. 
All requests for purchases shall be by requisition of and approval by the person in charge of any Department, Division, Bureau, Board or Commission for whose benefit the purchase is to be made. The requisition shall designate the Code number of the appropriation authorizing the expenditure for such purchase.  
Sec. 1.503. - Standard Specifications. 
The Purchasing Agent shall have authority to adopt standard specifications from time to time for each class or grade of the various articles, commodities and supplies ordinarily required by the City. The Purchasing Agent shall cause the same to be printed in looseleaf or typewritten form for distribution. Standard specifications shall be drafted so as to procure commodities and supplies of such quality and design as will serve the purpose required and to facilitate the making of bids therefrom. Whenever standard specifications have been adopted for items covered by standard specifications, requisitions shall be made in accordance therewith unless a change therein is necessary. Whenever such change is necessary, the reason therefor shall be stated on the requisition. In advertising for bids, it shall be sufficient to refer to the appropriate standard specification. A bidder may refer to the appropriate item of the standard specifications. The Purchasing Agent may require samples to be furnished with bids.  
Sec. 1.504. - Purchases Authorized. 
(1)  Purchases by the City, sales to the City, or authorizations for the purchase of goods by the City involving expenditures of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or less, the appropriation for which has been approved by the City Commission as part of the annual fiscal process and funds for which are in the City's annual budget, may be made without formal, sealed bidding by the Purchasing Agent, subject to any rules and policies that may be established by the City Commission. 
(2)  The Purchasing Agent may delegate the authority and responsibility to other City employees to obtain price quotations or bids or to make purchases in an amount of up to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for goods not currently covered by a City contract, as long as the employee complies with all applicable provisions of the City Charter and the City Code and with all applicable City rules and policies. The Purchasing Agent may withdraw a delegation previously granted when, in the sole judgment of the Purchasing Agent, it is advisable to do so. The authority delegated under this subsection may be used only by those employees specifically empowered to do so by the City Manager. This Section shall be implemented by a City Commission Policy. 
(Ord. No. 86-62, § 1, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 90-33, § 1, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 9-7-99)  
Sec. 1.505. - Purchases of More Than Ten Thousand Dollars. 
No requisition or purchase of more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be made unless authorized by the City Manager and approved by the City Commission. In case of an emergency, a requisition may be sent to the Purchasing Agent, but no awards shall be made upon any bids until same has been approved by the City Manager and the City Commission. All reasons for the emergency shall be stated on the requisition. 
(Ord. No. 86-62, § 2, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 90-33, § 2, 4-3-90)  
Sec. 1.506. - Purchases on Competitive Bidding. 
For any purchases involving an expenditure of more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), requests for bids shall be advertised in a daily newspaper, which requests shall establish the time and place for opening any bids received. The time for opening of bids shall be not less than ten (10) days from the date of said publication. This requirement may be expedited in cases of immediate need of the materials or services. Two (2) or more publications may be authorized where such has been the general practice of the City. In such cases where publication is not necessary because letters may be sent to all who are known able to bid, the Purchasing Agent may waive publication and send such letters. 
(Ord. No. 86-62, § 3, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 90-33, § 3, 4-3-90)  
Sec. 1.507. - Advertisement for Bids. 
The advertisement for bids shall be prepared by the Purchasing Agent and published in a daily newspaper. Every such advertisement shall specify the place where the bids will be received, the time of opening of same and a brief description of the materials and supplies to be purchased.  
Sec. 1.508. - Bids. 
Each bid shall be in writing on the form as provided by the Purchasing Agent. Each bid shall be signed by the bidder and shall contain the full name of any person or company interested therein. Each bid shall refer to the proposed purchase in the manner as herein specified.  
Sec. 1.509. - Opening of Bids. 
At the time prescribed in the advertisement of opening bids on purchase contracts, the Purchasing Agent shall, at the place as set forth in said advertisement, open all bids and publicly read each bid. All bids submitted after the time as set forth in the advertisement shall be void.  
Sec. 1.510. - Certification of Bids. 
The Purchasing Agent shall tabulate all such bids and purchases and certify them to the City Manager for approval as to the lowest and best bidder.  
Sec. 1.511. - Awarding Contracts. 
The award of the contract or purchase shall be made by the City Manager to the successful bidder and all such awards shall become public records to be signed by the City Manager and the Purchasing Agent.  
Sec. 1.512. - Requisitions between Departments. 
Whenever any Department, Division or any other branch or agency of the City requires service, equipment, materials or supplies from another Department, Division or any other branch or Agency of the City, requisitions may be made for such purpose with the appropriate credits and debits to appropriations. In such cases, no bids shall be required.  
Sec. 1.513. - Municipal Warehouse. 
The Purchasing Agent shall have charge of all storerooms and any general warehouse of the City which may be hereafter established for the storage of materials and supplies. He or she shall keep records of all stocks. He or she shall issue stock on requisitions, charging the stocks issued to such requisitioning unit at the purchase cost. He or she shall perform such other duties in regard to this function as may be necessary.  
Sec. 1.514. - Personal Property Not Needed for Any Municipal Use. 
If any Department, Division, Agency or Commission has personal property not needed, it shall certify such fact to the Purchasing Agent. Unless such property is needed by another branch or agency of the City, it shall be sold by the Purchasing Agent. Where the property involved has a value of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less, no bidding shall be necessary, but the Purchasing Agent shall seek to sell the same for the highest price. If the property is worth more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), it shall be sold to the highest and best bidder in the same manner as for a purchase or by public auction. 
(Ord. No. 69-62, 7-22-69)  
Sec. 1.515. - Emergency Purchases and Contracts. 
In the case of unexpected emergency wherein any delay in purchasing would possibly result in the interruption or detriment to the public service, the requirement for competitive bidding may, upon consent of the City Manager, be waived. Provided, however, that the City Commission shall be apprised of the situation at its next regular meeting. Competitive bidding shall not be required of any contract involving professional services, where the subject matter is of a noncompetitive character, nor in any case where competitive bidding is dispensed with under the provisions of this Chapter.  
Sec. 1.516. - Disqualifications for Bidders. 
No bid shall be accepted from or contract awarded to any person who is in arrears to the City upon debt or contract, or who is defaulter, as security or otherwise upon an obligation to the City, nor who shall in other respects be disqualified according to the provisions of this Code or the Grand Rapids City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 67-65, 12-19-67)  
Sec. 1.517. - Provision Against Discrimination in Contracts. 
(a)  Every contract to which the City is a party shall contain a provision requiring the contractor and his or her subcontractors not to discriminate against any employee or applicant for employment, to be employed in the performance of such contract, with respect to his or her hire, tenure, terms, conditions or privileges of employment, or any matter directly or indirectly related to employment, because of his or her race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry. Breach of this covenant may be regarded as a material breach of the contract as provided for in Act 251 of the Public Acts of 1955, as amended, entitled "Michigan State Fair Employment Practices Act." 
(b)  Every contract to which the City is a party shall contain a provision requiring the contractor and his or her subcontractors not to discriminate against any employee or applicant for employment to be employed in the performance of such contract, with request to his or her hire, tenure, terms, conditions or privileges of employment, or any matter directly or indirectly related to employment, because of his or her age or sex, except where based on a bona fide occupational qualification as provided for in Act 251 of the Public Acts of 1955, as amended, entitled "Michigan State Fair Employment Practices Act." 
(Ord. No. 68-50, 7-23-68) 
Cross reference— Fair employment practices, § 1.150.  
Secs. 1.518—1.530. - Reserved.  
Chapter 13 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 84-34, § 1, adopted and effective May 22, 1984, repealed former Chapter 13, Civil Defense, §§ 1.561—1.583, as amended by Ord. No. 74-31, adopted April 30, 1974. Section 2 of Ord. No. 84-34 added a new Ch. 13 as herein set out. 
Cross reference— Civil emergency, Ch. 161. 
State Law reference— Emergency Preparedness Act, MCL 30.401 et seq., MSA 4.824(11) et seq. 
 
ARTICLE 1. - INTENT AND PURPOSE 
 
Sec. 1.561. - Intent and Purpose. 
It is the intent and purpose of this Chapter to establish an organization that will ensure the complete and efficient utilization of all City resources during periods of emergency and disaster. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.562. - Coordinating Agency. 
The City of Grand Rapids Office of Emergency Management will be the coordinating agency responsible for City-wide emergency preparedness; it will provide the means through which the City Manager, Mayor and City Commission may exercise the authority and discharge the responsibilities vested in them by this Chapter and MCL 30.401 (1990 P.A.5O). 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.563. - Other Agencies; Etc., Not Affected by Chapter. 
This Chapter will not relieve any elected officials or City Departments of the normal responsibilities or authority given by general law or local ordinance, nor will it affect the work of the American Red Cross or other volunteer agencies organized for relief in a natural disaster. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
ARTICLE 2. - DEFINITIONS 
 
Sec. 1.564. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this Chapter, certain words used herein are defined as follows: 
1.  Disaster means an occurrence or imminent threat of widespread or severe damage, injury, or loss of life or property resulting from any natural or man-made cause, including, but not limited to, fire, flood, snow, ice or wind storm, wave action, oil spills, water contamination requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, utility failure, hazardous peacetime radiological incident, major transportation accident, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot, or hostile military or paramilitary action. Riots and other civil disorders are not within the meaning of this term unless they directly result from and are an aggravating element of the disaster. 
2.  District Coordinator means the State Police District Emergency Services Coordinator or his or her authorized representative. 
3.  Emergency Management shall have a broad meaning to include preparations for, and relief from, the affects of natural and manmade disasters as defined herein, and to include civil defense. 
4.  Emergency Management Coordinator shall mean the person appointed to coordinate emergency management within the City of Grand Rapids as prescribed in this Chapter. 
5.  Emergency Management Forces means all disaster relief forces; all agencies of the City government, private and volunteer personnel, public officers and employees; and all other persons or groups of persons having duties or responsibilities under this Chapter, or pursuant to a lawful order or directive authorized by this Chapter. 
6.  Emergency Management Volunteer shall mean any person duly registered and appointed by the Director and assigned to participate in the emergency management activity. 
7.  Emergency Operations Plan means the City of Grand Rapids' Emergency Operations Plan which has been prepared under Section 1.582 of this Chapter to coordinate disaster response and recovery within the City of Grand Rapids. 
8.  State of disaster means a declaration by executive order or proclamation by the Governor under the provisions of MCL 30.401 (1990 P.A. 50), which activities the disaster response and recovery aspects of State, County, local, and interjurisdictional disaster emergency plans, and authorizes the deployment and use of any forces to which the plan or plans apply. 
9.  State of emergency means a declaration by the Mayor pursuant to this Chapter which activates the disaster response and recovery aspects of the City of Grand Rapids' Emergency Operations Plan, and authorizes the deployment and use of any Emergency Management Forces to which the plan applies. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
ARTICLE 3. - ORGANIZATION FOR EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 
 
Sec. 1.565. - Authorized; Responsible Official. 
The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to create an organization to prepare for community disasters utilizing to the fullest extent existing agencies within the City. The City Manager, as administrative head of City government, shall be responsible for the direction of the Emergency Management Forces of the City working with the Emergency Management Coordinator. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.566. - Composition; Disaster Contingency Fund. 
The organization for providing emergency management shall consist of the following: 
(1)  The City of Grand Rapids Office of Emergency Management shall be administered by the Emergency Management Coordinator. Such assistants and other employees as are deemed necessary for the proper functioning of the organization will be assigned as needed. 
(2)  The employees, equipment and facilities of all City Departments, Boards, Institutions and Commissions suitable for, or adaptable to emergency management activities, may be designated as part of the Total Emergency Management Forces. Such designations shall be by the City Manager. 
(3)  A disaster contingency fund in a separate account within the Fire Department budget, set up to cover disaster expenses, and upon exhaustion of the fund, to make the City eligible for State assistance. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.567. - Cooperation and Assistance of Emergency Management Forces. 
All officers and employees of Departments, Commissions, Boards, Institutions and other Agencies of City government designated by the City Manager as Emergency Management Forces shall cooperate with the Emergency Management Coordinator in the formulation of the Emergency Operations Plan, and they shall assist the Coordinator in all matters pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
ARTICLE 4. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT COORDINATOR; DEPUTIES; ASSISTANTS 
 
Sec. 1.568. - Appointment of Coordinator; Qualifications. 
The City Manager shall appoint an Emergency Management Coordinator who shall be a person with the personal attributes, experience and training needed to coordinate the activities of the Agencies, Departments and individuals within the City to protect the public health, safety and welfare during emergency situations and disasters. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.569. - Appointment of Deputy Coordinators. 
Deputy Emergency Management Coordinators shall be appointed by the City Manager to work with the Coordinator on emergency planning matters. Deputy Coordinators shall be selected and shall serve as follows: 
(1)  There shall be one such Deputy Coordinator appointed from each key unit of the emergency management organizational structure, as contained in the Emergency Operations Plan. 
(2)  Deputy Coordinators shall assume the duties of the Coordinator whenever he or she is unavailable during disaster or emergency situations in the order designated by the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.570. - Assistants. 
Assistants shall be designated by the Coordinator and each Deputy Coordinator to assist them with their emergency management responsibilities, as contained in this Chapter and in the Emergency Operations Plan. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
ARTICLE 5. - RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE MAYOR 
 
Sec. 1.571. - Declaring State of Emergency. 
Under the following circumstances, the Mayor may declare a state of emergency exists in the City of Grand Rapids, thereby authorizing the utilization of Emergency Management Forces in accordance with the City of Grand Rapids' Emergency Operations Plan: 
(1)  Whenever, on the basis of information received from authoritative sources, he or she feels that a large-scale disaster or emergency situation in the City is imminent. 
(2)  During any period of disaster in the City, and thereafter as long as he or she shall deem it necessary. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84) 
Cross reference— Civil emergency proclamation, § 9.377.  
Sec. 1.572. - Declaring State of Disaster. 
In the event a disaster occurs which has not yet been declared a state of disaster by the Governor, and the Mayor determines that the situation is beyond the control of the City, the Mayor may request the Governor to declare a state of disaster by instructing the Emergency Services Coordinator to notify the District Coordinator in accordance with the procedures outlined in MCL 30.401 (1990 P.A. 50). 
The Mayor shall comply with the orders of the Director of the Department of State Police on matters of emergency preparedness. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84) 
State Law reference— Notification procedures, MCL 30.414, MSA 4.824(24).  
Sec. 1.573. - Emergency Interim Successors. 
Consistent with the requirements of Act 203 of the Public Acts of 1959, the City Commission shall adopt procedures for designating emergency interim successors during disasters when public officers are unavailable for exercising the powers and discharging the duties of their respective offices. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.574. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 6. - RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE CITY COMMISSION AND CITY MANAGER 
 
Sec. 1.575. - Powers and Authority. 
During a period of declared disaster or local emergency, the City Manager, with the advise and consent of the City Commission, shall have the authority: 
(1)  To assemble and utilize the Emergency Management Forces in accordance with the City of Grand Rapids' Emergency Operations Plan, and prescribe the manner and conditions of the use of such Emergency Management Forces; 
(2)  To appropriate and expend funds, make contracts, obtain and distribute equipment, materials and supplies for disaster purposes; 
(3)  To provide for the health and safety of persons and property, including emergency assistance to the victims of a disaster; 
(4)  To direct and coordinate the development of disaster plans and programs in accordance with the policies and plans established by the appropriate Federal and State agencies and this Chapter; 
(5)  To appoint, employ, remove or provide, with or without compensation, rescue teams, auxiliary fire and police personnel, and other disaster workers; 
(6)  To assign and make available for duty the employees, property or equipment of the City relating to fire fighting; engineering; rescue; health, medical and related services; police; transportation; construction; and similar items or service for disaster relief purposes within or without the physical limits of the City, as ordered by the Governor or the Director of the State Police. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.576. - Waiver of Legal Requirements Authorized in Event of Attack. 
In the event of foreign attack upon the State of Michigan, the City Commission shall have the Authority to waive the procedures and formalities otherwise required by law pertaining to the performance of public work, entering into contracts, the incurring of obligations, the employment of permanent and temporary workers, the utilization of volunteer workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase and distribution with or without compensation of supplies, materials and facilities, and the appropriation and expenditure of public funds. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Secs. 1.577-1.580. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 7. - POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT COORDINATOR 
 
Sec. 1.581. - General Responsibilities. 
The Emergency Management Coordinator shall be responsible, at the direction of the City Manager, for the administration, planning, coordination, and operation of all emergency preparedness activities in the City. He or she shall maintain liaison with the County, State, and Federal authorities, and the authorities of adjacent and nearby political subdivisions so as to ensure the most effective emergency operations. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.582. - Duties. 
The Emergency Management Coordinator's duties shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Development of the City of Grand Rapids' Emergency Operations Plan, and any other appropriate disaster plans, for the immediate use of all of the facilities, equipment, manpower, and other resources of the City for the purpose of minimizing or preventing damage to persons or property; and protecting and restoring to usefulness governmental services and public utilities necessary for the public health, safety and general welfare; 
(2)  Coordinating the recruitment and training of volunteer personnel and agencies to augment the personnel and facilities of the City for emergency purposes; 
(3)  Through public information programs, educating the population as to actions necessary and required for the protection of persons and property in case of a disaster; 
(4)  Conducting practice alerts and exercises to ensure the efficient operation of the City's emergency organization, and to familiarize residents of the City with emergency regulations, procedures and operations; 
(5)  Coordinating the activity of all other public and private agencies engaged in any emergency or disaster relief programs; 
(6)  Negotiating with owners or persons in control of buildings or other property for the use of such buildings or property for emergency or disaster relief purposes, and designating suitable buildings as public shelters; 
(7)  Establishing and maintaining administrative control over a local radiological defense program, to include emergency preparations for both peacetime radiation incidents and international wartime disasters; 
(8)  Coordinating City emergency preparedness activities with the County of Kent, other municipalities located therein, and adjacent counties, and to develop mutual aid arrangements with such other jurisdictions. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
ARTICLE 8. - VOLUNTEERS; APPOINTMENTS; RECORDS 
 
Sec. 1.583. - Volunteers Authorized. 
Each Department, Commission, Board, or other Agency of City government may at any time appoint or authorize the appointment of volunteer citizens to augment the personnel of such City Department, Commission, Board, or Agency in time of emergency. Such individuals shall be enrolled as Emergency Management Volunteers, and shall be subject to the rules and regulations set forth by the respective Department, Commission, Board, or Agency head for such volunteers. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.584. - Appointment by Coordinator; Records. 
The Emergency Management Coordinator may enlist volunteer citizens to form the personnel of an emergency service for which the City has no counterpart, or to temporarily augment personnel of the City engaged in emergency activities, and shall maintain formal records of all such volunteers. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
ARTICLE 9. - RIGHTS OF CITY EMPLOYEES 
 
Sec. 1.585. - Retention of Rights; Privileges; Compensation. 
City employees assigned to duty as part of the Emergency Management Forces pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter shall retain all of the rights, privileges and immunities of City employees, and shall receive the compensation incident to their employment. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
ARTICLE 10. - NO GOVERNMENTAL OR PRIVATE LIABILITY 
 
Sec. 1.586. - Indemnification of City and Its Agents. 
This Chapter is an exercise by the City of its governmental functions for the protection of the public health, safety and general welfare. As such, neither the City nor agents and representatives of the City, nor any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, nor Trustee, nor any of the agents thereof acting in good faith carrying out, complying with, or attempting to comply with this Chapter shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons or property as a result of said activity, except as may be provided pursuant to State law. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.587. - Persons in Control of Real Estate Used by City Not to Be Liable. 
Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants the City the right to inspect, designate and use the whole or any part of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during a disaster or during an authorized practice disaster exercise, shall not be civilly liable for the death of, or injury to, any person on or about such real estate or about such real estate or premises under such license, privilege or other permission, or for loss of, or damage to, the property of such person. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
ARTICLE 11. - SEVERABILITY 
 
Sec. 1.588. - Severability. 
Should any Section, clause, or provision of this Chapter be declared by the courts invalid for any reason, such declaration shall not affect the validity of this Chapter as a whole or any part thereof, other than the Section, clause or provision so declared to be invalid. 
(Ord. No. 84-34, § 2, 5-22-84)  
Sec. 1.589. - Reserved.  
Chapter 14 - UNIFORM CITY INCOME TAX[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— City tax lands, § 1.401 et seq.; special assessments, § 1.421 et seq.; purchases, contracts and sales, § 1.501 et seq. 
State Law reference— Municipal Finance Act, MCL 131.1 et seq.; Uniform Budgeting and Accounting Act, MCL 141.421 et seq.; City Income Tax Act, MCL 141.501 et seq. 
 
Sec. 1.590. - Adoption. 
The Uniform City Income Tax Ordinance as prescribed by Act 284 of the Michigan Public Acts of 1964, as amended, is hereby adopted as the Grand Rapids Uniform City Income Tax Ordinance and all the terms, provisions and conditions as found therein are hereby incorporated by reference.
