*Note: Ord. 89-20, adopted 3-21-89, amended Section 11 of Ord. 66-28 but did not become effective because it was not approved by a majority of the qualified electors voting on the question at an election held prior to July 1, 1989. 
Section 31 of said ordinance is amended to read as follows: 
Sec. 31.(1) An individual taxpayer, in computing his or her taxable income, is allowed a deduction of $750 for tax years 2005 through 2009, $375 for the first half of tax year 2010, $300 for the second half of tax year 2010, for a total of $675 for tax year 2010, and $600 for tax year 2011 and all tax years thereafter, for each personal and dependency exemption under the rules for determining exemptions and dependents as provided in the federal internal revenue code. The taxpayer may claim his or her spouse and dependents as exemptions, but if the taxpayer and the spouse are both subject to the tax imposed by this ordinance, the number of exemptions claimed by each of them when added together shall not exceed the total number of exemptions allowed under this ordinance. 
(2) An additional exemption is allowed under subsection (1) for a taxpayer who is sixty-five (65) years of age or older, or who is blind as defined in Section 504 of the Income Tax Act of 1967, Act 281 of the Public Acts of 1967, being Section 206.504 of the Michigan Compiled Laws, or if the taxpayer is both sixty-five (65) years of age or older and blind, two (2) additional exemptions are allowed under subsection (1). 
(3) An exemption is allowed under subsection (1) for a person with respect to whom a deduction under Section 151 of the Internal Revenue Code is allowable to another Federal taxpayer during the tax year and is therefore not considered to have a Federal personal exemption under subsection (1). 
Section 60. of said ordinance is amended to read as follows: 
Section 60. An employer shall file a return, furnished by or obtainable on request from the City, and pay to the City the full amount of the tax withheld on or before the last day of the month following the close of each calendar quarter except that if during any calendar month other than the last month of a calendar quarter, the amount withheld exceeds one hundred dollars ($100.00), the employer shall deposit the amount withheld with the City Treasurer before the end of the next calendar month. 
(Ord. No. 66-28, 6-28-66; Ord. No. 70-62, 8-25-70; Ord. No. 73-48, 7-3-73; Ord. No. 76-8, 2-3-76; Ord. No. 80-82, 11-25-80; Ord. No. 88-51, § 1, 7-26-88; Ord. No. 89-20, § 1, 3-21-89; Ord. No. 2000-21, § 1, 5-2-00; Ord. No. 2004-12, § 1, 3-23-04; Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 5-11-10/eff. 7-1-10) 
State Law reference— "Blind" defined, MCL 206.504.  
Sec. 1.591. - Rate of Taxation. 
Section 11 of the Uniform City Income Tax Ordinance of the City of Grand Rapids, as adopted by Ordinance 66-28, pursuant to the authority of Section 3c of Chapter 1 of Act 284 of the Public Acts of 1964, as amended (the City Income Tax Act, MCL 141.501 et seq.), is amended to read as follows: 
Section 11. Subject to the exclusions, adjustments, exemptions and deductions herein provided, an annual tax of 1.5% on corporations and resident individuals and of .75% on non-resident individuals for general revenue purposes is hereby imposed as an excise on income earned and received on and after the effective date of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 94-47, § 1, 12-13-94; Ord. No. 2010-07, § 1, 2-16-10; Ord. No. 2014-02, §§ 1—3, 1-28-14, eff. 7-1-15) 
Note— This Section shall become effective on July 1, 2015, pursuant to the authority of Section 3 of Chapter 1 of Act 284 of the Public Acts of 1964, as amended (the City Income Tax Act, MCL 141.503); provided, however, that this Ordinance shall not be effective unless the amendment is approved by a majority of the qualified electors voting on the question at a special election held on May 6, 2014. 
The income tax rates authorized by this Ordinance shall expire on June 30, 2030. On July 1, 2030, the annual income tax rates shall automatically revert to 1.3% on corporations and resident individuals and .65% on non-resident individuals.  
Secs. 1.592—1.599. - Reserved.  
Chapter 16 - PARKING VIOLATIONS BUREAU[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Automobile parking system, Ch. 30; parking and loading spaces, § 5.51 et seq.; parking violations by motor vehicle rentals, responsibility therefor, § 7.367; parking facilities, Ch. 97; parking regulations, § 10.40 et seq.; parking violations, § 10.64; parking violations declared civil infractions, § 10.68. 
 
Sec. 1.610. - Bureau Transferred. 
Supervision and control of the Parking Violations Bureau, which was established pursuant to Section 8391 of the Revised Judicature Act, State of Michigan, as added by Public Act 154 of 1968, for the purpose of handling alleged parking violations within the City, shall be transferred from the 61st District Court to the City Treasurer. The administrative authority of the 61st District Court over the Parking Violations Bureau shall also be transferred to the City Treasurer, and any parking violations tags or notices which were issued prior to adoption of Ordinance 81-57 shall be disposed of by the City Treasurer by means set forth in this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 68-79, 12-23-68; Ord. No. 73-34, 5-22-73; Ord. No. 81-57, 7-14-81)  
Sec. 1.611. - Location of Bureau. 
The City Treasurer shall establish a convenient location for the Parking Violations Bureau and adopt rules and regulations for the operation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 68-79, 12-23-68; Ord. No. 73-34, 5-22-73)  
Sec. 1.612. - Unscheduled Violations. 
No violation not scheduled in Section 1.615 of this Chapter shall be disposed of by the Parking Violations Bureau. The fact that a particular violation is scheduled shall not entitle the alleged violator to disposition of the violation at the Bureau and in any case the person in charge of such Bureau may refuse to dispose of such violation in which case any person having knowledge of the facts may make a sworn complaint before any court having jurisdiction of the offense as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 68-79, 5-22-73)  
Sec. 1.613. - Disposition of Violation. 
No violation may be settled at the Parking Violations Bureau except at the specific request of the alleged violator. No penalty for any violation shall be accepted from any person who denies having committed the offense. The City Treasurer or Deputy City Treasurer may void a parking notice or tag issued upon proven justifiable reason. The City Treasurer or Deputy City Treasurer must attach or note on the violation the result of the investigation of the Parking Violations Bureau, the Police Department, or the Transportation Department justifying the voiding of the violation. All persons shall be entitled to have any such violation processed before a court having jurisdiction thereof, if they so desire. The unwillingness of any person to dispose of any violation at the Parking Violations Bureau shall not prejudice that person or in any way diminish the rights, privileges and protection accorded to that person by law. 
(Ord. No. 68-79, 12-23-68; Ord. No. 77-67, 11-29-77; Ord. No. 81-57, 7-14-81)  
Sec. 1.614. - Information Concerning Bureau on Ticket. 
The issuance of a parking ticket or notice of violation by a police officer or any authorized employee of the City shall be deemed an allegation of a parking violation. Such traffic ticket or notice of violation shall indicate the length of time in which the person to whom the same was issued must respond before the Parking Violations Bureau. It shall also indicate the address of the Bureau, the hours during which the Bureau is open, and the amount of the penalty scheduled for the offense (or means for obtaining the same) for which the ticket was issued. 
(Ord. No. 68-79, 12-23-68)  
Sec. 1.615. - Fines. 
Fines for parking violations issued under this Code shall be established from time to time by resolution of the City Commission. Fines not paid within ten (10) days from the date of the violation notice will double. If the fine is not paid within ninety (90) days, the fine will triple. 
(Ord. No. 68-79, 12-23-68; Ord. No. 72-95, 12-12-72; Ord. No. 74-3, 1-15-74; Ord. No. 75-12, 2-11-75; Ord. No. 80-63, 8-12-80; Ord. No. 81-57, 7-14-81; Ord. No. 82-55, 7-6-82; Ord. No. 85-34, § 1, 5-28-85; Ord. No. 88-50, § 1, 7-26-88; Ord. No. 92-54, § 1, 8-25-92; Ord. No. 93-36, § 1, 8-24-93; Ord. No. 2000-17, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. 2001-45, § 1, 11-13-01; Ord. No. 2007-01, § 1, 1-9-07)  
Secs. 1.616—1.700. - Reserved.  
Chapter 18 - INVESTMENTS 
 
Sec. 1.801. - Legal Requirements as to City Treasurer. 
The City Treasurer shall invest or reinvest money in strict compliance with the City Charter of the City of Grand Rapids and specifically Sections 28, 29 and 30 of Title V, and Section 5 of Title VI thereof, and the laws of the State of Michigan and the Investment Program and Policy of the City of Grand Rapids as it may be amended from time to time. 
The City Treasurer is authorized to invest funds belonging to the City and its Boards, Commissions and authorities as provided in Act 66 of 1977 as amended (MCL 129.91 et seq., MSA 3.843(1) et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 77-73, 12-13-77) 
State Law reference— Investment of surplus funds by political subdivisions, MCL 129.91, MSA 3.843(1).  
Sec. 1.802. - Investment. 
The City Treasurer is hereby authorized to purchase, at their original issue or after they have been issued, securities which are permissible under the Sections of State law as outlined in Section 1.801, above, as they now read or may be amended, from money in his or her custody which is not required for the immediate necessities of the City and as he or she may deem wise and expedient, and to sell or exchange for other eligible securities and reinvest the proceeds of the securities so purchased. Investments shall be made in accordance with the City of Grand Rapids Investment Program and Policy. 
(Ord. No. 77-73, 12-13-77)  
Sec. 1.803. - Redemptions. 
From time to time the City Treasurer shall redeem the securities in which City money has been invested pursuant to Section 1.802 of this Chapter so that the proceeds may be applied to the purposes for which the original purchase money was designated or placed in the City Treasury. 
(Ord. No. 77-73, 12-13-77)  
Sec. 1.804. - Reports. 
The City Treasurer shall make a monthly report of all investments to the City Commission detailing, at minimum, conformance to the provisions of Section 1.801 of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 77-73, 12-13-77)  
Sec. 1.805. - Investment Deposits. 
The City Treasurer is hereby authorized to deposit for safekeeping with a State or national bank located within this State or with any Federal Reserve Bank or with a State or National bank located in any City designated as a reserve City by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, the securities in which City money has been invested pursuant to Section 1.802 of this Chapter; provided, however, that the City Treasurer shall take from such bank a receipt for the securities so deposited and shall not be responsible for such securities delivered to and receipted for by such bank until they are withdrawn therefrom by the City Treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 77-73, 12-13-77)  
Sec. 1.806. - Bidding Procedures. 
Competitive bidding procedures as outlined in the Investment Program and Policy shall be implemented by the City Treasurer and results of bidding shall be shown monthly pursuant to Section 1.804. 
(Ord. No. 77-73, 12-13-77)  
Sec. 1.807. - Financial Stability of Depositories. 
Pre-qualification of financial institutions to bid on City of Grand Rapids investments shall be implemented by the City Treasurer according to provision of the City of Grand Rapids Investment Program and Policy. Reporting to the City Commission shall be pursuant to Section 1.804. 
(Ord. No. 77-73, 12-13-77)  
Sec. 1.808. - Revisions. 
Any changes to the Investment Program and Policy must be approved by the City Commission by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 77-73, 12-13-77)  
Sec. 1.809. - Depositories. 
The establishment of funds and the depository for such funds shall be by City Commission resolution.  
Sec. 1.810. - Bad Check Fee. 
The City Treasurer shall assess a charge to any person who issues a check payable to the City of Grand Rapids which is, for any reason, returned without payment. The amount of the fee so charged shall be as determined by the City Commission, by resolution, upon the recommendation of the City Treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 85-77, § 1, 11-26-85)  
Secs. 1.811—1.819. - Reserved.  
Chapter 21 - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Downtown Development Authority, MCL 125.1651 et seq., MSA 5.3010(1) et seq. 
 
Sec. 1.901. - Title. 
This Chapter shall be known as the "Downtown Development Authority Ordinance" of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(Ord. No. 79-69, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 1.902. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this Chapter is to create a public body corporate to act in the best interests of the City to halt property value deterioration, increase property tax valuation where possible in the business district of the City, eliminate the causes of that deterioration and to promote economic growth pursuant to Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975 [MCL 125.1651 et seq., MSA 5.3010(1) et seq.]. 
(Ord. No. 79-69, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 1.903. - Definitions. 
The terms used herein shall have the same meaning as given them in Act 197 or as hereinafter in this Section provided, unless the context clearly indicates to the contrary, and shall be in addition to the terms provided in Act 197. 
(1)  Authority means the Downtown Development Authority of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(2)  Act 197 means Act No. 197 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1975 as now in effect or hereafter amended. 
(3)  City means the City of Grand Rapids. 
(4)  Commission means the Grand Rapids City Commission. 
(5)  Downtown District means the downtown district designated herein. 
(Ord. No. 79-69, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 1.904. - Creation of Authority. 
There is hereby created pursuant to Act 197 a Downtown Development Authority for the City of Grand Rapids, Michigan. The Authority shall be a public body corporate and shall be known and exercise its powers under title of "Downtown Development Authority of the City of Grand Rapids." The Authority may adopt a seal, may sue and be sued in any court of this State, and shall possess all of the powers necessary to carry out the purpose of its incorporation as provided herein and in Act 197. The enumeration of a power herein or in Act 197 shall not be construed as a limitation upon the general powers of the Authority. 
(Ord. No. 79-69, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 1.905. - Description of Downtown District. 
The Downtown District, also known as Downtown Development Area No. 1, in which the Authority shall exercise its powers as provided in Act 197 shall consist of the following described territory in the City of Grand Rapids: 
1.  District A includes a 46-acre, 10-block section of the east riverbank area. This district is generally bounded by the north line of the original Grand Center on the north, the rear lot lines of properties along the east side of Monroe Avenue (north of Pearl Street) and Ottawa Avenue on the east, Fulton Street on the south, and the Grand River on the west. 
2.  District B includes a 10-acre, 6-block section of Monroe Center and is generally bounded by rear lot lines of properties on the north side of Monroe Center between Pearl Street and Division Avenue, on the north, Division Avenue on the east, Fulton Street on the south, and Ottawa Avenue and Monroe Center on the west. 
3.  District C includes an 86-acre, 14-block section of the Heartside District and is generally bounded by Fulton Street on the north, Division Avenue and Ionia Avenue on the east, Wealthy Street on the south, and Grandville Avenue and the Grand River on the west. 
4.  District D includes a 34-acre section of the west riverbank development area and adjoining river surface, located south of Pearl Street. 
5.  District E includes a 46-acre section of the west river bank development area and adjoining river, located north of Pearl and extending to the I-196 expressway. 
6.  District F includes a 36-acre, 10-block area, west of US-131, which passes in a north-south direction through the western edge of downtown. District F is generally bounded by Pearl Street and Lake Michigan Drive on the south, Seward Avenue on the west, Bridge Street on the north between Seward Avenue and Winter Avenue, Winter Avenue on the east between Bridge Street and Douglas Street, and then Douglas Street on the north between Winter Avenue and Scribner Avenue. 
7.  District G includes a 14-acre area of 4 blocks plus portions of 3 other blocks bounded by Lyon Street on the north, Division on the east, and the boundary of District B on the south and west. This boundary generally follows the rear of properties located on the north side of Monroe Center and the east side of Monroe Avenue. 
8.  District H includes a 34 acre, 5-block area bounded by Michigan Street on the north, Division Avenue on the east, Lyon Street on the south, and the existing boundaries of District A and District E on the west. This area includes the governmental buildings located in the Calder Square and it includes the portion of the DeVos Place Convention Center site that is not included within other Districts. This area is also within the City of Grand Rapids SmartZone Authority district which also captures tax increment revenues. 
9.  District I is comprised of 279 acres and includes: (a) a 38-block area, including the Grand Rapids Community College Campus, St. Mary's Health campus, Mary Free Bed facilities and the remainder of area commonly known as the Heartside Neighborhood; (b) a one-block area bounded by Ionia Avenue, Logan Street, Century Avenue, and Wealthy Street; (c) a five-block area located west of Grandville Avenue, between Wealthy Street and US-131; and (d) a five-block area bounded by Lake Michigan Drive, US-131, Watson Street and Lexington/Seward Avenues. 
10.  District J is comprised of 55 acres and includes: (a) a six-block area located north and south of Bridge Street, NW; (b) a two-block area bounded by Scribner Avenue, Sixth Street, the east bank of the Grand River and I-196; and (c) a one-block area bounded by Monroe Avenue, Trowbridge Street, Bond Avenue, and I-196. 
11.  District K is comprised of 37 acres and includes a four-block area located east of the Grand River, between Newberry Street and I-196. This area is also within the City of Grand Rapids SmartZone Local Development Finance Authority district, which also captures tax increment revenues. 
12.  District L is comprised of 35 acres and includes a three-block area west of US-131 and south of Second Street between Turner Avenue and Seward Avenue. It includes portions of US-131 and I-196, between Seward Avenue and the Grand River, and south of Fourth Street. This area is within the Westside Corridor Improvement District, which also captures tax increment revenues. There is also a City of Grand Rapids Brownfield Redevelopment Authority plan amendment for the Bridge and Turner, LLC Project within this District. 
13.  District M is comprised of 17 acres and includes a two-block area west of the Grand River and east of Front Street between Leonard Street and Sixth Street. This District is within the Westside Corridor Improvement District, which captures tax increment revenues. 
14.  District N consists of 100 acres and includes a 12-block area bounded by Leonard Street to the north, Division Avenue on the east, Sixth Street on the south, and the Grand River on the west. This District includes the hillside east of Division Avenue bordering the Belknap Neighborhood between Mason Street and I-196. The Grand Rapids Tax Increment Financing Authority, City of Grand Rapids SmartZone Local Development Finance Authority, and the North Quarter Corridor Improvement District are all within this area and capture tax increment revenues. 
15.  District O consists of 4 acres and includes a 3-block area at the southeast and southwest corners of Division Avenue and Wealthy Street. The southwestern portion borders District I between Wealthy Street and Logan Street. The southeast corner includes the entire block east of Division Avenue, west to Sheldon Avenue, and south to Logan Street. 
16.  District P consists of 41 acres and includes a 12-block area south of Wealthy Street, east of the Grand River, west of US-131, and bounded by the existing railroad tracks to the south from Century Avenue to the pedestrian bridge at 700 Chestnut Street that extends over Market Avenue and the Grand River. This District is within the City of Grand Rapids SmartZone Local Development Finance Authority district, which captures tax increment revenues. 
In all, Downtown Development Area No. 1 contains approximately 873 acres, inclusive of public street and expressway rights-of-way and the Grand River. A map of Downtown Development Area No. 1 is included as Map 3 in the Authority's Development and Tax Increment Financing Plan. 
(Ord. No. 79-69, 10-16-79; Ord. No. 83-76, § 2, 12-20-83; Ord. No. 2007-73, § 1, 12-18-07; Ord. No. 2016-86, § 1, 12-6-16)  
Sec. 1.906. - Board. 
The Authority shall be under the supervision and control of a Board consisting of the Mayor of the City and eight (8) members. The members shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to approval by the Commission. Eligibility for membership on the Board and terms of office shall be as provided in Act 197. All members shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed. 
(Ord. No. 79-69, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 1.907. - Powers of the Authority. 
The Authority shall possess all of the powers necessary to carry out the purposes of its incorporation and shall have all powers provided by Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975 with the following exceptions: 
(1)  The power to levy ad valorem taxes on the real and tangible personal property not exempt by law and as finally equalized in the downtown district at the rate of not more than two (2) mills as set forth in Section 12 of Act 197 shall be limited to one (1) mill. 
(Ord. No. 79-69, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 1.908. - Termination. 
Upon completion of its purposes the Authority may be dissolved by the Commission. The property and assets of the Authority, after dissolution and satisfaction of its obligations, shall revert to the City. 
(Ord. No. 79-69, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 1.909. - Amendment. 
This Chapter may be amended pursuant to Section 1.2 of Chapter 1 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 79-69, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 1.910. - Downtown Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1. 
(1)  Preliminary findings: 
(a)  That a public hearing was held on the proposed Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, following the giving of notice thereof, all in accordance with Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended. 
(b)  That there are no findings or recommendations of a development area citizens' council, there having been no statutory requirement to form a development area citizens' council. 
(c)  That the proposed Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan meet the requirements set forth in Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended. 
(d)  That the proposed method of financing the proposed development is feasible and the Downtown Development Authority of the City of Grand Rapids has the ability to arrange the financing. 
(e)  That the proposed development is reasonable and necessary to carry out the purposes of Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended. 
(f)  That any land included within the proposed development area which is to be acquired is reasonably necessary to carry out the purposes of the Plan and of Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended, in an efficient and economically satisfactory manner. 
(g)  That the proposed Development Plan is in reasonable accord with the Master Plan of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(h)  That public services, such as fire and police protection and utilities, are or will be adequate to service the proposed project area. 
(i)  That changes in zoning, streets, street levels, intersections and utilities are reasonably necessary for the proposed project and for the City of Grand Rapids. 
(2)  Findings and determination: 
(a)  That based upon the foregoing findings, it is hereby held and determined that the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Area No. 1 constitutes a public purpose. 
(b)  That the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1 is hereby approved. 
(3)  Immediate effect. This Section approving Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1 is hereby determined to be immediately necessary for the preservation of public health, peace and safety and is hereby given immediate effect. 
(Ord. No. 80-86, 12-16-80)  
Sec. 1.911. - Ordinance Approving Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1 as Amended. 
(1)  Preliminary findings: 
(a)  That the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1 was adopted and approved by the Grand Rapids City Commission on the sixteenth day of December, 1980, in accordance with Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended. 
(b)  That prior to holding public hearings on the proposed amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1 as adopted by the Grand Rapids Downtown Development Authority on June 17, 1981, and October 21, 1981, the governing body of the City of Grand Rapids provided a reasonable opportunity to the members of the Kent County Board of Commissioners and to the members of the School Boards of any school district in which any portion of the development area as amended is located to meet with the governing body of the City of Grand Rapids; and the Grand Rapids Downtown Development Authority fully informed the members of the Kent County Board of Commissioners and of the School Boards of the fiscal and economic implications of the proposed development area as amended, and the members of the Kent County Board of Commissioners and of the School Boards had an opportunity to present their recommendations at the public hearings subsequently held on the proposed amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1 which were adopted by the Grand Rapids Downtown Development Authority on June 17, 1981, and October 21, 1981. 
(c)  That public hearings were held, following the giving of notice thereof in accordance with Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended, on proposed amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, which amendments were adopted by the Grand Rapids Downtown Development Authority on June 17, 1981, and October 21, 1981, respectively. 
(d)  That there are no findings or recommendations of a development area citizens' council, there having been no statutory requirement to form such a development area citizens' council. 
(e)  That the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for downtown Development Area No. 1 and said amendments thereto as adopted by the Grand Rapids Downtown Development Authority on June 17, 1981, and October 21, 1981, satisfy and comply with the requirements set forth in Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended. 
(f)  That the proposed method of financing the proposed development as set forth in said Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1 and said amendments thereto is feasible and the Downtown Development Authority of the City of Grand Rapids has the ability to arrange said financing. 
(g)  That the proposed development as set forth in the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1 and said amendments thereto is reasonable and necessary to carry out the purposes of Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended. 
(h)  That any land included within the development area as amended which is to be acquired is reasonably necessary to carry out the purposes of the Plan and of Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended, in an efficient and economically satisfactory manner. 
(i)  That said Development Plan as amended is in reasonable accord with the Master Plan of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(j)  That public services, such as fire and police protection and utilities, are or will be adequate to service the proposed project area as amended. 
(k)  That changes in zoning, streets, street levels, intersections, and utilities are reasonably necessary for the proposed project as amended and for the City of Grand Rapids. 
(2)  Findings and determination: 
(a)  That based upon the foregoing findings, it is hereby held and determined that the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, including the amendments thereto adopted by the Grand Rapids Downtown Development Authority on June 17, 1981, and October 21, 1981, constitute a public purpose. 
(b)  That the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No.1, and the amendments thereto adopted by the Grand Rapids Downtown Development Authority on June 17, 1981, and October 21, 1981, are hereby approved. 
(3)  Immediate effect. This Section approving Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1 as amended is hereby determined to be immediately necessary for the preservation of public health, peace and safety and is hereby given immediate effect. 
(Ord. No. 81-86, 12-15-81)  
Sec. 1.912. - The Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as Amended.

(n)  That on May 7, 2002, the Commission approved certain amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, as approved and recommended by the Authority on February 13, 2002. 
(o)  That on April 19, 2005, the Commission approved certain amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, as approved and recommended by the Authority on February 9, 2005.

(q)  That prior to holding a public hearing on the proposed amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, as approved and recommended by the Authority on October 12, 2016, the Commission provided a reasonable opportunity to meet with representatives of taxing jurisdictions levying taxes subject to capture by the Authority to discuss the fiscal and economic implications of the proposed amendments, and such taxing jurisdictions had an opportunity to present their recommendations at the public hearing subsequently held relating to the proposed amendments. 
(r)  That a public hearing was held, following the giving of notice thereof, in accordance with Act 197, on the proposed amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, which amendments were approved and recommended by the Grand Rapids Downtown Development Authority on October 12, 2016. 
(s)  That there are no findings or recommendations of a development area citizens' council, no development area citizens' council having been formed. 
(t)  That the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, and the amendments thereto, as approved and recommended by the Authority on October 12, 2016, meet the requirements of Act 197, including specifically Section 17(2). 
(u)  That the proposed methods of financing the proposed improvements and projects set forth in Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, and the amendments thereto, are feasible and the Authority has the ability to arrange the financing. 
(v)  That the proposed improvements and projects as set forth in Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, and the amendments thereto, are reasonable and necessary to carry out the purposes of Act 197. 
(w)  That any land included in Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, which is to be acquired, is reasonably necessary to carry out the purposes of the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, and the amendments thereto, and of Act 197, in an efficient and economically satisfactory manner. 
(x)  That Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, and the amendments thereto, are in reasonable accord with the master plan of the City. 
(y)  That necessary public services including fire and police protection and utilities are, or will be, adequate to service Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended. 
(z)  That any changes in zoning, streets, street levels, intersections and utilities are reasonably necessary for the proposed improvements and projects set forth in Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, and the amendments thereto, and for the City. 
(2)  Findings and Determination. 
(a)  That based on the foregoing findings, it is hereby held and determined that the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, and the amendments thereto approved and recommended by the Authority on October 12, 2016, constitute a public purpose. 
(b)  That the amendments to Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, approved and recommended by the Authority on October 12, 2016, and as modified as provided in III. Tax Increment Financing Plan for Grand Rapids Downtown Development Area No. 1, as amended, F. Special Millages reflected in revised Table 6 are hereby approved. 
(Ord. No. 82-82, 11-30-82; Ord. No. 83-57, 10-4-83; Ord. No. 83-77, §§ 1—3, 12-20-83; Ord. No. 84-73, §§ 1—3, 10-16-84; Ord. No. 87-28, §§ 1—3, 4-7-87; Ord. No. 87-39, §§ 1—3, 6-30-87; Ord. No. 2002-24, § 1, 5-7-02; Ord. No. 2005-19, § 1, 4-19-05; Ord. No. 2007-73, § 2, 12-18-07; Ord. No. 2016-86, § 2, 12-6-16)

Chapter 22 - TAX INCREMENT FINANCE AUTHORITY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Tax Increment Financing Plan for Downtown Development Area No. 1, §§ 1.911, 1.912. 
 
Sec. 1.925. - Title. 
This Chapter shall be known as the "Tax Increment Finance Authority Ordinance" of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(Ord. No. 85-67, § 2, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.926. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this Chapter is to create a public body corporate to act in the best interest of the City to halt a decline in property values, increase property tax valuation, eliminate the causes of the decline in property values, to promote growth, and to exercise all powers as provided in Act 450 of the Public Acts of 1980, as presently or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 85-67, § 2, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.927. - Definitions. 
The terms used herein shall have the same meaning as given them in Act 450 of the Public Acts of 1980, as amended, or as hereinafter in this Section provided, unless the context clearly indicates to the contrary and shall be in addition to the terms provided in Act 450. 
(1)  Authority means the Tax Increment Finance Authority of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(2)  Act 450 means Act No. 450 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1980 as now in effect or hereafter amended. 
(3)  City means the City of Grand Rapids. 
(4)  Commission means the Grand Rapids City Commission. 
(5)  Authority District means the Authority District designated herein. 
(Ord. No. 85-67, § 2, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.928. - Creation of Authority. 
There is hereby created pursuant to Act 450 a Tax Increment Finance Authority for the City of Grand Rapids, Michigan. The Authority shall be a public body corporate and shall be known and exercise its powers under title of "Tax Increment Finance Authority of the City of Grand Rapids." The Authority may adopt a seal, may sue and be sued in any court of this State, and shall possess all of the powers necessary to carry out the purpose of its incorporation as provided herein and in Act 450. The enumeration of a power herein or in Act 450 shall not be construed as a limitation upon the general powers of the Authority. 
(Ord. No. 85-67, § 2, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.929. - Description of Authority District. 
The Authority District in which the Authority shall exercise its powers as provided by Act 450 shall consist of that property located in the City of Grand Rapids, Kent County, Michigan, bounded on the North by the North line of Coldbrook Street, on the East by the East line of Ionia Avenue, on the South by the South line of Newberry Street, and on the West by the East line of the Grand River. 
(Ord. No. 85-67, § 2, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.930. - Board. 
The Authority shall be under the supervision and control of a Board consisting of eleven (11) persons appointed by the Mayor of the City of Grand Rapids subject to the approval of the City Commission. Eligibility for membership on the Board and terms of office shall be as provided in Act 450. All members shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed. 
(Ord. No. 85-67, § 2, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.931. - Powers of the Authority. 
The Authority shall possess all of the powers necessary to carry out the purposes of its incorporation and shall have all powers provided by Act 450 as presently amended or as it may be amended hereafter. 
(Ord. No. 85-67, § 2, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.932. - Termination. 
Upon completion of its purposes the Authority may be dissolved by the Commission. The property and assets of the Authority, after dissolution and satisfaction of its obligations, shall revert to the City. 
(Ord. No. 85-67, § 2, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.933. - Amendment. 
This Chapter may be amended pursuant to Section 1.2 of Chapter 1 of the City Code and pursuant to the provisions of Act 450. 
(Ord. No. 85-67, § 2, 10-29-85)  
Sec. 1.934. - Tax Increment Financing Plan and Development Plan for Monroe North Development Area. 
(1)  Preliminary findings: 
(a)  That a public hearing was held on the proposed Tax Increment Financing Plan and Development Plan for Monroe North Development Area, following the giving of notice thereof, all in accordance with Act 450 of the Public Acts of 1980 as amended. 
(b)  That there are no findings or recommendations of a development area citizens' council, there having been no statutory requirement to form a development area citizens' council. 
(c)  That the proposed Tax Increment Financing Plan and Development Plan meet the requirements set forth in Act 450 of the Public Acts 1980, as amended. 
(d)  That the proposed method of financing the proposed development is feasible and the Tax Increment Finance Authority of the City of Grand Rapids has the ability to arrange the financing. 
(e)  That the proposed development is reasonable and necessary to carry out the purposes of Act 450 of the Public Acts of 1980, as amended. 
(f)  That the amount of captured assessed value estimated to result from adoption of the Tax Increment Financing Plan and Development Plan is reasonable. 
(g)  That any land included within the proposed development area which is to be acquired is reasonably necessary to carry out the purposes of the Plan and of Act 450 of the Public Acts of 1980, as amended, in an efficient and economically satisfactory manner. 
(h)  That the proposed Development Plan is in reasonable accord with the Master Plan of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(i)  That public services, such as fire and police protection and utilities, are or will be adequate to service the proposed project area. 
(j)  That changes in zoning, streets, street levels, intersections and utilities are reasonably necessary for the proposed project and for the City of Grand Rapids. 
(2)  Findings and determination: 
(a)  That based upon the foregoing findings, it is hereby held and determined that the Tax Increment Financing Plan and Development Plan for Monroe North Development Area constitutes a public purpose. 
(b)  That the Tax Increment Financing Plan and Development Plan for Monroe North Development Area is hereby approved. 
(3)  Immediate effect. This Section approving the Tax Increment Financing Plan and Development Plan for Monroe North Development Area is hereby determined to be immediately necessary for the preservation of public health, peace and safety, and is hereby given immediate effect. 
(Ord. No. 85-85, § 1, 12-17-85)  
Sec. 1.935. - The Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Monroe North Development Area. 
(1)  Preliminary findings: 
(a)  That the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Monroe North Development Area was adopted and approved by the Grand Rapids City Commission on the 17th day of December 1985 in accordance with Act 450 of the Public Acts of 1980, as amended. 
(b)  That on August 29, 1989, the Grand Rapids City Commission approved certain amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Monroe North Development Area, as adopted by the Grand Rapids Tax Increment Finance Authority on April 12, 1989. 
(c)  That on July 23, 1996, the Grand Rapids City Commission approved certain amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Monroe North Development Area, as adopted by the Grand Rapids Tax Increment Finance Authority on May 8, 1996. 
(d)  That prior to holding public hearings on the proposed amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Monroe North Development Area, as adopted by the Grand Rapids Tax Increment Finance Authority on May 12, 1999, the governing body of the City of Grand Rapids provided a reasonable opportunity to the members of the Kent County Board of Commissioners and to the members of the school boards of any school district in which any portion of the development area is located, to meet with the governing body of the City of Grand Rapids; and the Grand Rapids Tax Increment Finance Authority fully informed the members of the Kent County Board of Commissioners and of the school boards, of the fiscal and economic implications of the proposed development and amendments, and the members of the Kent County Board of Commissioners and of the school boards, had an opportunity to present their recommendations at the public hearings subsequently held on the proposed amendments to the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Monroe North Development Area, which were adopted by the Grand Rapids Tax Increment Finance Authority on May 12, 1999. 
(e)  That public hearings were held, following the giving of notice thereof in accordance with Act 450 of the Public Acts of 1980, as amended, on proposed amendments to the Monroe North Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan, which amendments were adopted by the Grand Rapids Tax Increment Finance Authority on May 12, 1999. 
(f)  That there are no findings or recommendations of a development area citizens' council, there having been no statutory requirement to form such a development area citizens' council. 
(g)  That the Monroe North Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan, and the amendments thereto as adopted by the Grand Rapids Tax Increment Finance Authority on May 12, 1999, satisfy and comply with the requirements set forth in Act 450 of the Public Acts of 1980, as amended. 
(h)  That the proposed method of financing the proposed development as set forth in the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Monroe North Development Area, and the amendments thereto, are feasible and the Tax Increment Finance Authority of the City of Grand Rapids has the ability to arrange financing. 
(i)  That the proposed development as set forth in the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Monroe North Development Area, and the amendments thereto are reasonable and necessary to carry out the purposes of Act 450 of the Public Acts of 1980, as amended. 
(j)  That the amount of captured assessed value estimated to result from adoption of the Tax Increment Financing Plan and Development Plan is reasonable. 
(k)  That the Development Plan as amended is in reasonable accord with the master plan of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(l)  That public services, such as fire and police protection and utilities, are or will be adequate to service the proposed project area. 
(m)  That changes in streets, street levels, intersections, and utilities are reasonably necessary for the proposed project, as amended, and for the City of Grand Rapids. 
(2)  Findings and determination: 
(a)  That based upon the foregoing findings, it is hereby held and determined that the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Monroe North Development Area, including the amendments thereto, adopted by the Grand Rapids Tax Increment Finance Authority on May 12, 1999, constitute a public purpose. 
(b)  That the Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan for Monroe North Development Area, and the amendments adopted thereto by the Grand Rapids Tax Increment Finance Authority on May 12, 1999, are hereby approved. 
(Ord. No. 89-47, §§ 1—3, 8-29-89; Ord. No. 96-30, § 1, 7-23-96; Ord. No. 99-54, § 1, 10-12-99) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 89-47, §§ 1—3, adopted Aug. 29, 1989, was nonamendatory of the Code; hence, inclusion as § 1.935 was at the discretion of the editor.  
Secs. 1.936—1.949. - Reserved.  
Chapter 23 - DOWNTOWN IMPROVEMENT DISTRICT BOARD[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 86-29, § 1, adopted Apr. 22, 1986, added a new Chapter 22, §§ 1.950—1.961, to the Code. Said provisions have been redesignated as Chapter 23 by the editor in order to avoid duplication of Chapter numbers with previously enacted material. Subsequently, Ord. No. 2009-21, § 1, adopted May 12, 2009, repealed Ch. 23, in its entirety, which pertained to the Downtown Management Board. Section 2 of said ordinance enacted provisions designated as a new Ch. 23 to read as herein set out. See also the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis. 
Cross reference— Downtown Development Authority, Ch. 21. 
 
Sec. 1.950. - Title. 
This Chapter shall be known as the "Downtown Improvement District Ordinance" of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.951. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this Chapter is to create a Board for the management of the ongoing maintenance, security, promotion and continued operation of the Downtown District, as defined in this Chapter and as it may be amended and expanded from time to time, and related improvements and programs pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 1 of Act 120 of the Public Acts of 1961, as amended [MCL 125.981 to 125.987] (the "Act"). 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.952. - Creation of Board. 
Pursuant to Act 120 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1961, as amended (the "Act"), the Downtown Improvement District Board, originally created on August 22, 2000, by resolution of the City Commission (Proceeding No. 67692) is hereby continued and other provisions of said resolution are superseded by the provisions of this Chapter. The Downtown District is established as a Business Improvement District Board (the "Board") and shall, in a fiduciary capacity, oversee and manage the ongoing activities of the Downtown District pursuant to the Act. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09; Ord. No. 2013-48, § 1, 9-24-13)  
Sec. 1.953. - Board. 
The Board shall be composed of not less than ten (10) nor more than sixteen (16) members as determined and appointed by the Mayor with the concurrence of the City Commission. One (1) member of the Board shall be a representative of the City. The other members of the Board shall be appointed from a list of nominees solicited by the Mayor from businesses and property owners located in the Downtown District. A majority of the Board members shall be business or property owners or employees of businesses located on property or property owners in the Downtown District, which property is subject to special assessment pursuant to Section 1.961 hereof. In addition, Board membership shall include representation from non-profit and governmental entities that voluntarily pay said special assessment and the residential community living in the Downtown District. If the list of nominees is not acceptable to the Mayor, the Mayor shall request that the Downtown District businesses and property owners provide additional nominees which are acceptable to the Mayor for appointment. A member shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed. 
No Board member shall receive additional compensation from the City or the Board for serving on the Board. Board members may be reimbursed from Board funds for out-of-pocket expenses reasonably incurred in the performance of their duties on the Board." 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09; Ord. No. 2013-48, § 2, 9-24-13)  
Sec. 1.954. - Terms of Office. 
The members of the Board shall serve terms of three (3) years, however, in order to provide for staggered Board member terms where approximately one-third of the terms of Board members expire each year, some Board members may initially be appointed to serve terms of one (1) or two (2) years. All members appointed and confirmed as authorized by Proceeding No. 78258 shall continue to serve for terms established under said resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09; Ord. No. 2013-48, § 3, 9-24-13)  
Sec. 1.955. - Powers of Board. 
The Board shall manage the ongoing maintenance, security, promotion, and continued operation of the Downtown District, as amended and expanded from time to time, and related improvements and programs. In furtherance of these objectives, the Board shall have all powers set forth in the Act, as it may be amended from time to time. The Board may recommend to the City Commission that the City undertake one (1) or more of the following in the district: 
(1)  Open, widen, extend, realign, pave, maintain or otherwise improve highways and construct, reconstruct, maintain or relocate pedestrian walkways. 
(2)  Prohibit or regulate vehicular traffic where necessary to carry out the purposes of a development or redevelopment project. 
(3)  Regulate or prohibit vehicular parking on highways. 
(4)  Acquire, own, maintain or operate off-street parking lots or structures. 
(5)  Contract for the operation or maintenance by others of City off-street parking lots or structures, or appoint agents for the operation or maintenance of those lots or structures. 
(6)  Construct, maintain and operate malls with bus stops, information centers and other buildings that will serve the public interest. 
(7)  Acquire by purchase, gift or condemnation, and own, maintain, or operate real or personal property necessary to implement the goals of the Board. 
(8)  Provide for the maintenance, security and operation of a district. 
(9)  Promote economic activity in the District by undertakings including, but not limited to, conducting market research and public relations campaigns, developing, coordinating and conducting retail and institutional promotions, and sponsoring special events and related activities. 
(10)  Provide for or contract with other public or private entities for the administration, maintenance, security, operation and provision of services that the Board determines are a benefit to the district. 
The Board may expend funds it determines reasonably necessary to achieve its goal, within the limits of those monies made available to it by the City Commission from the financing methods specified in this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.956. - Financing. 
The activities of the Board or any corporation created by the Board may be financed from one (1) or more of the following sources: 
(1)  Donations, grants and gifts to the City or the Board, for use by the Board for the performance of its functions. 
(2)  From City funds or other sources approved by the City. 
(3)  From the issuance of general obligation bonds by the City, subject to the revised municipal finance act (PA 34 of 2001 [MCL 141.2101 to 141.2821]). 
(4)  From the issuance of revenue bonds by the City under the revenue bond act of 1933 (PA 94 of 1933, as amended [MCL 141.101 to 141.140]), or under any other applicable revenue bond act. 
(5)  From the levying of special assessments against land or interests in land, or both, for redevelopment and to defray the cost of administration, maintenance, security, promotion and continued operation of the Downtown District. 
The proceeds of a bond, note, or other obligation issued to finance a project authorized under this Chapter shall be used for capital expenditures, costs of a reserve fund securing the bonds, notes, or other obligations, and costs of issuing the bonds, notes, or other obligations. The proceeds of the bonds, notes, or other obligations shall not be used for operational expenses of a district. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.957. - Budget. 
The Board shall operate on a fiscal basis which coincides with the City's fiscal year. The Board shall, after soliciting and receiving input from the business and property owners in the Downtown District, prepare or cause to be prepared a proposed annual budget which shall be provided to the City Manager in a format acceptable to the City Manager. The City Commission reserves the right to determine what, if any, special assessment and the amount and the apportionment thereof that shall be levied on benefited property for use in the Downtown District, as amended and expanded from time to time, or to fund any portion of the Board's activities. 
Funds appropriated to the Board from the City's funds or the proceeds available from any Special Assessment levy shall be held by the City and disbursed to the Board from time to time for payment of expenses incurred net of any and all other monies otherwise available to the Board at the time of the request. 
The bookkeeping for the Board shall be performed in a manner consistent with the accounting policies and procedures followed by the City Comptroller and, consistent with the guidelines of the Government Accounting Standards Board, the Board shall be included in the general purpose financial statements of the City of Grand Rapids. The City Comptroller or his or her designee shall have the right at any time to examine the financial records of the Board or any corporation established by it. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09; Ord. No. 2013-48, § 4, 9-24-13)  
Sec. 1.958. - Rules of Procedure. 
The Board shall adopt such rules of procedure as it deems appropriate. All meetings of the Board shall be subject to the Michigan Open Meetings Act (Public Act 267 of 1976, as amended [MCL 15.261 to 15.275]). Public records of the Board shall be subject to disclosure in accordance with the Michigan Freedom of Information Act (Public Act 442 of 1976, as amended) [MCL 15.231 to 15.246]. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.959. - Termination. 
The Board may be dissolved in the sole discretion of the City Commission upon the completion of any fiscal year, provided that whenever the City Commission determines the necessity and duration of Ongoing Activity extends beyond a fiscal year, the Board shall exist to conduct its affairs for the duration specified in the resolution of necessity. Upon dissolution of the Board, all assets of the Board, and all assets of any nonprofit corporation established by the Board, shall become the sole property of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.960. - Downtown Improvement District Defined. 
As used in this Chapter, the Board may exercise its powers within the Downtown District, described as follows: 
That property located in the City of Grand Rapids, Kent County, Michigan; within a boundary beginning at the south right-of-way line of I-196 at the Division Avenue underpass and running easterly along the south right-of-way line of I-196 to Lafayette Avenue, then south along Lafayette Avenue to a point 128 feet south of Michigan Street, then west to Claremont Place; then south along Claremont Place to the centerline of Willow Court; then west along the centerline of Willow Court extended west approximately 90 feet to a point 130 feet east of the east r.o.w. line of Barclay Avenue; then southerly to a point 130 feet south of the south r.o.w. line of John Street; then east approximately 90 feet; then south approximately 65 feet; then east approximately 250 feet to the centerline of Lafayette Avenue; then south along Lafayette to Cherry Street; then east along Cherry 84 feet, then southerly approximately 153 feet to Cherry Street Alley, then east along Cherry Street Alley to Prospect Avenue, then south along Prospect Avenue to Logan Street, then west along Logan Street SE to Division Avenue S, then south along Division Avenue S to Logan Street SW, then west along Logan Street SW extended to Century Avenue, then north along Century Avenue to Wealthy Street, then west along Wealthy Street to Front Avenue, then northeasterly along Front Avenue to Emperor Street, then west along Emperor Street to Tolford Avenue, then north along Tolford Avenue to Butterworth Avenue, then west along Butterworth Avenue to Lexington Avenue, then north along Lexington Avenue to a point approximately 350 feet south of Fulton Street, then northeasterly along the east line of the proposed extension to Seward Avenue to Fulton Street, then north along Seward Avenue to Second Street, then east along Second Street to Alabama Avenue, then south along Alabama Avenue to First Street, then east along the south r.o.w. of First Street 200 feet, then south 248 feet, then easterly to Scribner Avenue, then northerly along Scribner to Sixth Street, then east along Sixth Street to the east bank of the Grand River, then north along the east bank of the Grand River to a westerly extension of Coldbrook Street, then east along Coldbrook Street to Division Avenue, then south along Division Avenue to the point of beginning. 
Boundaries described as following streets or alleys shall follow the centerline of such streets, unless described otherwise. The Board may recommend that the boundaries of the Downtown District be amended and expanded, subject to the approval of the City Commission by adoption of an Ordinance amending this Section. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.961. - Financing by Special Assessment. 
The City Commission shall have power to determine that the whole or any part of the cost of any Public Improvement or Ongoing Activity of the Board shall be defrayed by special assessment upon the properties especially benefited. In the event of a conflict between provisions of this Chapter and Chapter 10, "Special Assessments", the provisions of this Chapter shall prevail. The term "Public Improvement" as used in this Chapter shall be construed to mean any public work or public and special improvement which the City is empowered to undertake under the Act. The term "Ongoing Activity" shall refer to any of the following: the maintenance or operation of a Public Improvement, the maintenance or operation of off-street parking lots or facilities, programs to promote economic activity in the district, and provision of services or the administration of contracts related to the maintenance, security, operation of the district, as authorized by the Act. 
A special assessment shall be levied against assessable property on the basis of special benefits to that parcel from the total project. There is a rebuttable presumption that a district project specially benefits all assessable property located within the district. 
The Board may recommend to the City Commission that the special assessment district be divided in special assessment rate zones reflecting varying levels of special benefits or services. The Board may also recommend to the City Commission that the various businesses or properties be divided into distinct classes reflecting varying levels of special benefits. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.962. - Report Containing Maps and Estimates. 
Before the City Commission shall take action respecting any special assessment hereunder, the City Manager shall prepare a report containing: 1) a map of the proposed special assessment district; 2) an estimate of the cost of the proposed Public Improvement or Ongoing Operations; 3) the number of Board members in the district; 4) the proposed classes of property owners in the district; 5) the number and percentage of each class of business or property owner who are projected to pay an assessment and an estimate of the amount to be assessed to each such class; 6) the scope, nature, and duration of the Public Improvement or Ongoing Activity. After the report is presented to the City Commission, it shall be filed with the City Clerk and made available to the public for examination. The City Manager or City staff acting on behalf of the City Manager may enlist the aid of the Board in preparing the report and in doing other things that are part of the special assessment process. However, in all such matters, the Board's involvement shall be advisory only and final responsibility for conducting such activities shall rest with the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.963. - Hearing on Necessity. 
After the material required to be prepared by the City Manager is presented to the City Commission, the Commission may direct by resolution of a majority of the members elect that a public hearing concerning necessity for such proposed special assessment shall be held before the City Commission at a time and place to be fixed by it. The City Manager shall cause notice of the time and place of such hearing to be published once in the official newspaper of the City not less than ten (10) days prior to the date of said hearing. Such notice shall also state that the report is on file with the City Clerk for public examination. A like ten-day notice shall also be sent by first class mail to each owner of property subject to assessment in the proposed special assessment district as indicated by the records of the Assessor's Office at the address and to the person shown on the current tax assessment roll of the City. 
At the time and place specified in such notice of public hearing the City Commission shall meet and hear any person to be affected by the proposed special assessment. The hearing may be adjourned from time to time as shall be determined by the City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.964. - Determination of Necessity. 
After completion of the hearing, the City Commission may, by resolution of a majority of the members elect, declare the scope, nature and duration of the Public Improvement or Ongoing Activity to be necessary and determine to defray the whole or any part of the cost of the Public Improvement or Ongoing Activity by special assessment upon the properties especially benefited in proportion to the benefits thereto. In addition, by said resolution the City Commission shall order to be transmitted to the Assessor a map of the district fixed by it and a certified copy of said resolution. The City Manager shall transmit to the Assessor such facts as it may have necessary to make proper assessment. 
The total amount assessed for a Public Improvement may be made payable in not more than twenty (20) annual installments. A determination of necessity for Ongoing Activity shall be valid for a period specified in the resolution up to five (5) years in duration. 
The City Manager may recommend and the City Commission may approve one (1) or more special assessment districts covering all or any portion of the Downtown District related to a Public Improvement or Ongoing Activity benefiting properties in that district. 
The City Manager may recommend expansion of a special assessment district for the provision of Ongoing Activity to areas not originally receiving special benefit. A public hearing on the necessity of the proposed expansion shall be held, as provided in Section 1.963, and the City Commission may declare that the scope, nature and duration of the Ongoing Activity to be a necessity in the expanded area and may determine to defray the cost by special assessment, as provided in this Section 1.964. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.965. - Preparation of Assessment Roll. 
Within ninety (90) days after the adoption of a resolution making a determination of necessity for a Public Improvement, as specified in Section 1.964, the Assessor shall prepare a special assessment roll which shall contain the names of the owners and the descriptions of the several parcels of property in the special assessment district to be assessed for such Public Improvement, as fixed by the City Commission. 
Within thirty (30) days after the adoption of resolution making a determination of necessity for Ongoing Activity, as specified in Section 1.964, the Assessor shall prepare an initial special assessment roll which shall contain the names of the owners and the descriptions of the several parcels of property in the special assessment district to be assessed for such Ongoing Activity, as fixed by the City Commission. If the duration of the Ongoing Activity exceeds one (1) year, the special assessment roll shall be divided into annual installments, not exceeding five (5), with a separate installment for each fiscal year specified by the resolution determining the necessity of the special assessment. The annual installments may be either in equal amounts or in unequal amounts as the City Commission may determine is the need for each of the fiscal years covered by the resolution of necessity. 
Each special assessment roll shall spread and levy that part of the cost of the proposed Public Improvement or proposed Ongoing Activity against each of such property in the special assessment district as determined by the City Commission, in proportion as near as may be to the advantages which each parcel in such district shall be deemed by the Assessor to be benefited by the making of such improvement or conducting said activity. 
After the assessment roll is completed, the Assessor shall give notice to all persons assessed thereon of the completion of such roll and that the same will be open for ten (10) days for public inspection and for correction by the Assessor and of the time and place of the meeting of the Board of Review on the special assessment roll. Said notice shall be given by publication at least once in the official newspaper of the City not less than five (5) full days prior to the first day on which such special assessment roll will be open for public inspection. A like five-day notice shall also be sent by first class mail by the Assessor to each owner of property subject to assessment as shown on the current tax assessment rolls of the City. 
Immediately after the expiration of the ten-day period for public inspection and correction, the special assessment roll shall be signed by the Assessor and returned forthwith to the City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.966. - Hearing on Roll. 
At a regular session not less than one (1) week after the receipt of such special assessment roll from the Assessor and at the time and place specified in the notice given by the Assessor as required by Section 1.965, the City Commission shall act thereon as a Board of Review and shall continue to act at such other times as may be necessary and as it shall from time to time designate. Any person may appeal in writing to the City Commission acting as such Board of Review at any time prior to the opening of its first session as such Board of Review. The City Commission as such Board of Review shall have the power to correct or change the whole or any part of such special assessment roll or to return it to the Assessor for reassessment, in which latter case it shall take the same course as an original special assessment roll. At such time as the City Commission sitting as a Board of Review is satisfied with the special assessment roll, and is of the opinion that such special assessment roll results in the assessments being levied in accordance with the benefits, it shall cause such determination to be entered upon its minutes. Thereafter the City Commission shall adopt a resolution ratifying and confirming said special assessment roll and, in addition, by the terms of said resolution shall determine when such special assessments shall be due and paid or, if the same shall be paid in installments, it shall determine the due dates of the first and subsequent installments on said special assessment roll. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.967. - Return of Roll. 
If it shall be determined by the City Commission, acting as such Board of Review, to return said assessment roll to the City Assessor for reassessment, the reason for so doing and any instructions or recommendations shall be embodied in a resolution and a copy thereof certified to by the City Clerk as correct, shall be at once delivered, with said assessment roll, to the City Assessor. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.968. - Delivery of Roll to Treasurer. 
The special assessment roll as confirmed by the City Commission shall be delivered by the City Clerk to the City Treasurer for collection with the proper warrant for such purpose attached thereto signed by the Mayor and attested in due form by the City Clerk. In the event that the project will not be started immediately, the City Commission may, in the same resolution confirming the assessment roll, establish a date for collection by the City Treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.969. - Lien Established. 
Except as otherwise stated in this Section, all special assessments contained in any special assessment roll, including any part thereof deferred as to payment and such administrative charge as may be applicable thereto, shall from the date and time of receipt thereof by the City Treasurer constitute a lien upon the respective parcels of land or interest in land assessed, and until paid shall be a charge against the respective owners of the several parcels of land or interest in land. Such lien shall be of the same character and effect as the lien created for City taxes and shall include accrued interest and penalties. No judgment or decree nor any act of the City Commission vacating a special assessment shall destroy or impair the lien of the City on the premises assessed for such amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the same. For a special assessment to provide Ongoing Activity exceeding one (1) year in duration, a separate lien shall be established for each annual installment. For the first annual installment, the lien shall be established as of the date and time of the receipt of the special assessment roll by the City Treasurer. For the second annual installment, the lien shall be established on the first anniversary of receipt of the roll by the City Treasurer; for the third installment, it shall be the second anniversary date; for the fourth installment, it shall be the third anniversary date; for the fifth installment, it shall be the fourth anniversary of receipt of the roll by the City Treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.970. - Deficiency Assessments. 
The City Commission may provide for spreading of an additional assessment for any improvement in case it determines that the former assessment or assessments will not produce sufficient funds to pay for a Public Improvement or Ongoing Activity. Such additional assessment shall be spread upon a supplemental roll, which shall conform so far as may be practical to the original roll for such improvement, and shall be made, reviewed, delivered, collected, accounted for and returned in the same manner as the original roll, and all sales and redemptions of property therein described shall be made in the same manner as the sales and redemption upon said original roll. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.971. - Notice of Assessment. 
Upon receipt of a special assessment roll with the proper warrant for such purpose attached thereto as hereinbefore provided for, the City Treasurer shall mail statements of the several assessments to the respective owners, stating the amount of the assessment and the manner in which it may be paid, and, in addition, the City Treasurer shall publish notice of the fact that said special assessments are due in the official newspaper of the City on or prior to the date that said statements are mailed. Where the special assessment roll is divided into more than one (1) installment, published notice of the second and subsequent installments need not be given, but mailed notice to the owner as shown on the current tax assessment rolls of the City, stating the due date and amount of the next installment, shall be deemed sufficient. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.972. - Interest on Unpaid Installments. 
In addition to the principal amount of each annual installment there shall be added thereto and collected from the special assessment roll by the City Treasurer as part of each annual installment interest at a rate which shall be determined by the City Commission, which shall be adjusted to a rate equal to the rate borne by the bonds or other evidences of indebtedness issued or authorized to defray the cost plus one (1) percentum per annum on the entire unpaid balance of the special assessment, commencing with the due date of the first installment and computed to the due date of each particular installment. In addition to said annual interest, in the event that any special assessment or installment thereof shall not be paid within one (1) month of the due date thereof, penalties shall thereafter be charged and added to said past due assessment or installment in lieu of further interest on said installment, as provided in Section 1.375 of Chapter 9 of Title I of the Code of the City of Grand Rapids. Such penalties shall be collected at the same time and in the same manner as the special assessments and interest thereon are collected. The entire assessment, or the first installment thereof if divided into installments, may be paid during the first month after the due date thereof without interest. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.973. - Delinquent Installments. 
When any special assessment or any installment thereof, when divided into installments, shall have been due and unpaid for more than thirty (30) days, such fact shall be certified to by the City Treasurer and filed with the City Assessor. Said certified account shall contain an accurate description of the lot or parcel of land and such account shall be included by the City Assessor on a tax roll and tax warrant. The Assessor shall deliver a copy of said roll and warrant to the City Treasurer and notify him of the amount of special assessment within the time and in the manner and form provided for in the general tax law of the State. The special assessment shall become due and collected when other property taxes fall due and shall be returned for nonpayment in the same manner as other property taxes. Delinquent installments shall be collected as part of the tax roll in the manner and to the extent set forth in the Michigan general property tax law. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 5-12-09)  
Sec. 1.974. - Reserved.
