Chapter 25 - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, adopted August 28, 2012, effective September 4, 2012, amended chapter 25 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former chapter 25, §§ 2.1—2.20, pertained to combustible waste and solid waste, and derived from Ord. No. 85-69, § 1, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 91-08, §§ 1, 2, 1-29-91; Ord. No. 91-33, § 1, 6-18-91; Ord. No. 91-66, §§ 1—4, 12-17-91; Ord. No. 92-38, § 1, 6-16-92; Ord. No. 97-43, § 1, 9-9-97; Ord. No. 97-66, § 1, 12-30-97; Ord. No. 98-38, § 1, 8-18-98; Ord. No. 99-44, § 1, 8-10-99; Ord. No. 2000-08, § 1, 2-22-00; Ord. No. 2001-06, § 1, 2-20-01; Ord. No. 2002-23, § 1, 5-7-02. 
Cross reference— General health regulations, Ch. 71; secondhand dealers, Ch. 101; Housing Code, Ch. 140; litter, § 9.91 et seq.; property maintenance nuisances, § 9.107 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate disposal of garbage and rubbish, MCL 123.241 et seq., 123.361 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2.1. - Definitions. 
In the interpretation of this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
1.  Act 451 Plan means the Kent County Solid Waste Management Plan approved by the City of Grand Rapids, the Kent County Board of Commissioners and by the Director of the Department of Natural Resources, pursuant to the requirements and provisions of Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of Michigan, 1994, as amended, and any amendments thereto adopted in accordance with said Act. 
2.  Appliance is intended to include the following household major appliances that will not fit within a cart: refrigerators and freezers with doors removed, stoves, dishwashers, microwaves, air conditioners, washers, dryers, humidifiers, dehumidifiers, garbage disposals, trash compactors, furnaces and water heaters. 
3.  Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, refuse, waste water sludge, or other combustible materials. 
4.  Board of Public Works means the Kent County Board of Public Works established pursuant to the provisions of Act No. 185 of the Public Acts of 1957, as amended. 
5.  Bulk Item means any item that does not fit within a cart such as sofas, chairs, mattresses, lawnmowers, and other household items. 
6.  City Refuse Bags shall mean those polyethylene plastic bags sold by the City clearly distinguishable by their color, by the City Seal, and other markings, as intended for City collection. 
7.  City Refuse Carts shall mean rigid construction containers provided by the City clearly distinguishable by their color and markings as intended to be used for City collection. 
8.  Combustible Waste means Solid Waste that is combustible in the WTE as shall be determined solely by the Board of Public Works. "Combustible Waste" shall include: (a) Garbage; (b) combustible rubbish, such as paper, cardboard, cartons, wood, boxes, rags, cloth, bedding, leather, grass, leaves and brush, yard trimmings, tree limbs, timber, logs, and stumps six (6) inches in diameter or less, carpeting, and combustible construction and demolition debris; and (c) any other Solid Waste that is combustible in the WTE as shall be determined solely by the Board of Public Works. "Combustible Waste" shall exclude: (a) noncombustible Solid Waste, such as Ashes, noncombustible Rubbish, incinerator ash, incinerator residue, municipal and industrial sludge, animal waste, pathological and biological waste, asbestos and asbestos waste products, explosives, radioactive materials, appliances, concrete rubble, noncombustible construction and demolition debris, rock, gravel and earth materials, automobiles, trailers, equipment wire and cable; (b) all waste other than Solid Waste (such as Hazardous Waste, Site-Separated Materials, and Source-Separated Materials); and (c) any other type of waste that is noncombustible in the WTE as shall be determined solely by the Board of Public Works. 
9.  County means the County of Kent, Michigan, acting by and through its Board of Commissioners or its Department of Public Works. 
10.  Disposal Site means any of the following: (1) a Solid Waste transfer facility; (2) a single incinerator having an average daily design capacity exceeding fifty (50) tons of Solid Waste per day or two (2) or more incinerators located at one (1) site under the control of one (1) person and having an aggregate average daily design capacity exceeding one hundred fifty (150) tons of Solid Waste per day; (3) a sanitary landfill; (4) a Solid Waste Processing Plant; or (5) any other Solid Waste handling or disposal facility utilized in the disposal of Solid Waste. 
11.  Garbage means rejected food wastes, including waste accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter, used or intended for food or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in, or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetable. 
12.  Hazardous Waste means hazardous waste as defined in Act No. 64 of the Public Acts of Michigan, 1979, as amended from time to time, and as identified in administrative rules promulgated from time to time pursuant to said Act by the Director of the Michigan Department of Natural Resources. 
13.  Manager shall mean the person holding the position or acting in the capacity of the City Manager, appointed by the City Commission, or his or her duly authorized representative. 
14.  Person means any individual, firm, public or private corporation, partnership, trust, public or private agency or any other entity, or any group of such persons. 
15.  Premises means any enclosed area used for residential, commercial or industrial purposes, separately or in combination, to which a separate street address, postal address or box, tax roll description, or other similar identification has been assigned to or is in use by a Person having control of the area. 
16.  Regulations shall mean the City's Solid Waste Regulations governing the collection and disposal of recycling, refuse, and yard waste which are promulgated by the Manager under the authority of this Chapter. 
17.  Residential Unit shall mean a dwelling occupied by one (1) or more persons in the City, and so designated and arranged as to provide cooking, kitchen and sanitary accommodations for one (1) group of persons only. 
18.  Rubbish means nonputrescible Solid Waste, excluding Ashes, consisting of combustible and noncombustible waste, including paper, cardboard, metal containers, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, demolished building materials, or litter of any kind that may be a detriment to the public health and safety. 
19.  Site of Generation means any Premises in or on which Solid Waste is generated by any Person. 
20.  Recyclable Materials means materials including but not limited to bottles, cans, newspapers, corrugated containers, metals, and plastics that are eligible for pickup as part of the City's Single Stream Recycling Program, as determined by the City's Solid Waste Regulations. 
21.  Solid Waste means garbage, rubbish, ashes, incinerator ash, incinerator residue, street cleanings, municipal and industrial sludges, solid commercial and solid industrial waste, and animal waste provided, however, that this definition shall not include hazardous waste, site separated materials, source separated materials, human body waste, liquid or other waste regulated by statute, ferrous or non-ferrous scrap directed to a scrap metal processor or to a reuser of ferrous or non-ferrous products, and slag or slag products directed to a slag processor or to a reuser of slag or slag products. 
22.  Solid Waste Container means a container or receptacle designed or used for depositing, storing, or accumulating Solid Waste for collection or transportation by a Waste Hauler. Without limitation, this definition shall include dumpsters, packer boxes, and roll-offs or other receptacles designed or used to store Solid Waste or to transport Solid Waste from a Site of Generation. 
23.  Source-Separated Materials means recyclable materials as defined in this Chapter that are separated from Solid Waste prior to the collection of Solid Waste from a Site of Generation. 
24.  Tipping Fee means the fee established by the Board of Public Works to be charged upon delivery of Combustible Waste to the WTE. 
25.  Waste Hauler means any Person engaged, in whole or in part, in the business of collecting, transporting, delivering, or disposing of Combustible Waste generated within the City. 
26.  Waste to Energy Facility (WTE) means the mass-burn energy-generating incinerator constructed by or on behalf of, or available by contract or lease with, the County within the City of Grand Rapids in accordance with the Act 451 Plan. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.2. - Solid Waste Regulations. 
The Manager is hereby authorized to promulgate Regulations governing the collection and disposal of recycling, refuse, and yard waste; and establishing a schedule for the collection of the same. Such Regulations shall also provide for the type of containers acceptable for collection by the City. Solid Waste collection services shall be offered by the City to all Premises within the City in accordance with the Regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.3. - Authority to Discontinue Solid Waste Collection Service. 
Upon order of the Manager, the City may discontinue solid waste collection service to any Premises where the owner or occupant fails or refuses to comply with the provisions of this Chapter or any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this Chapter, and such service need not thereafter be reinstated until such violation is remedied to the satisfaction of the Manager, or his or her designee. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.4. - Outdoor Storage of Solid Waste and Cart Requirements. 
(1)  The owner or occupant of any residential unit within the City in which any Solid Waste shall be accumulated, shall maintain on said Premises one (1) or more refuse carts, each having a capacity of not more than one hundred (100) gallons. The number of carts kept on each Premises shall be sufficient to conveniently store the normal accumulation of Solid Waste on said Premises over a period of not less than seven (7) days; and for Recyclable Materials, not less than 14 days. Such carts shall be constructed of rigid metal or plastic with tightly fitting covers which are rodent-proof. Rigid refuse carts must be kept tightly covered except when opened for deposit or removal of Solid Waste. All Solid Waste being stored on any Premises between collections must be stored in a rigid container with a tightly fitting cover. 
(2)  Rigid carts for storage of Solid Waste shall be placed at the rear or side of buildings at a place which is reasonably inconspicuous and away from streets and places occupied by other persons. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.5. - Place of Collection. 
All Solid Waste intended for City collection shall be contained in one (1) or more City refuse bags or City refuse carts and shall be placed in the parkway near the curb adjacent to the property, unless otherwise specifically permitted at an alternate location by the Regulations. Such carts shall be placed at that location prior to 7:00 a.m. on the day scheduled for collection from that property. In no event shall any Solid Waste be placed at the curb for collection before 7:00 p.m. of the day preceding the scheduled collection day, whether collected by the City or by a private Waste Hauler. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.6. - Litter and Accumulation. 
No person shall throw or deposit any Garbage or Rubbish upon or into any street, alley or other property, public or private. It shall be the duty of every occupant of property and of every owner of unoccupied property at all times to maintain the Premises occupied or owned by him or her, in a clean and orderly condition, permitting no deposit or accumulation of Garbage or Rubbish upon such Premises. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12) 
Cross reference— Littering generally, § 9.91 et seq. 
State Law reference— Littering, MCL 752.901 et seq., MSA 28.603(1) et seq.  
Sec. 2.7. - Disposal of Combustible Waste and Solid Waste. 
(1)  Transportation and Disposal by Persons. No person shall dispose of any Solid Waste within the City other than by means of the City's Solid Waste collection service or by means of a Waste Hauler duly licensed by the City for such purpose. 
(2)  Transportation and Disposal by Waste Haulers. All Combustible Waste collected or transported by Waste Haulers shall be disposed of only in accordance with Section 2.14. All Solid Waste other than Combustible Waste collected or transported by Waste Haulers shall be disposed of only at disposal areas consistent with the Act 451 Plan. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.8. - Sale of City Refuse Bags and Carts. 
Pursuant to the Solid Waste Regulations promulgated under the authority of this Chapter, the City shall provide a means for the sale and distribution of City refuse bags and carts. No person shall possess for sale, sell, or offer for sale, any plastic bags, carts, or any other material or substance which shall imitate City refuse bags or carts. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.9. - Fees. 
Fees for Solid Waste services provided by the City in accordance with this Chapter shall be established from time to time by resolution of the City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.10. - Solid Waste Haulers. 
(1)  No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transporting, delivering, or disposing of Solid Waste in the City of Grand Rapids without first obtaining a Solid Waste Hauler License. Solid Waste Hauler Licenses shall be issued upon application to the City Clerk on forms provided by the Clerk upon payment of such fees as shall be required by Chapter 92. It shall be an express condition of each License that the Waste Hauler shall comply with all provisions of this Chapter. 
(2)  Except as provided herein, no person shall collect Solid Waste or Source-Separated Materials anywhere within the City between the following hours: 
a.  11:00 p.m. Saturday to 9:00 a.m. Sunday. 
b.  11:00 p.m. Sunday to 7:00 a.m. Monday. 
c.  11:00 p.m. Monday to 7:00 a.m. Tuesday. 
d.  11:00 p.m. Tuesday to 7:00 a.m. Wednesday. 
e.  11:00 p.m. Wednesday to 7:00 a.m. Thursday. 
f.  11:00 p.m. Thursday to 7:00 a.m. Friday. 
g.  11:00 p.m. Friday to 9:00 a.m. Saturday. 
h.  Federal holidays—11:00 p.m. the previous evening to 9:00 a.m. 
i.  Saturdays following a federal holiday observed on a weekday—11:00 p.m. the previous evening to 7:00 a.m. 
(3)  Subsection (2) shall not apply to the following: 
a.  The collection of Solid Waste and Source-Separated Materials within all that portion of the City's Downtown area, specifically the area lying west of a line with its northerly beginning at the intersection of Michigan Street and Barclay Avenue, thence south along Barclay Avenue to the intersection of Lyon Street, thence west along Lyon Street to Bostwick Avenue, thence south along Bostwick Avenue to Fulton Street, thence east along Fulton Street to Jefferson Avenue, thence south along Jefferson Avenue to State Street, thence southeasterly along State Street to Lafayette Avenue, thence south along Lafayette Avenue to the southerly point of ending of said line at the intersection of Lafayette Avenue and Wealthy Street. 
b.  The collection of Solid Waste and Source-Separated Materials within any industrially-zoned district (IT and IC) as identified in Chapter 61, so long as the carts being emptied are located at least one hundred (100) feet from any dwelling unit. 
c.  If the City receives verified complaints of three (3) or more separate incidents within any calendar year of either excessive noise of waste hauler activities at any one location by any one waste hauler or of a waste hauler operating during prohibited hours, then the Manager may order the responsible waste hauler to permanently comply with Subsection (2) at the location from which the excessive noise emanated or where operations were conducted during prohibited hours. Failure on the part of the hauler to comply with such directive may result in revocation of the hauler's license by the City Clerk as permitted under authority of Chapter 91 of this Code. 
d.  The collection of Solid Waste and Source-Separated Materials within a completely enclosed building. 
e.  The collection of Solid Waste and Source-Separated Materials anywhere within the City during the period of any disaster or emergency as determined and declared by the Mayor. 
f.  The collection of Solid Waste and Source-Separated Materials from any collection site anywhere within the City whenever a waiver permit has been validly issued for such collection pursuant to Regulations promulgated by the City Manager. 
(4)  Nothing in this Section is intended, nor shall it be construed, as authorizing the violation of the City's Noise Ordinance or waiving the application of its provisions to Waste Hauler operations. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12) 
Cross reference— License fee for waste haulers, § 7.48.  
Sec. 2.11. - Solid Waste Transportation Unit and Identification of Solid Waste Carts. 
(1)  Solid Waste Transportation Unit. 
a.  Any Solid Waste transportation unit operated in the City of Grand Rapids shall have the name of the duly licensed Waste Hauler, the address and telephone number plainly marked upon both sides of the vehicle in a place and color plainly visible, in letters and figures of three (3) inches or more. 
b.  A Solid Waste transporting unit shall not be parked in a residential area longer than necessary to collect Solid Waste unless within a completely enclosed garage or building. A Solid Waste transporting unit shall not be parked, stored or established at any location so as to cause a nuisance or hazard to health. 
(2)  Identification of Solid Waste Containers. 
a.  Solid Waste Containers having a capacity of at least one-half (½) cubic yard shall be plainly marked with the name and current street address or the name and current telephone number of the Waste Hauler which collects Solid Waste from or transports Solid Waste within the Solid Waste Container. The name and current street address or the name and current telephone number of the Waste Hauler shall be plainly marked on at least three (3) sides of the Solid Waste Container in letters and figures not less than three (3) inches in height. 
b.  The Waste Hauler collecting Solid Waste from or transporting the Solid Waste Container having a capacity of at least one-half (½) cubic yard shall be responsible for complying with this Section. It shall be a violation of this Section for any Waste Hauler to collect Solid Waste from or to transport such a Solid Waste Container unless the Solid Waste Container has been marked in compliance with this Section. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12) 
Cross reference— Nuisances, Ch. 151; general traffic regulations, Ch. 181.  
Sec. 2.12. - Insurance Requirements. 
An applicant for a Solid Waste Hauler License shall furnish to the City Clerk evidence of Contractor's Motor Vehicle, Bodily Injury and Property Damage Insurance in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence, with the City of Grand Rapids named as an additional insured on the Policy. In the event of cancellation or non-renewal of any policy required under this Section, the Solid Waste Hauler shall immediately notify the City Clerk of such cancellation or non-renewal. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.13. - Reserved.  
Sec. 2.14. - Delivery of Combustible Waste. 
(1)  Waste Haulers shall (a) deliver to the WTE all Combustible Waste collected or transported from a Site of Generation within the City and (b) pay the Tipping Fee for delivery of such Waste at the WTE (unless otherwise provided by contract between the City and the Waste Hauler). No Waste Hauler shall deliver Combustible Waste collected or transported from a Site of Generation within the City to any Disposal Site other than the WTE. 
(2)  Waste Haulers shall deliver to the WTE all Combustible Waste regardless of whether the Combustible Waste is transported in the same load or vehicle as Solid Waste which is not Combustible Waste. This requirement shall be absolute and unconditional unless the Board of Public Works, acting through its designated representatives, has made a prior written determination that a specific load of waste consists primarily of waste which would not be accepted for delivery at the WTE. Such a written determination of the Board of Public Works shall not be applicable to waste collected from any Site of Generation, any load or vehicle, any Waste Hauler or any facts or circumstances, other than those expressly identified in the written determination. 
(3)  Waste Haulers shall not deliver Combustible Waste to a site for site separation of recyclable materials unless the Board of Public Works, acting through its designated representatives, after request of the Waste Hauler, has made a prior written determination that such delivery does not violate this Ordinance. Such a written determination shall not be applicable to waste collected from any Site of Generation, any load or vehicle, any Waste Hauler, or any facts or circumstances other than those expressly identified in the written determination. A written determination pursuant to this Section shall not relieve the Waste Hauler from the obligation to deliver to the WTE all Combustible Waste remaining in a load after site separation of recyclable materials. 
(4)  Waste Haulers shall not deliver Hazardous Waste to the WTE. 
(5)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this Chapter, Waste Haulers shall not be prohibited from transporting Combustible Waste collected from a Site of Generation within the City for disposal at any Disposal Site located outside the State of Michigan. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.15. - Compliance with Laws, Rules and Regulations. 
Waste Haulers shall comply with the Act 451 Plan and all applicable Federal and State laws, statutes, rules and regulations (including, but not limited to, Act 451 and administrative rules promulgated pursuant to Act 451) in the collection, transportation, delivery, and disposal of Combustible Waste. Waste Haulers shall also comply with all rules and regulations of the Board of Public Works for the administration and operation of the WTE (including, without limitation, rules and regulations prohibiting delivery of loads consisting primarily of unacceptable waste as solely determined by the Board of Public Works acting through its designated representatives) and other Disposal Sites of the Kent County Refuse Disposal System. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Sec. 2.16. - Penalties. 
(1)  Any violation of this Chapter or the Regulations promulgated under the authority of this Chapter may result in termination or suspension of Solid Waste collection service, according to the procedures set forth in the Regulations for such termination or suspension of collection service. 
(2)  Any violation of this Chapter or the Regulations promulgated under the authority of this Chapter committed by any Waste Hauler may result in suspension or revocation of such Waste Hauler's license in accordance with Chapter 91 of the City Code. 
(3)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this Chapter, any violation of either this Chapter or the Regulations promulgated under the authority of this Chapter that is deemed to be a Nuisance under Chapter 151 of this Code shall be subject to abatement and all other remedies available under Chapter 151. 
(Ord. No. 2012-47, § 1, 8-28-12, eff. 9-4-12)  
Chapter 26 - CITY WATER SYSTEM[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Director of Public Service, Title VI, Sec. 9; power and duty of City Commission as to Public Works, Public and Special Improvements, Title X, Sec. 7. 
Cross reference— Department of Water, § 1.128; streets, Ch. 51; sewer and water connections, §§ 4.11, 4.12; sidewalks, Ch. 52; interference with natural or artificial drains § 5.366; general health regulations, Ch. 71; general building regulations, Ch. 131; plumbing regulations, Ch. 132; Mechanical Code, Ch. 134; floodplain construction, Ch. 144; waterways, Ch. 154; fire prevention, Ch. 159. 
 
ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2.21. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this Chapter is to establish standards, rules and regulations with respect to the use of the Grand Rapids Water System; to provide for the rates and charges for the connection to and use of the System. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.22. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this Chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this Section unless the context in which they are used specifically indicates otherwise: 
1.  Commercial user shall mean a person whose premises are used to offer services and/or products such as retail and wholesale stores, gasoline stations, restaurants, schools, churches, hotels, motels, nursing homes, private clubs, theaters and governmental buildings. 
2.  Commodity charge shall mean a variable unit charge payable by a user based on the actual water consumption as determined in this Chapter. 
3.  Customer class shall mean a governmental entity whose citizens receive the service of the System. 
4.  Director shall mean the Director of the Grand Rapids Water System. 
5.  Domestic user shall mean a person whose premises are domiciles for single or multiple family use. 
6.  Industrial user shall mean a person who operates a manufacturing or process facility which is engaged in producing a product. 
7.  Intermediate transmission lines shall mean those pipes which not only transport water to one (1) or more local service areas but also provide local service. 
8.  Local distribution lines shall mean those pipes which serve only the abutting property within only one (1) local service area. 
9.  Person shall mean any individual, firm, partnership, association, public or private corporation or public agency or instrumentality or any other entity receiving water service. 
10.  Premises shall mean each lot or parcel of land or building having any connection to the Water System. 
11.  Primary transmission lines shall mean those pipes whose only function is to transport water to and through one (1) or more local service areas, and to which water connection pipes are not attached. 
12.  Service charge shall mean a fixed charge payable by a user based on the size of his or her water meter. 
13.  Water connection pipe shall mean that pipe connecting the watermain with the premises served. This includes the connection to the watermain or the corporation cock, the shutoff valve, and the valves on the inlet and outlet sides of the meter. 
14.  Watermain shall mean the primary and intermediate transmission and local distribution lines of the System. 
15.  Water System or System shall mean the Grand Rapids Water System consisting of all plants, works, instrumentalities, lines and properties now or hereafter existing, used or useful in connection with the obtaining of a water supply, its treatment, distribution and all other necessary functions. 
16.  User class shall mean either a domestic, commercial or industrial group of users. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
ARTICLE 2. - WATER SYSTEM USE 
 
Sec. 2.23. - Management of the Water System. 
The Grand Rapids Water System shall be and remain under the management, supervision and control of the City Manager who may employ or designate such person or persons in such capacity or capacities as he or she deems advisable to carry out the efficient management and operation of the System. The City Manager or his or her designee may make such rules, orders or regulations as he or she deems advisable and necessary to assure the efficient management and operation of the System; subject, however, to the rights, powers and duties with respect thereto which are reserved by law to the City Commission of Grand Rapids. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.23.1 - Public water connection required. 
The owner of each house, building or other structure equipped with plumbing fixtures and used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other potable use, e.g., domestic use, situated within or outside the City and abutting any street, alley, right-of-way or public utility easement in which there is located, or may in the future be located, a public watermain served by the City Water System, shall, at her, his or its expense, install suitable plumbing facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly to the public watermain, provided said public watermain is within a two hundred (200) foot radius of the house, building or other structure where connection will occur and, provided further, such connection shall not be required to a house, building or other structure where on the effective date of this Section it was served by a private water well until such time as such private water well fails and the local health agency governing private water wells has determined that such failure exists and that it is unable to issue a permit for repair or replacement of such failed well within the parcel of property where the failed well is located. Well failure shall be as determined and defined by the local health agency governing private water wells within the areas served by the Water System. Except as provided in the immediately preceding sentences, all domestic water usage at such connected house, building or structure shall be through the Water System; private wells shall not be permitted to provide domestic water service to such house, building or structure; and once connected to the public Water System disconnection shall be prohibited. It shall be the owner's responsibility to plug or cap the abandoned domestic water well and contact the local health agency that governs private water wells for proper procedures for plugging and capping such abandoned domestic water wells. Notwithstanding any current or future agreement between the City and another municipality being served by the City Water System, said municipality shall have the option of adopting the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2010-64, § 1, 11-30-10)  
Sec. 2.24. - Standards and Regulations. 
Standards and regulations established in this Chapter or pursuant hereto are deemed to be the absolute minimum consistent with the preservation of the public health, safety and welfare and to fulfill the obligations of the City with respect to State and Federal Law and all rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.25. - Use of the Water System. 
Any person conforming to the standards, rules and regulations established in or pursuant to this Chapter shall be permitted to receive water provided there exists adequate water lines to which he or she can connect. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.26. - Service Connection. 
(1)  Application for water connection shall be made to the System on forms prescribed and furnished by it. Water connections and water meters shall be installed in accordance with the rules and regulations of this System and upon the payment of the required charges and fees. 
(2)  The City Commission of the City of Grand Rapids finds that the elimination of lead pipe water service connections from within the City is in the best interests of its citizens and will promote the public health, safety and welfare. Therefore, it is the public policy of the City Commission to encourage and facilitate the elimination of such lead pipes through the provisions of sub-section (3) hereof, and it is further the intent of the City Commission that such provisions be liberally construed to further this public policy. 
(3)  The City will assist residential property owners to eliminate lead pipe water service connections in the following situations, under the following terms and conditions: 
(a)  Category A. Whenever the City undertakes a street, watermain, or sewer main construction or improvement project and the City Engineer deems that the nature of the project lends itself to the elimination and replacement of lead pipe water service connections with a minimum of additional cost and disruption of sidewalks and other improvements, the City Engineer will notify the owners of all residential properties abutting the project for which the lead pipe water service connections could be replaced during project construction with such minimum cost and disruption that they can have such connections replaced at their cost at the then current standard Category A rates established by resolution of the City Commission pursuant to this sub-section. Such notice shall be by such means as shall be reasonably calculated to provide actual notice and understanding of the options available. The City Engineer shall keep an appropriate record of all such notices and the responses received. Notices given under this Category A must specify a date by which an affirmative response must be received in order to receive the advantages of minimum disruption and the rates established for Category A. 
(b)  Category B. For those residential properties which abutted a City project described in (a) above completed not more than three (3) years previously and whose then current owners had received notice of the opportunity to eliminate and replace their lead pipe water service connections at Category A rates but declined to do so, the current owners may apply for replacement of such service connections at their cost at the then current standard Category B rates established by resolution of the City Commission pursuant to this sub-section. 
(c)  Category C. For those residential properties which do not abut a current project described in (1) above and have not abutted such a project which has been completed less than three (3) years previously, the owners may apply for replacement of their lead pipe water service connections at their cost at the then current standard Category C rates established by resolution of the City Commission pursuant to this sub-section. 
(d)  The City Commission by resolution from time to time shall establish standard rates for each of the three (3) separate categories of properties stated above. In the establishment of such rates, the City Commission shall consider the actual cost differences and the differing degree of disruption of sidewalks and other facilities caused by elimination and replacement of lead pipe water service connections under the three (3) categories of properties, as well as any other factors it deems relevant. For the first year, the rates may be established after some replacement has already occurred and, thus, in setting these initial rates, the City Commission should consider, among other factors, any estimates of costs the City Engineer may have made regarding such replacement. 
(e)  The City Engineer shall establish, and pre-qualify as he or she deems appropriate, a list of licensed plumbing contractors who are willing to eliminate and replace lead pipe water service connections at the rates established by the City Commission. This list shall be provided to all property owners who wish to have their lead pipe water service connections eliminated and replaced, who can then arrange to have such work performed by any contractor on this approved list. 
(f)  All property owners electing to replace their lead pipe water service connections pursuant to this sub-section shall have the option of either paying off the full cost of the replacement at the established rates within thirty (30) days after completion of the work or of paying for the work at the established rates in a maximum of ten (10) annual installments of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) each, with interest at a rate as shall be established or adjusted from time to time by resolution of the City Commission. They shall elect their option by executing a written agreement in recordable form with the City Engineer prior to the performance of the work on their water service connection. This agreement shall state the language of (g) below. If the property owner elects to pay in installments, the City Engineer shall promptly record the agreement with the Kent County Register of Deeds and promptly provide the City Treasurer with a copy thereof. If the property owner elects to pay off the full cost within thirty (30) days, the City Engineer shall promptly provide the City Treasurer with a copy of the agreement; in such case, the City Engineer shall record the agreement with the Kent County Register of Deeds only if full payment is not received within thirty (30) days from the completion of the work. 
(g)  The cost of the work shall immediately and automatically become a lien against the premises for which the work is done as soon as such work is completed. Such lien shall be of the same character, and any late payments for the cost of such work, shall be subject to the same methods of collection, including penalties, interest, and late charges, as prescribed for special assessments in Chapter 10 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 92-40, §§ 1, 2, 7-14-92; Ord. No. 2016-13, § 1, 3-29-16)  
Sec. 2.27. - Meters. 
All premises using water shall be metered except as otherwise may be provided in this Chapter. All meters shall be the property of the System. No person except an authorized City employee shall break or injure the seal or change the location of, or alter or interfere in any way with, any water meter. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.28. - Inspection. 
The Director and other duly authorized employees of the City bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties at reasonable times for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter. Any person who applies for and/or receives water from the Water System under this Chapter shall be deemed to have consented to inspections pursuant to this Section, including entrance upon that person's property at reasonable times to make inspections. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.29. - Hydrant Use. 
No person, except an authorized employee of the City in the performance of his or her duties, shall open or use any fire hydrant except in case of emergency, without first securing permission from the Director and paying such charges as may be prescribed in the rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.30. - Restricting Water Use. 
The City Manager, or his or her designee, may regulate, limit or prohibit the use of water for any purpose. Such regulations shall restrict less essential water uses to the extent deemed necessary to assure an adequate supply for essential needs and for fire fighting. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.31. - Protection from Damage. 
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with or alter, any structure, property, appurtenance, equipment or any other item which is part of the Water System. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.32. - Enforcement. 
Any person found to be violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. The Director is hereby authorized to bring any appropriate action in the name of the City of Grand Rapids as may be necessary or desirable to restrain or enjoin any public nuisance, to enforce any of the provisions of this Chapter, to initiate criminal prosecution, and in general to carry out the intent and purpose of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77) 
Cross reference— General penalty, § 1.13.  
ARTICLE 3. - USE CHARGES 
 
Sec. 2.33. - Purpose and Establishment of Rates and Charges. 
Rates and charges for the installation of, connection to (including meter installation and setting charges), and use of the Water System are hereby established for the purpose of recovering the costs of construction, reconstruction, maintenance, operation, and replacement of the System. Such rates and charges along with fees, penalties and miscellaneous charges shall be established from time to time by resolution of the City Commission in accordance with the provisions hereinafter set forth. Rates and charges shall be made against all premises which use the System. The annual rate study conducted by the City and proposed changes in rates and charges and related fees, penalties and other miscellaneous charges along with explanatory materials shall be filed with the City Clerk at least twenty (20) days prior to the City Commission's consideration of an approval resolution for public review and comment. Notice of such filing and opportunity for review and comment shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the City and posted on the City's website at least twenty (20) days prior to consideration of the resolution by the City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 2015-63, § 1, 10-27-15)  
Sec. 2.34. - Local Distribution Charges. 
(1)  Whenever a watermain used for local distribution is constructed either through a special assessment project or as may be ordered or required by law, the property owners for whom the line is designed shall each pay their share of the cost of installation. Similarly, any property owner requesting service who has not previously paid his or her share of the cost of constructing the watermain used for local distribution shall pay those costs before service is permitted. 
(2)  The charge shall be established as provided in Section 2.33 and shall be known as the front foot rate and be determined by multiplying the rate per foot by the number of feet the property owner has fronting on the watermain used for local distribution. This charge will be annually reviewed and may change to reflect the current average cost of installation of local distribution lines. 
(3)  If the City Commission shall determine that it is not advisable to collect the front foot rate at the time of construction or connection (if not previously paid at the time of construction), it may direct that the cost be borne initially by the System and subsequently be collected from the property owner in accordance with this Section. 
(4)  Upon completion of construction or at the time connection is requested (if this cost has not been paid at the time of construction), the City Engineer shall certify to the City Comptroller the cost to be charged to the property owner. The Comptroller shall in turn certify the amount thereof to the City Treasurer. The City Treasurer shall bill the owner of the premises affected advising him or her that unless the amount so billed is paid within thirty (30) days from the date of mailing that the same shall be presented to the City Commission at the first meeting thereof after the expiration of thirty (30) days for assessment against said premises as a special assessment. In the event the bill for such installation and connection is not paid within thirty (30) days from the date said notice is mailed, the City Treasurer shall report the same to the City Commission which shall examine the same and if found by it to be correct shall confirm it as a special assessment against the premises affected, at which time the City Commission shall also direct the number of installments into which the same shall be divided, and shall direct the City Assessor to extend the same upon the tax roll as a special assessment in the manner provided in Chapter 10 of this Code. All collection procedures for special assessments established in Chapter 10 of this Code shall be applicable to assessments made hereunder. 
(5)  In lieu of the procedure above described, such installations and connections may be made at the expense of the System when the owner of the premises signs a written agreement agreeing to pay the expense of such installation and connections upon terms agreeable to the City Manager and that the unpaid balance shall constitute a lien upon his or her property of the same character and subject to the same methods of collection as prescribed for special assessments in Chapter 10 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 78-2, 1-10-78; Ord. No. 78-92, 12-19-78; Ord. No. 79-90, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 81-6, 1-20-81; Ord. No. 81-77, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 81-88, 12-15-81; Ord. No. 82-87, 12-21-82; Ord. No. 83-75, § 1, 12-20-83; Ord. No. 84-84, § 1, 12-11-84; Ord. No. 85-81, § 1, 12-17-85; Ord. No. 86-73, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 87-88, § 1, 12-29-87; Ord. No. 88-76, § 1, 12-20-88; Ord. No. 89-84, § 1, 12-19-89; Ord. No. 91-4, § 1, 1-15-91; Ord. No. 91-61, § 1, 12-10-91; Ord. No. 92-76, § 1, 12-15-92; Ord. No. 93-57, § 1, 12-14-93; Ord. No. 94-45, § 1, 12-13-94; Ord. No. 95-72, § 1, 12-12-95; Ord. No. 96-48, § 1, 12-17-96; Ord. No. 97-62, § 1, 12-16-97; Ord. No. 98-59, § 1, 12-15-98; Ord. No. 99-71, § 1, 12-14-99; Ord. No. 2000-71, § 1, 12-12-00; Ord. No. 2001-51, § 1, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 2002-69, § 1, 12-10-02; Ord. No. 2003-53, § 1, 12-23-03; Ord. No. 2004-81, § 1, 12-21-04; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 12-20-05; Ord. No. 2006-81, § 1, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2007-69, § 1, 12-18-07; Ord. No. 2008-54, § 1, 12-23-08; Ord. No. 2009-66, 12-15-09; Ord. No. 2010-72, § 1, 12-21-10; Ord. No. 2011-58, § 1, 12-20-11; Ord. No. 2012-63, § 1, 12-18-12; Ord. No. 2013-86, § 1, 12-17-13; Ord. No. 2014-87, § 1, 12-16-14; Ord. No. 2015-63, § 2, 10-27-15)  
Sec. 2.35. - Integrated Water Connection Fee Schedule. 
(1)  When a property owner or user is requested or required to connect to the System and has not previously paid or been assessed a connection fee, a connection fee in accordance with a connection fee schedule established as provided in Section 2.33 shall apply. 
(2)  Except as otherwise provided in the immediately succeeding paragraph, the foregoing integrated water connection base fee schedule for single-family and multi-family residential dwelling units shall be adjusted upward and downward as follows: A single-family residential dwelling unit located on a parcel containing twenty thousand (20,000) square feet shall pay the applicable integrated connection fee in accordance with the foregoing schedule. When determining the square footage of a residential parcel for the purposes of determining the appropriate integrated connection fee, parcel size may be adjusted downward to take into consideration such things as wetlands, lakes, streams and other unusual characteristics of the parcel in accordance with policies approved from time to time by the Utility Advisory Board. To the extent the size of a parcel, as adjusted, is greater than or less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet, one-half (½) the applicable integrated connection fee will increase or decrease by the same percentage increase or decrease in the parcel above or below twenty thousand (20,000) square feet. In the case of multi-family residential dwellings, in order to determine the size of the parcel assigned to each dwelling unit for purposes of calculating the integrated connection fee to be paid by each multi-family residential dwelling unit, the total square footage of the parcel, as adjusted, on which the multi-family residential dwelling is located shall be divided by the total number of residential units. Notwithstanding any other provision in this subsection, the integrated connection fee for a single-family residential dwelling unit or multi-family residential dwelling unit shall not exceed four and one-half (4½) times the applicable base integrated connection fee set forth in the foregoing schedule. 
There shall be no upward adjustment in the integrated water service connection fee payable for a single-family residential dwelling unit connecting to the Water System if (a) each of the following conditions are met (1) a building permit shall have been obtained, (2) the dwelling unit shall have been constructed, and (3) a certificate of occupancy shall have been issued prior to January 1, 2000 or (b) local building permit fees have been paid to the local governmental unit prior to January 1, 2000 for a single-family residential dwelling unit to be constructed on or after January 1, 2000. When connecting to the Water System, Users living in or owning such single-family residential dwelling units shall pay the applicable base integrated connection fee set forth in the Integrated Water Connection Base Fee Schedule adjusted downward, if applicable, in accordance with the immediate preceding paragraph. 
Effective January 1, 2005 and January 1st of every year thereafter, the Integrated Water Connection Base Fees shall be adjusted by a percentage, which is determined by the annual change in the Consumer Price Index (the "Index") calculated as follows: 
(a)  The Consumer Price Index shall be that Index referred to as the Consumer Price Index, US City Average, All Urban Consumers, published by the U.S. Department of Labor-Bureau of Statistics ((1982-84)=100). In the event the method of determining the Index is substantially altered, the basis for determining the annual change thereafter shall be the Index which is most comparable to the Index described above. 
(b)  For the purpose of computing the percentage change each calendar year, the Index for the month of August for the prior calendar year shall be subtracted from the Index for the immediately preceding August. The result so obtained (if positive) shall be divided by the Index for the month of August for the prior calendar year to obtain the percentage increase which shall be applied to the then current Integrated Water Connection Base Fee Schedule to determine the new calendar year schedule. 
The foregoing Integrated Connection Fee is due and payable at the time a User receives a permit to connect to the Water System. A permit issued by the City to connect to the Water System shall expire one hundred eighty (180) days from the date the permit was issued. 
The user receiving services who applies for a larger water meter than the one presently in service shall pay an Integrated Connection Fee which is the difference in cost between the meter size in service and the one applied for in accordance with the Integrated Connection Fee in effect at the time of application. No credit or rebate shall be made in the case of application for a smaller meter size. 
Existing commercial and industrial customers may request the installation of an additional meter to measure water used solely for irrigation purposes. There shall be no Integrated Connection Fee for the additional meter provided combined maximum capacity as defined by the American Water Works Association Standards C700-90 and C702-92, as amended, does not exceed the maximum capacity of the original meter. If the original maximum capacity is exceeded, the customer shall pay as an Integrated Connection Fee the difference between the fee for the original meter and what the fee would be if the maximum capacities of all meters were totaled. The additional Integrated Connection Fee shall be based upon the fees in effect at the time of installation of the additional meter. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 82-87, 12-21-82; Ord. No. 88-43, § 1, 6-28-88; Ord. No. 91-47, § 1, 9-24-91; Ord. No. 95-72, § 2, 12-12-95; Ord. No. 96-48, § 2, 12-17-96; Ord. No. 97-62, § 2, 12-16-97; Ord. No. 98-59, § 2, 12-15-98; Ord. No. 99-28, § 1, 6-8-99; Ord. No. 2000-31, § 1, 6-27-00; Ord. No. 2002-57, § 1, 10-1-02; Ord. No. 2004-81, § 2, 12-21-04; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 2, 12-20-05; Ord. No. 2006-81, § 2, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2007-69, § 2, 12-18-07; Ord. No. 2008-54, § 2, 12-23-08; Ord. No. 2010-72, § 2, 12-21-10; Ord. No. 2011-58, § 2, 12-20-11; Ord. No. 2012-63, § 2, 12-18-12; Ord. No. 2013-86, § 2, 12-17-13; Ord. No. 2014-87, § 2, 12-16-14; Ord. No. 2015-63, § 3, 10-27-15) 
Cross reference— Sewer and water connections, determination of necessity, §§ 4.11, 4.12.  
Sec. 2.36. - Water Use Charges. 
The rates and charges for water service furnished by the System shall be charged to all persons within or without the City Limits using or benefiting from the System. Such rates and/or charges shall reflect the proportionate cost actually incurred to provide service to the users within the governmental unit in which they reside. For those users of the System outside the City Limits, charges shall be based on the proportionate cost actually incurred to provide service to the users within the governmental entity in which they reside. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.37. - User Classes. 
For the purpose of determining retail user charges, the following user classes are established: 
(1)  Domestic. 
(2)  Commercial. 
(3)  Industrial. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.38. - Determination of User Charges. 
There shall be a two-part rate for users consisting of a commodity charge and a monthly service charge. The commodity charge shall be based on the actual water consumption as determined by this Chapter and the rules and regulations of the System. The monthly service charge shall be based on the size of the water meter as determined by this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
ARTICLE 4. - WATER RATES AND CHARGES 
 
Sec. 2.39. - Applicability. 
The users of the System complying with the provisions of this Chapter and rules and regulations duly adopted pursuant to this Chapter shall pay rates and charges established as provided in Section 2.33. Such rates and charges shall be designed to produce revenues which are proportionate to the cost of providing service to each user class of such customer class. Such cost shall include, but not be limited to, the cost of operation, maintenance, replacement, depreciation and a rate of return on the System's investment. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 2015-63, § 4, 10-27-15)

The fire protection charge is a flat fee for fire protection based on the size of the fire protection connection pipe. The charge is payable in advance and shall be as established pursuant to Section 2.33. 
(Ord. No. 88-76, § 4, 12-20-88; Ord. No. 89-84, § 3, 12-19-89; Ord. No. 2009-66, § 2, 12-15-09; Ord. No. 2010-72, § 4, 12-21-10; Ord. No. 2015-63, § 6, 10-27-15)

(1)  Water Service Pipe Costs shall be established pursuant to Section 2.33. 
(2)  Miscellaneous Charges for hydrant use, tapping permits, meter installation and seasonal turn off/on, frozen/damaged/missing meter, meter reading, security deposit, miscellaneous permit and inspection fees, service charges and penalties shall be as established pursuant to Section 2.33. 
(3)  Watermain Oversizing Rates shall be as established pursuant to Section 2.33. 
(Ord. No. 2012-63, § 4, 12-18-12; Ord. No. 2013-86, § 4, 12-17-13; Ord. No. 2014-87, § 4, 12-16-14; Ord. No. 2015-63, § 7, 10-27-15)  
Sec. 2.41.2. - Circuit Breaker. 
As agreed among the customer communities per the Uniform Water and Sewer Service Agreement, the Individual Circuit Breaker (ICB) and City and Customer Community Circuit Breaker programs have been established in order to relieve hardship. The former program serves to assist eligible water customers, and the latter program serves to normalize rates among customer communities to the extent that funds are available for such purpose. These programs shall be administered according to the terms of the Uniform Water and Sewer Service Agreement. The amount allocated for this purpose shall be established pursuant to Section 2.33. 
(Ord. No. 2012-63, § 5, 12-18-12; Ord. No. 2013-86, § 5, 12-17-13; Ord. No. 2014-87, § 5, 12-16-14; Ord. No. 2015-63, § 8, 10-27-15)  
Sec. 2.42. - Review of Rates and Charges. 
Annually, after the close of the fiscal year and prior to the adoption of the System's budget, there shall be a review of the rates and charges. Upon completion of the review, a report shall be prepared and presented to the City Commission summarizing the review and recommending rates and charges which assure that all the costs of the System will be recovered from customer and user classes proportionately to the cost of providing service to them. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.43. - Billing. 
Bills for water service shall be rendered in accordance with the established rules and regulations of the System. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.44. - Enforcement. 
Delinquent bills shall be collected as provided in the rules and regulations. The water service may be turned off to any premises to enforce the payment of water service charges in accordance with the rules and regulations. Water service shall not be reinstated until all the requirements of the rules and regulations are complied with. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77)  
Sec. 2.45. - Effective Date. 
This Ordinance shall take immediate effect, however, the rates, charges, fees, penalties, and miscellaneous charges and other established amounts set forth in Sections 2.34(2), 2.35(1), 2.40, 2.41, 2.41.1(1), (2) and (3) and 2.41.2 effective prior to the effective date of this Ordinance shall remain in effect through December 31, 2015. 
(Ord. No. 77-57, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 78-92, 12-19-78; Ord. No. 79-90, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 81-6, 1-20-81; Ord. No. 81-88, 12-15-81; Ord. No. 82-87, 12-21-82; Ord. No. 83-75, § 4, 12-20-83; Ord. ARTICLE 5. - WATER COOLED AIR CONDITIONING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Mechanical Code, Ch. 134. 
 
Sec. 2.46. - Purpose. 
The City Commission hereby declares that the health, welfare and safety of the people of this City requires water conservation on the part of the users of water cooled air-conditioning Systems so that the normal use of water for residential and industrial purposes will not be jeopardized. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, 7-1-80)  
Sec. 2.47. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this Article, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Water cooled air-conditioning system shall mean any combination of equipment, whether compressor type, or other type, by which heat is removed from the air or refrigerant by the use of water for the purpose of space cooling. 
(2)  Approved type is a water cooled air-conditioning system: 
a.  Which is equipped with cooling tower, atmospheric condenser, spray pond, or other equipment which shall directly or directly cool refrigerant, and 
b.  Which uses water from the Water System only for make-up water to replace water lost by evaporation or by flushing of the equipment, and 
c.  Which uses an average of less than eight (8) gallons of water from the Water System per hour per ton of cooling capacity when the unit is operating. 
(3)  Nonapproved type is a water cooled air-conditioning system which uses water as a cooling medium and not conforming to the requirements defined in Section 2.47(2). 
(4)  Rated capacity. The rated capacity of a water cooled air-conditioning system in tons shall be the twenty-four-hour heat removal capacity in BTUs divided by 288,000. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, 7-1-80)  
Sec. 2.48. - Prohibited Installations and Operations. 
No person shall install any water cooled air-conditioning equipment that is of the nonapproved type and which uses a supply of water from the City's Public Water System. Nor shall any person modify any existing approved type to a nonapproved type which is prohibited by this Section. Nor shall any person use or operate any water cooled air-conditioning equipment which has been installed or modified in violation of this Section. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, 7-1-80)  
Sec. 2.49. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall be found guilty of violating Section 2.48 shall be subject to penalty as provided by Chapter 1, Section 1.13 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, 7-1-80)  
Secs. 2.50—2.60. - Reserved.
