Secs. 2.316—2.400. - Reserved.  
Chapter 33 - POLE LINE AND DUCT SYSTEM 
 
Sec. 2.401. - Intent. 
This chapter is adopted pursuant to the Revenue Bond Act to establish a system to allow the use of street lighting poles and ducts by others to install, use and operate telecommunications and other lines, fiber, and related equipment and instrumentalities, and to provide for establishing and collecting rates, fees, and charges for use of that system. Revenue bonds may, at some time, be necessary in order to acquire, construct, improve, enlarge, extend, maintain or repair that system. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 1, 8-9-11)  
Sec. 2.402. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section unless the context in which they are used specifically indicates otherwise: 
Duct means a conduit owned by the City placed under or above the surface of the ground for the purpose of providing space for the placement of power or communications cables or wires. 
Managing Director means the Managing Director of the Department to which the System has been assigned who is appointed to that position by the City Manager or the designee of such appointed person. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, association, public or private corporation or public agency or instrumentality or any other entity. 
Pole means a City-owned utility or street lighting pole. 
Pole attachment means the physical attachment of power or communications cables or wires to a pole which may be part of a pole line or a single pole. 
Pole line means two (2) or more poles in a row or otherwise in proximity to one another such that power or communications cables or wires could be strung from one of the poles to one (1) or more other poles. 
Rate means the rate applicable for particular Use of the System. 
Revenue Bond Act means 1933 PA 94, as amended, MCL 141.101 et seq. 
System means the Grand Rapids Pole Line and Duct System consisting of all poles, pole attachments, ducts, conduit, works, instrumentalities, copper communications cable innerducts, lines, fiber cable, traffic signals, electric power lines and equipment, contract rights, and properties now or hereafter existing, used or useful in connection with such facilities and equipment. 
Use means the use of pole lines, ducts, conduit, equipment or other parts of the System by attaching or installing wire, fiber cable, channels, antennas or other lines or equipment on or within such parts of the System and includes even such wire, fiber, channels, antennas or other lines or equipment that is not operated until such time as it has been removed or is permitted by the City to stay in place even though it is not operated. 
User charge means a fee or charge payable by a User for Use of any part of the System or for costs related to that Use. 
User means the person who owns the wires, fiber, antennas, or other lines or equipment placed on or within any portion of the System or a person other than the owner of the premises who, according to the provisions of the Revenue Bond Act , has the responsibility to pay rates, fees and charges for the Use of any portion of the System. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 1, 8-9-11)  
Sec. 2.403. - System Created. 
(a)  There is established a City Pole Line and Duct System to be assigned to a department by the City Manager. 
(b)  All rights, title, interest, control and possession of all existing City street lighting poles, ducts, conduits, channels, fiber cable, wires, and lines, and related equipment, materials, spare parts, and other personal property used to construct, install, operate, maintain, repair, improve or replace street lighting poles, ducts, conduits, channels, wires and fiber, or other Services within or without the corporate limits of the City; all outstanding invoices and receivables in connection therewith; all equipment and tools used exclusively for repairing and maintaining such property used for operating, repairing, and maintaining poles, pole lines, and ducts within or without the corporate limits of the City; all drawings and plans used in connection with poles, pole lines, and ducts within or without the corporate limits of the City; all easements, permits, contract rights, and other rights and approvals needed to construct, acquire, install, operate, maintain or repair any portion of any property used in connection with pole lines and ducts within or without the corporate limits of the City; and all other rights, interests and property of any kind that are related to pole lines and ducts within or without the corporate limits of the City shall be part of the System segregated and separate from other City assets so that the System is operated as an enterprise fund. 
(c)  The City Manager shall appoint a Managing Director and shall assign to the System such City personnel as the City Manager shall choose. Such transferred personnel shall be transferred in accordance with applicable collective bargaining agreements and applicable City policies. 
(d)  After July 1, 2011, costs for acquiring, constructing, installing, operating, maintaining, repairing, extending, enlarging, replacing, or improving any portion of the System shall be paid at least partially from revenues paid by Users of Services of the System though other City funds shall be paid to the System in amounts reasonably related to the benefits of street lighting and other uses of the System. Borrowing may from time to time occur which shall be repaid from revenues paid by Users of the System and gifts, grants or other amounts as may be received from time to time for the benefit of the System. 
(e)  The System shall permit Use of pole lines and ducts by Users within or without the corporate limits of the City subject to applicable constitutional provisions, laws, rules, regulations, permit requirements, contracts, and conditions of any other needed governmental approvals. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 1, 8-9-11)  
Sec. 2.404. - System Standards. 
The Managing Director shall, with the City Manager's approval, adopt such standards for the System and Use of the System, standards for discontinuing service, and policies and procedures regarding the System and its use, construction, installation, operation, maintenance, repair, extension, replacement, improvement, and enlargement as are reasonable; as comply with applicable constitutional provisions, laws, rules, regulations, permit requirements, contracts, and conditions of any other needed governmental approvals; and as are substantially consistent with reasonable practices for such facilities. 
(a)  Without limiting the generality of this provision, such standards shall include: 
(1)  An application procedure for Use of any portion of the System. 
(2)  A requirement for an over-lashing agreement and payment of an over-lashing User charge for any over-lashing of a User's lines by any person other than that User. The User charge shall be the responsibility of the first-party User. 
(3)  A requirement that System Users provide accurate "as built" drawings showing what wire, fiber cable, antenna or other equipment is placed on or within the System with the details specified in the System standards. 
(4)  Requirements for Users to comply with the National Electrical Code, National Electrical Safety Code, standards of the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials, or other applicable codes in the construction, installation, repair, maintenance, removal, replacement or improvement of their wires, fiber cable, antenna or other equipment on or within the System. 
(5)  A requirement that any wire, fiber cable, line or other equipment placed on or within any part of the System that is no longer used shall be removed at the User's expense within thirty (30) days after its Use is discontinued or within thirty (30) days after any agreement or other permission for its Use of the System terminates. 
(6)  A requirement for a User or prospective User to pay any costs incurred to make the System ready for the User's or prospective User's Use. 
(7)  A requirement that User's relocate their wires, fiber, cable, antenna and any other equipment if such relocation is needed due to work on or affecting any portion of the System. 
(8)  A requirement and procedure for prior notification to and permission from the Managing Director for any access to any part of any duct that is part of the System in order to ensure the security of any power or communication lines and equipment within the System. This may include a requirement for observation by System personnel of those working on certain parts of the System. 
(b)  Such standards may also include: 
(1)  A requirement to use best available technology and best available practices to Use all or designated parts of the System. 
(2)  A requirement to periodically upgrade or replace wires, fiber, or other equipment in order: 
(i)  To prevent or reduce repeated needs to access the System for repair and maintenance of wires, fiber cable or other equipment that is approaching the end of its reasonably expected useful life; 
(ii)  To provide for additional space within ducts or other parts of the System where newer technology takes less space than the originally installed technology; 
(iii)  To enhance System security; 
(iv)  To enhance public health or safety or the health and safety of persons working on or within any parts of the System; or 
(v)  To protect System components or the property of any persons using or working on or within any parts of the System. 
(3)  Prioritization of Use of the System or any part of the System and, where reasonably necessary to protect the public health and safety, ordering some Users to discontinue Use of the System in order that other persons whose Use is a higher priority may make Use of the System. 
(4)  Such other requirements or matters that should be addressed in accordance with generally accepted and best practices for operating the System. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 1, 8-9-11)  
Sec. 2.405. - User Charges. 
(a)  The Users of the System shall pay User charges established as set forth below. User charges shall be charged to all System Users within or without the corporate limits of the City. User charges shall reflect the proportionate cost of constructing, installing, operating, repairing, maintaining, replacing, and improving the System. It is desirable that User rates, fees and charges provide sufficient revenues to cover the costs relating to the System including, but not limited to: (i) debt service on any debt of the System; (ii) costs of acquiring, constructing, installing, operating, maintaining, repairing, replacing, extending or enlarging the System or any portion thereof; (iii) depreciation of any portion or all of the System; (iv) a reasonable rate of return on the System's investment; (v) debt service or operational coverage that is required under the terms of any System debt, is required by other applicable law, or as is reasonable practice for such systems; and (vi) all costs relating to billing and collecting any User charges. The User charges shall include fees for application to Use the System, inspection and verification fees for ensuring compliance with System standards, and the pass-through of "make ready costs" as explained in subsection 2-404(a)(6). However, User charges may be established with consideration to the rates, fees and charges of other providers of poles, pole lines, and duct facilities and with consideration to any regulations that, while not applicable to the System, are applicable to other poles, pole lines, and duct facilities. 
(b)  The City Commission shall, on an annual basis, by resolution establish User charges for use of the System based on the recommendations of the Managing Director in consultation with the City's Chief Financial Officer, City Manager, and City Attorney or any of their respective designees. 
(c)  Annually, following the receipt of the annual audit for the immediately preceding fiscal year, there shall be a review of User charges. Based on the actual experience during the immediately preceding fiscal year and known or reasonably projected cost increases and decreases, System staff in coordination with the City's Chief Financial Officer and City Manager, or their designees, shall complete an annual rate study using a multi-step methodology that addresses System costs as provided in subsection (a) and that also includes what rates, fees and charges may be in effect for pole line and duct facilities owned and operated by others. Upon completion of the annual review and rate study, a report shall be presented to the City Commission summarizing the review and recommending User charges for the ensuing fiscal year. Accordingly, using audited data after the end of a fiscal year in June, a rate study will be completed and a report presented to the City Commission in such a time that rate and fee adjustments can be made to go into effect on the immediately following July 1. The City Commission may, by resolution adopted after a recommendation by the City Manager, make interim User charge adjustments as needed to address the System's revenue needs. 
(d)  The City Commission shall adopt initial User charges for System Use based on a report prepared by System staff in coordination with the City's Chief Financial Officer and City Manager, or their designees that reasonably projects System costs until after the end of the fiscal year ending June 30, 2013, so that audited data is available for one full year of System operation to use in establishing User charges as provided in subsections (b) and (c). The City Commission may, by resolution adopted after a recommendation by the City Manager, make interim User charge adjustments as may be needed to address the System's revenue needs. 
(e)  For any year in which the System collects more funds than needed to pay the costs detailed in subsection (a), User charges shall either be adjusted in the subsequent year so such excess funds are fully used to pay costs in the subsequent year or User accounts shall be credited with their proportional share of the excess collections. 
(f)  The User charges provided for in this Section shall not affect any existing contracts for Services of the System that are in effect on the effective date of this Chapter. Upon the expiration or other termination of such contracts, the User charges provided for in this Section shall take effect with respect to such Users currently subject to such a contract. However, the City Commission may approve three-year contracts for significant Users that establish User charges for that User for up to three (3) years where the City Commission determines that doing so is in the best interests of the general public. 
(g)  User charges may, pursuant to a contract with a User, be offset by the reasonable value the System accrues due to capital improvements, expansions, replacements or other facilities, materials, or services any User may, with prior written approval of the Managing Director, construct or install and convey to the System. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 1, 8-9-11)  
Sec. 2.406. - Billing and Enforcement. 
(a)  Billing and payments shall be provided for as follows: 
(1)  Bills for Use shall be issued at such times and in such manner as the Managing Director, with the consent of the City Manager, may reasonably determine. If annual billing is used, Users may be provided an option to pay quarterly with the payment of an additional fee to fully cover the costs incurred by the System to bill and collect the smaller, more frequent bills. A minimum bill amount may be set. 
(2)  Billing may be done in conjunction with, may be due at the same time as, and may be collected in the same manner as billing for other City utility services such as water and sanitary sewer services, including late payment charges as may be set pursuant to Section 2.405 of this Chapter. 
(3)  Payments shall be made according to the schedule provided in the annual rate study prepared pursuant to subsection 2.405(c) or, for the initial rates, by the report submitted pursuant to subsection 2.405(d), and late payments shall be subject to the late fees, rebilling fees, interest and other requirements established by the annual rate study prepared pursuant to subsection 2.405(c) or, for the initial User charges, by the report submitted pursuant to subsection 2.405(d). 
(4)  Where the User's Use of the System is related to connecting particular, identified premises, User charges shall be a lien on the specific premises served and may be collected in the manner provided in the Revenue Bond Act. Those bills that are delinquent for 6 months or more shall be added to the property tax roll and collected in the same manner; the lien shall be enforced in the same manner as ad valorem property taxes levied by the City. The lien remedy does not preclude any other remedy provided in law. Those premises outside the City that are served by the System that have delinquent bills will be certified to their governmental unit for collection as provided in the contract between the City and the governmental unit. However, no lien shall attach against any premises for which a lien is impermissible under the Revenue Bond Act. 
(b)  When a tenant is responsible for payment of bills and a lease has been executed containing a provision that the lessor not be liable for charges for Service: 
(1)  It shall be the responsibility of the lessor to so notify the System Business Office with an affidavit signed by both parties. The affidavit must state the pertinent provision of the lease and its expiration date. If such notification is provided, no lien shall attach to the premises subject to that notification. Upon expiration of the lease, a new affidavit must be submitted to retain exemption from the lien. 
(2)  The tenant shall then pay a deposit in the amount of the estimated annual bill for service charges for the premises. If the tenant is also required to make such deposits for City water or sanitary sewer services, then water and sanitary sewer services shall not be provided to the premises until the deposit required for Services of the System is made as provided in this subsection. 
(c)  Regardless of whether there is a lien remedy under this Section, the Managing Director may seek any remedy for non-payment available at law or in equity. Provided that written notice and an opportunity for a hearing by the City Manager or the City Manager's designee as provided in subsection (c) below is first given, remedies may include termination of Use of the System including the disconnection and even the removal of wiring, fiber cable, or other items using System pole lines, ducts or other facilities. 
(d)  A person responsible for payment of bills for Use of the System may request an administrative hearing to show why that person's bills are incorrect or other reason why that responsible person should not be obligated to pay the amounts billed if System staff and that responsible person have not reached a mutually satisfactory agreement. Hearing requests must be made in writing to the System's customer service office on or before the date the bill is due for payment without interest, extra fees, or penalties or such date as may be specifically provided in a notice of hearing given pursuant to subsection (c) above. Hearings will be held by the City Manager or the City Manager's designee. That hearing officer shall establish the rules for such hearings, and shall have the authority to settle all disputes and provide for credits to accounts or refunds. Decisions of the hearing officer shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 1, 8-9-11)  
Sec. 2.407. - Use of System Conditional. 
(a)  No person shall Use the System or any part of the System without having an application for such use approved pursuant to this Chapter. 
(b)  Use of any part of the System is also conditional upon compliance with this Chapter and with the System standards established pursuant to this Chapter. 
(c)  Use of any part of the System is also conditional upon the timely payment of User charges and other amounts required to be paid under this Chapter. 
(d)  No alterations, modifications, additions, or other changes may be made to any portion of the System, including, without limitation, any guys, extensions, or bends, without the prior written approval of the Managing Director. 
(e)  Use of any part of the System is also conditional upon the User consenting that the City shall not be liable to User or to its affiliates or customers for any damage to User's property, disruption in the operation of User's services, equitable relief, or for any damages arising out of a User's use of the Public Rights-of-Way, whether or not caused by City's action or inaction regarding PA 174 of 2013 commonly known as MISS DIG underground facility damage prevention and safety act (unless specifically ordered by the Michigan Public Service Commission pursuant to the act), Act of God, or any other reason whatsoever. 
(f)  Use of any part of the System is also conditional upon the User consenting to defend, indemnify, protect, and hold harmless the City, its officers, agents, employees, elected and appointed officials, departments, boards, and commissions from any and all claims, losses, liabilities, causes of action, demands, judgments, decrees, proceedings, and expenses of any nature (including, without limitation, attorneys' fees) arising out of or resulting from the acts or omissions of the User, its officers, agents, employees, contractors, successors, or assigns or the User's equipment failure. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 1, 8-9-11; Ord. No. 2019-34, § 1, 8-13-19)  
Sec. 2.408. - Violations, Penalties and Remedies. 
(a)  Violations of this Chapter or System standards established pursuant to this Chapter shall be a municipal civil infraction and those responsible shall be subject to fines, costs, court orders and other remedies and penalties as provided by state law and this Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Any violation of this Chapter or the System standards established pursuant to this Section is a public nuisance per se, subject to abatement as provided at law or in equity. 
(c)  Because compliance with this Chapter and the System standards established pursuant to this Chapter is a condition for initial or continued Use of the System, violations may, after notice and opportunity for a hearing as provided in subsections 2.406(c) and (d), result in termination of any Use of the System. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 1, 8-9-11)  
Chapter 34 - THERMAL ENERGY (STEAM) FRANCHISE 
 
Sec. 2.501. - Grant of Non-Exclusive Rights. 
A.  Term. The City of Grand Rapids (City) grants to VEOLIA ENERGY GRAND RAPIDS, LLC, its successors and assigns (Grantee), subject to the terms and conditions set forth below, the non-exclusive right, power and authority to construct, lay, extend, operate and maintain, repair and replace, plants, mains, pipes, and other appurtenances (Thermal Energy System) under the highways, streets, alleys and bridges of the City (hereinafter "Public Ways"), for the purpose of generating, transmitting, distributing and selling heat, steam, hot, chilled or condensed water ("Thermal Energy"), and to do local Thermal Energy business in the City of Grand Rapids, Kent County, Michigan, for a term of thirty (30) years (the "Term"). Not later than 18 months prior to the end of the Term, the Grantee and the City shall meet to discuss in good faith whether and under what terms and conditions the City would grant a new franchise ordinance in favor of the Grantee. 
B.  Home Rule. It is the intent of the Grantee and the City that the franchise granted by this Ordinance and all rates for service relating to the Thermal Energy System be subject to the "Home Rule", in accordance with 1919 PA 419, MCL 460.54. Home Rule, as applicable to the franchise granted by this Ordinance, shall mean that the rates and charges are fixed in, and regulated by, this Ordinance and the franchise issued hereunder. 
C.  Expansion of System. After first obtaining approval from City of the route and placement of the Thermal Energy System components, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, Grantee may expand its use of the Public Ways by constructing and maintaining its own plants, mains, pipes, and other appurtenances. Any expansion of the Thermal Energy System by the Grantee as approved by the City shall be subject to all terms and conditions of this Ordinance. In addition, City shall have the right to order all reasonable and necessary extensions of service after Grantee and the public have had an opportunity for public hearing thereon. Grantee shall have the right to request to recover in its rates the just and reasonable costs associated with constructing, operating, maintaining, repairing and replacing such extensions, over the specified lifetime of such extensions, through the procedures and criteria set forth in Section 2.507.A.(7) or 2.507.A.(8) of this Ordinance. When requested by Grantee, its successors or assigns, within thirty (30) days from the date of the order of the City Commission, and not thereafter, the reasonableness of such extension and of the order requiring the same shall be determined by arbitrators to be chosen as provided in Title VIII of the City Charter (Title VIII). The arbitrators shall have authority to modify any such order of City or to change or alter the time therein fixed. Such order of the City or determination of the arbitrators, as the case may be, shall be exclusive of any and all other actions or remedies and binding upon all persons having or claiming any rights in the Thermal Energy System or the franchise granted by this Ordinance, which order or determination shall be subject to appeal as provided in Section 23 of Title VIII. The failure to make and to put into operation such extensions to the extent, in the manner and time ordered by City, or by such arbitrators, as the case may be, and for one year thereafter, shall constitute cause for forfeiture of the franchise granted by this Ordinance. 
In addition, the right and franchise granted by this Ordinance shall extend throughout the entire City. Upon application of a prospective customer or customers in an area of the City not served by Grantee's initial distribution system, Grantee shall make the requested main extension at Grantee's expense if, in the reasonable judgment of Grantee, the Thermal Energy requirements of the prospective customer or customers will not disturb or impair service to existing customers and the estimated annual revenues therefrom reasonably warrant the capital expenditure required. If Grantee determines that the Thermal Energy requirements of the prospective customer or customers will not disturb or impair service to existing customers, but that the estimated annual revenues therefrom do not reasonably warrant the capital expenditure required, Grantee shall make the main extension if the prospective customer or customers make such contribution in aid of construction and other payments as may be provided for in the Rules and Regulations of Grantee. 
D.  Location in Public Ways. To the maximum extent possible, Grantee shall place its Thermal Energy System on, within, under and along existing utility facilities in the Public Ways. In addition, all placement of the Thermal Energy System shall be in areas approved by the City Engineer. 
E.  Transfer. Grantee shall not sell, assign, lease or sublease the franchise granted by this Ordinance, or allow another to use the same without the consent of the City Commission by ordinance duly passed, subject to Grantee's right to mortgage provided in Title VIII. Grantee shall not lease or sublease any portion of its Thermal Energy System within the City to a person who by law is required to obtain the City's permission or consent to transaction of business in the City and who lacks such permission or consent. 
F.  Connection by a Third Party. Grantee shall not allow the property of a third party or non-Thermal Energy System pipes or any other facilities to be connected or affixed or attached to any portion of its Thermal Energy System or allow other actions with a similar result without the written consent of the City Manager or that person's designee; provided that the foregoing provisions of this Section 2.501.F. shall not prevent the Grantee from maintaining the current connections to the facilities of the existing customers of the existing Thermal Energy System; provided further that the Grantee shall be permitted to modify said current connections and to connect prospective customers to the Thermal Energy System within the service area described on Exhibit A (the "Service Area"), subject to all of the other terms of this Ordinance, without obtaining the consent of the City Manager described above. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 1, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.502. - Consideration; Costs; Right-of-Way Fees. 
A.  In consideration of the rights, power and authority granted by the City, Grantee shall faithfully perform all duties required by the terms of this Ordinance. 
B.  In further consideration of the rights, power and authority granted by the City, Grantee agrees: 1) to pay to the City a non-refundable application fee in the amount of Ten Thousand Dollars ($10,000.00) (for purposes of Section 1 of Title VIII, the application by Grantee for the franchise granted by this Ordinance shall be deemed to have been made as of October 15, 2007); 2) to pay to the City an annual franchise fee in the amount of Fifty Thousand Dollars ($50,000.00), said amount to be increased (but not decreased) each year the franchise granted by this Ordinance is in effect by a factor that is 100% of the change in the CPI during the prior calendar year ("CPI" means the Midwest Region All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) Consumers Price Index (1982-1984=100 - CUUR0200SA0) as published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, U.S. Dept. of Labor. If this index is discontinued a comparable successor index reasonably acceptable to the parties shall be utilized. If publication of the CPI is discontinued, the parties will use a revised or replacement index that is similar to the discontinued CPI.); and 3) to compensate the City: (a) for the amount of its actual expenses incurred by the City in the drafting and preparation of this Ordinance, including reasonable actual attorney fees, and (b) for the amount of its actual expenses resulting from the process of adopting this Ordinance, including the costs of publication required by Section 1 of Title VIII. Grantee's total obligation to compensate the City for its actual expenses under this sub-paragraph B.3) shall not exceed Ten Thousand Dollars ($10,000.00). 
C.  In the event that (i) Grantee, or any company which is a subsidiary, affiliate or other related company to Grantee under common ownership of Veolia Energy North America Holdings, Inc., pays a fee, charge or other payment of any kind on a periodic basis (such as monthly, quarterly, annually) (collectively "Charges") to any municipality in the State of Michigan as a condition, or in consideration for the right to transact a local Thermal Energy utility business in that municipality, and (ii) said Charges, when considered in the context of the totality of the circumstances of that business, including without limitation the costs incurred by the utility to acquire the business, the size of the business and the revenues expected to be generated by the business, are disproportionately greater than the fees set forth in Section 2.502.B., Grantee shall notify the City, in writing, of the details of the fee or periodic charge within sixty (60) days of the effective date of the fee or periodic charge, at which time the franchise granted by this Ordinance shall be subject to revocation by the City, which revocation shall not be deemed "at will" for any purposes under this Ordinance. If within thirty (30) days of such notice Grantee agrees to pay to the City (in lieu of the annual franchise fees set forth in the above Section 2.502.B.) a fee or periodic charge proportionately equivalent to the Charges under terms agreeable to the City, the franchise granted by this Ordinance shall continue subject to such modification. Any modified or new franchise granted by the City to Grantee shall require payment of an equivalent fee or periodic charge as a condition of the new franchise. Grantee shall be permitted to request recovery of all fees paid in accordance with this Section 2.502.C. through its rates in accordance with the procedures and criteria set forth in Section 2.507.A.(7) or 2.507.A.(8) of this Ordinance. 
D.  Grantee agrees to abide by any current or future ordinance(s) of the City, if and when formally adopted, which may require the payment by Grantee of a fee, charge or other payment on a periodic basis (such as monthly, quarterly, annually), provided that any such future ordinance(s) apply equally to all Thermal Energy franchise holders. The City shall notify Grantee within sixty (60) days of the formal adoption of such an ordinance by the City pursuant to Section 1 of Title VIII, at which time the franchise granted by this Ordinance shall be subject to revocation by the City, which revocation shall not be deemed "at will" for any purposes under this Ordinance. If within thirty (30) days of such notice Grantee agrees to pay to the City a proportionately equivalent fee or periodic charge under terms agreeable to the City, the franchise granted by this Ordinance shall continue subject to such modification. Any modified or new franchise granted by the City to Grantee shall be subject to the provisions of such future ordinance(s), and shall require payment of a similar fee or periodic charge as a condition of the new franchise. Grantee shall be permitted to request recovery of all fees paid in accordance with this Section 2.502.D. through its rates in accordance with the procedures and criteria set forth in Section 2.507.A.(7) or 2.507.A.(8) of this Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 2, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.503. - Use of Public Rights-of-Way by Grantee. 
A.  No Burden on Public Ways. Grantee and its contractors, subcontractors and the Thermal Energy System shall not unduly burden or interfere with the present or future use of any of the Public Ways within the City. Grantee shall construct and maintain its Thermal Energy System so as to cause minimum interference with the use of the Public Ways and with the rights or reasonable convenience of property owners. No Public Way shall be obstructed longer than necessary during the work of construction or repair to the Thermal Energy System. Grantee's mains, pipes, structures and equipment shall be buried so as to not endanger or injure persons or property in the Public Ways as approved by the City Engineer. If the City in its reasonable judgment determines that any portion of the Thermal Energy System becomes an undue burden or interference with the use of any of the Public Ways within the City, Grantee at its expense shall modify its Thermal Energy System or take such other actions as the City may reasonably determine is in the public interest to remove or alleviate the burden, and the Grantee shall do so within the time period established by the City. The Grantee shall have the right to arbitrate this determination pursuant to the arbitration procedures set forth in Title VIII in the event that it disagrees; provided, however, that the Grantee shall comply with the determination of the City until and unless such determination is revised by the arbitrators. Grantee may request recovery in its rates for the just and reasonable costs of complying with any such determination in accordance with the procedures and criteria set forth in Section 2.507.A.(7) or 2.507.A.(8) of this Ordinance. 
B.  Restoration of Public Ways. Grantee and its contractors and subcontractors shall immediately restore, at Grantee's sole cost and expense and in a manner approved by the City, any portion of the Public Ways that is in any way disturbed, damaged, or injured by the construction, operation, maintenance or removal of the Thermal Energy System to as good or better condition than that which existed prior to the disturbance. This obligation of Grantee shall include restoration including, but not limited to, full width restoration of the affected area as determined by the City (through permit requirements or otherwise). In the event that Grantee, its contractors or subcontractors fail to make such repair within the time reasonably specified by the City, the City shall be entitled to complete the repair and Grantee shall pay to the City an amount equal to 125% of the total costs of the City related to such repair, including the City's internal overhead amounts. The City and Grantee understand that the additional 25% included above is included so as to cover the necessity of the City having to perform Grantee's duty to repair and amounts relating to such action by the City that are difficult or impossible to quantify. 
C.  Easements. Any easement over or under private property necessary for the construction or operation of the Thermal Energy System shall be arranged and paid for by Grantee. It shall be the responsibility of the Grantee to ensure that permission for any use or intrusion on private property has been obtained, whether through an easement or otherwise. The Grantee shall be required to obtain an easement from the City to cross over or under any property owned by the City other than the Public Ways. 
D.  Pavement Cut Coordination. Grantee and the City shall coordinate Grantee's construction program and all other work in the Public Ways with the City's program for street construction, rebuilding, reconstruction, resurfacing and repair (collectively, "Street Resurfacing"). Grantee shall meet with the official of the City primarily responsible for the Public Ways (currently the City Engineer) at least quarterly to this end. 
The goals of such coordination shall be to require Grantee to conduct all known work in the Public Ways in conjunction with or immediately prior to any Street Resurfacing planned by the City, and to prevent the Public Ways from being disturbed by Grantee for a period of years after such Street Resurfacing. All construction, excavation and pavement cuts by Grantee must be approved in advance by the City Engineer. 
E.  Marking. Grantee shall mark its Thermal Energy System as follows: A. Direct buried underground portions of the Thermal Energy System not containing any cable or wire shall have (1) for all new construction or for existing underground portions of the Thermal Energy System that are hereafter exposed (for repair or otherwise), several inches above Grantee's pipes, mains or other facilities, a continuous colored tape with Grantee's name and a toll-free number and a statement to the effect that there are buried Thermal Energy facilities (specifically identified) beneath, or such other marking as is required by the City Engineer, and (2) stakes or other appropriate above-ground markers with Grantee's name and a toll-free number and indicating that there are buried Thermal Energy facilities (specifically identified) below; and B. Direct buried underground portions of the Thermal Energy System containing any cable or wire shall have (1) for all new construction or for existing underground portions of the Thermal Energy System that are hereafter exposed (for repair or otherwise), a conducting wire placed in the ground at least several inches above the Grantee's cable or wire (if such cable or wire is non-conductive), or such other marking as is required by the City Engineer, (2) at least several inches above that a continuous colored tape with Grantee's name and a toll-free number and a statement to the effect that there is buried cable beneath, and (3) stakes or other appropriate above-ground markers with Grantee's name and a toll-free number and indicating that there is buried cable below. 
F.  Compliance with Laws. Grantee shall comply with all laws, statutes, ordinances, rules and regulations regarding the installation, construction, maintenance, ownership or use of its Thermal Energy System, whether federal, state or local, now in force or which hereafter may be promulgated. The City Commission may make all reasonable regulations necessary to secure in the most ample manner the safety, welfare and convenience of the public. Before any installation is commenced, Grantee shall secure all necessary permits, licenses and approvals from all appropriate departments, agencies, boards or commissions of the City or other governmental entity as may be required by law, including, without limitation, the City's Temporary Occupancy Permits, and all utility permits and highway permits. Grantee shall comply in all respects with applicable codes, including, but not limited to, the City's then-standard construction specifications and permit requirements, horizontal and vertical separation requirements, and industry standards. Grantee shall comply with all zoning and land use ordinances and historic preservation ordinances as may exist or may hereafter be amended. 
G.  Street Vacation. If City vacates or consents to the vacation of a street or alley within its jurisdiction, and such vacation necessitates the removal and relocation of Grantee's facilities in the vacated Public Way, Grantee agrees, as a condition of this Ordinance, to consent to the vacation and to move its facilities when asked to do so by the City or a court of competent jurisdiction. Grantee shall relocate its facilities to such alternative route as the City, acting reasonably and in good faith, shall designate. Grantee may apply, in the same manner as any other private utilities, for a portion of any funds that are made available to private utilities relating to any public works improvement projects that include the requirement that the Grantee relocate a portion of its facilities. Grantee may request recovery in its rates of the just and reasonable costs of complying with any such relocation requirement in accordance with the procedures and criteria set forth in Section 2.507.A.(7) or 2.507.A.(8) of this Ordinance. 
H.  Relocation. If the City requests Grantee to relocate, protect, support, disconnect, or remove its facilities because of street or utility work, Grantee shall relocate, protect, support, disconnect, or move its facilities, to such alternate route as City, acting reasonably and in good faith, shall designate. Grantee may request recovery in its rates of the just and reasonable costs of complying with any such relocation requirement in accordance with the procedures and criteria set forth in Section 2.507.A.(7) or 2.507.A.(8) of this Ordinance. 
I.  Public Emergency. The City shall have the right to demand that all or parts of the distribution system be de-energized and made safe, without prior notice, and to sever, disrupt, dig up or otherwise destroy facilities of Grantee, if such action is deemed necessary by the City Manager or his/her designee, Police Chief or Fire Chief because of a public emergency. Public emergency shall be any condition which, in the opinion of any of the officials named, poses an immediate threat to the lives or property of the citizens of the City, caused by any natural or man-made disaster, including, but not limited to, storms, floods, fire, accidents, explosions, major water main breaks, hazardous material spills, etc. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the City agrees to include representatives of the Grantee in its emergency joint response planning teams and the City and the Grantee agree to work closely together in coordinating and implementing all emergency response activities involving the Grantee's facilities. Grantee may request recovery in its rates of the just and reasonable costs of repairing any of its facilities damaged pursuant to any such action taken by the City or the Grantee in response to a public emergency in accordance with the procedures and criteria set forth in Section 2.507.A.(7) or 2.507.A.(8) of this Ordinance. 
J.  MISS DIG. If eligible to join, Grantee shall subscribe to and be a member of "MISS DIG", the association of utilities formed pursuant to Act 53 of the Public Acts of 1974, as amended, MCL 460.701. et seq., and shall conduct its business in conformance with the statutory provisions and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
K.  Use of Existing Facilities. Grantee shall utilize existing plants, mains, pipes, conduits, and other facilities wherever practicable, and shall not construct or install any new, different, or additional plants, mains, pipes, conduits or other facilities unless expressly authorized by the City, provided that the Grantee shall be permitted to modify current customer connections and to connect prospective customers to the Thermal Energy System within the Service Area, subject to all of the other terms of this Ordinance, without obtaining the separate express authorization by the City described above. 
To the extent that Grantee chooses to construct additional facilities and, as a result, the City incurs incremental costs beyond the fees and charges otherwise required to be paid by the Grantee pursuant to this Ordinance, Grantee agrees to compensate the City for such incremental costs as reasonably determined by the City. 
L.  As-Built Drawings. Subject to any applicable Homeland Security restrictions, Grantee shall provide the City with As-Built drawings and specifications in form and substance including, but not limited to CAD and other digital format, acceptable to the City within thirty (30) days of the completion of any new construction by Grantee. 
M.  Employee Identification. All personnel of Grantee or its contractors or subcontractors who have as part of their normal duties contact with the general public shall wear on their clothing a clearly visible identification card bearing their name and photograph. Grantee shall account for all identification cards at all times. Every service vehicle of Grantee, its contractors or subcontractors shall be clearly identified as such to the public. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 3, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.504. - No City Liability; Indemnification. 
A.  City Not Liable. The City, and its agents, employees, and contractors, shall not be liable to Grantee or Grantee's customers for any interference with or disruption in the operation of Grantee's Thermal Energy System, or the provision of service over or through the Thermal Energy System, or for any damages arising out of Grantee's use of the Public Ways. 
B.  Indemnification. As part of the consideration for this Ordinance, Grantee shall defend, indemnify, protect and hold harmless City, its officers, agents, employees, departments, boards, and commissions from any and all claims, losses, liabilities, causes of action, demands, judgments, decrees, proceedings, and reasonable expenses of any nature (including, without limitation, actual fees and expenses of attorneys, expert witnesses and consultants), arising out of or resulting from the acts, errors or omissions of Grantee, its officers, agents, employees, contractors, successors, or assigns, but only to the extent of the fault of the Grantee, its officers, agents, employees, contractors, consultants, successors, or assigns. 
C.  Assumption of Risk. Grantee undertakes and assumes for its officers, agents, contractors, consultants, and subcontractors and employees, all risk of dangerous conditions, if any, on or about any City-owned or controlled property, including Public Ways, and Grantee hereby agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the City against and from any claim asserted or liability imposed upon the City for personal injury or property damage to any person arising out of the installation, operation, maintenance or condition of the Thermal Energy System or Grantee's failure to comply with any federal, state or local statute, ordinance or regulation. 
D.  Notice, Cooperation and Expense. City shall give Grantee prompt notice of the making of any claim or the commencement of any action, suit or other proceeding covered by the provisions of this Section. 
Nothing herein shall be deemed to prevent City from cooperating with Grantee and participating in the defense of any litigation by City's own counsel. 
Grantee shall pay all expenses incurred by City in defending itself with regard to any such actions, suits or proceedings to the extent that they are related to the actions or inactions of Grantee. These expenses shall include all out-of-pocket expenses such as attorney fees and shall also include the reasonable value of any services rendered by or on behalf of the City Attorney, and the actual expenses of City's agents, employees or expert witnesses, and disbursements and liability assumed by City in connection with such suits, actions or proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 4, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.505. - Insurance. 
Grantee shall, at the time of ownership or construction of any systems, equipment, mains, pipes or other facilities obtain and maintain in full force and effect, for the entire effective period of this Ordinance, the following insurance covering all insurable risks associated with its ownership and use of its Thermal Energy System: 
(a)  A comprehensive general liability insurance policy, including Completed Operations Liability, Independent Contractors Liability, Contractual Liability coverage and coverage for property damage from perils of explosion, collapse or damage to underground utilities, commonly known as XCU coverage, in an amount not less than Five Million Dollars ($5,000,000.00). 
(b)  An Automobile Liability Insurance Policy to cover any vehicles used in connection with its activities under this Ordinance, in an amount not less than Two Million Dollars ($2,000,000.00). 
(c)  Worker's Compensation and Employer's Liability Insurance with statutory limits. 
The City shall be named as an additional insured in all applicable policies. All insurance policies shall provide that they shall not be canceled or modified unless thirty (30) days' prior written notice is given to the City. Grantee shall provide the City with a certificate of insurance evidencing such coverage as a condition of this Ordinance and shall maintain on file with the City a current certificate. All insurance shall be issued by insurance carriers licensed to do business by the State of Michigan or by surplus line carriers on the Michigan Insurance Commission approved list of companies qualified to do business in Michigan. All insurance and surplus line carriers shall be rated A+ or better by A.M. Best Company. 
Each policy which is to be endorsed to add the City as an additional insured hereunder shall contain cross-liability wording, as follows: 
In the event of a claim being made hereunder by one insured for which another insured is or may be liable, then this policy shall cover such insured against whom a claim is or may be made in the same manner as if separate policies had been issued to each insured hereunder. 
If the insurance policies required by this Section are written with deductibles, the deductibles shall be approved in advance by the City. Grantee agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the City from and against the payment of any deductible and from the payment of any premium on any insurance policy required to be furnished by this Ordinance. 
Grantee shall require that its contractors and subcontractors working in Public Ways carry, in full force and effect, workers' compensation, comprehensive public liability and automobile liability insurance coverage of the type which Grantee is required to obtain under the terms of this Section with appropriate limits of insurance. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 5, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.506. - Franchise Not Exclusive. 
The rights, power and authority granted herein are not exclusive, provided that Grantee's customers shall be prohibited from directly or indirectly reselling or otherwise re-transmitting for the use of others any of the Thermal Energy sold by Grantee under this Ordinance. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the actions of any of Grantee's customers in redistributing or re-transmitting Thermal Energy within any facility of said customer, or in charging tenants, licensees or other similarly situated individuals within such facility for a portion of such Thermal Energy, shall not be prohibited by the terms of this Section 2.506. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 6, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.507. - Rates, Rules and Regulations. 
A.  Service Rates. Subject to the provisions of Title VIII, Grantee shall be entitled to charge the inhabitants of the City for Thermal Energy furnished at the rates set forth below: 
The monthly Service Rate charges to customers of the Thermal Energy System for Thermal Energy service shall be equal to the sum of the following three components: (1) Service Charge, (2) Variable Charge, and (3) Government Mandated Costs. 
(1)  Service Charge. The Service Charge is Seven Dollars and Forty Cents ($7.40) per pound per hour of peak annual Thermal Energy billing demand ("Peak Demand"), such Peak Demand to be reasonably determined by the Grantee from time to time, based upon each customer's connected load and historic and projected maximum requirements for Thermal Energy, and paid in twelve equal monthly installments. If the franchise granted by this Ordinance becomes effective on any date other than January 1, the Service Charge described above shall be prorated so to cover only the number of days then remaining in the first calendar year under said franchise and shall remain the same (without proration) for the next full calendar year. Beginning January 1, 2010, and effective as of the first day of January during each year the franchise granted by this Ordinance is in effect, the Service Charge shall be increased or decreased, as applicable, by a factor that is 100% of the change in the CPI during the prior calendar year. "CPI" means the Midwest Region All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) Consumers Price Index (1982-1984=100 - CUUR0200SA0) as published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, U.S. Dept. of Labor. If this index is discontinued a comparable successor index reasonably acceptable to the parties shall be utilized. If publication of the CPI is discontinued, the parties will use a revised or replacement index that is similar to the discontinued CPI. 
(2)  Variable Charge. The Variable Charge is calculated monthly by the following formula: 
VC = CC + EC 
CC = the Consumables Charge, expressed in $, and calculated per the following formula: 
CC = CCosts × (MU/TU) 
CCosts = the costs actually incurred by Grantee's Thermal Energy System during the billing period for those non-fuel consumable costs that typically vary with production, including, without limitation, chemicals, water and sewer charges and purchased electricity. 
MU = Metered usage during the billing period for each customer expressed in Mlbs. 
TU = Total metered usage for all customers during the billing period expressed in Mlbs. 
EC = the Energy Charge, expressed in $, and calculated per the following formula: 
EC = {K × FC} × {MU + (MU/TU × LL)} 
K = 1.4 mmBtu per Mlb. 
FC = Fuel Cost is the weighted average burner tip cost of natural gas and fuel oil consumed by Grantee's Thermal Energy System during the billing period, including, without limitation, all wholesale, transportation, pipeline charges, balancing and imbalancing fees, brokers fees, lost and unaccounted for fuel, distribution and storage charges and taxes, fees and surcharges related thereto, expressed in units of $/mmBtu (determined by dividing total Fuel Costs incurred by total mmBtus of fuel consumed). 
LL = Line Loss = 13,000 Mlbs. per month 
(3)  Government Mandated Costs. Government Mandated Costs are calculated by multiplying (x) the ratio of (i) the Peak Demand of each customer to the (ii) total Peak Demand of all Thermal Energy System customers in good standing times (y) the cumulative total of all Government Mandated Costs. Government Mandated Costs shall mean any costs resulting from any new law or regulation, or any new governmental or court interpretation of an existing law or regulation ("Change in Law") that requires Grantee to expend (i) more than $10,000 of additional capital for plant or equipment or (ii) any incremental amount exceeding $10,000 for additional labor, fuel, operating costs, taxes, fees or other charges payable to a governmental unit. Grantee shall notify the City in writing of any Change in Law that Grantee believes will require Grantee to expend more than $10,000 so as to trigger an increase in the Service Rate as described above, and the City shall have ninety (90) days to take action to reduce such expenses. If the City reduces its Government Mandated Costs to an amount below $10,000 within said ninety (90) day period, no increase in the Service Rate shall occur as a result of the Change in Law. Capital investments resulting from a Change in Law will be amortized over ten (10) years at an interest rate of 300 basis points over the U.S. Prime Rate that is in effect when the capital investment is placed in service, as published in the Wall Street Journal. Labor, fuel and operating costs resulting from a Change in Law will be implemented as of the next January 1st. 
(4)  Purchased Steam. In the event Grantee is able to supplement steam it generates at the Fulton Street Plant by purchasing steam from one or more third-party suppliers, Fuel Cost in the above Variable Charge formula will be subject to modification to include the cost of purchased steam. 
(5)  Rate Discounting. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, the Grantee is authorized, in its sole discretion, and during such period or periods of time as the Grantee may deem advisable, to charge any customer or class or classes of customers rates for Thermal Energy which are lower than those otherwise specifically authorized herein. 
(6)  State Sales Tax. The rates provided for herein are exclusive of Michigan State Sales tax, use tax, utility tax or any other similar tax, which taxes shall be added to bills issued by Grantee, as required by law. 
(7)  Changes to Service Rates; Methodology. From time to time, but not more than once every two (2) years, the Grantee may seek the approval of the City for changes in rates and/or rate methodology by filing an application therefor. Such application shall include an explanation of the requested changes and the supporting evidence for such changes. Upon such application, the City shall set rates pursuant to the procedures described in Section 2.507.A.(8) (opportunity for the City to request information, opportunity for an evidentiary hearing, rates approved on a going forward basis). The criteria for changes in rates and rate methodology shall be as follows: 
(a)  The rates for Thermal Energy shall be just and reasonable to the Grantee's customers in light of the prevailing costs of energy available from other suppliers for the same purpose and in the same quantities; 
(b)  The rates for Thermal Energy shall be just and reasonable to the Grantee in light of Grantee's fully loaded costs to produce, transmit and distribute such Thermal Energy, including overhead, general and administrative costs and costs of capital improvements, together with a fair and reasonable return on Grantee's investment such that Grantee can secure financing on a stand-alone basis from independent third parties for its capital needs. 
(8)  Review of Rates by City. Effective with the billing cycle following June 30, 2013, and every fourth anniversary thereafter ("Rate Review Dates"), the rates then in effect shall be subject to review and adjustment at the request of the City pursuant to the following procedure: Not later than 12 months prior to each Rate Review Date, the City shall have the option of serving Grantee with a notice for a review of Grantee's rates. Such notice may request that changes be made to the Service Rates in the form of decreases or increases in any component, method of adjustment to any component or changes to the rate methodology. Grantee shall respond to said notice with such data and other information as the City shall determine to be appropriate, including Grantee's costs and revenues for the four year period immediately preceding the date of the notice, or such shorter period as shall have elapsed since the date upon which the Ordinance becomes operative per Section 2.514 hereof. The City shall then, following opportunity for an evidentiary hearing conducted by the City Manager or his designee, approve such rates on a going forward basis as are just and reasonable according to the standards set forth above in Section 2.507.A.(7)(a) and (b). 
(9)  General Provisions. The Grantee and the City shall have the right to appeal to arbitration pursuant to Section 23 of Title VIII, any Thermal Energy Service Rate set by the City with which the appealing party disagrees. The City shall reach its final rate determination within 120 days following the close of any evidentiary hearing held after it provides notice to the Grantee under Section 2.507.A.(8) or the Grantee petitions the City for a change in rates pursuant to Section 2.507.A.(7). 
B.  Rules and Regulations; Filing Obligations. Grantee shall have the right from time to time to make reasonable Rules and Regulations for the conduct of its business and the rendering of Thermal Energy service in accordance with applicable law, subject to reasonable City approval. A copy of the initial Rules and Regulations to be implemented by Grantee relating to the franchise granted by this Ordinance are attached hereto as Exhibit A. Any proposed modification(s) to Grantee's Rules and Regulations shall be filed with the City Clerk of the City. If the City does not act within sixty (60) days to approve or disapprove said modification(s), they shall be deemed approved. Grantee shall keep a copy of its then-current Rates, Rules and Regulations on file with the City Clerk of the City. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 7, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.508. - Temporary Service Rate Increase. 
In months of December 2013 through June 2015, the monthly Service Rate shall be increased by $0.10 per Mlb to enable Grantee to recover exceptional costs incurred in conjunction with the City's Weston Street reconstruction project. 
(Ord. No. 2013-85, § 1(7a), 12-17-13)  
Sec. 2.509. - Revocation. 
The franchise granted by this Ordinance is subject to revocation at the will of the City Commission upon sixty (60) days' written notice to the Grantee. If this franchise is terminated at the will of the City (and without any material violation of this Ordinance or the franchise by Grantee, its successors or assigns), the City shall pay to Grantee the sum of Three Hundred Thousand Dollars ($300,000.00) for each full year of the thirty (30) year franchise Term then remaining; provided, however, that no such payment shall be required if the City has terminated this Ordinance at the end of its Term or if the City has exercised its Right to Acquire as set forth herein, and provided further that this payment amount may be increased by mutual agreement of the Grantee and the City as necessary to account for future capital investments made by the Grantee from time to time. In addition, in the event of a material violation of the franchise granted hereby, this Ordinance may be revoked or forfeited either by the City Commission, or by a court of competent jurisdiction, at the choice of the City, without payment by the City of the amount described above in this Section 2.509. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 8, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.510. - Valuation. 
Within one year after the effective date of this Ordinance, the value, defined as fair market value, of the Thermal Energy system, including the property that is part of or used in connection with the Thermal Energy System within the City, and of such portion of such property beyond the City Limits as is actually and necessarily used in, belonging to and is a part of the local Thermal Energy service, and which the City is authorized to own and operate under the constitution and general laws of the State, shall be fixed and determined by mutual agreement of the City and Grantee; provided, that the value thus fixed or determined in no case shall include any value of the franchise. There shall be added annually to the value so fixed and determined, the value of additions and betterments, and there shall be deducted therefrom all amounts properly charged off under the Generally Accepted Accounting Principles of the United States for depreciation and obsolescence. If the parties cannot agree on such value of the property of the Thermal Energy System, such value shall be determined by arbitration as provided in Section 23 of Title VIII: Provided, that nothing shall be added on account of additions or betterments unless the expenditures therefor shall have been approved by the City Commission as reasonably necessary to the Thermal Energy System or economically prudent, provided further that the Grantee shall also have the right to appeal any decision regarding such additions or betterments to arbitration pursuant to said Section 23. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 9, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.511. - Annual Reports. 
Grantee or any corporation or person exercising the franchise granted by this Ordinance shall file annually on the first Monday in April, in the office of the City Clerk, a statement subscribed and sworn to by at least two officers of such corporation or by the individual in control of the Thermal Energy System, setting forth in detail for the preceding calendar year, the then actual cost of the plant or business operated by such corporation or persons, the actual encumbrances, debts or obligations thereof, the amount of stock issued and to whom issued and the consideration therefore, the gross earning, the expenses and nature thereof and the net income after deducting all proper costs and expenses, the names and residences, and the amount of stock of all stockholders, and if any bonds have been redeemed and not cancelled that fact shall also be stated. Every such corporation or person who fails to comply with the provisions of this section shall be liable to the City in the sum of one hundred dollars for each day of such failure, to be recovered in an action of assumpsit in the Superior Court; and at the end of sixty (60) days, if such default shall continue, it shall constitute case for forfeiture of such franchise. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 10, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.512. - Right to Acquire. 
At the end of the Term or upon any permitted termination of the franchise granted by this Ordinance, and also at fifteen years from the time of the taking effect thereof, and upon any five-year anniversary thereafter, or upon forfeiture thereof, City shall have the right to buy and take over all the property that is part of or used in connection with the Thermal Energy System within the City, and of such portion of such property beyond the City Limits as is actually and necessarily used in, belong to and a part of the local service, and which the City may own and operate under the constitution and general laws of the State, at the actual value thereof as fixed under Section 2.510 of the franchise as herein provided, and in the manner set forth in Title VIII. If said right to purchase shall be exercised by City at the end of the first fifteen year period, or at any five year period thereafter, then, except in case of forfeiture or violation of this Ordinance or franchise by Grantee, its successors or assigns, there shall be added as part of the purchase price to the value of the property, determined as provided in this section, four percent (4%) of the amount thereof for each full year of the thirty (30) year franchise Term then remaining: Provided, that such shall not include any value of the franchise; provided further, that this amount shall be in lieu of any amount described in Section 2.509; and provided further that this percentage amount may be increased by mutual agreement of the Grantee and the City as necessary to account for future capital investments made by the Grantee from time to time. If City does not elect to so purchase the property then, at the termination of the franchise granted by this Ordinance, the City Commission may provide that Grantee, its successors or assigns, shall sell the same at the price equal to the value, defined as fair market value, as ascertained as provided in Section 2.510 hereof, to any party to whom a new franchise may be granted, conditioned on the obligation of the grantee of such new franchise to purchase the same: Provided, that said grantee, his successors, or assigns, shall have the right to continue to operate such public utility under the terms of such reasonable franchise as the City may adopt and give efficient service until such time as the City is ready to acquire, take possession of and operate the same, and in default thereof, the City Commission may at once direct and authorize the taking of possession and operation of the same during such interval on the account of said grantee, its successors or assigns. 
If City does not exercise any of its rights as set forth in this Section 2.512 above, then, at any time within twenty-four (24) months after the franchise granted by this Ordinance expires, or is revoked, surrendered or otherwise terminated, Grantee shall have the option of either abandoning in place or removing at its own expense, its personal property from the Public Ways. In the event that Grantee decides to remove its property and such removal is not effected within said twenty-four (24) month period, the City may, within a further period of three (3) months, require that all or any part of the remainder of such personal property be removed promptly by Grantee, at the sole expense of Grantee. In the event of removal, Grantee shall restore the Public Ways and other public places so as to conform with the then current condition of same at the date of such restoration. Any such personal property not removed or required to be removed within twenty-seven (27) months after the expiration, revocation, surrendered or other termination of the franchise granted by this Ordinance shall be deemed to have been abandoned in place, and Grantee shall, upon request, provide the City with an instrument transferring ownership or such personal property to the City. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 11, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.513. - City Jurisdiction. 
Grantee shall be and remain subject to all Ordinances, rules and regulations of the City now in effect or which might subsequently be adopted for the regulation of land uses or for the protection of the health, safety and general welfare of the public; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed as a waiver by Grantee of any of its existing or future rights under Michigan or Federal law or a limitation upon the existing or future powers of the City pursuant to its Charter or Michigan or Federal law. For purposes of Title VIII, if the two arbitrators selected for any arbitration thereunder are unable to choose the third arbitrator, the City and Grantee shall take the names of all those approved as commercial mediators or commercial arbitrators for the Federal District Court for the Western District of Michigan and a name shall be drawn at random for the third arbitrator. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 12, 10-7-08)  
Sec. 2.514. - Effective Date. 
This Ordinance, being immediately necessary for the preservation of public health, peace, and safety, shall be given immediate effect; however, it shall not become operative until the 46th day after the later of: (1) its effective date, or (2) the date the Grantee has unconditionally accepted the franchise in writing. The Ordinance shall continue in effect for a period of thirty (30) years thereafter, subject to revocation at the will of the City pursuant to Section 2.509 hereof at any time during said thirty (30) year period; provided, however, it shall cease and be of no effect unless and until within fifteen (15) days after adoption the Grantee shall file its written acceptance of the same with the City Clerk, and pay to the City the sum required by Section 2.502 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 2008-38, § 13, 10-7-08)  
Secs. 2.515—2.600. - Reserved.
