Sec. 3.114. - Downtown Vendors Limited to Public Right-of-way. 
No person shall operate a Vending Cart in the Downtown District except upon the public sidewalk or public right-of-way, except that a Vending Cart may be operated on private property with the permission of the owner and the occupant of that property and in compliance with the Zoning ordinance and all other applicable federal, state and local laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2009-05, § 2, 2-17-09; Ord. No. 2016-78, § 1, 11-15-16)  
Sec. 3.115. - Exceptions. 
The provisions of this Chapter shall not apply to Vending in connection with Special Events as provided for in this Code in which case the Special Events provisions of this Code and any resolution adopted in connection with the special event shall apply; nor shall the provisions of this Chapter apply to motorized mobile Vending vehicles operated solely in connection with construction sites in the Downtown District provided that such mobile Vending operations are operated on private property with the consent of the owner or occupant of that property. 
(Ord. No. 2009-05, § 2, 2-17-09; Ord. No. 2016-78, § 1, 11-15-16)  
Chapter 47 - LYON SQUARE 
 
Sec. 3.201. - Purpose. 
The purposes of this Chapter are to ensure that the unique improvements made to the portion of the public street, heretofore designated as Lyon Street, are preserved and made available for the use and enjoyment of the general public and abutting properties on an equitable basis and to regulate the competing vehicular and pedestrian traffic uses on a street not generally open to all vehicular use. The City Commission hereby determines that, to achieve this purpose, it is necessary to rename that portion of the street, to define its boundaries, to designate zones within those boundaries, to specify permissible and prohibited activities within those zones, and to limit motor vehicle use to emergency and authorized vehicles, and to vehicles used in providing delivery and maintenance services to buildings adjacent to its boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 86-4, § 1, 2-4-86)  
Sec. 3.202. - Designation as Lyon Square. 
That portion of the public street heretofore designated as Lyon Street, between Monroe Avenue and the Grand River, is hereby designated Lyon Square. 
(Ord. No. 86-4, § 1, 2-4-86)  
Sec. 3.203. - Definition of Area. 
The legal description of the area designated Lyon Square is on file with the City Clerk. The area includes all that property which has the following general boundaries: 
(1)  The George W. Welsh Auditorium, the Grand Center, and the Metro Bank Building on the north; 
(2)  The Amway Grand Plaza Hotel and the Exhibitor's Building on the south; 
(3)  Monroe Avenue on the east; 
(4)  The Grand River on the west. 
(Ord. No. 86-4, § 1, 2-4-86)  
Sec. 3.204. - Use Zones. 
Lyon Square is hereby divided into use zones the locations of which shall be identified on maps which the Office of Special Events shall prepare and make available to the public. Uses permitted in each zone shall be only those which are listed in this Chapter. The zones and the uses permitted in each are as follows: 
(1)  Zone 1. Right-of-way for pedestrians and for vehicles which this Chapter authorizes to be operated on Lyon Square, except that the owners and lessees of property abutting Lyon Square may, pursuant to permit, conduct in this zone activities described in the last sentence of Section 3.206(3). 
(2)  Zone 2. Public use zone open to use by the general public except that sub-zones may be reserved by permit for particular programs or events. This zone shall be comprised of the following sub-zones with the indicated restrictions on vehicle use: 
a.  Zone 2A. The general location of this sub-zone is the amphitheater area adjacent to the Grand River. Vehicle use for loading/unloading and similar activities is allowed only by permit. 
b.  Zone 2B. The general location of this sub-zone is the area adjacent to the Welsh Auditorium. Vehicle use is prohibited. 
c.  Zone 2C. The general location of this sub-zone is the area adjacent to the Exhibitor's Building/Amway Grand Plaza Hotel. Vehicle use is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 86-4, § 1, 2-4-86; Ord. No. 2011-31, § 1, 8-23-11)  
Sec. 3.205. - Permits. 
All requests for permits required by this Chapter shall be made to the Office of Special Events, except as otherwise provided for herein. If the request is to reserve a sub-zone for a particular program or event, it must be made at least ten (10) days prior to the time the requested use is to start. Such ten-day deadline may be waived by the Office of Special Events, provided that the City Manager or his or her authorized designee determines there is adequate time to properly process the request and issue the permit. A requested permit may be issued upon compliance with all the requirements for such permits, and upon such reasonable terms and conditions, including public liability insurance, a security deposit against damage to City property, and a permit fee, as the Office of Special Events deems reasonably necessary or appropriate to adequately protect the public health, safety and welfare. Permits will be issued on a first-come, first-served basis, except that if competing requests for permits for the same area and time are made more than thirty (30) days in advance, the Office of Special Events or authorized designee may issue the permit for that use which in his or her judgment will benefit the greatest number of people and/or best meet the spirit and purpose of this Chapter. A permit may be revoked by the Office of Special Events upon violation by the permit holder or anyone engaging in the activities allowed by the permit of any of the provisions of this Chapter or of any of the conditions upon which the permit was issued. 
(Ord. No. 86-4, § 1, 2-4-86; Ord. No. 2011-31, § 1, 8-23-11)  
Sec. 3.206. - Conditions for Use. 
Use of Lyon Square for other than general public use shall be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Such use may occur only between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m.; provided, however, that for community-wide special events the time may be extended to not later than 1:00 a.m. with the express written permission of the City and the adjoining property owners. 
(2)  The kinds of programs, activities and uses for which sub-zones may be reserved by the general public are those of the same nature as for which a Park Permit is generally required if conducted in a City Park. 
(3)  The owners and lessees of property adjacent to sub-zones 2B and 2C may, pursuant to permit, conduct activities in those sub-zones that are related to simultaneous activities being conducted on their properties, generally without restriction as to the type of activity, so long as otherwise lawful, other than as such restrictions may be necessary to avoid conflicts involving the uses and scheduling of other zones. Such owners and lessees may also, pursuant to permit, conduct activities in all zones of Lyon Square approved by the Office of Special Events, which traditionally have been conducted in those areas prior to the enactment of this Chapter. 
(4)  Any use or activity involving the sale and use of alcoholic beverages shall be subject to State law and the City's Alcohol Policy and permit procedures administered by the Office of Special Events. 
(5)  The person or organization to whom a permit is issued shall be responsible for controlling the conduct of persons and activities attending and/or participating in the program for which the permit was issued. No conduct otherwise unlawful will be permitted. If illegal conduct or activity occurs at any such program, the Office of Special Events or authorized designee may, in his or her discretion, deny future requests for permits for the same or similar programs or future requests for other programs made by the permit holder, or any person directly affiliated with the permit holder. 
(6)  Any other reasonable conditions deemed necessary by the City Manager or his or her designee to preserve the spirit and purposes of this Chapter which are set forth in written rules and regulations promulgated by the Office of Special Events. 
(Ord. No. 86-4, § 1, 2-4-86; Ord. No. 88-59, § 1, 8-23-88; Ord. No. 2011-31, § 1, 8-23-11)  
Sec. 3.207. - Sales. 
Sales and vending activities are prohibited in Lyon Square, except for those sales activities which are specifically authorized by permit in connection with an activity authorized by the last sentence of Section 3.206(3) or which are an approved part of a City co-sponsored event as defined in the City's Co-sponsored Event Policy administered by the Office of Special Events. 
(Ord. No. 86-4, § 1, 2-4-86; Ord. No. 2011-31, § 1, 8-23-11)  
Sec. 3.208. - Prohibition of Motor Vehicles and Other Wheeled Devices. 
It is unlawful to use or operate a motor vehicle, including a motorcycle or moped, bicycles, or any other wheeled devices including rollerskates, skateboards, or similar devices on any portion of Lyon Square, with the following exceptions: 
(1)  Emergency vehicles responding to emergencies may be operated and parked anywhere necessary. 
(2)  City-owned vehicles, official vehicles, and other vehicles which are specifically authorized by special permit may be operated and parked as necessary within those zones in which vehicle use is permitted. 
(3)  Vehicles used in connection with loading/unloading and maintenance activities at buildings abutting on Lyon Square may be operated and parked within those zones in which vehicle use is permitted, but only as necessary and only for as long as necessary. 
(4)  Vehicles used in connection with construction or similar activities at buildings abutting on Lyon Square may be operated and parked within those zones in which vehicle use is permitted, but only pursuant to and upon conditions contained in a written permit issued by the City Engineer. 
(5)  Vehicles may be accepted for valet parking and vehicles may be returned to valet customers while stopped in a traffic lane within Lyon Square, if the valet drop-off and pick-up site is otherwise approved pursuant to a City issued valet parking license. 
(6)  Wheelchairs transporting physically disabled persons and baby carriages, strollers, and wagons transporting young children may be operated and used anywhere necessary or convenient. 
(Ord. No. 86-4, § 1, 2-4-86; Ord. No. 2011-31, § 1, 8-23-11)  
Sec. 3.209. - Prohibition of Structures, Statues and Displays. 
It shall be unlawful to erect a structure, statue or display of any kind anywhere within Lyon Square except by permit either in connection with and related to a simultaneous activity being conducted in one of the buildings abutting on Lyon Square or to provide protection from the weather for an activity otherwise permitted. It shall also be unlawful to maintain any such structure, statue or display for a continuous period in excess of seven (7) days. 
(Ord. No. 86-4, § 1, 2-4-86)  
Secs. 3.210—3.220. - Reserved.  
TITLE IV—STREETS AND SIDEWALKS

Chapter 51 - STREETS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Control of Public Streets and Places, Title V, Sec. 32; Director of Public Service, Title VI, Sec. 9; Director of Public Welfare, Title VI, Sec. 11(a); City to Control and Regulate Use of Streets, Title VIII, Sec. 14; Pavement of Streets by Street Railway, Title VIII, Sec. 15; Payment for Public Improvements, Title VIII, Sec. 16; Plan of Streets and Alleys—City Manager to Approve, Title X, Sec. 4; Separation of Grade Crossings, Title X, Sec. 6; Street Intersection Improvements—How Paid, Title X, Sec. 8; Persons Contributing Lands for Streets—Assessment Against, Title X, Sec. 21; Title X, Sec. 23. 
Cross reference— Designation of streets where outdoor meetings may be held, § 1.47; Department of Public Service, § 1.126 et seq.; Parking Violations Bureau, Ch. 16; Downtown Development Authority, Ch. 21; combustible and solid waste, Ch. 25; City Water System, Ch. 26; City Sewage Disposal System, Ch. 27; parks and public grounds, Title III; sidewalks, Ch. 52; special events, Ch. 53; parking and loading spaces, § 5.51 et seq.; street requirements for subdivisions, § 5.336; historic preservation, Ch. 68; taxicabs, Ch. 94; bus companies, Ch. 95; parking facilities, Ch. 97; CATV consent agreement, Ch. 110; general building regulations, Ch. 131; water service and drainage systems, § 8.35 et seq.; sign location control, Ch. 142; grading and soil erosion control, Ch. 143; flood plain construction, Ch. 144; fences, Ch. 141; sweeping litter into gutters, § 9.94; curfew, Ch. 156; fire prevention, Ch. 159; trespassing on railroad property, Ch. 162; general traffic regulations, Ch. 181.

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4.1. - Definitions. 
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this Chapter shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street shall mean all of the land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, alleys and boulevards in the City, and includes lawn extensions and sidewalks and the area reserved therefor where the same are not yet constructed. 
(2)  Department shall be deemed to refer to the Department of Public Service of the City. 
(3)  Director shall mean the Director of Public Service of the City.  
Sec. 4.2. - Damage and Obstruction Prohibited. 
No person shall make any excavation in, or cause any damage to any street in the City, except under the conditions and in the manner permitted in this Chapter. No person shall place any article, thing or obstruction in any street, except under the conditions and in the manner permitted in this Chapter or as expressly permitted elsewhere in this Code, but this provision shall not be deemed to prohibit temporary obstructions incidental to the expeditious movement of articles and things to and from abutting premises, nor to the lawful parking of vehicles within the part of the street reserved for vehicular traffic. The City Commission may, by resolution, authorize the City Manager to grant permits for certain uses in any street within the City which the Commission deems to be for the benefit of the general public. 
(Ord. No. 65-12, 9-7-65)  
Sec. 4.3. - Permits and Bonds. 
Where permits are required by this Chapter, a complete application shall be submitted to the Director upon such forms as prescribed with any required accompanying materials. Application fees shall be set from time-to-time by resolution of the City Commission. Permits shall be revocable by the Director for failure to comply with this Chapter, any rules and regulations adopted pursuant hereto, and any lawful orders of the Director or his or her duly authorized representative, and shall be valid only for the period of time endorsed thereon. Application for a permit under the provisions of this Chapter shall be deemed an agreement by the applicant to promptly complete the work permitted, observe all pertinent laws and regulations of the City in connection therewith, repair all damage done to the street surface and installations on, over or within such street, including trees, and protect and save harmless the City from all damages or actions at law that may arise or may be brought on account of injury to persons or property resulting from the work done under the permit or in connection therewith. Except as otherwise specified in this Chapter, where liability insurance policies are required to be filed in making application for a permit, they shall have a minimum combined single limit of liability for bodily injury and property damage for each occurrence in an amount as determined necessary by the Director. A duplicate executed copy of the original of the insurance policy, approved as to form by the City Attorney, shall be filed with the City Clerk. A deposit shall be required and used to defray all expenses to the City arising out of the granting of the permit and work done under the permit or in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 71-31, 5-25-71; Ord. No. 80-2, 1-2-80; Ord. No. 2018-06, § 1, 2-6-18)  
Sec. 4.4. - Street Openings. 
No person shall make any excavation or opening in or under any street without first obtaining a written permit from the Director. No permit shall be granted until the applicant shall post a cash deposit and file a liability insurance policy as required by Section 4.3.  
Sec. 4.5. - Emergency Openings. 
The Director may, if the public safety requires immediate action, grant permission to make a necessary street opening in an emergency, provided that a permit shall be obtained on the following business day and the provisions of this Chapter shall be complied with.  
Sec. 4.6. - Backfilling. 
All trenches in a public street or other public place, except by special permission, shall be backfilled in accordance with regulations adopted pursuant to this Chapter. Any settlement shall be corrected within eight (8) hours after notification to do so.  
Sec. 4.7. - Sidewalk Vaults. 
Openings through the sidewalk for the delivery of fuel or any other purpose when lawfully in existence, shall not be greater than thirty (30) inches in diameter, shall be circular in form, and shall be effectually closed when not in actual use by an iron cover set flush within the surface of the sidewalk, level with the sidewalk, and securely locked in place. All openings in the sidewalk for the admission of light and air shall be closed and protected whether by substantial iron grating or illuminating pavement of a design and so placed as to be satisfactory to the Director. 
No person shall open and leave open and unguarded any manhole or other opening in any sidewalk or public street. Such guard shall consist of a railing or fence at least three (3) feet high and made of iron piping at least one and one-half (1½) inches in diameter of such substantial material sufficient to withstand pressure from pedestrians and by stationing thereat while so open a person whose duty it shall be to warn persons traveling upon said sidewalk or highway of the opening therein.  
Sec. 4.8. - Utility Poles. 
Utility poles may be placed in such streets as the Director shall prescribe and shall be located thereon in accordance with the directions of the Director. Such poles shall be removed or relocated as the Director shall from time to time direct.  
Sec. 4.9. - Maintenance of Installations in Street. 
Every owner of, and every person in control of, any estate hereafter maintaining a sidewalk vault, coal hole, manhole, or any other excavation, or any post, pole, sign, awning, wire, pipe, conduit or other structure in, under, over or upon, any street which is adjacent to or a part of his or her estate, shall do so only on condition that such maintenance shall be considered as an agreement on his or her part with the City to keep the same and the covers thereof, and any gas and electric boxes and tubes thereon, in good repair and condition at all times during his or her ownership or control thereof, and to indemnify and save harmless the City against all damages or actions at law that may arise or be brought by reason of such excavation or structure being under, over, in or upon the street, or being unfastened, out of repair or defective during such ownership or control.  
Sec. 4.10. - New Paving. 
Whenever the City Commission shall determine to pave or resurface any street, the Director shall, not less than thirty (30) days prior to commencement of construction, serve notice upon all public utilities, requiring them to install all necessary underground work in advance of the paving or resurfacing.  
Sec. 4.11. - Sewer and Water Connections. 
When such paving or resurfacing shall have been ordered or declared necessary by the City Commission, such sewer and water connections as are necessary shall be installed in advance of such paving or resurfacing, and the cost thereof shall be charged against the premises adjacent thereto, or to be served thereby, and against the owner of such premises. Where such paving or resurfacing is financed in whole or in part by special assessment, the cost of such sewer and water connections may be made chargeable against the premises served or adjacent thereto, as a part of the special assessment for such paving or resurfacing. Where such paving or resurfacing is financed otherwise than by special assessment, the cost of the sewer and water connections so installed, shall be a lien on said premises adjacent thereto, or to be served thereby, and shall be collected as provided for assessments on single lots pursuant to the provisions of this Code.  
Sec. 4.12. - Determination of Necessity. 
The necessity for such sewer and water connections shall be determined by the Director, which determination shall be based upon the size, shape and area of each abutting lot or parcel of land, the lawful use of such land under the zoning regulations of the City, the character of the locality and the probable future development of each abutting lot or parcel of land. The Director shall give written notice of the intention to install such sewer and water connections, and to charge the cost of the same to the premises, to each owner of land abutting the street to be furnished with such connections, as shown by the records of the City Assessor in accordance with Chapter 1 of this Code. Any owner objecting to the installation of any such sewer or water connection shall file his or her objections in writing within seven (7) days after service of such notice with the Director who shall, after considering each such objection made in writing, make a final determination of the sewer and water connections to be installed.  
Sec. 4.13. - Prohibited Openings. 
No permit to make any opening or excavation in or under a paved street shall be granted to any person within a period of two (2) years after the completion of any paving or resurfacing thereof. If a street opening is necessary as a public safety measure, the Director may suspend the operation of this Section as to such street opening.  
Secs. 4.14—4.17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 2. - CURB CUTS 
 
Sec. 4.18. - Permit; General Requirements. 
No opening in or through any curb or any street shall be made without first obtaining a written permit from the Director. Curb cuts and sidewalk driveway crossings to provide access to private property shall comply with the following: 
(1)  No single curb cut shall be less than ten (10) feet, nor more than thirty (30) feet. 
(2)  The minimum distance between any curb cut and a public crosswalk shall be five (5) feet. 
(3)  The minimum distance between curb cuts, except those serving residential property, shall be twenty-five (25) feet. 
(4)  The maximum number of lineal feet of sidewalk driveway crossings permitted for any lot, parcel of land, business or enterprise, shall be forty-five (45) percent of the total abutting street frontage up to and including two hundred (200) lineal feet of street frontage plus twenty (20) percent of the lineal feet of street frontage in excess of two hundred (200) feet. 
(5)  The necessary adjustments to utility poles, light standards, fire hydrants, catch basins, street or railway signs, signals, or other public improvements or installations shall be accomplished without cost to the City. 
(6)  All construction shall be in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the Director.  
Sec. 4.19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 3. - SIDEWALK OBSTRUCTIONS 
 
Sec. 4.20. - Sidewalk Obstructions. 
No person shall occupy any street with any materials or machinery incidental to the construction, demolition or repair of any building adjacent to said street, or for any other purpose, unless as permitted in Section 4.21. 
(Ord. No. 2018-06, § 2, 2-6-18)  
Sec. 4.21. - Pedestrian and bicyclist passage. 
(1)  Permit. A Temporary Occupancy Permit shall be obtained for any work that is conducted in or on a sidewalk or bicycle facility, including trails. A description of the purpose for any obstructions shall be provided, including a project schedule that describes duration, dates, and times of day. Any permit issued pursuant to the terms of this section may be revoked by the City Engineer for permit violations. 
(2)  Site plan. A site plan shall be submitted for review. The Plan shall show any and all sidewalks, bicycle facilities, trails, bus stops, and traffic lanes, as well as all trees, lane striping, hydrants and traffic signs which will be affected. 
(3)  Traffic Control Plan. A detailed routing and traffic control plan shall be submitted as part of the permit application where a sidewalk, bicycle facility or trail will be obstructed. The Plan shall demonstrate how pedestrian and bicyclist access will be maintained, and ADA Compliance satisfied. 
a.  At least six (6) feet of space shall be kept clean and clear for the free passage of pedestrians in mixed-use commercial zone districts, as defined in Article 6 of Chapter 61 of the City of Grand Rapids Zoning Ordinance; 
b.  At least four (4) feet of space shall be kept clean and clear in residential zone districts, as defined in Article 5 of Chapter 61 of the City of Grand Rapids Zoning Ordinance; and 
c.  At least five (5) feet of space shall be kept for the passage of bicyclists where bicycle facilities are present. 
(4)  Safety. Sidewalks or paths shall be defined on both sides by fencing, barricades, cones, construction tape or other devices for the purposes of delineating construction zones. If the construction area is prone to falling objects or debris a covered path shall be required which is covered by a hard roof and contains lighting. Sidewalks and paths shall be ADA compliant and kept free of equipment, materials, snow and ice, and debris. 
(5)  Materials. Paths shall be made of dense (hard), non-porous, non-skid material that is resistant to settlement and penetration by narrow wheels, cane/walkers/crutches and small-heeled shoes in all weather conditions. 
(6)  Signs. Detailed drawings of all signs, to include dimensions, intended to be placed for the purposes of directing pedestrian and bicycle traffic shall be submitted as part of the permit application. 
(7)  Administrative Departures. If building operations or construction activities causing the sidewalk, bicycle facility, or trail obstruction would impair the safety of the public or substantially affect the constructability of a project, an Administrative Departure may be requested. A permit application shall be submitted with sufficient detail to indicate the nature and necessity of the request, as well as proposed mitigation measures. The Director may waive some or all of the requirements of this section. In making a departure decision, the Director shall consider: 
a.  Street Type and Mode Emphasis from the Vital Streets Plan. 
b.  Context and surrounding land uses, including topography. 
c.  Vehicular, pedestrian, bicycle, and transit volumes. 
d.  Nature of users (i.e. vulnerable populations, ADA accessibility, etc.). 
e.  Proximity of traffic control devices and other safety elements (i.e. street lighting, sight lines, etc.). 
f.  Availability and practicality of alternative routes (i.e. convenience, distance, level of service, continuity, logical terminus). 
g.  Availability and practicality of alternative safety methods (i.e. flagmen provided by construction contractor, etc.). 
h.  Time of day, time of week, time of year, duration. 
i.  Nature of construction activities and their potential dangers to the public. 
(8)  Approval. Permit approvals shall be limited to the time required for the essential needs of a project to be satisfied whereby occupancy of the sidewalk, bicycle facility or trail can be re-opened, or an alternative access plan can be instituted which more fully complies with this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 87-24, § 1, 3-31-87; Ord. No. 2018-06, § 3, 2-6-18)  
Sec. 4.22. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 4. - SAFETY REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 4.23. - Safeguards. 
All openings, excavations and obstructions shall be properly and substantially barricaded and railed off, and at night shall be provided with prescribed warning lights. Warning lights perpendicular to the flow of traffic shall not be more than three (3) feet apart, and parallel to the flow of traffic not over fifteen (15) feet apart.  
Sec. 4.24. - Shoring Excavations. 
All openings and excavations shall, where necessary, be properly and substantially sheeted and braced as a safeguard to workmen and to prevent cave-ins or washouts which would tend to injure the thoroughfare or subsurface structure of the street.  
ARTICLE 5. - VACATING, NAMING STREETS; HOUSE NUMBERS 
 
Sec. 4.25. - Street Names. 
Street names, whether public or private, shall be established either by the City Commission, adjacent County jurisdictions or the State of Michigan by approval of a final subdivision plat, a condominium plat, a site development plan or similar public document and shall not be changed except by official governmental amendment. All street names approved after adoption of this subsection shall conform to the following rules: 
(1)  No new street name shall duplicate an existing street name located within the County of Kent unless it is an extension or continuation of an existing street. 
(2)  The same principal part of a new street name shall not be used more than once by varying suffixes such as Street, Drive, Way or Lane nor by varying prefixes such as North or East or N. or E. 
(3)  No new street name shall contain punctuation such as hyphens, periods or apostrophes. 
(4)  No new principal street name shall contain more than nineteen (19) letters or spaces in its principal part, exclusive of suffix designations such as Street, Avenue, Drive, Way or Lane. 
(5)  No new street name shall contain numbers. 
(6)  No new street name shall have a prefix nor include either the words or the abbreviations for the words North, South, East or West. 
(7)  For ease of mapping, short streets shall have short names. 
(8)  All street names shall be followed by a suffix designating the type of street, such as Street, Drive, Way or Lane. 
(9)  The suffix "Avenue" shall be restricted to streets on a north-south alignment and the suffix "Street" shall be restricted to east-west alignments. The direction of extensions or likely extensions shall determine the proper suffix for curved or diagonal streets. 
(10)  All street names shall be followed by a directional abbreviation such as NW, SW, NE or SE as established by the intersection of Division Avenue and Fulton Street. 
(Ord. No. 91-28, § 1, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 4.26. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-74, § 2, adopted December 15, 2015, repealed § 4.26, which pertained to vacating streets. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 4.27. - Street Addresses. 
Street addresses for all property and buildings within the City of Grand Rapids shall be designated and assigned by the City. Street address numbers shall conform to the following regulations unless assigned differently prior to adoption of this Section: 
(1)  Street address numbering shall either begin with the number one (1) progressing east or west from Division Avenue or begin with the number one (1) and progressing north or south from Fulton Street. 
(2)  Street addresses shall be even numbers on the East or South sides of a street and odd numbers on the West or North sides of a street. 
(3)  Street address numbers shall increase by eight hundred (800) each mile from Division Avenue or Fulton Street (two (2) digits for each thirteen and two tenths (13.2) feet on one side of a street). 
(4)  Street addresses located on curving streets shall be continuously and consecutively numbered from the lowest number through to the end. 
(5)  No street address shall contain more than four (4) numbers. 
(6)  Street address suffixes such as F(front), R(rear), S(side), H(half) or 1 / 2 shall be used only where such identification is needed for public safety or for numbering consistency. 
(7)  One (1) street address, only, shall be assigned to each principal building located upon a parcel of property except that: 
(a)  Buildings legally subdivided into separate sub-parcels by condominium or similar legal separations may be provided with a separate street address for each such sub-parcel, to the extent possible while conforming to subsections (1) through (4) above. 
(b)  A building entrance serving only one (1) distinctive internal use or one (1) rental unit may be given a separate street address. 
(c)  Principal entries located on separate streets may have street addresses on each street provided there is no public internal connection between them. 
(8)  Rental sub-units within a building shall be identified by alphabetical and/or numerical unit numbers established by the owner, unless permitted to have a separate street address by subsection (7) above. 
(Ord. No. 91-28, § 1, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 4.28. - Address Identification. 
Street address identification of a building or its principal entry is deemed to be essential to the public safety and welfare. The owner of a principal building shall cause the street address to be placed thereon next to the entrance and in such other locations as to be in clear view of the street, as well as in such additional locations to be in clear view of any adjacent public alleyway used to provide public services. The street address numbers shall be well maintained, located at least twenty-four (24) inches above ground level, be at least three (3) inches in height or such larger size to be legible from the street or public alleyway and of contrasting color to the background to which they are attached. Any freestanding building identification sign shall also display the principal street address of the building. Upon observing a building not so identified: 
(1)  The City shall notify the owner of these requirements and request compliance within a reasonable period of time. Upon failure of the owner to comply with this request, the City shall order compliance within an additional reasonable period of time. Upon failure of the owner to comply with the order, the administrator of the Code shall either refer the matter to the City Attorney for prosecution or take other appropriate action that will arrange to so identify the building. 
(2)  An administrative fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be paid by the owner for a reinspection to determine compliance with any order issued after the first notice of the requirements of this Article. The cost and fee shall be considered a personal debt of the owner to the City and may be placed as a lien upon the property until paid. 
(Ord. No. 91-28, § 1, 6-4-91; Ord. No. 93-31, § 1, 7-13-93)  
Secs. 4.29, 4.30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 6. - DRAINS AND DRIVEWAY APPROACHES 
 
Sec. 4.31. - Definitions. 
In the interpretation of this Article, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  The term "gutter" or "road ditch" shall be deemed to mean that part of the right-of-way which is shaped, crowned, sloped or graded for drainage purposes. 
(2)  The term "driveway culvert" shall be deemed to mean a drainpipe or other structure of concrete, masonry, metal, vitrified tile or other materials or combination thereof approved by the Public Service Director and used to convey or carry surface water across, under or through any driveway or road ditch and/or to connect two (2) or more sections of a gutter or road ditch. 
(3)  The term "driveway approach" shall mean any area in which, because of topography, elevation, position or location, it is necessary to enclose the gutter or road ditch in a driveway culvert in order to have a proper and suitable entrance to any property abutting on any public right-of-way.  
Sec. 4.32. - Permit Required. 
It shall be unlawful for anyone to construct any driveway approach over, in or through any gutter or road ditch or to install or construct a driveway culvert through any road, street or public right-of-way without first having obtained a permit from the Public Service Director as hereinafter provided.  
Sec. 4.33. - Application. 
Applications for permits shall be made to the Inspection Department and shall state the name of the applicant, the location of the platted property upon which any driveway approach or culvert is sought to be constructed and the size and type of construction needed. Upon approval by the Public Service Director, a permit shall be granted. Within thirty (30) days thereafter, the Public Service Director shall cause the driveway culvert to be installed in accordance with the terms of the permit.  
Sec. 4.34. - Fee. 
A fee shall be charged for the issuance of the permit in such sum as the City Commission may require, by resolution.  
Sec. 4.35. - Obstructing Drain. 
It shall be unlawful for anyone to retard or obstruct the flow of storm or surface water in or through any driveway culvert, gutter or road ditch in or through any road, street or public right-of-way.  
Sec. 4.36. - Notice to Remove Obstruction. 
The owner of platted property in front of which there is an obstructed gutter or roadway ditch shall, within twenty (20) days after notification in writing from the Public Service Director, remove such obstruction or interference or apply for permit to cause a new driveway culvert to be installed so that the flow of the surface or storm water is not obstructed or retarded. If the owner does not reside or maintain a mailing address on the property, notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the property and shall be delivered by certified mail to the owner's last known address.  
Sec. 4.37. - Surety Required. 
No permit shall be issued by the Inspection Department for any construction in or on any platted property, where there is no driveway approach, or a new driveway approach is deemed necessary because of the existing conditions, unless the applicant shall provide surety in such amount as is reasonably necessary, based upon the current construction costs, as established by the Public Service Director. 
Cross reference— Insurance and bonds generally, § 1.12; permits and bonds for work under this Chapter, § 4.3.  
Sec. 4.38. - Removal by City. 
If the property owner does not remove the obstruction or apply for a permit as stated herein within twenty (20) days after notification, the City may do the necessary work, and the cost thereof shall be charged or assessed against the property in the same manner as provided by statute for a lien.  
Secs. 4.39—4.46. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 7. - STREET POLE DECORATIONS 
 
Sec. 4.47. - Permit Required. 
No person shall use any street lighting standard or any other pole or fixture within any street or public place for any decoration purpose without first obtaining a written permit from the Director. No permit shall be granted until the applicant shall post a cash deposit and file a liability insurance policy as required by Section 4.3. 
Before any permit shall be issued, samples or drawings of any proposed decoration shall first be submitted to the Chief Engineer of the Street Lighting Division or one (1) of his or her designated assistants, and said Engineer or assistant shall approve the proposed decoration before a permit may be issued. If electricity is to be used in the proposed decorations, the application for the permit will so indicate.  
Sec. 4.48. - Wind Load. 
No decoration shall be permitted which will create an unsafe wind load on the lighting standard or which, because of the material of the decoration, impose any damage or discoloration to the lighting standard or will in any manner scratch the lighting standard.  
Sec. 4.49. - Installation. 
All decorations must be affixed, attached and installed in a workmanlike manner and shall conform to the decorations as approved by the Street Lighting Division. All decorations are subject to inspection by the Street Lighting Division and if upon inspection it is determined that the decorations do not conform to the decorations as approved or such decorations have been affixed, attached or installed in an unworkmanlike manner or for any reason should the decorations be considered as unsafe or harmful to the lighting standard, then such decorations may be removed summarily by the Street Lighting Division and the costs of removing same shall be borne by the person or business who authorized such installation.  
Sec. 4.50. - Electrical Installations. 
All electrical installations shall be done so as not to overload the circuit, transformers or any other part of the City's street lighting system.  
Secs. 4.51—4.60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 8. - CORNER CLEARANCE 
 
Sec. 4.61 - Clearance Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain, place, store, erect, plant or allow to grow any object, wall, sign, billboard, vehicle, bush, tree, shrubbery, fence (other than the chainlink type) or anything which might be hazardous or dangerous for vehicular or pedestrian traffic, any of which, separately or together, is more than thirty (30) inches in height above the level of the nearest public sidewalk, or the street if there is no sidewalk, and which is within twenty (20) feet of the nearest point of the intersection of any two (2) of the following: street, alley, roadway, railroad bridge, viaduct, overpass or driveway (public or private). Provided, however, that said twenty (20) feet shall be ten (10) feet whenever the point of intersection involves a driveway (public or private).  
Sec. 4.62. - Exceptions. 
The following shall be considered excepted from the provisions of Section 4.61: 
(1)  Any wall, embankment or permanent structure existing lawfully prior to the passing of Ordinance 1485; 
(2)  Any permanent structure for which approval or permit has been obtained from the proper authorities; 
(3)  Any building or structure which is permitted, under Chapter 61 of this Code (Zoning) to be nearer the intersection than as provided herein; and, 
(4)  Any building or structure for which the Board of Zoning Appeals has granted a variance.  
Sec. 4.63. - Enforcement. 
The Traffic Engineer or his or her duly authorized representative and any member of the Grand Rapids Police Department shall have the Authority to enforce Section 4.61 and order the owner, lessee, officer of a corporation and any person in charge of any property where there is a violation of any provision thereof, to correct any situation or condition. Failure to comply with such order shall constitute, in addition to the violation itself, a separate and distinct offense.  
Secs. 4.64—4.67. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 9. - ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 4.68. - Additional Regulations Authorized. 
The City Manager may make additional regulations pertaining to openings and excavations in the streets, curb cuts, or street obstructions, which regulations shall be subject to the approval of the City Commission. No person shall fail to comply with any such regulations.  
Sec. 4.69. - Removal of Encroachment. 
Encroachments and obstructions in the street may be removed and excavations refilled and the expense of such removal or refilling charged to the abutting landowner when made or permitted by him or her or suffered to remain by him or her, otherwise than in accordance with the terms and conditions of this Chapter. The procedure for collection of such expenses shall be prescribed in Article 1, Chapter 151 of the City Code.  
Sec. 4.70. - Temporary Street Closings. 
The Director shall have authority to temporarily close any street, or portion thereof, when he or she shall deem such street to be unsafe or temporarily unsuitable for use for any reason. He or she shall cause suitable barriers and signs to be erected on said street, indicating that the same is closed to public travel. When any street or portion thereof shall have been closed to public travel, no person shall drive any vehicle upon or over said street except as the same may be necessary incidentally to any street repair or construction work being done in the area closed to public travel. No person shall move or interfere with any sign or barrier erected pursuant to this Section without authority from the Director.  
Sec. 4.71. - Louis Campau Promenade. 
(1)  The public street designated the Louis Campau Promenade is hereby reserved for the exclusive use of pedestrian traffic, except as otherwise provided in this Section. It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate or park a vehicle, except for motorized assistive devices for individuals with mobility impairments, upon the Promenade except as permitted in this Section. 
(2)  Operators of emergency vehicles responding to an emergency on or adjacent to the Promenade and City of Grand Rapids employees operating City-owned vehicles on official business on or adjacent to the Promenade may operate and park such vehicles upon the Promenade as necessary. 
(3)  Deliveries to, and maintenance operations at, buildings abutting the Promenade which require that a vehicle be operated upon the Promenade may only be made before 10:00 a.m. or after 10:00 p.m., unless special permission is obtained from the Traffic Safety Director. 
(4)  The City Engineer may grant written permission to operate and park on the Promenade vehicles which will be directly involved in construction activities immediately adjacent to the Promenade but only to the extent that he or she determines that such use of the Promenade is necessary to the proper conduct of such construction activities. Such a permit shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other permits which may be required by the City for the use of public right-of-way during construction activities. 
(Ord. No. 83-26, 4-26-83; Ord. No. 95-4, § 1, 2-7-95)  
ARTICLE 10. - VACATING RIGHTS-OF-WAY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-74, § 1, adopted December 15, 2015, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as §§ 4.81—4.88. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, the provisions have been redesignated as §§ 4.72—4.79, at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 4.72. - Definitions. 
(1)  For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section unless the context in which they are used specifically indicates otherwise: 
Encroachment means an intrusion or invasion by any building, fence, pipe, pole, wire, wall or other structure or object in, on, under or over any portion of any right-of-way. 
Major vacation means the vacation of the entire width or significant portion of any developed right-of-way so that it is no longer reasonably usable for public vehicular or pedestrian travel and any vacation where any portion of the part to be vacated lies within twenty-five (25) meters of a lake or the general course of a stream. 
Minor vacation means the vacation of a platted, dedicated or otherwise designated but undeveloped right-of-way or the vacation of a portion of the width of a developed public right-of-way leaving the remainder in a condition that it is still reasonably usable by the public for vehicular or pedestrian travel. 
Reasonably usable means the right-of-way provides for unimpeded passage with height clearance of at least 15 feet and complies with all other minimum clearance, setback, and build-to lines as prescribed by the City Zoning Ordinance. 
Right-of-way means any strip of land within the City platted, dedicated or otherwise designated for vehicular or pedestrian travel by the public and any strip of publicly-owned land within the City designated on official City documents and actually used by the public for pedestrian or vehicular travel, including, without limitation, streets, roads, alleys, boulevards, sidewalks, bicycle lanes, curb-lawns and lawn extensions. 
Vacate means to abandon, discontinue, surrender and relinquish the public rights in and the public ownership, use, maintenance and control of any right-of-way. 
Vacation means the abandonment, discontinuance, surrender and relinquishment of the public rights in and the public ownership, use, maintenance and control of any right-of-way. 
(2)  Whenever a City official is designated in this article by reference to the officer's title, it shall include that official, any designee of that official, and that official's successor or staff member assuming that official's duties in the event of absence, vacancy, or reorganization. 
(Ord. No. 2015-74, § 1, 12-15-15)  
Sec. 4.73. - City Commission Action Required; Encroachment Agreement. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided by applicable state law, the vacation of any portion of any right-of-way in the City may only occur by action of the City Commission in accordance with this article and with the concurrence of the Kent County Circuit Court. 
(2)  However, the City Commission may approve license agreements allowing non-permanent encroachments upon rights-of-way in the City. Among any other terms imposed by the City Commission, such agreements shall be only three (3) years in duration in accordance with the requirements of the City Charter, though they may be renewable, and shall provide that any encroachment be completely removed upon the expiration, non-renewal or other termination of the agreement. Such agreements shall also be recorded with the Kent County Register of Deeds against the property from which the encroachment extends and shall constitute a lien against that property unless and until the encroachment is removed. The City Engineer shall prepare and propose for the City Commission's approval, guidelines to be applied in considering requests for encroachment agreements and requirements to be included in encroachment agreements. 
(3)  The City Engineer may approve a licensing agreement for encroachment to be in effect during the pendency of a circuit court action for vacation of a right-of-way that has received City Commission approval. 
(4)  The City Engineer may approve temporary encroachment agreements allowing the installation of temporary foundation support systems in rights-of-way provided these systems are decommissioned no later than the earlier of completion of construction or within three (3) years. After decommissioning, such temporary construction components may be abandoned in place in accordance with the terms of the agreement, the form of which and fees for which shall be approved from time to time by resolution of the City Commission. 
(5)  Any other provision of this chapter notwithstanding, the City Engineer, in consultation with other City staff the City Engineer deems appropriate, may review and approve encroachments for City special events where the encroachment will be for six (6) or fewer weeks. 
(Ord. No. 2015-74, § 1, 12-15-15)  
Sec. 4.74. - Request for Vacation. 
(1)  The consideration of the vacation of all or any portion of a right-of-way may be initiated by any person owning property abutting the portion of the right-of-way proposed for vacation or by the City Manager or City Engineer. 
(2)  A property owner may initiate consideration of the proposed vacation by filing a formal written request for the proposed vacation with the City Engineer. That written request, in addition to any other information or items reasonably required by the City Engineer, shall include at least the following: 
(a)  The requesting property owner's name, address, telephone number(s), and e-mail address. 
(b)  The legal description of the portion of the right-of-way proposed for vacation, which shall, if requested by the City Engineer, be supported by a survey. 
(c)  The address, permanent parcel number and legal description of the property owner's property that abuts the portion of right-of-way proposed for vacation. 
(d)  An explanation of the reasons for proposing the vacation. 
(e)  A promise to undertake and complete the required Circuit Court action to complete the proposed vacation, if it is approved by the City Commission, and to escrow with the City Treasurer an amount the City Attorney deems necessary to undertake and complete the required Circuit Court action. 
(f)  The signature of the property owner below a statement attesting the information in the request to be true, accurate and complete. 
(g)  (i)  A sealed drawing showing the area proposed for vacation which shall include existing property lines and dimensions where extensions into the public right-of-way are requested, including existing structures, landscaping, outdoor seating, and requisite appurtenances, and (ii) a map illustrating the property owned by the property owner, and all affected property as defined below. 
(h)  A list of addresses and permanent parcel numbers of all affected property: 
(i)  For a major vacation, the list must include all parcels lying within three hundred (300) feet of any part of the portion of right-of-way proposed for vacation. 
(ii)  For a minor vacation, the list must include all parcels abutting any part of the portion of right-of-way proposed for vacation and any parcels the access to any portion of which may be affected by the proposed vacation. 
(iii)  For any vacation, the list must include the owners of any non-City utility lines or facilities within the right-of-way proposed for vacation. 
(i)  A fee to process the request in an amount established from time-to-time by City Commission resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2015-74, § 1, 12-15-15)  
Sec. 4.75. - Staff Review and Recommendation. 
(1)  Within seven (7) days after receiving a request for vacation or encroachment completed as required by Section 4.83, the City Engineer shall send a copy of the request and supporting documents to the Planning Director, City Attorney, Enterprise Services Managing Director, Fire Chief, Police Chief, and any other City staff the City Engineer believes should review the request given the location and features of the area around the requested vacation or encroachment. Those receiving copies, in addition to the City Engineer, shall review and make a recommendation regarding the request for vacation or encroachment in accordance with this Section. 
(2)  The City Engineer shall also send a copy of the request to the owners of any utilities or easements in the portion of right-of-way proposed for vacation or access to which utilities may be affected by the proposed vacation or encroachment with a letter providing twenty-one (21) days for comment on the proposed vacation or encroachment. 
(3)  The following criteria shall be used in reviewing and making a recommendation regarding the request for vacation and any action on a request for an encroachment agreement under Subsection 4.82(2). 
(a)  After considering any proposed improvements, will the proposed vacation inhibit or impede safe and efficient access to any parcel, building or structure by emergency personnel or equipment, by residents, employees or patrons, including those with mobility limitations, by vendors or suppliers serving building occupants, or by others needing access to the parcel or premises? 
(b)  After considering any proposed improvements, will the proposed vacation inhibit or impede safe and efficient travel of vehicles or pedestrians using the right-of-way? 
(c)  After considering any proposed improvements or retained easements addressing them, will the proposed vacation inhibit or impede access to, maintenance on, or replacement of, any existing or reasonably foreseeable above or underground infrastructure, utility lines, facilities, or appurtenances within the portion of right-of-way proposed for vacation? 
(d)  Is the proposed vacation reasonably needed to use or continue to use an existing building or structure in a financially viable way? 
(e)  Will the proposed vacation allow for desired renovation, improvement, change in use, or other economic development objective on the property owned by the property owner requesting the vacation? 
(f)  Will the proposed vacation adversely affect other parcels, area residents or occupants, or the general public? 
(g)  What, if any, other impacts, effects, benefits, and disadvantages will result from the proposed vacation? Can they be addressed to minimize or preclude adverse effects of the proposed vacation? 
(h)  What, if any, precedent will be set by the proposed vacation that may be applicable to other sites in the City? 
(i)  Is a variance needed for the encroachment due to setbacks? 
(4)  Within twenty-one (21) days after receiving the request for vacation or encroachment, each City official getting a copy of the request for vacation shall address the criteria in Subsection (2) in a written response to the City Engineer which includes that official's recommendation to approve, approve with conditions, or deny the proposed right-of-way vacation. 
(5)  Within fourteen (14) days after receiving the written reviews and recommendations of the other City officials and from the owner of any affected utility, the City Engineer shall make a written report and recommendation to the City Commission along with a proposed resolution to approve the proposed vacation, deny the proposed vacation, or approve vacating a portion of the right-of-way that is less than that proposed, and, if appropriate, to add conditions to any approval to address the interests of the general public, affected utilities, or affected property owners, residents or occupants. A resolution approving a vacation of all or any portion of a right-of-way may also preserve easements for existing or future infrastructure, utility lines, poles and appurtenances. 
(Ord. No. 2015-74, § 1, 12-15-15)  
Sec. 4.76. - City Commission Action. 
(1)  The City Commission, by resolution, may approve the proposed vacation, deny the proposed vacation, or approve vacating a portion of the right-of-way that is less than that proposed, and may add conditions to any approval to address the interests of the general public, affected utilities, or affected property owners, residents or occupants. A resolution approving a vacation of all or any portion of a right-of-way may also preserve easements for existing or future infrastructure, utility lines, poles and appurtenances. 
(2)  Unless otherwise waived by the City Commission for good cause stated in the resolution, a resolution approving a vacation shall require that the requesting property owner bear the costs of initiating and completing the required Circuit Court lawsuit to confirm the vacation and, in the case of a major vacation, to undertake and complete any required plat amendment. The resolution shall further specify (i) whether the City's legal counsel (either the City Attorney or special legal counsel) will undertake and complete the Circuit Court action or whether the requesting party's legal counsel will do so, (ii) who will be performing any surveying and other work related to any required plat amendment, (iii) the estimated costs to be incurred by the City or the party requesting the vacation to undertake and complete the Circuit Court action and any required plat amendment, and (iv) the amount required to be escrowed with the City pursuant to an escrow agreement in a form and substance acceptable to the City Attorney to ensure the Circuit Court action and any required plat amendment are properly undertaken and completed. 
(3)  If the City Commission's action is to approve the vacation of a street, title to that portion of the land vacated by the City Commission's resolution shall vest in the abutting property owners by operation of law. If the City owns the right-of-way in fee, unless otherwise so determined by the City Commission, the party requesting the vacation shall pay to the City the fair market value of the area that is vacated and the City shall provide a quit claim deed for such property. The fair market value shall be established by an appraisal or by an estimate prepared by the City Assessor or the City's right-of-way agent. 
(4)  A certified copy of the resolution shall be recorded with the Kent County Register of Deeds and a copy shall also be sent to the Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs, or its successor agency. 
(Ord. No. 2015-74, § 1, 12-15-15)  
Sec. 4.77. - Circuit Court Action. 
If the City Commission approves a vacation, an action shall be initiated in the Kent County Circuit Court and the following requirements shall apply: 
(1)  For a major vacation, proceedings shall be initiated and completed in the Kent County Circuit Court in accordance with the requirements of the Land Division Act, 1967 PA 288, as amended, for amending or revising a plat, MCL 560.221 et seq. 
(2)  For a minor vacation, (i) anyone having an interest in any parcel abutting any part of the portion of right-of-way proposed for vacation and any parcels the access to any portion of which may be affected by the proposed vacation, (ii) the owners of any non-City utility lines or facilities within the right-of-way proposed for vacation, and (iii), unless the City is initiating the Circuit Court action, the City shall be joined as parties defendant. Unless specifically required by applicable state law, no plat amendment shall be required. The Circuit Court shall confirm the proposed vacation as approved by the City Commission unless a party to the proceedings objects and the objection is for a reason that is not adequately addressed by a requirement or condition provided in the City Commission resolution approving the vacation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-74, § 1, 12-15-15)  
Sec. 4.78. - Vesting of Title. 
(1)  For a major vacation, title shall vest as provided in Section 227a of the Land Division Act, MCL 560.227a. 
(2)  For a minor vacation, title shall vest as follows: 
(a)  Title to a right-of-way the full width of which is vacated by the court's judgment shall vest in the rightful owners of the lots, within the subdivision covered by the plat, abutting the right-of-way. 
(b)  If the lots abutting the vacated right-of-way on both sides belong to the same owner, title to the vacated right-of-way shall vest in that owner. If the lots on opposite sides of the vacated right-of-way belong to different owners, title up to the center line of the vacated right-of-way shall vest in the respective owners of the abutting lots on each side. 
(c)  If only part of the width of a street or alley, not extending beyond the center line, is vacated, title to the vacated part of the street or alley shall vest in the owner of the lots abutting the same. 
(3)  When title to any part of a vacated right-of-way vests in an abutting owner, any future legal description of the abutting lot or lots shall include that part of the vacated right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2015-74, § 1, 12-15-15)  
Sec. 4.79. - Compliance with City Code of Ordinances and State Law. 
Nothing within this article, or within any approval or agreement issued by the City, shall relieve a person of the duties and obligations imposed under other applicable provisions of the City's Code of Ordinances or State Law. To the extent of any conflict between any provision of this article and any provision of State Law, the provision of State Law shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2015-74, § 1, 12-15-15)  
Chapter 52 - SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Sidewalk vaults, § 4.7; sidewalk obstructions, § 4.20; zoning, Ch. 61; subdivision regulations, Ch. 64; Housing Code, Ch. 140; sweeping litter into gutters, § 9.94; merchants to keep sidewalks free of litter, § 9.95; parking prohibited on sidewalk, § 10.45(1); sidewalks and bicycle trails, § 10.132. 
 
ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4.81. - Definitions, Sidewalk Builders' Licenses, Revocation and Penalties. 
(1)  Definitions. In interpreting the provisions of this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
(a)  "Director" shall mean the Director of Public Service or his or her authorized representative. The City Engineer is hereby designated as the Director's authorized representative. 
(b)  "Engineer" shall mean the City Engineer or his or her duly authorized representative. 
(c)  "Sidewalk" shall mean that portion of the street right-of-way designated for pedestrian travel. 
(d)  "Areaway" shall mean an extended basement of a building within the street right-of-way. 
(e)  "Areaway Sidewalk" shall mean a sidewalk constructed over an areaway. 
(f)  "Driveway Approach" shall mean that portion of a driveway which lies within the public right-of-way and extends from the inner edge of the sidewalk to the street pavement or edge of a graded roadway. 
(g)  "Parkway" shall mean the area between the sidewalk and the street curb line. 
(h)  "Retaining Wall" shall mean a wall built on the outer edge of the sidewalk line for the purpose of confining earth. 
(i)  "Improvements" shall mean sidewalks, driveway approaches, retaining walls and areaways located within public rights-of-way. 
(2)  Sidewalk Builder's License Required. No person shall build, rebuild or repair sidewalks, driveway approaches, retaining walls, curbs, curbs and gutters or areaways in the street right-of-way without first obtaining a Sidewalk Builder's License. An application for such license shall be filed with the City Engineer and shall set forth the full name of the applicant, residence, and number of years experience in concrete construction work. Prior to the issuance of a license by the City Engineer, the applicant shall meet all of the following requirements. 
(a)  Examination Required. Each applicant shall pass a written examination, prepared and administered by the City Engineer, testing the applicant's qualifications and knowledge of sidewalk and driveway approach construction work. 
(b)  Payment of Annual License Fee Required. Each applicant shall remit payment of the annual license fee. 
(i)  Setting of Fees. The amount of the Sidewalk Builder's License Fee shall be established from time to time by resolution of the City Commission. Such fees are to become effective for the subsequent year beginning January 1. 
(ii)  First Issuance and Renewal Fees Distinguished. There shall be three (3) fees established for the Sidewalk Builder's License. 
(1)  A first issuance fee shall be charged when an applicant for a license does not have an existing valid and current license. This shall include, but not be limited to, first-time applicants or applicants whose license has expired without being properly renewed. 
(2)  A renewal fee shall be charged to those applicants who have an existing valid and current license and file a renewal application prior to the expiration of such valid and current license on or before December 31 of the current license year. 
(3)  A grace period renewal fee shall be charged for those applicants who file a renewal application on or after January 1 and prior to February 1 of each year. Applicants making renewal during this renewal period shall pay one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of the established renewal fee for the license. Licenses not renewed during the January renewal grace period shall be deemed expired. Applications to renew filed on or after February 1 shall be assessed a fee equal to a first issuance fee. 
(c)  Bond Required. Each applicant shall furnish to the City Engineer a surety bond in the amount of Ten Thousand Dollars ($10,000.00). Such bond shall provide that the licensee shall fully perform and comply with the Grand Rapids Standard Construction Specifications, Sidewalk Rules and Regulations and provisions of the City Code with regard to the construction of sidewalks, driveway approaches, retaining walls, curbs, curbs and gutters and areaways; and shall promptly repair, replace, restore, or rebuild any finished work in which defects of materials or workmanship may appear or to which damage may occur because of such defects during the one-year period subsequent to the date of final inspection of such work, and shall comply in every respect with the provisions of Section 1.12. 
(d)  Insurance Required. Each applicant shall acquire the following insurance coverage, and shall continuously maintain such coverage during the period in which the Contractor is performing services. Each applicant shall provide the City with acceptable proof of the following types and amounts of insurance coverage: 
(i)  Workers Compensation Insurance as required by Michigan Statute. 
(ii)  Comprehensive General Liability Insurance on an "Occurrence Basis" with limits of liability not less than $1,000,000 per occurrence and/or aggregate combined single limit, Personal Injury, Bodily Injury, and Property Damage. 
(iii)  Comprehensive Owned and Non-Owned Automobile Liability Insurance with limits of liability not less than $1,000,000 per occurrence combined single limit, Bodily Injury and Property Damage. Coverage shall include all owned vehicles, all non-owned vehicles, and all hired vehicles. 
(iv)  The City of Grand Rapids shall be named as an additional insured by endorsement to the Comprehensive General Liability policy. 
(v)  Certificates of insurance evidencing that the Contractor has secured all of the foregoing insurance must be provided to the City. A minimum of thirty (30) days notice to the City prior to the cancellation of, or change in, any such insurance shall be endorsed on each policy and noted on each certificate. 
(vi)  Such insurance shall comply with the provisions of Section 1.12. 
(e)  License Expiration. Sidewalk Builder's Licenses issued under this Chapter shall be subject to annual renewal, and shall expire on the 31st day of December of each year. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Article, any Sidewalk Builder's License issued in the year 2007 shall expire on December 31, 2007. The fee for such Sidewalk Builder's License issued in 2007 shall be established on a pro-rated basis from May to December 2007. 
(3)  Revocation of License. The City Manager or his or her designee shall have the power to revoke any license issued hereunder upon the satisfactory proof that the licensee has: 
(a)  Violated any of the provisions of this Chapter, or 
(b)  Violated any of the provisions of the Grand Rapids Standard Construction Specifications or Sidewalk Rules and Regulations. 
Should a license holder wish to appeal the City Manager's action, he or she may request in writing to the City Engineer, a hearing by the City Commission's Community Development Committee to be held within fourteen (14) days of receipt of said request. The license holder shall be given written notice of the reasons for the license revocation, and the date, time and place of such hearing, at least seven (7) days prior to the hearing. At the hearing, the Committee shall consider the written and/or oral presentations by both the license holder and the City Manager and within ten (10) days thereafter, either confirm the original license revocation or reinstate said license. 
(4)  Violations and Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who shall build, rebuild or repair any sidewalk, driveway approach, retaining wall, curb, curb and gutter or areaway without first obtaining a license shall be guilty of a violation of this Chapter. 
(b)  Penalty for violations shall be as provided in Chapter 1, Section 1.13. 
(c)  In addition to any fine and/or imprisonment, any person convicted of a violation of this Chapter shall be required to make restitution to the property owner in a manner as shall be satisfactory to the Director. 
(Ord. No. 70-52, 7-28-70; Ord. No. 84-63, § 1, 9-11-84; Ord. No. 97-59, § 1, 12-2-97; Ord. No. 2007-20, §§ 1, 2, 3-27-07)  
Sec. 4.82. - Permits and Specifications. 
(1)  No permit to build, rebuild or repair any sidewalk, driveway approach, retaining wall, curb, curb and gutter or areaway in the street right-of-way shall be issued to any person except a licensed Sidewalk Builder. 
(2)  Before starting any work in the street right-of-way, the Sidewalk Builder shall take out a permit. Application for such permit shall: 
(a)  Be accompanied by the permit fee as specified in the City Code or in the Sidewalk Rules and Regulations Permit Fee Schedule. 
(b)  Be accompanied by a plan or sketch showing that the existing ground surfaces adjacent to and within limits of the public right-of-way shall be graded and/or excavated to conform to the established sidewalk grade on completion of the construction pursuant to the permit. Said plan or sketch shall show that a sloping grade beginning at the established sidewalk grade and sloping toward the curb or proposed curb line shall be maintained in order that surface waters shall run toward the street gutter or drainage ditch. The Engineer shall furnish line and grade stakes as may be necessary for proper location of the established sidewalk grade. The necessity for said plan or sketch may be waived by the Engineer. 
(c)  No Building Permit for the construction or alteration of any building or structure shall be issued by the Inspection Services Department until the property owner has filed said plan or sketch. 
(3)  All construction work in the public right-of-way requires a permit unless such work is covered by a City contract. 
(4)  If any job or construction covered by this Chapter is started before a permit is obtained, an amount equivalent to Two Hundred (200) percent of the fee shall be paid before a permit is issued. 
(5)  Permits shall be effective for a period of sixty (60) days. If the work is not completed within this time, the permit shall be null and void. Refunds or credits of permit fees will not be allowed. 
(6)  Every sidewalk, driveway approach, curb, curb and gutter or areaway shall be built, rebuilt or repaired in accordance with the Grand Rapids Standard Construction Specifications and Sidewalk Rules and Regulations as approved by the City Commission. 
(7)  A copy of the Sidewalk Rules and Regulations will be furnished to each licensee. Additional copies are available at One Dollar ($1.00) each. The Director is hereby authorized and directed to make and promulgate all necessary rules, regulations, plans and specifications for carrying out the design of this Chapter and to direct the proper construction of such work. Any neglect or refusal on the part of any person so building such structures to conform with such rules and regulations shall be deemed in violation of this Chapter and subject to the penalties provided. 
(8)  Line and Grade Stakes. After a permit is issued, the Engineer shall, upon request of the Sidewalk Builder, furnish line and grade stakes as may be necessary for proper control of the work; but this shall not relieve the contractor of the responsibility of making careful and accurate measurements in constructing the work to the lines furnished by the Engineer. Stakes will normally be set within forty-eight (48) hours. When it is necessary to replace stakes disturbed or destroyed without fault of the City or its employees, a charge of Ten Dollars ($10.00) per stake shall be paid. 
(9)  Valve Boxes and Cleanouts. When valve boxes, sewer cleanouts, hand-hole covers, gas valves, hydrants or other utility installations occur in sidewalks or driveway approaches, proper allowances must be made for these structures. Metal castings or frames shall be adjusted to the finished grade of the sidewalk surface. Concrete shall be kept far enough away from the covers so that they can easily be removed and replaced after the concrete has set. When a box is not perpendicular to the slab surface, the major portion of the box cover shall be set below the surface. When larger openings exist leading to underground chambers, the covers for these shall be set about one-half (½) inch higher than the average for drainage. In case of frames larger than six (6) inches across, standard sidewalk expansion joint material shall be placed on two (2) adjacent sides of square or rectangular frames and completely around circular frames. This material may be one-quarter (¼) inch thick, but not over one-half (½) inch thick. 
(10)  Areaway Sidewalk. No person shall build any areaway or areaway sidewalk in any public right-of-way in the City until plans for same have been approved by the Engineer and permission has been granted by the City Commission. 
(a)  Areaway walks must be constructed in accordance with the specifications for reinforced concrete sidewalks in the Grand Rapids Standard Construction Specifications and in the Sidewalk Rules and Regulations. 
(b)  When an areaway is to be abandoned or the adjacent building demolished, the sidewalk shall be removed, the areaway backfilled and a new sidewalk constructed according to the Grand Rapids Standard Construction Specifications. 
(11)  The City Manager or his or her designee shall establish the Sidewalk Rules and Regulations to carry out the purpose of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 70-52, 7-28-70; Ord. No. 84-63, § 2, 9-11-84; Ord. No. 2016-80, § 1, 11-15-16) 
Cross reference— Sidewalk builder's permit fee, § 7.48(52).  
Sec. 4.83. - Permit Suspension or Revocation. 
The Director may suspend or revoke any permit issued pursuant to this Chapter for failure to comply with the terms of this Chapter, the Grand Rapids Standard Construction Specifications or the Sidewalk Rules and Regulations. The Director may suspend or revoke such permit and order any work thereunder to cease by serving notice of such action and the reasons therefor. 
(Ord. No. 70-52, 7-28-70; Ord. No. 84-63, § 3, 9-11-84)  
Sec. 4.84. - Responsibility for Driveway Approaches, Retaining Walls and Areaways. 
All driveway approaches, retaining walls and areaways, hereinafter called improvements, within the City shall be maintained by the owner of land adjacent to or abutting upon the improvement. This maintenance shall include building, rebuilding and removing all obstacles, including snow and ice as required by Section 4.89. 
(Ord. No. 70-52, 7-28-70; Ord. No. 84-63, § 4, 9-11-84; Ord. No. 97-59, § 2, 12-2-97; Ord. No. 2014-30, § 1, 6-3-14)  
Sec. 4.85. - Driveway Approaches, Retaining Walls and Areaways Not in Good Repair. 
The City Engineer is hereby authorized and directed to order any person who owns property abutting to any driveway approach, retaining wall or areaway that is not in good repair, to build, rebuild or repair such improvements in accordance with the Grand Rapids Standard Construction Specifications as applicable. As used in this section, property owner means the owner of land upon which there is a driveway approach, retaining wall or areaway or the owner of the property abutting or adjacent to any of these improvements. 
(1)  Service of Notice to Repair. The City Engineer shall serve a Notice to Repair on any property owner by first-class mail to the property owner's address. The City Engineer's responsibility for communicating to the property owner is limited to notifying the taxpayer of record in the City Assessor's Office at the time of the first Notice to Repair. 
(2)  Content of Notice to Repair. The Notice to Repair will specify the location of the improvements, detail the work or repair required and specify that such work must be completed within sixty (60) days after service of such notice, unless otherwise specified on the Notice to Repair. The Notice to Repair shall also set forth an appeal process whereby the property owner may contest the Notice to Repair requirements. 
(3)  Appeals. Any property owner, upon service of a Notice to Repair, may file an appeal of said notice if requested within fourteen (14) days after the date of the Notice to Repair.
