State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 257.683 et seq. 
 
Sec. 10.71. - Inspection. 
The operator of a motor vehicle shall submit to inspection of the equipment of said vehicle upon the request of a police officer and he or she shall conform to such direction as the police officer may give him or her in order to determine the adequacy of the equipment of said motor vehicle, and if said vehicle does not comply with the equipment and standards herein established, the police officer may arrest the driver or may order the driver to have the vehicle fixed forthwith and report to the traffic division for inspection thereof within forty-eight (48) hours.  
Sec. 10.72. - Brakes. 
Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with adequate brakes which shall consist of a service brake capable of stopping the vehicle without deviation from direction within a distance of thirty (30) feet from a speed of twenty (20) miles an hour on a dry, smooth, hard surface road free from loose material; and an emergency brake capable of holding the vehicle on any grade which it can ascend.  
Sec. 10.73. - Horn. 
Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a warning device capable of producing a sound audible under normal conditions for a distance of not less than two hundred (200) feet; provided, however, that it shall be unlawful for a vehicle to be equipped with, and no person shall use, any siren, exhaust, compression or sparkplug whistle, and no person shall make any unnecessary or unreasonably loud or continued sound by means of a warning device; provided further that authorized emergency vehicles may be equipped with and use bells, sirens or exhaust whistles. 
Cross reference— Prohibited motor vehicle noise, § 9.63(5)—(8), (19), (20).  
Sec. 10.74. - Rear View Mirror. 
Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a mirror so adjusted that the operator shall have a clear view of the highway to the rear under all conditions. In addition, all motor vehicles shall be equipped with an outside rear view mirror on the driver's side which shall be positioned to give the driver a rear viewing angle from the driver's side of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 73-47, 6-26-73)  
Sec. 10.75. - Windshield Cleaning Devices. 
(1)  Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a device for cleaning rain, snow or other moisture from its windshield, which device can be controlled or operated by the driver of the vehicle. Every windshield wiper on a motor vehicle shall be maintained in good working order. 
(2)  No motor vehicle manufactured after January 1, 1956, shall be operated on a street or roadway unless it is equipped with a windshield washer maintained in operable condition at all times capable of cleaning the windshield so as to afford the driver a clear view of the street or any intersecting street. 
(3)  No commercial vehicle licensed as such shall be operated on any street or roadway at any time between December 15 and March 15, both dates inclusive, unless it is equipped with a hot air windshield defroster or an electrically heated windshield or such other device designed to heat the windshield and maintained in operable condition at all times.  
Sec. 10.76. - Noise and Smoke. 
(1)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle, except fire apparatus, on a roadway or any other place open to the general public unless such motor vehicle is equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise and annoying smoke, and no person shall use a muffler cut-out, bypass or similar device on a roadway or any other place open to the general public. 
(2)  The engine, power mechanism, and exhaust system of every motor vehicle shall be so equipped, and/or adjusted, and/or operated as to prevent excessive fumes, smoke or noise. 
(3)  No muffler shall be replaced, changed or altered in any manner so as to increase the noise or smoke emitting from the exhaust system. 
(Ord. No. 68-33, 5-14-68) 
Cross reference— Air pollution control, § 9.31 et seq.; motor vehicle noise prohibitions, § 9.63(5)—(8), (19), (20).  
Sec. 10.77. - Lights. 
(1)  Headlights and tail lights. Every vehicle while being operated during the hours of darkness shall be equipped with white headlights and at least one (1) red tail light clearly discernible under normal operating conditions for a distance of not less than five hundred (500) feet, the lamps or lights of which shall be on and projecting a beam to the front or rear, respectively, subject to the following requirements. 
(2)  Head lamps for motor vehicles; number, height: 
(a)  Every motor vehicle other than a motorcycle or motor driven cycle, shall be equipped with at least two (2) headlamps with at least one (1) on each side of the front of the motor vehicle, which headlamps shall comply with the requirements and limitations set forth in this Section. 
(b)  Every motorcycle and every motor driven cycle shall be equipped with at least one (1) and not more than two (2) headlamps which shall comply with the requirements and limitations of this Section. 
(c)  Every headlamp upon every motor vehicle, including every motorcycle, shall be located at a height measured from the center of the headlamp of not more than fifty-four (54) inches nor less than twenty-four (24) inches above the level surface upon which said vehicle stands. 
(d)  Whenever a motor vehicle equipped with headlamps as herein required is also equipped with any auxiliary lamps or a spot lamp, or any other lamp on the front thereof projecting a beam of an intensity greater than three hundred (300) candle power, not more than a total of four (4) of any such lamps on the front of a vehicle shall be lighted at any one (1) time when upon a highway. 
(3)  ( Reserved. ) 
(4)  Rear lamps: 
(a)  Every motor vehicle, trailer, semi-trailer, pole-trailer and any other vehicle which is being drawn in a train of vehicles shall be equipped with at least one (1) rear lamp mounted on the rear, which, when lighted as hereinbefore required, shall emit a red light plainly visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the rear. 
(b)  Either a tail lamp or a separate lamp shall be so constructed and placed as to illuminate with a white light the rear registration plate and render it clearly legible from a distance of fifty (50) feet to the rear. Any tail lamp or tail lamps, together with any separate lamp for illuminating the rear registration plate, shall be so wired as to be lighted whenever the headlights or auxiliary driving lamps are lighted. 
(5)  Multiple beam road lighting equipment; color, intensity, indicator: 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided, the head lamps, or the auxiliary driving lamps, or combinations thereof, on motor vehicles shall be so arranged that selection may be made between distributions of light projected to different elevations, subject to the following requirements and limitations. 
(b)  Head lamps shall in all cases emit a white light; auxiliary lamps may emit either a white or amber light. 
(c)  There shall be an uppermost distribution of light, or composite beam, so aimed and of such intensity as to reveal persons and vehicles at a distance of at least three hundred fifty (350) feet ahead for all conditions of loading. 
(d)  There shall be a lowermost distribution of light, or composite beam, so aimed and of sufficient intensity to reveal persons and vehicles at a distance of at least one hundred (100) feet ahead; and under any condition of loading none of the high intensity portion of the beam shall be directed to strike the eyes of an approaching driver. 
(e)  Every motor vehicle except motorcycles and motor driven cycles registered in this State which has multiple beam road lighting equipment shall be equipped with a beam indicator, which shall be lighted whenever the uppermost distribution of light from the headlamps is in use and shall not otherwise be lighted. Said indicator shall be so designed and located that when lighted it will be readily visible without glare to the driver of the vehicle so equipped. 
(6)  Reflecting discs. Reflecting discs shall be placed on the sides of any vehicle or load thereon if its lights are not discernible by persons approaching at right angles thereto. 
(7)  Flashing lights. Flashing lights are prohibited on motor vehicles, except on an authorized emergency vehicle or on any vehicle as a means for indicating a right or left turn. 
(8)  Additional lights. Additional lights may be placed on motor vehicles provided they are permitted by the Vehicle Code for the State of Michigan, and not prohibited in this Section. 
(9)  Signal lamps. When a vehicle is equipped with a stop lamp or other signal lamps, such lamp or lamps shall at all times be maintained in good working condition. No stop lamp or signal lamp shall project a glaring or dazzling light. 
(Ord. No. 77-15, 4-5-77)  
Sec. 10.78. - Projecting Loads. 
Whenever the load of any vehicle shall extend more than four (4) feet beyond the rear of the bed or body thereof, there shall be displayed at the end of the load in such position as to be clearly visible at all times from the rear thereof, a red cloth flag not less than twelve (12) inches, both in length and width, except that during the period of darkness, there shall be displayed at the end of any such load a red light plainly visible under normal atmospheric conditions at least five hundred (500) feet from the rear and sides of such vehicle.  
Sec. 10.79. - Fenders. 
It shall be unlawful to operate any passenger motor vehicle on the roadway unless such motor vehicle is properly equipped with mud guards or fenders of not less than eight (8) inches in width.  
Sec. 10.80. - Truck Weight; Height; Length. 
(1)  No person shall operate or drive upon the roadway of this City a vehicle whose total weight, including load, exceeds eighteen thousand (18,000) pounds per axle unless he or she either complies with the rules and regulations set forth in Section 257.722 of the 1970 Compiled Laws of the State of Michigan, as it may be amended from time to time, or receives a permit to do so from the Proper Authority. 
(2)  No vehicle exceeding thirteen and one-half (13½) feet in height or fifty-five (55) feet in length shall be driven or moved on a roadway, nor shall the total outside width of any vehicle or load thereon exceed ninety-six (96) inches, unless a permit is secured from the Proper Authority; provided, that any trackless trolley, coach, gas or diesel, with a maximum outside width of not to exceed one hundred two (102) inches and a maximum overall length, inclusive of front and rear bumpers, all not to exceed forty (40) feet, may be operated within the City of Grand Rapids.  
Sec. 10.81. - Trailers. 
Every vehicle or trailer drawn by any motor propelled vehicle must be so attached to such vehicle with such forms of coupling devices as will prevent such vehicle or trailer from being deflected more than six (6) inches from the path of the towing vehicle's wheels. Such vehicle or trailer must also be connected to the towing vehicle by suitable safety chains or devices, one (1) on each side of the coupling and at the extreme outer edge of the vehicle and each such chain or device and connection so used shall be of sufficient strength to haul the trailer when loaded.  
Sec. 10.82. - Operation of Unsafe Vehicle. 
No person shall drive or move a vehicle nor shall the owner thereof cause or knowingly permit a vehicle which is in unsafe condition to be moved on any roadway so as to endanger any person, or which does not contain such parts or is not at all times equipped with such lamps and other equipment in proper condition and adjustment as provided in this Chapter.  
Sec. 10.83. - Unauthorized Operation of Motor Vehicles on the Property of Another. 
No person shall drive or park a motor vehicle or trailer in any of the following areas or locations: 
(a)  Upon any portion of a street, highway or other public right-of-way not set aside as a roadway. 
(b)  Upon the sod or grass in any public park. This subsection shall not apply to persons employed in the park, nor shall it apply to others directed to drive or park within the park by a police officer or Park Department employee. 
(c)  Upon the property of any other person unless the operator has the consent of the owner, tenant or other person in occupancy or possession of the property. If the property is posted as private, or with signs prohibiting trespassing, the failure of the operator of a motor vehicle that is driving or parking on the property to display to a police officer, upon request, a written authorization of the owner, tenant or other person in occupancy or possession for the vehicle or operator to be on the private property, shall constitute prima facie proof that the driving or parking was without consent. 
(Ord. No. 71-38, 6-15-71; Ord. No. 77-21, 5-10-77)  
Sec. 10.84. - Avoidance of Traffic Control Device. 
No driver of a vehicle shall attempt to avoid obedience to any traffic-control device by driving upon or through any private property. 
(Ord. No. 73-16, 2-27-73) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, MCL 257.611(2).  
Sec. 10.85. - Child Restraint System. 
(1)  Except as provided in this Section, or as otherwise provided by law or by a duly promulgated Federal or State regulation, each driver transporting a child in a motor vehicle shall properly secure each child in a child restraint system as follows: 
(a)  Any child less than one (1) year of age in a child restraint system which meets the standards prescribed in 49 C.F.R. 571.213. 
(b)  Any child one (1) year of age or more but less than four (4) years of age, when transported in the front seat, in a child restraint system which meets the standards prescribed in 49 C.F.R. 571.213. 
(c)  Any child one (1) year of age or more but less than four (4) years of age, when transported in the rear seat, in a child restraint system which meets the standards prescribed in 49 C.F.R. 571.213, unless the child is secured by a safety belt provided in the motor vehicle. 
(2)  This Section does not apply to a driver who is a nonresident of Michigan or to any child being nursed. 
(3)  This Section does not apply if the motor vehicle being driven is a bus, school bus, taxicab, moped, motorcycle, or other motor vehicle not required to be equipped with safety belts under Section 710b of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.710b) or Federal law or Federal or State regulations. 
(4)  This Section shall not apply to any class of children exempted by rules promulgated by the Secretary of State pursuant to Section 710d(5) of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.710d). However, the driver of a motor vehicle in which any such children so exempted are transported shall restrain such children by any alternate means of protection specified by the Secretary of State. 
(5)  A person who violates this Section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(6)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, a person who violates this Section may be ordered to pay a civil fine of not more than Ten Dollars ($10.00) and costs. However, the court shall waive any civil fine or cost if the person, before the appearance date on the citation, supplies the court with evidence of acquisition, purchase or rental of a child seat system meeting the requirements of this Section. 
(Ord. No. 83-13, 3-15-83) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, MCL 257.710d.  
Secs. 10.86—10.92. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 6. - MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 10.93. - Deposit in Roadway. 
No person shall throw, scatter, sweep, deposit, place or leave in front or over, or in any roadway anything or substance liable to injure any person or damage the tires or any other part of any vehicle; and no person shall sprinkle a roadway to such an extent as to leave standing water or mud thereon.  
Sec. 10.94. - Obstructing Driver's View. 
No motor vehicle shall be operated while the windshield, sidewings, or any window thereof is so defective, obstructed or covered that the operator does not have a clear and unimpeded view through the full original surface thereof, or while the vision of the operator is obstructed in any way by any dangling ornament or other suspended object except as authorized by law. Provided, however, that official certificates in the lower right- or left-hand corner of the windshield shall be lawful. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, MCL 257.709.  
Sec. 10.95. - Load Security. 
No vehicle shall be driven or moved on a roadway unless it is so constructed or loaded as to prevent its contents from shifting, dropping, leaking or sifting, or otherwise escaping therefrom, without permission from the Proper Authority. 
Cross reference— Truck loads causing litter, § 9.97.  
Sec. 10.96. - Load Obstructing View. 
No motor vehicle shall be driven, moved or operated while it is loaded in such manner that the operator does not have unimpeded vision of the full width of the roadway directly at the front of the vehicle.  
Sec. 10.97. - Overloaded Vehicles. 
No motor vehicle shall be so loaded that it cannot be moved at a speed of at least five (5) miles per hour on any grade on which it is proceeding.  
Sec. 10.98. - Lugged Wheels. 
No motor vehicle shall be propelled which has metal spikes, lug or corrugations projecting from any wheel nor shall any machine or vehicle having a caterpillar tread, nor shall any heavy machinery such as tractors, concrete mixers, trenching machines, or excavating machines be propelled in any manner on their wheels or treads on the roadway of this City, nor shall any vehicle, machinery or other objects be driven, moved or dragged in such manner as to tear up or damage the surface of the roadway. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, MCL 257.710.  
Sec. 10.99. - Advertising. 
No vehicle used exclusively or primarily for advertising purposes shall be allowed on the roadway of this City except with the consent and under the regulations of the Proper Authority.  
Sec. 10.100. - Trucks, Prohibited Streets. 
No commercial vehicle of over one (1) ton capacity, except passenger carrying vehicles shall be driven on Monroe Avenue between Division Avenue and the south line of Michigan Street, provided that any such vehicle may be driven not more than one (1) block in said portion of Monroe Avenue when necessary for the purpose of loading or unloading. 
Cross reference— Truck routes, § 10.36.  
Sec. 10.101. - Loading Construction Materials. 
No person engaged in the loading, unloading or storing of materials for the excavation or construction of a building which will when completed face on two (2) or more streets, shall permit such loading, unloading or storing except on the less congested of the said two (2) or more streets, unless otherwise directed by the Proper Authority.  
Sec. 10.102. - Unauthorized Signs. 
(1)  No unauthorized person shall erect, maintain, move, deface, change the wording of, or otherwise interfere with or damage any traffic signal or device. 
(2)  No unauthorized person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway any sign, signal, marking or device which is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device or railroad sign or signal or the flashing, rotating or oscillating light of any emergency vehicle or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic device, railroad sign or signal, or the flashing, rotating or oscillating light on any emergency vehicle. This subsection shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property adjacent to highways of signs giving useful directional information, and of a type which cannot be mistaken for official signs. 
Cross reference— Similar provisions prohibiting certain signs, § 8.831(5). 
State Law reference— Similar provision, MCL 257.615 and MCL 257.616.  
Sec. 10.103. - Painting Curbs. 
No person shall paint or otherwise mark any curbing or other part of a roadway unless authorized to do so by the Proper Authority.  
Sec. 10.104. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-61, § 1, adopted October 8, 2013, repealed § 10.104, which pertained to standing horses. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 10.105. - Hitching on Vehicles. 
No person shall catch onto, hitch onto, or jump on or off of any vehicle while it is in motion.  
Sec. 10.106. - Motorcycles, Scooters. 
(1)  Not more than one (1) person shall ride upon a motorcycle unless upon a proper seat provided therefor, either at the rear of the operator's seat or in an attached sidecar. Both the operator and any other person riding in any other manner shall be deemed to be violators of this Section. 
(2)  No motor driven cycle shall be used to carry more than one (1) person. 
(3)  No motorcycle or motor driven cycle shall be driven more than two (2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of such vehicles. 
(4)  No person operating a motor driven cycle or a motorcycle shall pass between lines of traffic, but may pass on the left of traffic moving in his or her direction in the case of a two-way street, or on the left or right of traffic in the case of a one-way street, in an unoccupied lane. 
(5)  No person operating a motorcycle or motor driven cycle shall carry any package, bundle or Article which prevents the driver from keeping both hands upon the handlebars of said vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 67-5, 4-4-67; Ord. No. 67-25, 5-16-67; Ord. No. 70-54, 8-4-70; Ord. No. 73-12, 2-13-73; Ord. No. 2013-67, §§ 1, 2, 10-22-13) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 257.656 et seq.  
Sec. 10.107. - Ride Within Vehicle. 
No person shall ride upon any portion of a passenger vehicle except within the body of such vehicle, and no person shall ride upon the fenders or running board of any vehicle; and no driver shall permit any person to ride as prohibited aforesaid.  
Sec. 10.108. - Coasting on Street. 
No person shall coast or slide along or upon any sidewalk or roadway except as may be designated by the City Commission.  
Sec. 10.109. - Bus Stops, Loading Zones. 
The Proper Authority is authorized in the consideration of public safety and the regulation of traffic to designate, set aside, and mark such areas for buses to stop in for the purpose of loading and unloading passengers, the cost thereof to be borne by the company served. 
(Ord. No. 71-34, 5-25-71) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 257.676b.  
Sec. 10.110. - Through Streets. 
The Proper Authority may, upon consideration of the traffic flow, designate certain roadways, or portions thereof, as main traveled or through roadways, by erecting at each entrance thereto a traffic control device.  
Sec. 10.111. - Opening Vehicle Doors. 
No person shall open a door of a motor vehicle on the side facing the traveled portion of the roadway in such a manner as to interfere with vehicles, bicycles, or pedestrians lawfully proceeding on such public roadway. 
(Ord. No. 2015-52, § 3, 9-22-15)  
Sec. 10.112. - Excessive Noise. 
No person shall use any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle upon any roadway or any other place open to the general public so out of repair, so loaded, or in such a manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, rattling, squealing of tires or any other noise detrimental to the health and well being of any other person. 
(Ord. No. 68-32, 5-14-68)  
Sec. 10.113. - Usurping Parking Space. 
In any parking space where there is sufficient room for only one (1) vehicle, and an operator of a motor vehicle has stopped the said motor vehicle with the obvious intent of backing into the one (1) space available, it shall be unlawful for the operator of another motor vehicle to drive or propel or "nose" his or her motor vehicle forward into said space, or in any way usurp, or attempt to usurp, said space, or interfere with the operator of the motor vehicle backing into said space; and the operator of the motor vehicle backing shall be entitled to said parking space. Any person violating the provisions of this Section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.  
Sec. 10.114. - Abetting Violation. 
Every person who commits, attempts to commit, conspires to commit, or aids or abets in the Commission of, any act declared in this Chapter to be an offense, whether individually or in connection with one (1) or more persons, or as a principal, agent or accessory, shall be guilty of such offense, and every person who falsely, fraudulently, forcibly or wilfully induces, coerces, requires, permits or directs another to violate any provision of this Chapter shall likewise be guilty of such offense.  
Secs. 10.115—10.120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 7. - PEDESTRIANS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Stop required near crosswalk, § 10.19; blocking intersection or crosswalk prohibited, § 10.20; standing in roadway, § 10.28. 
 
Sec. 10.121. - Pedestrians Regulated. 
Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control signals as heretofore declared in this Chapter, traffic control devices and the order or direction of any Police Officer, notwithstanding the provisions of the existing traffic laws, when such officer is directing or regulating traffic in the interest of public safety, but all other places pedestrians shall be granted those rights and be subject to the restrictions stated in this Chapter.  
Sec. 10.122. - Crosswalks. 
The operator of a vehicle shall stop for a pedestrian crossing the roadway within any marked crosswalk, or within any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection, except at intersections where the movement of traffic is being regulated by a police officer or a traffic control signal; and at such regulated intersections operators of vehicles shall stop for all pedestrians crossing or who have started to cross the roadway on the "go" or "walk" signal. 
(Ord. No. 2018-05, § 1, 2-6-18)  
Sec. 10.123. - Crossing Other Than at Crosswalk. 
(1)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than a crosswalk shall yield the right-of-way to all oncoming vehicles. 
(2)  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all oncoming vehicles.  
Sec. 10.124. - Prohibited Crossings. 
Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signs are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk.  
Sec. 10.125. - Vehicle Stopped for Pedestrian. 
When a vehicle has stopped to permit a pedestrian who is properly crossing the roadway to proceed, it shall be unlawful for the operator of another vehicle approaching from the rear to pass such stopped vehicle.  
Sec. 10.126. - Hitchhiking. 
No person shall stand on or near the roadway and solicit a ride from the operator of any vehicle other than public carriers.  
Sec. 10.127. - Standing in Roadway. 
No pedestrian shall leave the curb and stand in any portion of the roadway while waiting for the "go" or "walk" signal.  
Sec. 10.128. - Blind Persons. 
Any driver of a vehicle who approaches within ten (10) feet of a person wholly or partially blind, carrying a cane or walking stick white in color, or white tipped with red, shall immediately come to a full stop and take such precautions before proceeding as may be necessary to avoid accident or injury to such person.  
Sec. 10.129. - Walking on Roadway. 
Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for pedestrians to walk upon the main traveled portion of the roadway. Where sidewalks are not provided, pedestrians shall, when practicable, walk on the left berm or shoulder of the roadway facing traffic which passes nearest unless otherwise directed by the proper signs or markings. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 257.676b.  
ARTICLE 8. - BICYCLES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-52, § 4, adopted September 22, 2015, amended Article 8 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Article 8, §§ 10.130—10.150, pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
 
Sec. 10.130. - Definitions. 
As used in this Article, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Bicycle means every mechanical means of transportation having at least two (2) tandem wheels, fully operable pedals, and propelled solely by human power or with an assistive electric motor of less than seven hundred fifty (750) watts, upon which any person or persons may ride. 
(2)  Bicycle Lane means a portion of a roadway which has been designated by striping, signing and/or markings for the preferential or exclusive use of persons riding bicycles. 
(3)  Trail means a section of sidewalk or other pathway which is physically separated from motorized vehicular traffic by an open space or barrier, and which is set aside for use by bicycles and pedestrians and is so designated by signs. 
(4)  Bicyclist means a person fifteen (15) years of age or older who is operating or riding a bicycle. 
(Ord. No. 2015-52, § 4, 9-22-15)  
Sec. 10.131. - Manner of Operation. 
(1)  Bicyclists. Operators of bicycles on a public highway shall be granted all of the rights and shall conform to all of the rules herein established for the operation of motor vehicles including the direction and instructions of police officers, traffic control signals and devices applicable to vehicles. 
(2)  Number of riders. A bicycle shall not be ridden by more persons than the number for which it was originally designed and manufactured. Passengers are allowed when using seats, trailers, or other carrying devices designed for use in conjunction with a bicycle. 
(3)  Two (2) Abreast. Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two (2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. Persons riding bicycles two (2) abreast shall not impede the normal and reasonable movement of traffic and, on a laned street, shall ride within a single lane. 
(4)  Erratic driving. No operator shall cause or permit a bicycle to curve to and fro. 
(5)  Hand on controls. At least one (1) hand of the operator shall be on the handle bar at all times except when he or she is in the act of signaling. 
(Ord. No. 2015-52, § 4, 9-22-15)  
Sec. 10.132. - Sidewalks, Bicycle Lanes and Trails. 
(1)  No bicyclist shall operate or ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk within the Downtown Improvement District as described in Section 1.960 of the City Code except in that portion of the Downtown Improvement District that is north of I-196. 
(2)  No bicyclist shall operate or ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk where traffic control devices or signs are posted or displayed prohibiting riding a bicycle thereon. 
(3)  When a bicyclist is operating or riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk or trail, the bicyclist shall yield the right-of-way to all other lawful users of the sidewalk or trail, and to all other persons so near to the sidewalk or trail as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(4)  When a bicyclist is operating or riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk or trail, he or she shall give an audible warning either verbally, by bell, or other suitable warning device to pedestrians and other lawful users of the sidewalk or trail. Such signal shall be given a reasonable distance before overtaking or passing by such pedestrian or other lawful user of the sidewalk or trail. 
(5)  When any person is operating or riding a bicycle upon a designated trail, he or she shall yield right-of-way to all vehicles turning onto streets or roadways intersecting the trail. 
(6)  When any person operating or riding a bicycle upon a designated trail or sidewalk is approaching an intersecting street or roadway, he or she shall slow down to a speed which will permit him or her to stop prior to entering the intersection, and shall make such reasonable observations as will enable him or her under the existing conditions of the trail, the sidewalk, the weather, the visibility and any other conditions then existing to yield the right-of-way and he or she shall yield the right-of-way to traffic on the intersecting street or roadway prior to entering the intersecting street or roadway. 
(7)  When any person is operating or riding a bicycle upon a designated trail, he or she shall obey all traffic control devices and signs posted thereon, and all traffic control devices controlling vehicular traffic on any street adjacent or parallel to the trail. 
(Ord. No. 2015-52, § 4, 9-22-15)  
Sec. 10.133. - Reserved.  
Sec. 10.134. - Equipment. 
(1)  Lights. A bicycle or an electric personal assistive mobility device being operated on a roadway between one-half (½) hour after sunset and ½ hour before sunrise shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least five hundred (500) feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear which shall be visible from all distances from one hundred (100) feet to six hundred (600) feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful lower beams of head lamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(2)  Brakes. Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. 
(Ord. No. 2015-52, § 4, 9-22-15)  
Sec. 10.135. - Hitching to vehicles. 
No person upon any bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself or herself to any vehicle upon a roadway or sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 2015-52, § 4, 9-22-15)  
Sec. 10.136. - Speed. 
(1)  No person shall operate his or her bicycle in a manner or at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper under the conditions then existing, or at speed greater than will permit him or her to bring his or her vehicle to a stop within the assured clear distance ahead. 
(2)  Unless otherwise posted, no person shall operate a bicycle upon a sidewalk at a speed greater than ten (10) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 2015-52, § 4, 9-22-15)  
Sec. 10.137. - Reserved.  
Sec. 10.138. - Private Property. 
No person shall ride a bicycle on private property unless the rider has the permission of the owner to ride thereon. 
(Ord. No. 2015-52, § 4, 9-22-15)  
Sec. 10.139. - Accident Reports. 
When any person is riding upon a street, highway, sidewalk, bicycle path and the bicycle is involved in an accident resulting in injury or death to a person or damage to property, the rider shall within twenty-four (24) hours report the accident to a Police Officer or personally report the accident to the Police Department at the Information Desk at Police Headquarters. 
(Ord. No. 2015-52, § 4, 9-22-15)  
Secs. 10.140—10.160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 9. - ACCIDENTS 
 
Sec. 10.161. - Operator's Duty. 
The operator of a vehicle who knows or should know that he or she has been involved in an accident upon either public or private property, when the property is open to travel by the public, resulting in injury or death to any person or damage to any property shall: 
(1)  Immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of the accident, and 
(2)  Render to any person injured in such accident reasonable assistance in securing medical aid or transportation of injured person or persons, and 
(3)  Give his or her name, address and the registration number of the vehicle he or she is driving, and the name and address of the owner, and exhibit his or her operator's or chauffeur's license to any person injured and the driver or occupants of any vehicle collided with or to the owner of the property damaged, and 
(4)  Forthwith report such accident to the nearest or most convenient police station or police officer, unless there is no personal injury and the apparent extent of the damage to all property is not more than Four Hundred Dollars ($400.00); provided, however, that if the property damaged is a parked vehicle or other stationary property, and the owner or possessor thereof is not present, the operator shall either locate the owner or possessor of such property and notify the owner or possessor of such property of the name and address of the driver and owner of the striking vehicle or, if such owner or possessor cannot be located, shall forthwith make a report of the accident to the nearest or most convenient police officer. 
(Ord. No. 79-24, 4-24-79; Ord. No. 93-8, § 1, 2-9-93) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 257.617 et seq.  
Sec. 10.162. - Presumption. 
The license plates displayed on a vehicle involved in any accident shall constitute a prima facie presumption that the owner thereof was the person who operated such vehicle at the time and place where the accident occurred.  
Sec. 10.163. - Garageman's Report. 
A person in charge of any garage or repair shop receiving a motor vehicle which shows evidence of having been involved in an accident, collision or struck by a bullet, shall immediately make a written report to the Police Department, on forms provided for that purpose, giving the engine number, license number, and the name and address of the owner or operator of such motor vehicle.  
Sec. 10.164. - Examining Reports. 
The reports required to be filed pursuant to Sections 10.161 and 10.163 may be examined by any person making such report or his or her attorney designated in writing and shall not be open to general public inspection nor shall copying of lists of such reports be permitted. The reports required by Section 10.161 shall not be available for use in any court action, nor shall the information contained therein be referred to in any way as evidence of the negligence or due care of any party involved in an accident, at the trial of any action at law to recover damages.  
Secs. 10.165, 10.166. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 10. - SNOWMOBILES 
 
Sec. 10.167. - Definitions. 
As used in this Article: 
(a)  Operator means any person who operates or is in actual physical control of a snowmobile. 
(b)  Owner means any person, other than a lienholder, having the property in or title to a snowmobile and entitled to the use or possession thereof. 
(c)  Operate means to ride in or on and to control the operation of a snowmobile. 
(d)  Person means an individual, partnership, corporation, the State and any of its agencies or subdivisions, and any body of persons whether incorporated or not. 
(e)  Snowmobile means any motorized vehicle designed for travel primarily on snow or ice steered by wheels, skis or runners. 
(f)  Snowmobile dealer means any person engaged in the sale of snowmobiles. 
(g)  Highway or street means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(h)  Roadway means that portion of a highway improved, designated, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. If a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways the term roadway refers to any such roadway separately, but not to all such roadways collectively. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 257.1501 et seq.  
Sec. 10.168. - Operation Within City Limits. 
Except as otherwise provided, no snowmobile shall be operated within this City unless registered by the owner as provided in Act No. 74 of the Michigan Public Acts of 1968, as amended. No registration is required for a snowmobile operated exclusively on lands owned or under the control of the snowmobile owner. The certificate of registration issued by the State of Michigan shall accompany the vehicle and be made available for inspection upon demand by any Peace Officer. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 10.169. - Registration Numbers Displayed. 
The owner of any snowmobile having been issued a certificate of registration for the snowmobile shall paint on or attach in a permanent manner to each side of the forward half of the snowmobile the identification number in block characters of good proportion, not less than three (3) inches in height, reading from left to right. The numbers shall contrast so as to be distinctly visible and legible. No number other than the number awarded to a snowmobile under the State law, or granted reciprocity under the State law, shall be painted, attached or otherwise displayed on either side of the forward half of the snowmobile. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 10.170. - Change of Information on Registration. 
The owner of any snowmobile shall notify the Michigan Secretary of State within fifteen (15) days if the snowmobile is destroyed or abandoned, is sold or an interest therein transferred either wholly or in part to another person, or if his or her address no longer conforms to the address appearing on the certificate of registration. The notice shall consist of a surrender of the certificate of registration on which the proper information shall be noted on a place to be provided. When the surrender of the certificate is by reason of the snowmobile being destroyed or abandoned, the Secretary of State shall cancel the certificate and enter such fact in his or her records and the number may be then reassigned. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 10.171. - Dealer's Responsibility. 
A dealer shall maintain in safe operating condition all snowmobiles rented, leased or furnished by him or her. The dealer, his or her agents or employees shall explain the operation of the snowmobile being rented, leased or furnished and if such dealer, his or her agent or employee believes the person to whom the snowmobile is to be rented, leased or furnished is not competent to operate such snowmobile with competency to himself or herself and to the safety of others, he or she shall refuse to rent, lease or furnish the same. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 10.172. - Dealer's Liability Insurance. 
Any dealer renting, leasing or furnishing any snowmobile shall carry a policy of liability insurance subject to limits exclusive of interests and costs, with respect to such snowmobile, as follows: 
Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) because of bodily injury or death of one (1) person in any one (1) accident and subject to said limit for one (1) person, 
Twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) because of bodily injury or death of two (2) or more persons in any one (1) accident, and 
Five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) because of injury to or destruction of property of others in any one (1) accident, 
or in the alternative, demand and be shown proof that the person renting, leasing or being furnished a snowmobile carries liability policy of at least the type and coverage as specified above. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 10.173. - Out of State Registration. 
A snowmobile registered in another State or in a province of Canada to a nonresident of this State may be operated within the State of Michigan under authority of such registration not to exceed twenty (20) days. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 10.174. - Operation on Highways, Roadways and Streets. 
No person shall operate a snowmobile upon the main traveled portion of any roadway, as defined in Section 55 of Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of 1949, being Section 257.55 of the Compiled Laws of 1948 (MSA 9.1855), or on a highway or street within ten (10) feet of such roadway, with the following exceptions: 
(a)  Properly registered snowmobiles may cross highways, except limited access highways and freeways as defined in Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of 1949 if such crossing can be made in safety and it does not interfere with the free movement of vehicular traffic approaching from any direction on such highway. The snowmobile operator shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicular traffic upon any highway. 
(b)  Snowmobiles may be operated on highways in the County road systems which are not maintained for winter wheel vehicular traffic by removal of snow. 
(c)  Snowmobiles may be operated on a street and highway during a period of emergency, when so declared by a policy agency having jurisdiction, when travel by conventional automotive equipment is not possible. 
(d)  Snowmobiles may be operated on the highways within the restrictions set forth herein for the purposes of crossing bridges and culverts. 
(e)  Snowmobiles may be operated on County highways not having ten (10) or more feet of traversable right-of-way outside the traveled portion of the roadway as far off the highway as possible. 
(f)  Snowmobiles may be operated on a street or highway for a special snowmobile event of limited duration which is conducted according to a prearranged schedule under permit from the City. 
(g)  Whenever it is impractical to gain immediate access to an area adjacent to a public highway where a snowmobile is to be operated, the vehicle may be operated adjacent and parallel to the highway for the purpose of gaining access to the area of operation. This subsection shall apply to the operation of a snowmobile from the point where the vehicle is unloaded from a motorized conveyance to and from the area where the snowmobile is to be operated when loading and unloading cannot be effected in the immediate vicinity of the area of operation without causing a hazard to vehicular traffic approaching from either direction on the highway. Loading or unloading must be accomplished with due regard to safety at the nearest possible point to the area of operation. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 10.175. - Safety Features Necessary for Operation in City. 
No snowmobile shall be operated in this City unless it has at least one (1) headlight, one (1) taillight and adequate brakes capable of producing deceleration at fourteen (14) feet a second on level ground at a speed of twenty (20) miles an hour. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 10.176. - Restrictions on Operator and Snowmobile. 
No person shall operate a snowmobile: 
(a)  At a rate of speed greater than is reasonable and proper having due regard for conditions then existing; 
(b)  While under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotic drugs, barbital or any derivative of barbital; 
(c)  During the hours from one-half (½) hour after sunset to one-half (½) hour before sunrise without displaying a lighted headlight and a lighted taillight; 
(d)  In any nursery, planting area, or natural area of forest reproduction and when growing stock may be damaged; 
(e)  Unless it is equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise and annoying smoke; or 
(f)  While transporting thereon a bow or a firearm unless the same be securely encased. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 10.177. - Accident Reporting. 
The operator of a snowmobile involved in an accident within the City resulting in injuries to or death of any person, or property damage in an estimated amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more, or some person acting for him or her, or the owner of the snowmobile having knowledge of the accident, shall immediately by the quickest means of communication notify the Police Department of the City. 
(Ord. No. 68-65, 11-5-68)  
Sec. 10.178. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 95-40, § 1, adopted July 11, 1995, repealed § 10.178, which pertained to hours of operation of snowmobiles in parks. See the Code Comparative Table.  
ARTICLE 11. - HIGH OCCUPANCY VEHICLE LANES 
 
Sec. 10.179. - Traffic Lane—Reserved For High Occupancy Vehicles Only. 
(1)  One (1) or more traffic lanes of any street or roadway may be designated by the City Commission as reserved for use by buses herein called High Occupancy Vehicles (HOVs), at such times and on such days as determined by the City Commission. All lanes so designated shall be appropriately marked with such signs or other markers as the City Commission or its designee direct. 
(2)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this subsection, the designation of any lane or lanes of any street or roadway as reserved for HOVs only shall not apply to the use of such lanes by: 
a.  Emergency vehicles such as fire-fighting vehicles, ambulances, and rescue squad vehicles and tow trucks for purposes of providing emergency service in the HOV lane; 
b.  Vehicles operated by law enforcement agencies; 
c.  Vehicles of public utility companies operating in response to an emergency call; 
d.  City maintenance vehicles, such as street sweepers and snow plows, working on such lanes; 
e.  Private vehicles that must utilize the HOV lane to permit a right-turn movement; and 
f.  School buses. 
(Ord. No. 2014-52, § 1, 7-22-14)  
Sec. 10.180. - Civil Infraction Violation. 
No operator of a vehicle shall operate that vehicle in a traffic lane designated for buses as described in Section 10.179 of the Code, unless otherwise authorized herein. A violation of this section shall constitute a civil infraction, as provided for in Chapter 170 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2014-52, § 1, 7-22-14)  
Chapter 182 - ELECTRIC PATROL VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 10.181. - Incorporation of State law. 
The Electric Patrol Vehicle Act, 1997 PA 55 as amended, being MCL 257.1571 et seq., is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as if fully set out herein. 
(Ord. No. 2018-41, § 1, 7-10-18)  
Sec. 10.182. - Operation by City Employees. 
Police, fire, emergency service, and parking enforcement employees of the City of Grand Rapids may operate an electric patrol vehicle in the course of their duties on a street, highway, or sidewalk within the boundaries of the City of Grand Rapids as authorized by this ordinance or state law. 
(Ord. No. 2018-41, § 1, 7-10-18)  
Sec. 10.183. - Compliance with State Law. 
Operation of an electric patrol vehicle shall comply with the requirements of this ordinance and state law. 
(Ord. No. 2018-41, § 1, 7-10-18)  
Chapter 183 - RECOVERY OF CITY COSTS AND EXPENSES 
 
Sec. 10.200. - Purpose. 
The City finds that a significant number of the traffic arrests and traffic accidents in the City involve drivers operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicants such as alcoholic beverages or a controlled substance, or a combination thereof. Furthermore, the City finds that there is a greater likelihood of personal injury or property damage in accidents involving a driver operating under the influence of intoxicants. As a result, the City finds that a greater operational and financial burden has been placed on the City's public safety services by persons operating a motor vehicle under the influence of intoxicants, and that it is necessary to recover these increased costs of enforcement activities caused by such persons, as expressly is authorized by MCL 769.1f. 
(Ord. No. 2010-28, 6-15-10)  
Sec. 10.201. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter, the terms listed below shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Emergency response shall mean: 
(a)  The providing, sending, and/or utilizing police, firefighting, and/or emergency rescue services by the City to a motor vehicle accident in which one or more drivers were operating a motor vehicle under the influence of one or more intoxicants; or 
(b)  The making of a traffic stop and arrest by a law enforcement officer when the driver is or was operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of one or more intoxicants. 
(2)  Expense of emergency response shall mean the direct costs associated with the occurrence of an emergency response. These costs shall include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(a)  The salaries or wages, including overtime pay, of law enforcement personnel for time spent responding to the incident, arresting the person, processing the person after the arrest, preparing reports on the incident, investigating the incident, and collecting and analyzing evidence, including determining blood alcohol content and determining the presence of and identifying controlled substances or other intoxicants; 
(b)  The salaries and wages, including overtime pay, of fire department personnel in responding to and providing firefighting, rescue and/or emergency medical services in relation to the incident; 
(c)  The cost of medical supplies lost or expended by fire department personnel in providing services in relation to the incident; 
(d)  The salaries, wages and other compensation, including, but not limited to, overtime pay of prosecution personnel for time spent investigating and prosecuting the offense or offenses resulting in conviction. 
(3)  Operating under the influence of one or more intoxicants shall mean: 
(a)  Operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage, controlled substance, or a combination of intoxicants; or 
(b)  Operating with an unlawful blood alcohol content as defined by the Michigan Vehicle Code; or 
(c)  Operating while visibly impaired due to the consumption of alcoholic beverages, controlled substances, or a combination of intoxicants. 
(Ord. No. 2010-28, 6-15-10)  
Sec. 10.202. - Liability For Expense of an Emergency Response. 
(1)  Any person is liable for the expense of an emergency response if that person, while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or a combination of intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance, proximately causes any incident resulting in an emergency response as defined by this chapter. 
(2)  For the purpose of this Chapter, a person is under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or the combination of an intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance, when his or her physical or mental abilities are impaired to a degree that he or she no longer has the ability to operate a motor vehicle with the caution characteristic of a sober person of ordinary prudence, regardless whether such person is charged or convicted. 
(3)  It shall be presumed that a person was operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of an intoxicating liquor if a chemical analysis of his or her blood, urine or breath indicates that the amount of alcohol in his or her blood was in excess of seven one-hundredths (0.07) percent. 
(4)  This Chapter shall be construed to impose a responsibility and liability of a civil nature on the part of the operator of the motor vehicle and shall not be construed to conflict, contravene, enlarge or reduce any criminal liability or responsibility, including fines and cost which may be imposed by a court on a person who is convicted of any criminal offense arising from the incident that resulted in an emergency response. 
(Ord. No. 2010-28, 6-15-10)  
Sec. 10.203. - Cost Recovery Schedule. 
(1)  The Police Department, Fire Department, and City Attorney shall periodically evaluate the actual costs incurred in making such emergency responses and determine an average cost during emergency responses. This amount shall be amended from time to time to reflect increases or decreases in the salaries of all personnel, along with the costs for police vehicles and other necessary equipment. 
(2)  The City Attorney, or his or her designee, shall forward the average cost developed in subsection (1) of this section to the district court and circuit court having jurisdiction over the City. This cost, as restitution to the City, may be imposed by the court during the imposition of any sentence upon any person liable under this section. 
(Ord. No. 2010-28, 6-15-10)  
Sec. 10.204. - Collection and Enforcement. 
(1)  The amount ordered to be paid under this chapter shall be paid to the clerk of the court who shall transmit the payment amount to the City Treasurer. 
(2)  If not otherwise ordered by the court, the reimbursement amount ordered shall be made immediately. The court may order that reimbursement be made within a specified period or in specified installments. 
(3)  If the person convicted is placed on probation, any reimbursement ordered under this section shall be a condition of that probation. 
(4)  A court order for reimbursement under this Chapter may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment in a civil action. 
(5)  In the event that a person who is subject to liability under this Chapter is not charged or convicted of any criminal offense arising from the incident that resulted in an emergency response, the City Treasurer shall submit a bill for recovery of costs by first class mail to the person liable for the expenses as set forth in this Chapter. 
(6)  A person who receives a bill from the City Treasurer under subsection (5) of this section shall pay the bill within thirty (30) days of receipt. If payment is not received by the City within such thirty-day period, the City Treasurer may request the City Attorney to institute a civil action on behalf of the City in the same manner as in the case of an obligation under a contract, express or implied. 
(Ord. No. 2010-28, 6-15-10)  
Secs. 10.205—10.250. - Reserved.
